superEntry.entry:
alphabetical letter m c
[The twenty-fourth letter of the alphabet; called miymN. It is one of the letters termed majohuwrap, or vocal, and of those termed XafahiyRap or labial: it is a letter of augmentation. ＝ -A2- As a numeral, it denotes forty.]

R. Q. 1 maOomaOato c
R. Q. 1. maOomaOato She (a ewe or she-goat or a gazelle) uttered continuously the cry miYo miYo, (K,) or (accord. to the Tes-heel) mAaCLI maMCi: [and this is confirmed by a verse which I have cited voce taxawRana:] (MF:) thus written in his Háshiyeh. (TA.)

1 maWuja c
1. maWuja, aor.
maAu^a
(or maOaja, aor,
maAa^a
, M), inf. n. muWuwjapN, It (water) was, or became, what is termed OujaAj, (S, K,) i. e., salt, (TA,) [or bitter, or salt and bitter, &c.].

maMCN maOojN c
maMCN maOojN, (and, as occurring in a verse of Ibn-Harmeh, maAjN, without C, IB,) Water such as is termed OujaAj, (S, K,) i. e., salt, (TA,) [or bitter, or salt and bitter, &c.]

1 maOada c
1. maOada, aor.
maAa^a
, (S, L, K,) inf. n. maOodN, (S, L,) It (a plant, L, K, and a tree, L, and a branch, S, L) was, or became, flourishing and fresh, and soft, tender, and supple: (L:) or it quivered, shook, or played loosely, and was, or became, succulent, or sappy, (L, K,) and flourishing and fresh, and soft, tender, and supple: (K:) it (a branch or twig) became filled with its first sap: and maWuda, aor.
maAu^a
, it (a plant) became succulent, or sappy. (L.) yamoOadu maOodFA HasanFA It (a branch) is [beautifully] soft, tender, and supple, and quivering. (S, L.)

4 AmOd c
4. AmOd It (the imbibing of moisture, L, K, and the [rain or season called] rabiyE, and the like, L) caused a plant [or tree or branch] to become flourishing and fresh, and soft, tender, and supple: (L:) or to quiver, shake, or play loosely, and to become succulent, or sappy, (L, K,) and flourishing and fresh, and soft, tender, and supple. (K).

8 AmtOd xayorFA c
8. AmtOd xayorFA He gained, or acquired, good, or prosperity. (S, L, K.)

maOodN c
maOodN and yamoWuwdN↓ A [plant or tree or] branch [flourishing and fresh, and soft, tender, and supple: see 1: or] quivering, shaking, or playing loosely, and succulent, or sappy, flourishing and fresh, and soft, tender, and supple: (K:) or a plant [or tree] or branch soft, tender, and supple; (S, L;) and maYiydN↓ signifies the same, (K,) applied to a branch; and so maAYidN↓: (TA:) which last also signifies a branch succulent, or sappy; and so maOodN, (L,) and mumoOadN↓: (TA:) and (as some say, L) maOodN signifies soft, tender, or supple, applied to anything. (L, K.) ― -b2- In like manner, maOodN and yamoWuwdN↓ are applied to (assumed tropical:) a man: (K:) and maOodapN (TA) and yamoWuwdapN and yamoWuwdN to a female. (K.) You say rajulN maOodN, (L,) and yamoWuwdN, (S, L,) (assumed tropical:) A young, and soft, or tender, man: and UimoraOapN maOodapN, (L,) and yamoWuwdapN, (S, L,) and yamoWuwdN, (L,) (assumed tropical:) a young, and soft, or tender woman: (S, L:) and jaAriypN maOodapN, (K,) and yamoWuwdapN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) a soft, or tender, damsel: (K:) and jArypN maOodapu AlXRabaAbi, and maAdapN, without C, (assumed tropical:) a damsel having youthful softness, thinness of skin, and plumpness. (L.) ― -b3- maOodu AlXRabaAbi (assumed tropical:) The softness, or tenderness, of youth. (L.) ― -b4- makaAnN vaOodN maOodN [A place moist and soft]; (S, L;) as also vaYidN maYidN↓. (T, art. vOd.) ＝ -A2- maOodN The moisture that exudes from the earth, before it springs forth: (L, K:) of the dial. of Syria. (L.)

maYidN c
maYidN: see maOodN.

maYiydN c
maYiydN: see maOodN.

maAYidN c
maAYidN: see maOodN.

mumoOadN c
mumoOadN: see maOodN.

yamoWuwdN c
yamoWuwdN: see maOodN.

1 matRa c
1. matRa, aor.
matuta
, inf. n. matRN, He extended, or stretched out, (S, K,) a rope, &c. (TA); i. q. madRa (S, K) and maTRa and magaTa. (TA.) ― -b2- matRa fiI AlsRayori i. q. madRa. (TA.) ― -b3- matRa, aor.
matuta
, inf. n. matRN, He drew [water], or drew up [a bucket], without a pulley. (S, K.) ― -b4- matRa, aor.
matuta
, inf. n. matRN; (S, K;) and matomata↓, inf. n. matomatapN; (K;) He sought to bring himself near [to another], or to approach [to him], or to gain access [to him], or to advance himself in [his] favour, (tawasRala,) by relationship, (S, K,) or by what is termed Huromap, [see maAtRapN, below,] or by other means: (TA:) or i. q. tawaSRal [which seems here to signify nearly or exactly the same as twsRl] by relationship, or by what is termed daAlRap [or blandishment, &c.] (L.) ― -b5- matRa Uilayohi biAlXRaIoCi He sought to bring himself near to him, &c., (twsRl Alyh,) by the thing. (M.) ― -b6- matomata↓ He sought to bring himself near, &c., [to another,] by affection, or love, or by relationship. (IAar.) ― -b7- laA tamutRaAoni UilaI AllRehi biHabolK walaA tamudRaAni Uilayohi bisababK [Ye two shall not approach, or obtain access, to God by means of any friend, nor shall ye do so by means of any relation]. A trad. (TA.) ― -b8- matRahu i. q. Talaba Uilayohi AlmataAta, q. v. infra. (L.)

3 mAtR fulaAnFA c
3. mAtR fulaAnFA He reminded such a one of what are termed mawaAtR [pl. of maAtRapN, q. v.]. (A.)

5 tamatRaI c
5. tamatRaI, originally tamatRata, which has not been heard, (like taZanRaI for taZanRana, TA,) i. q. tamaTRaI. (K.) ― -b2- tamatRaI fiI AlHaboli He bore upon the rope in order to break it, (K,) or to stretch it out. (TA.) See also art. mtw.

R. Q. 1 mtmt c
R. Q. 1. mtmt: see 1, in two places.

matRaI c
matRaI dial. form of mataI, q. v. (K.) It occurs in the following instances:
Oalamo tasoOali AlOaTalaAla matRaI EuhuwduhaA
[Didst thou not ask the remains of the dwelling, when were their times?] AHát asked As respecting mtRI in this hemistich, and he answered, I know not. AHát thinks that it is for mataI: or that it may be for matRFA, inf. n. of matRa; and that the meaning may be [Didst thou not ask the remains of the dwelling,] whereof the times when men were present there are (or were) long past, or distant, or remote? but he confesses that he does not know. (L.) MF remarks upon it, that it is very extraordinary. (TA.)

mataAtN c
mataAtN signifies maA yumatR bihi; (K;) i. e., That whereby one seeks to bring himself near [to another], or, to approach [to him], or, to advance himself in [his] favour; or to gain access [to him]. (TA.) Talaba Uilayohi AlamatAta [He sought the means of drawing near to him, or, of advancing himself in his favour, &c.: or he sought access to him]. (TA.) [See also maAtRap↓, which signifies the same.]

maAtRapN c
maAtRapN i. q. HuromapN and wasiylapN: [the former signifies, Anything that is sacred or inviolable; and here, such a bond, or tie, or the like; or a quality &c. to be regarded as sacred, or inviolable; or that which renders one entitled to respect and reverence: so says IbrD: the latter, a thing whereby one seeks to bring himself near, or to approach, to another, or to advance himself in his favour:] (S, K:) pl. mawaAtRu. (S.) [See also mataAtN, which signifies the same.] ― -b2- bayonanaA raHimN maAtRapN, i. e. qariybapN, Between us is a near relationship. (L.)

1 mataOa c
1. mataOa, aor.
mataAa
, He beat a person with a staff or stick. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also, inf. n. matoCN, (TA,) He extended, or stretched out, a rope: (S, K:) a dial. form of mataA. [See art. mtw]. (S.)

1 mataHa AlmaMCa c
1. mataHa AlmaMCa, aor.
mataHa
, (inf. n. matoHN, S,) He drew water: (S, Msb, K:) or he drew up water by means of the pulley and its appertenances. (L.) ― -b2- mataHa AldRalowa He drew out the bucket: (Msb:) or he pulled the rope of the bucket, drawing [the rope] with one hand, and taking [it to draw again] with the other hand, at the head of the well; as also mataHa biAldRalowi. (L.) ＝ -A2- mataHa bihaA Pepedit. (S, K.) ― -b2- mataHa bisaloHihi Alvum dejecit; (S, K;) as also mataxa bihi. (TA.) ＝ -A3- mataHa AlnRahaAru (tropical:) The day advanced, the sun becoming high: (S, K:) a dial. form of mataEa: (S:) became prolonged. (TA.) ― -b2- mataHa, and AmtH↓, (tropical:) It (a day, and a night,) was long, or prolonged. Said of a summer-day and of a winter-night. (As.)

4 OamotaHa
4: see 1.

5 AlUibilu tatamatRaHu fiI sayorihaA c
5. AlUibilu tatamatRaHu fiI sayorihaA (tropical:) The camels move their fore-legs alternately turaAwiHu biOayodiyhaA, A, and some copies of the K; in other copies of the K, tatarawRaHu;) in going along, (K,) like as the drawer of water moves alternately his two arms. (A.)

8 AmttH c
8. AmttH He pulled out a thing: (Aboo-Turáb and T, art. ntH, and K:) as also UinotataHa. (Aboo-Turáb and T, ubi supra.)

matoHN c
matoHN inf. n. of 1: see matuwHN.

bYorN matuwHN c
bYorN matuwHN (tropical:) A well from which one draws water with the two hands by means of the pulley: (S, L, K:) or, of which the bottom, or part from which the water is drawn, is near to the mouth: pl. mutuHN. (L.) [See also jaruwrN.] ― -b2- [You say,] sironaA EuqobapF matuwHFA [in the CK Eaqbapa] (tropical:) We proceeded a long march. (S, L, K, *) ― -b3- bayonanaA farosaHN matoHFA↓, and maAtiHN↓, and matRaAHN↓, (tropical:) Between us is a long league. (L.) ― -b4- layolN matRaAHN (tropical:) A long night. (S, K.) ― -b5- UilaI AllRayoli yawomN matRaAHN↓ (tropical:) A day in which travelling is prolonged until the evening without intermission or alighting. (L.) See maAtiHN.

matRaAHN c
matRaAHN: see matuwHN. ― -b2- farasN matRaAHN (tropical:) A long horse, (A, TA,) that stretches himself out much or takes long steps, madRaAdN, (A, K,) in going along. (TA.)

maAtiHN c
maAtiHN and matuwHN↓ A drawer of water; (S;) applied to a man who draws the water from the mouth of the well: one who draws it from the bottom being called maAYiHN: pl. of maAtiHN, mutRaAHN. (L.) ― -b2- maAtiHN A camel that draws water: pl. mawaAtiHu. (L.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce camRapN.] ― -b3- See mtuwHN.

1 mavRa c
1. mavRa, [aor.
maviva
,] It (a bone) distilled, or let flow, the only matter that was in it: (TA:) [like navRa]. ― -b2- mavRa, (S, K, aor.
mavava
, inf. n. mavRN, TA,) and mavomava↓, (K,) or, as in some copies of the K, vamavomava↓, (TA,) It (a niHoI, or butterskin,) exuded [its butter: as also navRa]. (S, K.) You do not say of it naDaHa. (S.) ― -b3- yamivRu mavRa AlHamiyti He sweats like the butter-skin. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b4- mavRa, aor.
maviva
, He (a man) sweated by reason of fatness. (TA.) ― -b5- jaACa yamivRu He came in a fat state, and looking as though he were anointed. (TA.) ― -b6- mavRa qayoHFA wadamFA, aor.
mavuva
; or aor.
maviva
; accord. to different readings of a phrase in the story of Abrahah; [It exuded matter and blood]: in the former case, the verb is trans.; in the latter, intrans.; and qyHA, in the latter case, is regarded as a specificative. (Suh.) ― -b7- mavRa XaAribahu, (aor.
mavuva
, inf. n. mavRN, ISd,) He put some grease upon his mustaches: (S, K:) or he greased his mustaches so that they glistened: (ISd:) or he wiped his mustaches with his hands, they having been greased, and left some remains, or traces, of grease visible upon them: (AZ:) IDrd thinks mavRa and navRa to be syn. (TA.) ― -b8- mavRa AljuroHa, [aor.
mavuva
,] He removed the purulent matter from the wound: (Aboo-Turáb, K:) or he anointed the wound; as also navRa. (Aboo-Turáb.) ― -b9- mavRa, aor.
mavuva
, (inf. n. mavRN, TA,) He wiped his hand (or fingers, TA,) with a napkin, or with dry grass, (S,) or the like: (TA:) a dial. form of maXRa: (S:) or he wiped anything: (TA:) [as also nivRa.]

R. Q. 1 mavomava c
R. Q. 1. mavomava He saturated a wick with oil. (K.) ― -b2- mavomava, He immersed [a thing] in water. (K.) ＝ -A2- mavomava, (inf. n. mavomavapN, S, and mivomaAvN, S, K,) He mixed, or confounded. (S, K.) You say mvmv Oamorahumo He confounded their affair. (S.) ― -b2- mavomavahu He moved it, or shook it, about; (S, K;) like mazomazahu: (As, S:) you say Oaxacahu famavomavahu He took it, and moved it, or shook it, about, and went forwards and backwards with it. (S.) ― -b3- A poet says,
vumRa QsotaHavRa caroEahu QsotiHovaAvaA
nakafotu Hayovu mavomava AlmiyomaAvaA
i. e., I came upon his track: and [the case is, that] the viper makes its course confused: therefore the poet means, that he came upon (OaSaAba) a confused track. (S, app. from As.) [It seems to me, that he is speaking of the track of a viper.] mivomaAvN, with kesreh, is the inf. n.; and mavomaAvN, with fet-hah, is the subst. (S, K.) [By the subst., is here meant the ideal subst., or abstract noun, (like zalozaAlN and qaloqaAl, as dis-
tinguished from zilozaAlN and qiloqaAlN,) signifying Mixture, or confusion.] ＝ -A3- mavomavuwA binaA, (K,) or mvmvwA bnA saAEapF, and tamavomavuwA↓, (TA,) i. q. lavolivuwA. (K.)

R. Q. 2
R. Q. 2: see 1 and R. Q. 1.

nabotN mavRaAvN c
nabotN mavRaAvN A moist plant. (TA.)

mavomaAvN c
mavomaAvN: see R. Q. 1.

1 majRahu mino fiyhi c
1. majRahu mino fiyhi, (S, K, &c.,) and majRa bihi, aor.
majuja
, and some allow
majaja
, but this is not well known, and, unless the medial letter of the pret. be pronounced with kesreh by those who use this form of the aor., it is to be rejected utterly, (TA,) He cast it forth, or ejected it, or spirted it, from his mouth; meaning beverage, or wine, XaraAb: (S, K:) and spittle: or, accord. to some, water only: or a thing: (L:) or, properly, something fluid; lafaZahu being used to signify “ he cast it forth ” from his mouth when the thing meant is not fluid: but used with relation to all other things that are perceived by any of the senses, figuratively: (MF:) accord. to Sh, it is used to signify the pouring forth of water, and of spittle, from the mouth, when it is ejected to a short distance or far; or, as some say, only when it is ejected far. (TA.) It is made trans. by means of bi because syn. with ramaI [which is trans. by the same means]. (MF.) ― -b2- majRati AlnRaHolu AlEasala The bees ejected the honey from their mouths. (TA.) ― -b3- majRa AlEiroqu biAldRami The vein ejected, or spirted forth, blood. (TA.) ― -b4- majRati AlXRamosu riyqahaA (tropical:) [The sun ejected its spittle; meaning the filmy substance described in the explanation of luEaAbu AlXRamosi]. (A.) ― -b5- hecaA kalaAmN tamujRuhu AlOasomaAEu (tropical:) This is language which the ears reject. (MF.) ― -b6- qaraOa MyapF famajRa bihaA (tropical:) He read a verse of the Kur-án, and dismissed it from his mind]; i. e., did not reflect upon it. (MF, from a trad.) ＝ -A2- majRa and bajRa, (TA in this art.,) or majRa and najRa, (TA in art. nj,) acc. to IAar, are syn. (TA.)

4 AmjR c
4. AmjR, (S, K,) and, by poetic licence, Oamojaja, (TA,) inf. n. UimojaAjN, (As,) He (a horse) ran violently: (TA:) or he (a horse) began to perform the act of running, before it (his run, As) was vehement, or ardent. (qabola Oano yaDoTarima). (As, S, K.) ― -b2- He (a man) went, or went forth journeying, through (fI) countries. (S, K.) ― -b3- He went away, or departed, to (UilI) a country or town. (TA.)

7 AnmjRt nuqoTapN mina Alqalami c
7. AnmjRt nuqoTapN mina Alqalami A drop [of ink] became spirted from the reed-pen. (S, K.)

R. Q. 1 majomaja fiI xabarihi c
R. Q. 1. majomaja fiI xabarihi, (inf. n. majomajapN, TA,) He was not explicit in his information. (S, K.) [See also HajoHaja.] ― -b2- majomaja AlkitaAba He made the writing indistinct in its letters: (S, K:) or he rendered the writing confused, and marred it with the pen. (Lth.) majomaja xaTRahu He made his handwriting confused. (A.) ― -b3- majomaja bifulaAnK He pursued an indirect course of speech with such a one, and turned him back from one state to another: (Shujáa Es-Sulamee, K:) as also bajobaja bihi. (Shujáa.)

majRN c
majRN (S, K) and mujaAjN↓ (TA) The grain of the maAX: (K:) or the grain called mAX; and called by the Arabs xulRarN and zinRN: (T:) or a kind of grain resembling the lentil, (but more round, TA); an arabicized word; in Persian mAX: (S:) or, accord. to El-Jawáleekee, it is Arabic: accord. to AHn, what is called majRapN [n. un. of majRN, which is a coll. gen. n.,] is a sour or salt, or salt and bitter, plant, or tree, (HamoDapN) resembling the TaHomaMC, but more delicate, and smaller. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See mujaAjN.

mujujN c
mujujN Drunken men. (K.) ― -b2- Bees. (K.)

mujaAjN c
mujaAjN (S, K) and mujaAjapN (S) Spittle, or saliva, that one casts forth from his mouth: (S, K:) or the latter, [and so, app., majRapN↓, see majRaAjapN] a portion of such; a gob of spittle. (TA.) ― -b2- mujaAjN fami AljaAriyapi Girl's saliva, or spittle. (TA.) ― -b3- Also mujaAjN, (K,) and mujaAju AlnRaHoli [The ejected spittle of the bees], (S, K,) honey. (S, K.) ― -b4- mujaAju AljaraAdi (tropical:) The slaver of locusts. (TA.) ― -b5- mujaAju AldRabaI The slaver of little locusts. (L.) ― -b6- mujaAju Almuzoni (tropical:) [The ejected spittle of the clouds; i. e.,] rain. (S, K.) ― -b7- mujaAjp also signifies (tropical:) The expressed juice of a thing. (S.) ― -b8- mujaAju AlEinabi (tropical:) What flows of the expressed juice of grapes. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See majRN.

majRaAjN c
majRaAjN (tropical:) A writer: so called because his pen emits ink. (TA.)

AlOucunu majRaAjapN walilnRafosi HamoDapN c
AlOucunu majRaAjapN walilnRafosi HamoDapN (assumed tropical:) The ear is wont to reject instruction, through forgetfulness, while the mind has eager desire to listen thereto, is said in a trad. (TA.) And in another trad., walilnRafosi HamoDapN liloOucuni majRapN↓ [meaning the same]. (TA., art. HmD.) [See also HamoDapN.]

maAjRN c
maAjRN One whose slaver flows by reason of old age, or extreme age: (K:) an old man who ejects his spittle, and cannot retain it, by reason of age: you say OaHomaqu maAjRN, meaning a stupid, or foolish, drivelling, or slavering, fellow: (S:) and so, simply, maAjRN: or stupid, or foolish, and decrepit: fem. with p: (TA:) and pl. maAjRuwna (IAar) and mujRaAjN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, An old she-camel: (K:) or a she-camel so old that she ejects the water from her throat: (S:) and in like manner an old and slavering he-camel: fem. with p: (TA:) and pl. majajapN. (IAar.)

qawolN mamojuwjN c
qawolN mamojuwjN (tropical:) A saying which the ear rejects. (TA.)

tamajRaHa c
tamajRaHa: see tabajRaHa in art. bjH.

1 majada c
1. majada, aor.
majuda
, inf. n. majodN; (L, K;) and majuda, aor.
majuda
, inf. n. majaAdapN; (S, L, K;) He (a man, S) was, or became, possessed of, or characterized by, majod [or glory, honour, dignity, nobility, &c.; he was, or became, glorious, in a state of honour or dignity, noble, &c.: see majodN below]. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- See 3. ― -b3- majadati AlUibilu, (AZ, IAar, S, L, K,) aor.
majuda
, (AZ, L,) inf. n. majodN (AZ, L, K) and mujuwdN; (AZ, S, L, K;) and Amjdt↓; (L, K;) The camels fed in a land abounding with pasturage, and satiated themselves therewith: (AZ, L:) or, lighted upon abundant pasturage: (IAar, L, K:) or, obtained of fresh herbage, (xalFI, S, K,) or of herbage, (L,) nearly as much as satiated them, (S, L, K,) and their bodies made this known. (L.) See 4. ― -b4- majadati Alganamu, inf. n. mujuwdN, The sheep, or goats, ate of leguminous plants so as to blunt the sharpness of their hunger. (A.) ― -b5- [Hence, app., accord. to the A, the signification of majada and majuda given in the commencement of this art.]

2 mjRdhu c
2. mjRdhu, inf. n. tamojiydN, He attributed, or ascribed to him, majod [or glory, honour, dignity, or nobility, &c.; he glorified him; honoured him; &c.]; (S, L;) he magnified him, and praised him; as also Amjdhu↓. (L, K.) ― -b2- mjRdhu and Amjdhu↓ He (God) honoured his (a man's) deeds, or actions: or may He honour his deeds, or actions! (A.) ― -b3- mjRdhu and Amjdhu↓ He made it (a gift) large, or abundant. (L, K.) ― -b4- See 4.

3 mAjdhu c
3. mAjdhu, inf. n. mijaAdN, He vied, or competed, with him (EaAraDahu) in majod [or glory, honour, dignity, nobility, &c.]. (L, K.) You say, maAjadotuhu famajadotuhu↓, (aor. of the latter
majuda
, S, L,) I vied, &c., with him in glory, &c., and overcame him therein. (S, L, K.)

4 Oamojada
4: see 1 and 2. ― -b2- nazaluwA bihimo faOamojaduwhumo [They alighted at their abode as guests, and they entertained them honourably]. (A.) ― -b3- Amjd waladahu, and liwaladihi, He chose [noble or generous] mothers [whereon to beget his children; and thus caused his children to be noble or generous]. (A, TA.) ― -b4- OamojadanaA fulaAnN qirFI Such a one gave us a sufficient and superabundant entertainment. (L.) ― -b5- Amjdhu sabRFA wacamRFA He reviled and dispraised him much. (IKtt.) ― -b6- Amjd AlUibila; (AZ, IAar, L, K;) and mjRdhA↓, (S, L, K,) inf. n. tamojiydN; (S, L;) and majadahaA↓; (K;) He filled the camels bellies with fodder, (AZ, L, K,) and satiated them: (AZ, L:) or he fed the camels upon abundant pasturage: (IAar, L:) or he satiated the camels: (K:) or he fed them upon herbage so as nearly to satiate them, in the beginning of the [season called] rabiyE: (L:) or he half-filled their bellies with fodder: (K:) the people of El-'Áliyeh say, AlnRaAqapa majada↓, (L,) or AldRaAbRapa, aor.
majuda
, inf. n. majodN, (S,) he filled the belly of the she-camel, (L,) or of the beast of carriage, (S,) with fodder: (S, L:) and the people of Nejd, mjRdhA↓, inf. n. tamojiydN, he half-filled her belly with fodder: (AO, A'Obeyd, S, L:) and Amjd AldRaAbRapN He gave the beast of carriage much fodder. (As, L.)

5 tmjRd c
5. tmjRd He had majod [or glory, honour, dignity, nobility, &c.,] attributed, or ascribed, to him. (L.)

6 tmAjd c
6. tmAjd He mentioned his [i. e. his own] majod [or glory, honour, dignity, nobility, &c., made a show of glory, &c.]; (K;) or the goodness of his actions, and the glory, &c., of his ancestors. (TA.) ― -b2- tmAjd Alqawomu fiymaA bayonahumo The people vied among themselves, or competed, for, or in, majod [or glory, honour, dignity, nobility, &c.], each mentioning his own mjd. (S, * L, K. *)

10 Astmjd c
10. Astmjd [He desired, or sought, majod, or glory, honour, dignity, nobility, &c.;] he gave largely from a desire of majod. (S, L.) ― -b2- It is said in a proverb, fiI kulRi XajarK naAro waQsotamojada Qlomaroxu waQloEafaAro (tropical:) In all trees is fire; but the markh and 'afár yield much fire: (S, L, K: *) as though they had taken as much fire as sufficed them, (S, L,) and were therefore fit substances for striking fire: (L:) or because they yield fire quickly; wherefore they are likened to him who gives largely from a desire of majod. (S, L.) See maroxN, and EafaArN.

majodN c
majodN Glory; honour; dignity; nobility; syn. EizRN (Msb) and XarafN [q. v.] (L, Msb) and karamN: (S, L, K:) or ample glory, honour, dignity, or nobility: (L:) or the acquisition of glory, honour, dignity, or nobility; syn. nayolu XarafK: (M, L, K:) or the acquisition of what suffices thereof and of lordship: (L:) [and hence, acquired glory, honour, dignity, or nobility:] or only glory, honour, dignity, or nobility, transmitted by one's ancestors: (M, L, K:) ISk says, that majod and Xaraf are [transmitted] by one's ancestors; but Hasab [q. v.] and karam may belong to a man without ancestors who possessed these qualities: (S, L:) or, specially, nobleness, or generosity, of ancestors: (M, L, K:) or personal glory, or nobility with goodness of actions: and nobleness, or generosity, of actions: (L:) or generosity; liberality; syn. karamN (S, L, K) and saxaMCN: (L:) or manly virtue or moral goodness; syn. muruwoCapN. (L.) [Accord. to the A, majodN thus used, and consequently each of the words in this art. derived from it, is tropical: but if so, it is a Haqiyqap EurofiyRap, or word so much used in a particular tropical sense as to be, in this sense, conventionally regarded as proper.]

majiydN c
majiydN (from majuda, L) and maAjidN↓ (from majada, L) A man (S) possessing, or characterized by, majod [or glory, honour, dignity, nobility, &c.; glorious, in a state of honour or dignity, noble, &c.]: (S, L, K:) glorious, in a state of honour or dignity, noble, abounding in good, and beneficent; but the former has a more intensive sense: or the latter, characterized by gloriousness or nobleness of actions: (K:) or, by personal glory or nobility with goodness of actions; and the former has a more intensive sense: or both, generous and munificent: (L:) and the latter, good in disposition, and liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous: (ISh, L, K:) pl., either of the former or of the latter, OamojaAdN. (L.) ― -b2- Almajiydu as an epithet of God signifies The Glorious, or Great, or Great in dignity, who gives liberally, or bountifully: or the Bountiful and beneficent: (L, TA:) and AlmaAjidu↓ is applied in the same manner: (L:) or the former, He who is glorified for his deeds. (T, L.) ― -b3- majiydN is also applied in the Kur as an epithet to the throne (EaroX) of God; and to the Kur-án; (L.) and signifies exalted; sublime; (IAar. L, K;) noble; (Zj, L, K;) when thus applied: (IAar, Zj, L, K:) but in ch. lxxxv., v. 15, for cuw AlEaroXi Almajiydi, some read cw AlEaroXi Almajiydu, making Almjyd an epithet of cw; and in the same ch., v. 21, for huwa quraMnN majiydN, some read hw quroMnN majiydK, making mjyd an epithet of God. (L.) Almajiydu alone also occurs in a trad. as meaning the Kur-án. (L.)

maAjidN c
maAjidN: see majiydN. ― -b2- Also, applied to a camel: see majadati AlUibilu: pl. mujRadN and mujudN and mawaAjidu. (L.) ― -b3- maAjidN Much; abundant; syn. kaviyrN. (K, TA.) [In the CK, kaviyrN Almajodi.] ― -b4- layosato bimaAjidapK lilTRaEaAmi walaA lilXRaraAbi She does not eat or drink much. Said by Aboo- Habbeh, describing a woman. (L.)

Oamojadu c
Oamojadu [More, or most, glorious, honourable, noble, &c.]: pl. OamaAjidu. (A.)

huwa Oaholu AltRamaAjiydi c
huwa Oaholu AltRamaAjiydi He is a fit, or deserving, object of praises for majod [or glory, honour, dignity, nobility, &c.]. (A, TA.)

1 majVra
1: see bjr; and as an imitative sequent see art. dEr.

3 mAjrhu c
3. mAjrhu, inf. n. mumaAjarapN and mijaArN, (tropical:) He practised usury with him; syn. raAbaAhu. (K.) See also 4.

4 Amjr fiI AlbayoEi c
4. Amjr fiI AlbayoEi, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. UimojaArN, He practised what is termed majorN in selling; he sold a thing for what was in the belly of a certain she-camel (S, Msb) or other beast: (Msb:) or he practised what is termed muHaAqalap: see majorN, below: (Msb:) or i. q. maAjara, inf. n. mumaAjarapN; (tropical:) [he practised usury: see 3.] (TA.)

majorN c
majorN What is in the belly of a pregnant animal, (IAar, Mgh,) or of a she-camel, (Msb, K,) and of a ewe or a she-goat, (K,) when her pregnancy has become manifest: (TA:) or (Msb; in the K, and) the sale of a thing for what is in the belly of a certain she-camel: (S, Msb:) or the sale of a camel, or other thing, for what is in the belly of a she-camel: (AZ, Mgh, * TA:) or the purchase of what is in the bellies of she-camels and of ewes or she-goats: and the purchase of a camel for what is in the belly of a she-camel: and majarN↓ [signifies the same, but] is a word of weak authority, or a barbarism; (K:) and the latter appears to be the case, for it is rejected by Az and IAth: (TA:) or (Msb; in the K, and) i. q. muHaAqalapN [or the sale of corn in the ear for wheat-grain]: (IAar, Msb, K:) and muzaAbanapN [or the sale of dates on the tree for dates by measure]: and (assumed tropical:) a game of hazard; syn. qimaArN: and (assumed tropical:) usury; syn. ribFI: (IAar, K:) it is a subst. from Oamojara fiI AlbayoEi. (Msb.) majorN, (S,) or bayoEu Almajori, (TA,) is forbidden in a trad. (S, TA.) Perhaps bayoEu Almajori may be termed mjr in this trad. tropically. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A great army (see a verse cited in art. dhm).

majarN c
majarN: see majorN.

2 mjRshu c
2. mjRshu, (S, A, &c.,) inf. n. tamojiysN, (A, K,) He made him a majuwsiIR [or Magian]: (S, A, Msb, K:) he taught him the religion of the majuws. (TA.)

5 tmjRs c
5. tmjRs He became a majuwsiIR [or Magian]; (S, A, K;) he became of the religion of the majuws. (Msb.)

Almajuwsu c
Almajuwsu [The Magians]; a certain nation: it is a Persian word: (Msb:) majuwsu [here written in two copies of the S and in the CK with tenween, but afterwards shown in the S to be imperfectly decl., and expressly said to be so in the Msb, art. hwd,] is pl. of majuwsiIRN: (S, K:) [or rather the former is a coll. gen. n., and the latter is the n. un.:] the latter is a rel. n. from AlmajuwsiyRapu, q. v., (S,) and is an epithet applied to a man: (K:) Almajuwsu has the article Al only because it is used as a pl., (Aboo-'Alee, S, M, L,) for AlmajuwsiyRuwna; (ISd, L;) for otherwise mjws could not receive the art., being of itself determinate; and it is also of the fem. gender; wherefore, with respect to inflection, it is like the qabiylap, not the HaIR; and the same is the case with respect to yahuwdu; (Aboo-'Alee, S;) [i. e.,] each of these two words is imperfectly decl. because they mean thereby the qbylp [so called, so that it is a fem. proper name]. (Msb, art. hwd.) majuwsu was a certain man with small ears, who instituted a religion (K) for the majuws, (TA,) and invited [them] to it: (K:) so says Az: he was not Zarádusht [or Zoroaster] the Persian, as some say, because he [Zarádusht] was after Abraham, whereas the religion of the mjws is [more] ancient; but Zarádusht revived it, and published it, and added to it: (MF:) the name is arabicized, from manoja kuwX, or myj kwX, or miyxa kuwX, (as differently written in different copies of the K, the first being the reading in the TA, and the last being that in the CK), the latter of which words signifies “ the ear, ” [in Persian, but written with k,] and the former meaning “ short. ” (TA.)

AlmajuwsiyRapu c
AlmajuwsiyRapu The religion of the majuws [or Magians]. (S, K.) Mohammad said that the qadariyRap were the majuws of his people, because the latter believed in two principles, light and darkness, and ascribed good to light and evil to darkness, and in like manner the qdryRp ascribed good to God, and evil to man and the devil. (TA.)

1 maHRa c
1. maHRa, (S, K,) aor. yamiHRu and yamuHRu [the latter contr. to analogy] (K) and yamaHRu, (L,) inf. n. maHRN and maHaHN and muHuwHN; (K;) and AmHR↓; (S;) It (a garment) became old and worn-out. (S, K.) ― -b2- It (a dwelling) had its vestiges obliterated. (L.) ― -b3- It (a writing) became obliterated. (L.) ＝ -A2- maHRa AlkacRaAbu, aor. yamuHRu, inf. n. maHaAHapN, [The liar pleased, or contented, with his words, but did, or performed, nothing: or lied, from whatsoever place he came]. (L.)

4 OamoHaHa
4: see 1.

maHRN c
maHRN (S, K) and maAHRN↓ (TA) An old and wornout garment. (S, K.)

muHRN c
muHRN The purest, best, or choicest, part of anything. (K.) ― -b2- The yolk of an egg; (S, K;) as also muHRapN↓: (ISh, K:) or the entire contents of an egg; (K;) the yolk and the white. (ISh.)

muHRapN c
muHRapN: see muHRN.

maHRaAHN c
maHRaAHN One who pleases or contents thee with his words, but who does, or performs, nothing: (T, S, K:) an habitual liar: (S, K:) one who will not tell thee truly whence he comes; who lies to thee even respecting the place whence he comes. (L.)

maAHRN c
maAHRN: see maHRN.

1 maHuta c
1. maHuta, aor.
maHuta
, It (a day) was violently hot: (S:) or was hot. (K.) ― -b2- laOamoHatanRaka I will assuredly fill thee with anger. (K.)

maHotN c
maHotN Strong; vehement; violent; or intense; syn. XadiydN; (S, K;) as an epithet applied to anything. (S.) ― -b2- yawomN maHotN A day violently hot; like HamotN: (S:) or a hot day. (K.) layolapN maHotapN [A night vehemently hot: or a hot night]. (TA.) ― -b3- maHotN Intelligent: or acute in mind; (K;) or of full strength of heart, and acute in mind: (TA:) pl. muHuwtN and muHataACu; (K;) the latter as though formed from the imaginary sing. maHiytN. (TA.) ― -b4- maHutN Pure; free from admixture; genuine. (K.) ― -b5- EarabiIRN maHotN baHotN A pure, or genuine, Arab. (TA.) [See also baHotN.]

1 maHava XayoYFA c
1. maHava XayoYFA i. q. Havamahu. (L.)

maHovN c
maHovN One who mixes with people, and eats and converses with them. (MF, from the Námoos of [the Mulla 'Alee] El-Káree: [but SM expresses some doubt of its correctness, or whether it be correctly mxv].

maHaArapN mHAr mHArh mHArp
maHaArapN: see art. Hwr, to which it belongs accord. to As and others: Lth mentions it in art. mHr. (TA.)

1 maHoSN c
1. maHoSN [an inf. n. of which the verb is app. maHaSa, aor.
maHaSa
,) A thing's becoming, or being, clear, pure, or free from admixture. (TA.) See also 5, throughout. ＝ -A2- maHaSahu: see 2, in three places. ＝ -A3- maHaSa, aor.
maHaSa
, (S, K,) inf. n. maHoSN, (TA,) He (an antelope) ran: (S, K:) or ran vehemently: (TA:) or vigorously: (AA, TA:) or was quick, or swift, in his running; as also fiI Eadowihi AmtHS↓. (TA.) And hence, (TA,) maHaSa AlsRayora, [app. for fiI AlsRayori,] said of a man, He exerted himself, or was vigorous, in journeying. (K, TA.)

2 mHRShu c
2. mHRShu, inf. n. tamoHiySN, He rendered it clear, pure, free from every admixture or imperfection or the like; as also maHaSahu↓, aor.
maHaSa
, inf. n. maHoSN. (Az, A, TA.) You say, maHRaSa AlcRahaba, (A, TA,) or maHaSahu↓, (S, K,) He cleared, or purified, the gold from what was mixed with it, (S, A, K,) i. e. from the earth, or dust, and dirt, (TA,) biAlnRaAri by fire. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) He (God) purged, or purified it; namely a man's heart: and him; namely a man repenting. (A.) It is said in the Kur, [iii. 135,] waliyumaHRiSa QllRehu QlRaciyna QmanuwA (tropical:) And that God may purify those who believe: (TA:) or purge away the sins of those who believe: (Fr, TA:) or these words have another meaning, which see below. (TA.) It is also said in a trad., mentioning a sedition, or conflict and faction, or the like, yumaHRaSu AlnRaAsu fiyhaA kamaA yumaHRaSu cahabu AlmaEodini, i.e. (tropical:) Men shall be cleared therein, one from another, like as the gold from the mine is cleared from the earth, or dust. (TA.) tamoHiySu AlcRunuwbi signifies (tropical:) The purging of sins. (TA.) And you say, maHRiSo EanRaA cunuwbanaA, meaning (tropical:) Remove thou, or put thou away, from us our sins. (TA.) [But this phrase may be rendered somewhat differently; as will be seen below.] And QllRehu maA bika maHaSa↓, and maHRaSahu; i.e. (tropical:) May God remove, or put away, what is in thee. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, also,] (assumed tropical:) He tried, proved, or tested, him: (S, IAth, K:) and accord. to Ibn-'Arafeh, the verb has this meaning in the phrase quoted above from the Kur: [but he adds,] because the trial of the Muslims diminishes their sins: for (TA) tamoHySN also signifies The diminishing [a thing]. (Ibn- 'Arafeh, K.) You say, maHRaSa QllRehu Eanoka cunuwbaka May God diminish thy sins. (TA.) ― -b4- And the clearing, or cleansing, flesh from sinews, (K, TA,) for the purpose of twisting them into a bow-string. (TA.)

4 OamoHaSa
4: see 5, throughout.

5 tmHRS c
5. tmHRS [It became clear, pure, free from every admixture or imperfection or the like; as also AnmHS↓; and UimRaHaSa↓; and OamoHaSa↓; and maHaSa↓, q. v.] ― -b2- [Hence,] tmHRSt cunuwbuhu (tropical:) [His sins became purged away]. (A, TA.)
And tmHRSt AlZRalomaMCu (tropical:) The darkness became cleared away, or removed. (A, TA.) And AlXRamosu OamoHaSati↓, and AnmHSt↓, (K,) and UimRaHaSat↓, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The sun appeared, and became clear, after an eclipse. (K, TA.) And AlrRajulu OamoHaSa↓, (inf. n. UimoHaASN, TA) (assumed tropical:) The man recovered from his disease. (Ibn-'Abbád, K. *)

7 AnmHS c and UimRaHaSa
7. AnmHS UimRaHaSa: see 5, in two places.

8 UimotaHaSa
8: see 1.

mumaHRaSN c
mumaHRaSN One whose sins are put away from him: mentioned by Kr.: but he says, I know not how this is; for that which is mumaHRaS is the sin [itself]. (TA.)

1 maHaDahu c
1. maHaDahu, (S, A, K,) aor.
maHaDa
, (K,) inf. n. maHoDN, (TK,) He gave him to drink [milk such as is termed] maHoD; (S, A, K;) as also AmHDhu↓. (S, K.) ― -b2- He made it (namely milk) to be such as is termed maHoD; (A;) and AmHDhu↓ signifies [the same; or] he made it (milk, or anything, S) to be pure, sheer, free from admixture, unmingled, unmixed, or clear. (S, Msb.) ― -b3- [And hence,] maHaDotu AlwudRa, aor. and inf. n. as above, (tropical:) I made love, or affection, true, or sincere; as also OamoHaDotuhu↓. (Msb.) And maHaDahu AlwudRa, (S, A, K,) and AlnRuSoHa, (A,) and maHaDa lahu AlnRuSoHa, (TA,) (tropical:) He made love or affection, and good advice, to be pure, or sincere, to him; [i.e. he was pure, or sincere, to him in love, or affection, and in good advice;] as also AlwudRa AmHDhu↓; (S, A, K;) or, accord. to IDrd, this latter only; (A;) but this latter was unknown to As; (IB;) and AlnSH AmHDhu↓; (A;) and lh AlnSH AmHD↓. (TA.) And OamoHaDahu↓ AlHadiyva (tropical:) He was true, or veracious, to him in the narration, or in discourse. (IKtt, K.) And fulaAnN AlHaqRa maHRaDaniI↓ (assumed tropical:) [Such a one declared, or told clearly, to me the truth]. (A, TA, voce SabRaHa.) ＝ -A2- maHiDa, (Sgh, K,) aor.
maHaDa
, inf. n. maHaDN, (TK,) He drank [milk such as is termed] mHD; (Sgh, K;) as also AmtHD↓. (S, K.) See also 10. ＝ -A3- maHuDa, aor.
maHuDa
, inf. n. muHuwDapN, (assumed tropical:) He became pure in his Hasab [or grounds of pretension to respect]. (S, K.) And maHuDa fiI nasabihi, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He was pure, or unmixed, in his race, lineage, or parentage. (Msb.)

2 maHRaDa
2: see above.

4 AmHDhu c
4. AmHDhu: see maHaDahu, throughout. ― -b2- AmHD AldRaAbRapa (tropical:) He fed the beast of carriage with maHoD, meaning qatR [a kind of trefoil, or clover]. (IKtt.)

8 UimotaHaDa
8: see maHiDa.

10 AstmHD c
10. AstmHD [He asked for, or demanded, or desired, milk such as is termed maHoD]. (A.) ― -b2- [In a copy of the A, it has also assigned to it the signification given above to maHiDa and AmtHD; but in this instance I think it a mistranscription for AmtHD.]

maHoDN c
maHoDN Milk that is pure, sheer, free from admixture, unmingled, unmixed, or clear; (Lth, S, A, K;) without froth; (Lth, A;) or not mixed with water: (S, Msb;) whether sweet or sour; no other milk being so called: (S:) but it occurs repeatedly in trads. as meaning milk absolutely: (TA:) pl. miHaADN. (K.) It is said in a trad. (baAriko lahumo fiI maHoDihaA wamaxoDihaA Do Thou bless them in their [the beasts'] pure milk and churned milk. (TA.) And in another, faQEomiduwA UilaI XaApK mumotaliYapF XaHomFA wamaHoDFA [And betake yourselves to a ewe, or she-goat,] fat, and abounding with milk. (TA.) [See also an ex. voce zubodN: and another voce SarRaHa.] ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Anything (Az, TA) pure, sheer, free from admixture, unmingled, unmixed, genuine, or clear; (Msb, TA;) that is not mixed with any other thing. (Az, Msb, TA.) You say, fiDRapN maHoDN, (K,) and maHoDapN, (A, K,) and mamoHuwDapN↓, (K,) (tropical:) Pure, unmixed, unalloyed, silver: (A, * K:) so says Sb: but you say, hecihi AlfiDRapu maHoDFA (tropical:) [This is silver in a pure state]; putting the last word in the accus. case, used as an inf. n. (TA.) And EarabiIRN maHoDN (tropical:) An Arabian of pure, or unmixed, race, or lineage, or parentage: (S, A, Msb: *) [a genuine Arabian:] and the epithet is the same as fem. [and dual] and pl., (S, Msb,) accord. to the more approved usage; (Msb;) [for it is originally an inf. n.;] but you may, if you please, use the fem. and dual and pl. forms, as in the instances of [the synonymous epithets] qalobN and baHotN: (S:) and AlnRasabi huwa mamoHuwDu↓ (tropical:) he is pure, or unmixed, in race, or lineage, or parentage: (K, TA:) and AlDRariybapi mamoHuwDu↓ (tropical:) rendered pure in nature, or disposition; (Az, O;) freed from faults or vices: (Az:) and maHoDu AlHasabi (tropical:) pure in grounds of pretension to respect: (TA:) and AlHasabi mamoHuwDu↓ (tropical:) rendered pure therein: (O, K:) the pl. of maHoDN thus used is miHaADN [a pl. of mult.] and OamoHaADN [a pl. of pauc.]. (TA.) You say also, OuHibRuka HubRFA maHoDFA (tropical:) [I love thee with a pure, sincere, or true, love]. (A.) And maHoDu AlUiyomaAni occurs in a trad. as meaning (tropical:) Pure faith or belief. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, i. q. qatRN [A kind of trefoil, or clover]. (IKtt)

maHiDN c
maHiDN A man who loves [milk such as is termed] maHoD; like as one says, XaHimN laHimN, meaning one “ who loves fat and flesh meat: ” (O:) or one who eagerly desires maHoD; as also maAHiDN↓: (K:) each is a relative epithet; (TA:) or ↓the latter signifies a possessor of maHoD; (S, K;) similar to laAbinN and taAmirN: (S:) and the former, a drinker of maHoD. (TA voce vafilN, q. v.)

maAHiDN c
maAHiDN: see maHiDN, in two places.

OumoHuwDapN c
OumoHuwDapN (tropical:) True, or sincere, advice. (K, TA.)

mamoHuwDN c
mamoHuwDN: see maHoDN, in four places.

mxRx AlEaZoma c
mxRx AlEaZoma, (K,) and tmxRxhu↓ and AmtxRhu↓ (S, K) and maxomaxahu↓, (K,) He extracted the marrow from the bone. (S, K.)

4 AmxR c
4. AmxR It (a bone) was, or became, marrowy; had, or contained, marrow in it. (S, K.) ― -b2- It (a camel, S, L, and a sheep or goat, L, K) became fat: (S, L, K:) or became in the first stage of fatness; or in the last stage when becoming lean. (L.) ― -b3- AmxR (tropical:) It (a branch, or twig,) became sappy, and succulent. (L, K.) ― -b4- (tropical:) It (standing corn, K, or its grain, L) became supplied with the farinaceous substance. (L, K.)

5 tamaxRaRa
5: see 1.

8 Uimotaxaxa
8: see 1.

R. Q. 1
R. Q. 1: see 1.

maxRN c
maxRN i. q. liynN Softness, &c.: or layonN soft, &c. (So in different copies of the K.)

muxRN c
muxRN The marrow (niqoI, in the CK naqiIR,) of a bone; (K;) that which is in a bone; (S;) the substance which is extracted from a bone; (IDrd;) the greasy or oily substance which is in a bone: (Msb:) pl. mixaxapN (S, K) and mixaAxN. (K.) ― -b2- [Any kind of pulp.] ― -b3- muxRapN↓ is a more special term than muxRN, (S,) signifying A portion, or piece, of marrow. (L.) ― -b4- XarRN mRaA yujiyuWka UilaI muxRapi EuroquwbK [It is an evil thing that compelleth thee to have recourse to the marrow of a hock]. A proverb. (S.) [See art. Erqb.] ― -b5- muxRN also signifies (sometimes, S,) (assumed tropical:) The brain. (S, K.) ― -b6- Also, The bulb (lit. fat, XaHomap,) of the eye. (A, K.) Mostly used in this sense in poetry. (TA.) ― -b7- Also, (tropical:) Good, profit, or advantage. Ex. laA OaraI liOamorika muxRFA I see no good, or profit, or advantage, [pertaining] to thy affair. (A.) ― -b8-
Also, (tropical:) The purest, choicest, best, or most excellent, part of anything: (S, A, L, K:) and muxRapN↓ (A, L) and muxaAxapN↓. (TA.) Ex. heWulaMCu muxRu Alqawomi, and muxRatuhumo↓, (tropical:) These are the best of the people. (A.) And AldRuEaMCu muxRu AlEibaAdapi (tropical:) Supplication is the purest, or best, part of religious worship, or devotion. (L, from a trad.) And hecaA mino muxRi qalobiI, and muxRatihi↓, (tropical:) This [proceeds] from the purest, or best, [affections] of my heart. (L.)

muxRapN c
muxRapN: see muxRN.

maxiyxN c
maxiyxN A bone containing marrow. (K.) ― -b2- maxiyxapN A ewe, (L, K,) and a she-camel, (L,) having marrow in her bones. (L, K.) ― -b3- Also, the latter, (tropical:) An excellent she-camel: (TA:) pl. maxaAYixu. (K.)

muxaAxapN c
muxaAxapN What one sucks from a bone; (L;) what comes forth from a bone into the mouth of him who sucks it. (K.) ― -b2- See muxRN.

mumixRN c
mumixRN act. part. n. of OamaxRa. ― -b2- bayona AlmumixRapi wAlEajofaMCi [Between the fat she-camel or ewe, and the lean]. A proverb. (S, A, L.) Said of a thing which is of a middling sort. (A.) ― -b3- lisaAnN mumixRN A sharp, or ready, tongue, powerful to speak: and a tongue that intercedes well. (A.) OamorN mumixRN (A, L, K) and mumaxRixN↓, (A,) A thing, or an affair, in which is excellence, and good: (A:) or, that benefits; syn. TaAYilN: (L:) but accord. to the K, long; syn. TawiylN. (TA.)

mumaxRixN c
mumaxRixN: see mumixRN.

1 maxaja AldRalowa c
1. maxaja AldRalowa, (aor.
maxaja
, K, inf. n. maxojN, TA) He drew the bucket, and dashed it in the water, in order that it might fill: (Lh, S, K:) or maxaja AldRalowa wagayorahaA, and maxaja bihaA, and tmxRjhA↓, and tmxRj bihaA, and tmAxjhA↓, and tmAxj bhA, he agitated, or moved about, the bucket, &c. (TA.) ― -b2- maxaja AlbiYora He agitated the water of the well violently: and he plied the well with the large bucket. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] maxaja, (aor.
maxaja
, inf. n. maxojN, TA) Inivit feminam. (As, S, K.)

5 tamaxRaja
5: see 1. ― -b2- tmxRj AlmaMCa He agitated the water; put it in motion, or into a state of commotion. (A'Obeyd, K.)

6 tamaAoxaja
6: see 1.

1 maxarati AlsRafiynapu c
1. maxarati AlsRafiynapu, (S, A, K,) or mxrt Alsfynp AlmaMCa, (TA,) aor.
maxara
(S, K) and
maxura
, (S, TA,) inf. n. maxorN and muxuwrN, (S, K,) The ship clave the water with its stem, and ran: (AHeyth:) or clave the water with a noise: (A:) or ran, cleaving the water with a noise: (S:) or ran: or faced the wind in her course: (K:) or advanced and retired. (TA.) And maxara AlsRaAbiHu The swimmer clave the water with his arms (K, TA.) in swimming. (TA.) The primary signification of maxorN is the act of cleaving: and it also signifies the making a noise or sound. (TA.)

5 tmxRr AlrRiyHa c
5. tmxRr AlrRiyHa He (a horse) faced the wind, (K,) or turned his nose towards the wind, (TA,) for the sake of greater ease to himself; as also AmtxrhA↓, and AstmxrhA↓. (K.) It is mostly said of the camel: you say, tmxRrt AlUibilu AlrRiyHa The camels faced the wind, and snuffed it. (TA.) And, met., of a man; as in the following ex.: xarajotu OatamaxRaru AlrRiyHa, app. meaning, (tropical:) I went forth to snuff the wind. (TA.) You also say, AlrRiyHa Uisotamoxarotu↓ (assumed tropical:) I directed my nose towards the wind. (S, A.) And it is said in a trad., UicaA OaraAda OaHadukumu Albawola faloyatamaxRari AlrRiyHa (S, K) (assumed tropical:) When any one of you desires to make water, let him see whence the wind blows, and not face it, that it may not drive back the urine against him, (S, TA,) and cause it to sprinkle him; but let him turn his back to the wind. (TA.) And again, (K,) in a trad. of Surákah, as related by ISh, on the same subject, (TA,) UisotamoxiruwA↓ AlrRiyHa, i.e., Turn ye your backs to the wind, (K,) in making water; (TA;) as though, (kaOanRahu: so in the copies of the K; but in the Nh of IAth, liOanRahu, for, TA) when one turns his back to it, he (as it were, TA) cleaves it with his back, so that it passes on his right and left: for though tamaxRurN sometimes means the act of facing the wind, yet in this trad. it means the turning the back: (K:) but this is not properly its meaning; for the meaning is, the looking to see whence the wind blows: then the man is to turn his back. (TA.) You say also tmxRrt AlUibilu AlkalaOa The camels turned themselves towards the pasture. (L.)

8 Uimotaxara
8: see 5, throughout.

10 Uisotamoxara
10: see 5, throughout.

maAxirapN c
maAxirapN sing. of mawaAxira, (TA,) which occurs in the Kur, xvi. 14, (S,) and xxxv. 13, (TA,) meaning, Ships cleaving the water with their stems: (K, * TA:) or thrusting the water with their stems: (Ahmad Ibn-Yahya:) or the sound of the running whereof, (Fr, K,) by means of the winds, (Fr,) is heard: (Fr, K:) or running: (S:) or advancing and retiring by means of one wind. (K.)

maAxuwrN c
maAxuwrN (tropical:) The shop of a vintner: so called by the people of El-'Irák: (L, voce HaAnuwtN:) a place of assembly of vintners: (TA:) a place of assembly of vicious or immoral persons: (S, TA:) a place of assembly, (A,) or a house, (K,) which gives reason for suspicion, or evil opinion. (A, K.) And (tropical:) He who superintends or manages such a house, and leads [others] to it. (K.) An arabicized word, from [the Persian] mayoxuwro, or maIo xuwro, or mayoxawAro, (as in different copies of the K,) meaning “ a winedrinker ”: so that as a name of the place, it is tropical: (TA:) or Arabic, from maxarati AlsRafiynapu, (K,) meaning “ the ship advanced and retired ”; (TA;) because of men's frequenting it, going to and fro: (K:) in which case also it is tropical. (TA.) Pl mawaAxiyru (A, K) and mawaAxiru. (K.) The former pl. occurs in a trad. (TA.)

1 maxaDa AllRabana c
1. maxaDa AllRabana, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
maxuDa
, (S, A, Msb, K,) and
maxiDa
, and
maxaDa
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. maxoDN, (Msb,) He churned, or beat and agitated, the milk, (Mgh,) in the mimoxaDap: (A, Mgh:) and (A) he took the butter of the milk: (A, K:) or he extracted, or fetched out, the butter of the milk, by putting water in it, and agitating it: (Msb:) or maxoDN signifies one's agitating the mimoxaD wherein is the milk of which the butter has been taken. (Lth.) ― -b2- [Hence,] maxoDN relates also to many things. (TA.) Thus, you say, (TA) maxaDa AlXRaIoCa, (K, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He shook, or agitated, the thing vehemently. (K, TA.) It is said in a trad., murRa Ealayohi bijinaAzapK tumoxaDu maxoDFA; (L;) or tumoxaDu maxoDa AlzRqR; (O;) (assumed tropical:) [A bier with a corpse was conveyed past him] being shaken, or agitated, quickly; (L, TA;) or being shaken, or agitated, vehemently [like as the milkskin is shaken, &c.] (O, TA.) You say also, maxaDa AldRalowa, (K,) or biAldRalowi, (Fr, S, O, L,) which latter is the correct phrase, (TA,) or maxaDa AlmaMCa biAldRalowi (A,) and maxaDa AlbiYora biAldRalowi, (TA,) (tropical:) He dashed the bucket in the water of the well, to fill it: (Fr., S, O, L, K:) or he drew much water with the bucket: (A:) and the last, he drew much with the bucket from the well, and agitated it. (TA.) ― -b3- And [hence,] maxaDa raOoyahu (A, Msb) (tropical:) He turned over, or revolved, his idea, or opinion, [in his mind,] and considered what would be its results, (Msb,) until the right course appeared to him. (A, Msb.) ― -b4- And maxaDa QllRehu AlsRiniyna HatRaI kaAna celika zubodatahaA (tropical:) [God caused the years to revolve until that was their issue, or result]. (A, TA.) ― -b5- And maxaDa said of a camel, (tropical:) He brayed (hadara) in his XiqoXiqap [i.e. faucial bag, or bursa faucium]. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- maxiDato, (ISh, IAar S, Msb, K,) aor.
maxaDa
; (S, K;) or maxaDato; (so in a copy of the A and in a copy of the Mgh) or both; (JK, K;)
aor. of the latter, as of the former,
maxaDa
; (K;) and muxiDato; (ISh, L, K;) but this last is disallowed by IAar; (TA;) and the generality of Keys and Temeem and Asad say mixiDato, with kesr to the m, [for maxiDato,] and in like manner they do in the case of every [incipient] letter before a guttural letter in words of the measures faEilotu and faEiylN; (Nuseyr, TA;) inf. n. maxaADN (ISh, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and mixaADN (Msb, K) and maxaDN; (A;) said of a she-camel, (ISh, S,) or of a woman, (IAar,) or absolutely, (A, Mgh,) or also absolutely, (Msb, TA, *) of a woman, and of a she-camel, and of other beasts, (TA,) (tropical:) She was taken with the pains of parturition, (ISh, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) being near to bringing forth; (Msb;) as also maxRaDato↓, inf. n. tamoxiyDN; (K;) and tmxRDt↓; (ISh, and so in some copies of the K;) each of these last two is correct; (TA;) and AmtxDt↓. (ISh.) And maxiDato said of a woman, (tropical:) Her child moved about in her belly, previously to the birth: (Ibráheem El-Harbee:) and in like manner, biwaladihaA tmxRDt↓, (S, * TA,) said of a she-camel, (tropical:) her young one became agitated in her belly at the time of bringing forth: (TA:) and tmxRDt↓ [alone], said of a ewe, or she-goat, (assumed tropical:) she conceived, or became pregnant. (As, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] maxiDa AlsRaHaAbu bimaAYihi, and tmxRD↓, (TA,) and AlsRamaMCu tmxRDt↓, (A, TA,) (tropical:) [The cloud, or clouds, and] the sky, or heaven, prepared, or became ready, to rain. (A, TA.) And AllRayolapu Eano SabaAHi sawoCK tmxRDt↓, (A,) or yawomi sawoCK, (TA,) (tropical:) The night had an evil morning. (TA,) And AldRahoru biAlofitonapi tmxRD↓ (tropical:) Time, or fortune, brought trial, civil war, sedition, or the like: (K, TA:) as though from AlmaxaADu. (K.) 'Amr Ibn-Hassán, one of the Benu-l-Hárith-Ibn-Hemmám-Ibn-Murrah, says, (Seer, S,) but the saying is also ascribed to Sahm Ibn-Khálid Ibn- 'Abd-Allah Esh-Sheybánee, and to Khálid Ibn- Hikk Esh-Sheybánee, (TA,)
Almanuwnu lahu biyawomK tamaxRaDati↓
OanaI walikulRi HaAmilapK tamaAmu
meaning [Time, or fortune,] was pregnant with a day for him, of which the time of birth had come: [for for every one that is pregnant there is a term of completion.] (S.)

2 maxRaDa
2: see maxiDato.

4 AmxD AllRabanu c
4. AmxD AllRabanu The milk attained to the proper time for [its being churned, or] having its butter taken, or extracted. (S, A, Msb.) In the O and K, it is made to signify the same as AmtxD: but it seems that Sgh has inadvertently omitted, after it, the words HaAna lahu Oano yumoxaDa, and that the author of the K has copied him without referring to other lexicons. (TA.) ― -b2- Also AmxD, (K,) said of a man, (TA,) (tropical:) He had his she-camels taken with the pains of parturition; (K, TA;) and his she-camel, in like manner. (TA.)

5 tmxRD c
5. tmxRD It (milk) was, or became, agitated in the mimoxaDap; (S, A, * TA;) as also AmtxD↓. (S, O, K.) [See also 4.] ― -b2- It (milk) had its butter taken. (K.) ― -b3- (tropical:) It (a child, or young one,) moved about in the belly of its mother; as also ↓the latter verb. (S, TA.) ― -b4- See also maxiDato and what follows it, to the end of the paragraph.

8 UimotaxaDa
8: see 5, in two places: ― -b2- and see maxiDato.

10 AstmxD AllRabanu c
10. AstmxD AllRabanu The milk was slow in becoming thick and fit for churning, and its butter would hardly, if at all, come forth: such is the best of milk, because its butter is in it. (A.) ― -b2- Also, The milk was slow in acquiring flavour after it had been collected in the skin. (TA.)

maxoDN c
maxoDN: see maxiyDN.

maxaADN mxAD
maxaADN (assumed tropical:) The pains of parturition; (S, Msb;) as also mixaADN↓. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- Applied to she-camels, (tropical:) Pregnant: (AZ, As, S, ISd, A, Msb, K, &c.:) used in this sense as an epithet of good omen, whence they augur that their young ones will become agitated in their bellies at the time of parturition: (ISd:) having their young in their bellies: (M, TA:) or such as are called EiXaAr, that have been ten months pregnant: (Th, K:) but ISd says, I have not found this explanation of mxAD on any authority beside that of Th: (TA:) [see also EuXaraMCu:] it has no proper sing: (S:) a single one is termed xalifapN, (AZ, As, S, A, &c.,) which is extr. (K, TA) with respect to rule: (TA:) or maxaADN signifies, or it signifies also, (accord. to different copies of the K,) she-camels in the state in which they are from the time when the stallion is sent among them (ISd, K) until he brays (HatRaI yahodira), or, accord. to another relation, until they are left (HtRI tugodara), i.e., (ISd,) until he ceases (HtRI yanoqaTiEa, in the copies of the K, erroneously, HtI tnqTE, TA) from covering: (ISd, K:) a pl. (K) having no sing. (ISd, K.) ― -b2- Hence, (S,) Aibonu maxaADK (tropical:) A young male camel, which, (As, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) having completed a year (As, S, Mgh) from the day of its birth, (As,) has entered upon the second year: (As, S, Mgh, Msb, K:) because his mother, (S, IAth, Mgh, K,) from whom he has been separated, (S,) has become adjoined to the maxaAD, (S, IAth, Mgh, K,) or pregnant camels, (IAth, K,) whether she have conceived or not; (S, IAth, * K; *) for they used to make the stallion-camels to cover the females a year after these had brought forth, (IAth, K, *) in order that their young ones might become strong, so that they conceived in the second year: (IAth:) or because its mother has been covered, and has conceived, and become adjoined to the maxaAD, i.e., to the pregnant camels; and this appellation it bears until it has completed the second year; but when it has entered upon the third, it is called Aibonu labuwnK: (Msb:) or a young male camel when his mother has conceived: (K:) or whose mother has become pregnant: or when the she-camels among whom is his mother have become pregnant, though she have not become so: (IAth, K:) the female is called binotu maxaADK; (IAth, Msb, K;) or Aibonapu maxaADK: (S:) the pl., (S, Msb, K,) of both the male and female appellations, (Msb,) is banaAtu maxaADK, (S, Msb, K,) only; like banaAtu labuwnK and banaAtu MwaI. (S.) Sometimes one adds to it the article Al, (Msb, K,) saying, Aibonu AlmaxaADi: (Msb:) [for] Abn mxAD is indeterminate; and when you desire to make it determinate, you affix the article Al, as above; but this only makes it determinate as a generic appellation. (S.)

mixaADN c
mixaADN: see maxaADN.

maxuwDN c
maxuwDN: see maAxiDN, in two places.

maxiyDN c
maxiyDN and mamoxuwDN↓ (S, Msb, K) and maxoDN↓ (TA, voce maHoDN, q. v.) [Churned milk:] or milk which has been churned (AlRaciI qado muxiDa), and of which the butter has been taken: (S:) or milk of which the butter has been taken: (K:) or milk of which the butter has been extracted, or fetched out, by putting water in it, and agitating it. (Msb.)

maAxiDN c
maAxiDN, applied to a she-camel, (ISh, IAar, S, K,) and to a woman, and a ewe or she-goat, (IAar, Msb, K,) and any pregnant animal, (S, A, * Msb,) (tropical:) Taken with the pains of parturition, (ISh, IAar, S, A, Msb,) being near to bringing forth; (IAar, Msb, K;) as also maxuwDN↓: (ISh:) and, applied to a ewe or she-goat, having conceived; as also ↓the latter epithet; (As, K;) pl. of the former, muxRaDN (S, Msb, K) and mawaAxiDu. (A, K.) ― -b2- The Arabs say, in one of their imprecations, SabRa QllRehu Ealayoka OumRa HubayonK maAxiDFA, meaning (assumed tropical:) [May God pour upon thee] the night. (Ibn-Buzurj.)

UimoxaADN c
UimoxaADN Fresh milk (Haliyb), (K,) or churned milk (labanN maxiyDN), (Lth,) as long as it remains in the mimoxaDap: (Lth, K:) or, as some say, milk collected in the place of pasturage until it amounts to the quantity of a camel-load: pl. OamaA xiyDu. (Lth.) You say UimoxaADN mino labanK and UiHolaAbN mino labanK: (Lth:) or the former is of ewes or she-
goats, or of cows; and the latter, of camels. (TA, in art. Hlb, q. v.) ― -b2- See also mimoxaDN.

mimoxaDN c
mimoxaDN A skin; syn.; siqaMCN; (K;) as also UimoxaADN↓, which is mentioned by Sb, and thus explained by Seer: (TA:) or a skin (sqAC) in which is maxiyD [or churned milk, &c.]: (TA:) or the receptacle in which the milk whereof the butter has been taken is agitated: (Lth:) and mimoxaDapN↓ [and app. the former also] the vessel, (Mgh,) or receptacle, (Msb,) [generally a skin,] in which milk is churned or beaten and agitated; (Mgh, K; *) or in which the butter of the milk is extracted, or fetched out by putting water in it, and agitating it; (Msb;) [i.e. a churn;] i. q. UiboriyjN. (S.)

mimoxaDapN c
mimoxaDapN: see what next precedes.

mimoxaADN c
mimoxaADN (assumed tropical:) A she-camel having a quick flow of milk. (JK.)

mamoxuwDN c
mamoxuwDN: see maxiyDN.

musotamoxiDN c
musotamoxiDN Milk slow in becoming thick and fit for churning: (K:) or that hardly, if at all, becomes so; and when it has become so, is churned; and this is the best of the milk of ewes or goats, because its butter is destroyed (Asthlk) in it. (TA.) [But see 10.]

1 maxoTN c
1. maxoTN, [an inf. n., of which the verb is app. maxaTa,] the act of flowing; and of going, coming, or passing, out, or forth: this is the primary signification; and hence muxaATN, q. v. (TA) ― -b2- [Hence also,] maxaTa AlsRahomu, (S, K,) aor.
maxaTa
and
maxuTa
, inf. n. muxuwTN, (K,) (tropical:) The arrow transpierced, (S, K,) and went forth on the other side. (S.) ― -b3- [And] maxaTa bihi Aljamalu (assumed tropical:) The camel went quickly with him. (Sgh, K.) ― -b4- [And] maxaTa fiI AlOaroDi, inf. n. maxoTN, (assumed tropical:) He went away quickly in the land. (TA.) ＝ -A2- maxaTa AlSRabiIRa, inf. n. maxoTN, He wiped the nose of the child; and in like manner you say of a lamb or kid: (L:) and mxRThu↓, (Msb,) inf. n. tamoxiyTN, (Z, K,) he removed the mucus from out of his nose: (Msb:) and he (the pastor) wiped off from its (a lamb's or kid's) nose what was upon it [at the time of the birth]. (Z, K.) And maxaTa AlmuxaATa He cast the mucus (S, K) mino Oanofihi from his nose. (S.) ― -b2- [And hence,] maxaTa AlsRayofa (tropical:) He drew the sword (K, TA) from its scabbard; (TA;) as also AmtxThu↓: (S, K:) and sometimes they said, (S,) maA fiI yadihi AmtxT↓ (tropical:) he pulled out what was in his hand; (S, K;) he seized, took away quickly by force, or snatched away, what was in his hand: (S, L, K:) and rumoHahu mino marokazihi AmtxT↓ (tropical:) he pulled out his spear from its place in which it was stuck. (TA.) ― -b3- [And] maxaTahu, (S, K, *) aor.
maxaTa
, inf. n. maxoTN, (S,) (assumed tropical:) He drew it; pulled it. (S, K. *) You say, maxaTa fiI Alqawosi (assumed tropical:) [He drew the bow; or drew, or pulled, its string with the arrow]. (S.)

2 maxRaTa
2: see 1.

4 AmxT AlsRahoma c
4. AmxT AlsRahoma, (S, K,) inf. n. UimoxaATN, (TA,) (tropical:) He made the arrow to transpierce, (S, A, K,) and to go forth on the other side. (A.)

5 tamaxRaTa
5: see 8.

8 AmtxT c
8. AmtxT He blew his nose; ejected the mucus from his nose; (S, Msb, K;) as also tmxRT↓: (S, K:) or the latter signifies he had the mucus removed from out of his nose. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 1, in three places.

muxaATN c
muxaATN Mucus; snivel; what flows from the nose, (S, K, TA,) like luEaAb from the mouth: (TA:) pl. OamoxiTapN only. (TA.) ― -b2- muxaATu AlXRayoTaAni, (K,) also called muxaATu AlXRamos, and luEaAbu AlXRamos, and riyqu AlXRamosi, all these appellations having been heard from the Arabs, (TA,) (tropical:) [The fine filmy cobwebs called gossamer, which are occasionally seen in very hot and calm weather, when the sun is high, floating in the air, in stringy or flaky forms;] what appears in the sun's rays to him who looks into the air in the time of vehement midday-heat: (K, TA:) mxAT AlXyTAn is explained by Z and IB as meaning what comes forth from the mouth of the spider. (TA in art. xyT.)

muxaATapN c
muxaATapN (AO, K) and muxRayoTN↓, (K,) called by the latter name by some of the people of ElYemen, (Sgh, TA,) and by the people of Egypt [in the present day], (TA,) [and muxRayoTaA↓, (Golius, on the authority of Ibn-El-Beytár, but if it end with a short A, i.e. without C, it should be written muxRayoTaI,)] [The cordia myxa, or smooth-leaved cordia; also called sebestena, and sebesten, and Assyrian plum;] a kind of tree, (K, TA,) producing a viscous fruit, [whence its name, like the Greek μύξα, which signifies both mucus and this kind of plum,] which is eaten; (TA;) called in Persian sibisotaAn [or saPisotaAn]; (K, TA;) i. q. OaTobaMCu Alkalobap [bitch's dugs], [its fruit] being likened thereto. (TA.) (See De Sacy's “ Abd-allatif, ” pp. 68 — 72.]

muxRayoTN c
muxRayoTN and muxRayoTaA: see what next precedes.

sahomN maAxiTN c
sahomN maAxiTN (tropical:) An arrow transpiercing, and going forth on the other side. (TA.)

OamoxaTu mino sahomK c
OamoxaTu mino sahomK (tropical:) [More transpiercing than an arrow]: a proverb. (JK.)

1 madRahu c
1. madRahu, (S, L, K,) aor.
maduda
, (L,) inf. n. madRN; and madRa bihi; and mdRdhu↓; [or this has an intensive or a frequentative signification;] and tmdRdhu↓; (L, K;) and mAdRhu↓, or mAddhu, (as in different copies of the K, TA,) inf. n. mumaAdRapN and midaAdN; (K;) He drew it (namely a rope, &c., A); pulled it: strained it: extended it by drawing or pulling; stretched it. (L, K, El-Basáïr.) You say also madRa Alqawosa [He drew the bow]; (S, Msb, K, in art. nzE;) and madRa mina AlbiYori [He drew water from the well]. (S, K, art. mtH.) [Hence, app., madRa biOarofaAdiI: see rifodN.] ― -b2- qaAYilu kalimapi AlzRuwri waAlRaciI yamudRu biHabolihaA fiI AlUivomi sawaMCN [The utterer of falsehood and he who transmits it are in respect of the sin alike]: a trad. of 'Alee; in which the utterer of the falsehood is likened to him who fills the bucket in the lower part of the well, and the relater thereof to him who draws the rope at the top. (L.) ― -b3- madRa He extended, or stretched forth, his hand or arm, foot or leg, &c. (The Lexicons passim.) ― -b4- bayonanaA tamadRadonaAhu↓ We drew, pulled, strained, or stretched, it between us, or together. (L.) [But in a copy of the M, it is tamaAdadonaAhu.] ― -b5- madRa AlHarofa, aor.
maduda
, inf. n. madRN, He lengthened the letter. (L.) ― -b6- madRa Sawotahu (tropical:) He prolonged, or strained, his voice [as the Arab does in chanting]: (L:) and fiI AlSRawoti tamadRada↓ Einoda AlwaEiydi (assumed tropical:) [He strained the voice in threatening]. (K, art. nmr.) ― -b7- madRa, inf. n. madRN, (tropical:) It (his sight) was, or became, stretched, and raised, UilaI XaIoCK towards a thing. (K.) ― -b8- madRa baSarahu UilaI XaIoCK, aor.
maduda
, [inf. n. madRN,] (tropical:) He stretched, and raised, his sight towards a thing. (A, * L.) ― -b9- madadotu EayoniI UilaI kacaA (tropical:) I looked at such a thing desirously. (IKtt, El-Basáïr.) ― -b10- madRaha, aor.
maduda
, (Lh, L,) inf. n. madRN, (Lh, L, K,) He expanded it, or stretched it out: (L, K:) he extended it, elongated it, or lengthened it. (L.) ― -b11- madR QllRehu AlOaroDa God expanded, or stretched out, and made plain, or level, the earth. (Lh, L.) ― -b12- madRa QllRehu AlZRilRa (tropical:) God extended, or stretched forth, the shade. (A.) See 8. ― -b13- madRa QllRehu fiI Eumorihi (tropical:) God made his life long; (S, A, * L;) as also AmdRa↓. (IKtt.) ― -b14- madRa QllRehu fiI Eumorika (tropical:) May God make thy life long! (L.) ― -b15- mudRa fiI Eumorihi (tropical:) He had his life lengthened. (L.) ― -b16- AlOajala OamadRa↓, inf. n. UimodaAdN, (tropical:) He deferred, or postponed, the term, or period of duration. (K.) ― -b17- lahu fiI AlOajali AmdR↓ (tropical:) He deferred, or postponed, to him the term, or his term. (TA.) ― -b18- madRahu, aor.
maduda
, (L,) inf. n.
madRN; and AmdRhu↓, inf. n. UimodaAdN; (L, K;) but the latter is little used; (L;) (tropical:) He made him to continue; to go on long; left him, or let him alone, long, or for a while; granted him a delay, or respite. (L, K. *) Ex. madRahu fiI gayRihi, (S, L,) and AmdRhu↓, (L,) (tropical:) He made him to continue, &c., in his error. (S, L.) And in like manner, madRa QllRehu lahu fiI AlEacaAbi (tropical:) God made him to continue, or go on long, in a state of punishment. (L.) See also 3. ― -b19- madRa fiI AlsRayori (tropical:) He made much advance in journeying. (L.) ― -b20- madRahu, inf. n. madadN and midaAdN, He made it much in quantity; increased it. (L, TA.) ― -b21- madRa, (S, L, Msb,) aor.
maduda
, [contr. to analogy,] (L,) inf. n. madRN; (S, L, K;) It (water, L, and a river, S, L, and a sea, or great river, L) flowed: (S, L, K:) it (water, L, and a sea, or great river, L, Msb) increased; as also AmdR↓; both of which verbs are also used transitively: (Msb:) or became much in quantity, copious, or abundant, in the days of the torrents; as also AmtdR↓: (L:) contr. of jazara [it ebbed]. (Lth, S, M, K in art. jzr.) ― -b22- waAdiI kacaA yamudRu fiI nahori kacaA Such a valley flows into and increases such a river. (A, L.) ― -b23- madRahu, (Lh, S, L, Msb,) aor.
maduda
, (Lh, L,) inf. n. madRN; (Lh, L, Msb;) and AmdRhu↓; (L, Msb;) It (a thing) entered into it, (i. e., a like thing,) and increased it, or made it copious or abundant: (Lh, L:) it (a river, S, L, or sea, or great river, L, Msb) flowed into it, (i. e., another river, or sea, or great river,) and increased it, replenished it, or made it copious or abundant: (S, * L, Msb: *) it (a well) fed it, i. e., another well: (L:) [see an ex. in a verse cited in art. grw, conj. 3]: both these verbs are also used intransitively. (Msb.) ― -b24- [madRRti AlsRuwqu (assumed tropical:) The market was full of people and of goods for sale. See the part. n.] ― -b25- madRa Alqawoma, [aor.
maduda
, inf. n. madRN,] He became an auxiliary to the people: (K:) and madadonaAhumo We became auxiliaries to them: somewhat differing from OamadonaAhumo↓, which signifies We aided them, or succoured them, by others than ourselves: (AZ, S, L, K:) you say, bimadadK Oamodadotuhu↓ I aided him, and strengthened him, [or increased his numbers and strength,] with an army: (S, * Msb:) and AlOamiyru junodahu biAlxayoli waAlrRijaAli OamadRa↓ The commander aided, or succoured, his army with cavalry and infantry, or with horses and men: and bimaAlK kaviyrK AmdRhumo↓ He aided them with, or, as some say, gave them, much wealth: (L:) and [it is said in the Kur, lii. 22,] waOamodadonaAhumo bifaAkihapK (S, L) And We will increase their provision time after time with fruit: (Beyd, Jel:) or with relation to evil, you say madadotuhu; and with relation to good, Oamodadotuhu↓: (K:) so says Yoo: (L:) this is generally the case; and the following are examples: OamodadonaAhumo bifaAkihapK [explained above]: and namudRuhumo mina AlEacaAbi (ElBasáïr) [Kur, xix. 82,] We will prolong and increase to them punishment: (Beyd;:) but Z relates, that Akh said the reverse, like waEada and OawoEada: the usage of the Arabs, however, does not accord with either of these assertions. (MF.) ― -b26- madRa It (anything) became full, and rose. (Sh, L.) ― -b27- madRa AlsRiraAja, (aor.
maduda
, A, [inf. n. madRN,]) He put oil (or the like, K) into the lamp. (A, L, K.) ― -b28- madRa AldRawaApa, (aor.
maduda
, inf. n. madRN, Msb,) and AmdRhaA↓, He put ink into the receptacle thereof; (S, * Msb;) he increased its water, and its ink. (L.) ― -b29- In like manner, madRa Alqalama, and AmdRhu↓, He supplied the reed-pen with ink. (L.) ― -b30- madRahu mudRapF mina AldRawaApi, aor.
maduda
; and mudRapF OamadRahu↓ is also allowable; (L;) or simply madRahu (A) and OamadRahu; (S, A, K;) He gave him a dip of ink from the receptacle thereof with a reed-pen. (S, TA.) ― -b31- madRa, inf. n. madRN, He dipped the reedpen in the receptacle of ink a single time for writing. (Msb.) See also 10. ― -b32- madRa AlOaroDa, (aor.
maduda
, A, inf. n. madRN, L,) He manured the land with dung: (A, K:) or he added to the land manure composed of dung and ashes, or of earth or dust and dung, or of strong earth; or simply earth; or sand; to render it more productive. (L.) ― -b34- madRa AlUibila, (AZ, S, A, L, K.) aor.
maduda
, inf. n. madRN; (AZ, L;) and AmdRhA↓; (S, A, L;) He gave madiyd (or water upon which had been sprinkled, or with which had been mixed, some flour, or the like, &c.) to the camels to drink: (AZ, S, A, L, K:) or he put some barley coarsely ground, and then moistened, into the camel's mouths: (AZ, L:) or madRahu bimadiydK, aor.
maduda
, inf. n. madRN, signifies, as some say, he fed him with fodder. (M.)

2 madRaRa
2: see 1, first sentence.

3 maAdadotuhu c
3. maAdadotuhu, inf. n. mumaAdRapN and midaAdN, I pulled him, he pulling me: (Lh, L:) I contended with him in drawing or pulling, in straining, or in stretching; syn. jaAcabotuhu. (L.) ― -b2- mAdRhu AlvRawoba [He pulled, strained, or stretched, the garment, or piece of cloth with him]. (A.) ― -b3- maAdRahu He prolonged to him a time. (L, from a trad.) ― -b4- maAdRa fiI AlmudRapi (tropical:) He prolonged, protracted, or lengthened, the space of time. (IAth, from a trad.) ― -b5- mAdRhu, (L,) inf. n. mumaAdRapN (L, K) and midaAdN, (L,) (tropical:) He protracted, delayed, or deferred, with him; put him off. (L, K. *) See also 1.

4 Oamodada
4: See 1 throughout. ― -b2- AmdR fiyhi He (God) made it (the means of subsistence) ample: made it (wealth or the like) abundant: increased it, namely, a sea or river. (IKtt.) ― -b3- AmdRhu He made it (anything) to become full, and to rise. (Sh, L.) See also 1. ― -b4- AmdR, inf. n. UimodaAdN, He aided, or succoured: and he gave. (K.) See madRa Alqawoma. ― -b5- AmdR fiI miXoyatihi He (a man) walked with an elegant, and a proud, and self-conceited, gait, with an affected incline of his body from side to side. (TA.) See also 5. ― -b6- AmdR (inf. n. UimodaAdN, L, &c.) It (a wound) produced midap, or thick purulent matter. (S, L, Msb. K.) ― -b7- AmdR (inf. n. UimodaAdN, K) It (the plant called Earofaj, S, L, K, and the SilRiyaAn, and the Tariyfap, TA) became succulent, the sap running in it: (S, L, K:) and it, (the twig, or wood, of any of the three plants above mentioned,) being rained upon became soft, or supple. (L.)

5 tmdRd c
5. tmdRd: see 8. ― -b2- It (leather, A) or a skin for water, &c., and anything that may be extended by drawing or pulling, (L,) stretched. (A, * L.) ― -b3- See also 1. ― -b4- tmdRd He (a man) stretched himself: he walked with an elegant, and a proud, and self-conceited, gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side, and stretching out his arms: syn. tamaTRaI. (S, L.) [Both these verbs are commonly used in the present day in the former sense.] See also 4.

6 tamaAdRaA AlvRawoba c
6. tamaAdRaA AlvRawoba [They two pulled, strained, or stretched, the garment, or piece of cloth, together]. (A.)

8 AmtdR c
8. AmtdR, (S, L, K,) and tmdRd↓, [or this has an intensive or frequentative signification,] (L, K.) It (a rope, &c., A) because drawn, or pulled: it became strained: it became extended by drawing or pulling; it extended itself; it stretched. (L, K, El-Basáïr.) See also 5. ― -b2- AmtdR It became expanded, or stretched out. (Msb.) ― -b3- It became elongated, or extended, or long. (Msb.) ― -b4- [It (a time) became protracted.] ― -b5- AmtdR bihimu AlsRayoru (tropical:) The journey became long to them. (A, * L.) ― -b6- AmtdR (tropical:) It (a man's life) became long. (A.) ― -b7- (tropical:) It (the shade) became extended, or stretched forth. (A) ― -b8- It (a disease) spread. (A.) See 1. ― -b9- AmtdR: (A, L;) and madRa↓, (L, K,) inf. n. madRN; (S, L, K;) (tropical:) It (the day, S, A, L, K, and the period of morning called AlDRuHaI, L,) became high; it became advanced, the sun being high: (S, L, K:) and the former, (tropical:) it (the day) shone forth. (L.) ― -b10- AmtdR; and madR↓, inf. n. madR; (TA;) said of the shade, (tropical:) It extended]. (A.) ― -b11- AmtdR UilaI AlUijaAbapi Uilayohi [app. (assumed tropical:) He strained himself to give his consent to it.] (K, voce UinbaAEa, q. v. in art. bwE.)

10 AstmdR mina AldRawaApi c
10. AstmdR mina AldRawaApi; (A, L, Msb, K:) and madRa minohaA↓, inf. n. madRN; (L, Msb, K;) He took ink from the receptacle thereof with the reed-pen, for writing: (Msb:) or he took a dip from the receptacle of ink with the reed-pen. (L.) See also 1. ― -b2- AstmdR AlnRafasa [He drew breath.] (M,
TA, art. nfs.) ― -b3- AstmdR He asked, sought, or desired mdada [or aid, or succour, in war, &c.]. (S, L, K.) ― -b4- AstmdRhu He asked, sought, or desired, of him (a commander, A) madd [or aid, or succour, in war, &c.] (A, * L.)

R. Q. 1 madomada c
R. Q. 1. madomada He fled. (T, L, K.)

mdRN c
mdRN inf. n. of 1, q. v. ― -b2- [As a subst.] qadoru madRi AlbaSari (tropical:) A piece of land (S, L) [occupying] the space of the extent of vision; i. q. madaAhu. (S, L, K.) It is said in the K, art. mdI, that one should not say mdR AlbSr, but only madaAhu; this was originally said by El-Hareeree: but some urge against it the expression in a trad., madRu Sawoti AlmuWacRini: (MF:) the trad. is, UinRa AlmuWacRina yugofaru lahu madRa Sawotihi, or, according to another reading, madaI Swth; i. e., (tropical:) Verily the muëdhdhin shall be forgiven to the extent of the prolonging of his voice; meaning, largely. (L, TA.) ― -b3- Oatayotuhu madRa AlnRahaAri, and madRa AlDRuHaI, (A,) and fiI madRipi, (L,) (tropical:) I came to him at the time when the day, and the morning, was hïgh; or was advanced, the sun being high. (A, L,) madRa is here an inf. n. put adverbially. (L.) ― -b4- hecaA madRu AlnRahaAri AlOakobaru (tropical:) This is the highest time of day. (A.) ― -b5- kalimaAtihi suboHaAna QllRehi midaAda↓, (A, L, K,) and madadahaA↓, (L,) and midaAda AlsRamawaAti, (L, K,) and madadahaA, (L,) (tropical:) I extol, or celebrate, or declare, the absolute purity, or perfection, or glory, of God, much as his words are numerous, (L,) and, as the heavens are many, or large: (L, K: *) mdAd↓ and mdd↓ are here inf. ns. of madRahu, q. v.: (L:) or the first of these phrases is from mdAd the pl. of mudRN, a certain measure. (K.) ― -b6- madRN, app. an inf. n. used as a subst., A flow of water; a torrent: pl. muduwdN. (Msb.)

mudRN c
mudRN A certain measure with which corn is measured; equal to a pint (riTol) and one third, (S, L, Msb, K,) of the standard of Baghdád, (Msb,) with the people of El-Hijáz, (S, L, Msb,) and accord. to Esh-Sháfi'ee; (L;) i. e., the quarter of a SaAE; the SAE being five pints and one third: (Msb:) such was the mdR of the Prophet; (L, TA;) and the SAE above defined was that of the Prophet: (Msb, art. SwE:) or two pints, (S, L, Msb, K,) with the people of El-'Irák, (S, L, Msb,) and accord. to Aboo- Haneefeh, (L,) who held the SAE to be eight pints: (Msb, art. SwE:) or the quantity (of corn, L) that fills the two hands of a man (of moderate size, K) when he extends his arms and hands; (L, K;) and therefore called mudR: (K:) pl. [of pauc.] OamodaAdN and [of mult.] midaAdN (L, Msb, K) and midadapN (L. K) and midadN. (L.) ― -b2- midaAdN pl. of mudRN, or inf. n. of madRa, see madRN.

madadN c
madadN (S, K, &c.) ― -b2- Oamoruhumo madadN Their affair, or case, is conformable to the just mean; like OamadN and zamamN. (TA in art. zm). ― -b3- Aid, or succour, given to one's people in war, &c., such as an auxiliary force, and corn; (T, L;) an accession to an army, &c.; (Mgh;) a military force forming an accession to warriors in the cause of God: (L:) pl. OamodaAdN only: (Sb, L:) in like manner, maAdRapN↓ signifies anything wherewith one aids a people in war, &c. (L.) ― -b4- [A mystic aid imparted by a waliIR.] ― -b5- See madRN.

madRapN c
madRapN A single act of drawing or pulling; of straining; of stretching; &c. (S, L.) ― -b2- See mudRapu.

mudRapN c
mudRapN (tropical:) The utmost, or extreme, extent, term, limit, reach, or point, of time, and of place. (L, K.) Ex. lihecihi AlOumRapi mudRapN (tropical:) To this nation, or people, is [appointed] an extreme term of endurance, or continuance. (L.) ― -b2- mudRapN (tropical:) A long space of time; or any space of time; syn. burohapN: (S, L, K:) a portion of time, whether little or much: (IAth, Msb:) pl. midaAdN. (A.) ― -b3- mudRapN A dip of ink; the quantity of ink that is taken upon the reed-pen. (S, A, * K.) The vulgar say madRapN↓ and midRapN. (TA.)

midRapN c
midRapN Thick purulent matter, (A, Msb,) i. q. qayoHN, (S, L, Msb, K,) that collects in a wound: (S, L:) the thin is called SadiydN. (A, Msb.) ― -b2- See mudRapN.

madadiIRN c
madadiIRN An auxiliary soldier. (L.)

midaAdN c
midaAdN Anything that is added in a thing, because of its utility: this is the original signification accord. to old lexicologists. (MF.) ― -b2- Ink; syn. niqosN (S, L, K) and HiborN; (MF;) that with which one writes: (L, Msb:) so called because it aids the writer: (IAmb, L:) this is the common acceptation of the word. (MF.) ― -b3- midaAdN (or midaAdu AlsRiraAji, A) Oil (or the like, K) that is put into a lamp. (A, L, K.) ― -b4- midaAdN (or midaAdN AlOaroDi, A) Dung: (A, K:) or manure composed of dung and ashes, or of earth or dust and dung, or of strong earth; and simply earth or dust; and sand. (L.) ― -b5- midaAdN A row of trees; not of palm-trees. (IAar, in TA, voce OusokuwbN, q. v.) ― -b6- A mode, manner, fashion, and form. (L, K.) Ex. banawoA buyuwtahumo EalaI midaAdK waAHidK They built their houses after one mode, &c. (L.) ― -b7- midaAdu qayosK A certain game (T, K) of the Arabs, (K,) or of children. (T.) ― -b8- yanobaEivu fiI AlHawoDi miyzaAbaAni midaAduhumaA OanohaAru AljanRapi [Two pipes, or spouts, whereof the sources (lit. the source) of the supply are the rivers of paradise, pour into the pond which is without its precincts]; i. e., the rivers of paradise flow into those pipes, or spouts, and increase their flow, or make it copious, or abundant. (L, K. *) ― -b9- midaAdN sing. of OamidRapN, (L,) which signifies The large needles (masaAlRu, M, L, TT; in the CK and a MS copy of the K, misaAk; in the TA, masaAk) [which are inserted] in the two sides of a piece of cloth when its manufacture is commenced.
