(M, L, TT, K.) ― -b10- Also, the pl., The threads which compose the warp of a web. (K.)

madiydN c
madiydN Drawn, or pulled: strained: stretched: lengthened: i. q. mamoduwdN↓. (L, K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Tall: long: (L, K:) fem. with p: (L:) and pl. mududN, (L, K,) which preserves its original form [instead of becoming mudRN] because it does not resemble a verb. (Sb, L.) ― -b3- madiydu AlqaAmapi, (S, L,) and Aljisomi (L,) (tropical:) A man tall of stature, (S, L,) and, of body. (L.) ― -b4- qadRN madiydN (tropical:) A tall stature. (A.) ― -b5- fiI EamadK mumadRadapK↓, in the Kur, [civ., last verse,] is explained by Th as signifying (tropical:) Upon tall pillars. (L.) ― -b6- Oaqamotu mudRapF madiydapF (tropical:) I remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, a long space of time. (A.) ― -b7- Almadiydu The second metre (baHor) in prosody: (L, K:) so called because of the extension of its OasobaAb and OawotaAd. (L.) ― -b8- madiydN Water upon which is sprinkled, (S, K,) or with which is mixed, (L,) some flour (AZ, S, A, L, K) or the like, (S,) or meal of parched barley or wheat, (A, L,) or barley (L, K,) coarsely ground, (L,) or sesame, (AZ, L, K,) or seeds, (AZ, L,) and which is given to a camel to drink: (AZ, S, A, L, K:) or barley coarsely ground, and then moistened, and put into the mouth of a camel: (AZ, L:) or i. q. xabaTN: (IKtt:) and, (K,) or as some say, (L,) fodder. (L, K.)

midRaAnN c
midRaAnN: see UimidRaAnN.

suwqN maAdRapN c
suwqN maAdRapN (assumed tropical:) A market full of people and of goods for sale. (TA, art. Hkr.) ― -b2- maAdRapu XaIoCK The accession, or that which is added, whatever it be, to a thing. ― -b3- You say, daEo fiI AlDRaroEi maAdRapa AllRabani Leave thou in the udder the accession, to the quantity of milk, which has collected and become added to that previously left therein. (L.) See also EiynapN, last sentence. ― -b4- You also say, AlOaEoraAbu maAdRapu AlUisolaAmi (A, L) (tropical:) The Arabs of the desert are the means of aiding the Muslims, and increasing their armies, and strengthening them by the contribution of their wealth as alms: a phrase occurring in a trad. (L.) See also madadN. ― -b5- maAdRapu baHorK [The supply of a sea or great river]. (Az, in L, art. bHr.) ― -b6- maAdRapN Continuous increase; syn. ziyaAdapN mutRaSilapN: (S, A, L, K:) that whereby a thing is extended: the p is added to give intensiveness to the signification. (M, L.) ― -b7- [Also, in the conventional language of philosophy, Substance
having extent, or extended; matter; the material, or materials, of which a thing having form consists, or is composed: considered as that of which a thing having form consists, it is termed also TiynapN: considered as capable of assuming or receiving form, it is especially termed hayuwlaI: as that from which composition commences, EunoSurN: and as that to which resolution reduces a thing, UisoTuqisN, or OusoTuqusN, as it is generally written and pronounced: the pl. is mawaAdRu. ― -b8- The radical substance of a word, the radical letters, collectively, of a word.]

OamadRu c
OamadRu [More or most tall, high, long, &c.] ― -b2- huwa mino OamadRi AlnRaAsi qaAmapF (tropical:) He is of the tallest of men in stature. (A) ― -b3- naEamo waOaXadRahu waOamadRahu Yes: even the utmost thereof, and the most that could be thereof. Said in reply to the question “ Hast thou done it? ” (A.) ― -b4- OamadRu SawotFA Higher or louder, or highest or loudest, of voice. (Mgh, art. lqI.)

OumoduwdN c
OumoduwdN Custom; habit. (K.)

UimidRaAnN c
UimidRaAnN (of the measure UifoEilaAnN, [originally UimodidaAnN,] S, L) and midRaAnN↓ (L, K) Salt water: (L, K:) or very salt water: (S, L:) or the water of salt earth. (L.) ― -b2- Also, the former, Water exuding from the earth: (L, K:) sometimes written, (K,) or as some say, (L,) UimRidaAnN (L, K.)

mamoduwdN c
mamoduwdN: see madiydN. ― -b2- (tropical:) Much wealth. (A.)

mamadRu HabolK c
mamadRu HabolK The place of a rope at which it is drawn, or pulled, strained, or stretched. (A.)

mumadRadN c
mumadRadN A tent of skin (TiraAfN) extended, or stretched, with the ropes called OaTonaAb. It is with teshdeed to denote intensiveness. (S, L.) ― -b2- See madiydN.

1 madaHahu c
1. madaHahu, (S, K,) aor.
madaHa
, (K,) inf. n. madoHN (S, K) and midoHapN, (K,) as some say, but correctly this latter is a simple subst.; (TA;) and AmtdHhu↓; (S, K;) and mdRHhu↓, (K,) inf. n. tamodiyH; (TA;) [but this, and that next preceding it, have an intensive signification, as is shown by the explanation of their pass. part. ns., which see below;] and tmdRHhu↓; (K:) [which seems to imply some degree of effort in the agent;] He praised, eulogized, or commended, him; spoke well of him; mentioned him with approbation: (S, K:) or he described him as characterized by goodliness, beauty, or elegance; opposite of camRahu: and he enumerated his generous qualities or actions; opposite of hajaAhu: (MF:) or he praised him for his goodly qualities, whether natural or depending upon his own will; and hence it is of more common application than Hamadahu: accord. to El-Khateeb El-Tebreezee, it is from the phrase tamadRaHati AlOaroDu “ the land became ample, or spacious; ” whence it would seem to signify he amplified his phrase: accord. to Kh, madaHahu relates to an absent person; and madahahu, to one who is present: and accord. to EsSarakustee, madohN is descriptive of the state, or condition, and external appearance or form; and of nothing beside. (Msb.)

2 madRaHa
2: see 1.

3 mAdHhu c
3. mAdHhu He praised, eulogized, or commended, him reciprocally. (A.)

5 tmdRH c
5. tmdRH He affected (takalRafa) to be praised, eulogized, or commended; endeavoured, or constrained himself, to gain praise, eulogy, or commendation. (S, K.) huwa yatamadRaHu UilaI AlnRaAsi He seeks to gain the praise, eulogy, or commendation, of people. (A.) ― -b2- He praised, eulogized, or commended, himself. (TA.) ― -b3- He gloried: he boasted of abundance which he did not possess. (K.) ― -b4- AlEarabu tatamadRaHu biAlsRaxaMCi [The Arabs glory in liberality, bounty, munificence, or generosity]. (A.) ― -b5- See 1. ― -b6- tamadRaHati AlxaASirapu, (S, K,) and AmtdHt↓, and UimRadaHat↓ [originally UinomdaHat], (K,) The hypochondre, or flank, became distended, expanded, or dilated, (S, K,) by reason of satiety; like tndRHt: occurring in this sense in a verse of Er-Rá'ee, as some relate it; as others relate it, it is tmcRHt. (S.) ― -b7- baTonuhu AmdHR↓ His belly became wide, or distended; a dial. form of AndHR. (S.) This, says F, is a mistake; but it is no mistake; and he has perverted the words of J, which are confirmed by Sgh and the author of the L and many others. (MF.) ― -b8- Also tmdRHt AlOaroDu, and AmtdHt, and AmRdHt↓ (K) and AnmdHt↓, (TA,) The land became ample, or spacious. (K.) The first and second are formed by substitution of m for n from tndHt and AntdRHt. (L.)

6 tmAdHwA c
6. tmAdHwA They praised, eulogized, or commended, one another. (A.) AltRamaAduHu AltRacaAbuHu Praising one another is slaughtering one another. (S, art. cbH, A.)

7 UinomadaHa
7: 8, and 9. See 5 and 1.

midoHapN c
midoHapN and madiyHN↓ and OumoduwHapN↓ (S, K,) Praise; eulogy; commendation: (S:) that with which one is praised, eulogized, or commended; (K;) meaning poetry, or verse, with which one is praised, eulogized, or commended: (TA:) pl. of the first, midaHN; (A;) of the second, madaAYiHu; and of the third, OamaAdiyHu. (K, A.)

madiyHN c
madiyHN: see midoHapN.

madRaAHN c
madRaAHN [One who praises, &c., much, or often; a habitual praiser, &c.] (TA in art. Hvw; &c. See an ex. voce HavaA.)

maAdiHN c
maAdiHN Praising, eulogizing, or commending; or a praiser, eulogizer, or commender: pl. madRaHN. (TA.)

mamaAdiHu c
mamaAdiHu Praiseworthy, commendable, or good, qualities or dispositions, &c.; contr of maqaAbiHu. (L, art. qbH.)

OumoduwHapN c
OumoduwHapN: see midoHapN.

mumadRaHN c
mumadRaHN A man much, or greatly praised; (S, K;) as also mumotadaHN↓: (TA:) praised by every tongue. (A.)

mumotadaHN c
mumotadaHN: see mumadRaHN.

1 madarahu c
1. madarahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
madura
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. madorN, (Msb, TA,) He plastered it (a place) with [madar, or] clay, or loam, or mud; as also mdRrhu↓, (M, K,) inf. n. tamodiyrN. (TA.) He repaired it (namely a watering-trough or tank) with madar; (S, Msb;) i. e., clay, or loam, or mud: (Msb:) he closed the interstices of its stones with madar: (S, K:) he plastered its surface with clay, or loam, or mud, in which was no sand, in order that it might not cleave open, or in order that its water might not issue forth. (TA.)

2 madRara
2: see 1. ＝ -A2- mdRr, (A, K,) inf. n. tamodiyrN, (K,) (tropical:) Alvum dejecit: because he who does so makes use of madar [for purification]; and the excrement is metonymically termed clay: (A:) cacavit: (K:) mostly said of the hyena. (TA.)

4 OamodiruwnaA mino mamodaratikumo c
4. OamodiruwnaA mino mamodaratikumo [Give ye to us some madar from your place whence ye take madar]. (A.)

8 Amtdr Almadara c
8. Amtdr Almadara He took what is called madar. (K.)

madarN c
madarN [a coll. gen. n.] Pieces, or bits, [or lumps, or clods,] of dry, or tough, clay, (M, A, K,) such as is cohesive: (TA:) or [simply] pieces of clay: (Az, Msb:) or compact or cohesive earth: (Msb:) or tough or cohesive clay in which is no sand: (M, Msb, K:) n. un. with p. (S, M, Msb, K.) In the expression AlHijaArapu waAlmidaArapu↓ [Stones and pieces of dry or tough clay, &c.], the latter word is used after the manner of an imitative sequent, and is not used alone, as a broken pl.: (M:) or it is an imitative sequent. (K.) ＝ -A2- (tropical:) Cities [or towns or villages]: or a region, district, or tract, of cities or towns or villages, and of cultivated land; (K, TA;) because its buildings are [generally] of madar: (TA:) and its n. un., madarapN↓, (tropical:) a city or town or
village; syn. balodapN, (K,) or qaroyapN; (S, Msb, K;) because its buildings are generally of madar: (Msb:) or a town or village built of clay or mud and unburnt bricks: and also a large city. (L.) You say, Oaholu Almadari waAlwabari (tropical:) [The people of the towns or villages, and of the tents]. (S.) And maA raOayotu fiI Alwabari waAlmadari mivolahu (tropical:) I have not seen in the desert and the towns or villages the like of him. (A.) And it is related in a trad., that the Prophet said to 'Ámir Ibn-Et-Tufeyl, Become thou a muslim, and he replied, EalaI OanRa liIa Alwabara walaka Almadara (tropical:) [On the condition that to me shall pertain the desert, and to thee the towns or villages]. (A.) You say also, fulaAnN sayRidu madaratihi (tropical:) Such a one is the chief of his town or village. (Msb.) And banuw madoraMCa↓ (tropical:) The people of the cities or towns or villages and cultivated land. (K.)

madarapN c
madarapN: see madarN.

banuw madoraMCa c
banuw madoraMCa: see madarN.

madiyrN c
madiyrN and mamoduwrN↓ A place plastered with [madar, or] clay, or loam, or mud. (TA.)

midaArapN c
midaArapN: see madarN.

maAdirN c
maAdirN [One who plasters with madar:] one who plasters his watering-trough or tank with his ordure, in order that no one beside himself may water at it: pl. madarapN. (A.)

DiboEaAnN OamodarN c
DiboEaAnN OamodarN: see DabuEN.

mimodarN c
mimodarN An instrument with which one plasters with [madara, or] clay, or loam, or mud. (TA, art. sbH.)

mamodarapN c
mamodarapN (S, K) and mimodarapN, (K,) which latter is extr. [with respect to form], (TA,) or mamodurapN, like maqoburapN, (A,) A place in which is [madar, or] clay, or loam, or mud, unmixed with sand, (K,) prepared for closing the interstices of the stones of watering-troughs or tanks; (TA;) a place from which madar is taken for that purpose. (S.) See 4.

mamoduwrN c
mamoduwrN: see madiyrN.

muco c
muco and mco: see art. mnc.

1 maciHa c
1. maciHa, (S,) aor.
macaHa
, (L,) inf. n. macaHN, (S, K,) His (a man's, S) thighs rubbed each other: (S, L, K:) when he walked, (S,) by reason of his fatness: (Námoos:) or his thighs rubbed each other, and twisted, so that they became excoriated; as also faxicaAhu macRaHato↓: (L:) or the parts between the inner sides of the roots of his thighs (maA bayona AlrRufogayoni) and his buttocks became inflamed: (K, TA:) [for AxtrAq, in the CK, I read AHtrAq, as in other copies of the K, and in the TA: see also waciHa.]. ― -b2- maciHa is said to signify It (a thing) rubbed against another thing, and became much cracked, or chapped, thereby. ISd thinks that it relates especially to an animal. (L.) ― -b3- Also, maciHa He had his testicle much chapped by its rubbing against something. (K.) ― -b4- maciHati AlDRaOonu, inf. n. macaHN, The sheep sweated in the inner sides of the roots of the thighs, or the parts called OarofaAg: (L:) or, in their thighs. (TA.)

2 macRaHa
2: see 1.

5 tamacRaHato xaASirataAhu c
5. tamacRaHato xaASirataAhu His two hypochrondres, or flanks, became inflated, or swollen, by reason of his having satiated himself with drink. (K.) [See also tamadRaHa and tanadRaHa.]

OamocaHu c
OamocaHu A man whose thighs rub each other when he walks. (S.) [See 1.]

1 macirati AlbayoDapu c
1. macirati AlbayoDapu, (S, A, K,) aor.
macara
, (A, K,) inf. n. macarN, (TA,) The egg became corrupt, or rotten. (S, A, K.) And macirati Aljawozapu The nut became bad, or corrupt; as also tmcRrt↓. (K.) ― -b2- macirato maEidatuhu His stomach became in a corrupt state: (S:) and macirato nafosuhu, (S, K,) and maEidanuhu, (K,) his soul [or stomach] became heavy; or it heaved, or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; syn. xabuvato; (S, K;) as also tmcRrt↓. (S, A, K.) You say, raOayotu bayoDapF mcirapF famacirato licelika nafosiI I saw a rotten egg, and my soul [or stomach] heaved, or became agitated by a tendency to vomit, thereat; syn. xabuvato. (S.)

4 Amcrt AlbayoDapa c
4. Amcrt AlbayoDapa She (a hen) caused the egg to become corrupt, or rotten. (S, A.)

5 tamacRara
5: see 1, in two places.

Xacara macara c
Xacara macara and Xicara micara: see art. Xcr. The latter word is an imitative sequent to the former. (TA.)

bayoDapN macirapN c
bayoDapN macirapN A corrupt, or rotten, egg. (A, K.) ― -b2- UimoraOapN macirapN A dirty, or filthy, woman, (K, TA,) whose odour is like that of a rotten egg. (TA.)

1 marRa c
1. marRa, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
marura
, (S, M,) inf. n. marRN [and mamarRN] and muruwrN, (S, M, Msb, K,) He, or it, passed; passed by, or beyond; went; went on; proceeded; passed, or went, along, or through, or over; went away; passed away; syn. jaAza; (M, K;) and cahaba; (S, M, Msb, K;) and maDaI; (A, Mgh;) as also AstmrR↓. (S, A, Mgh, K.) You say, marRa AlrRajulu, (TK,) and AldRahoru, (Msb,) and AlOamoru; and AstmrR↓; (A, Mgh;) The man, (TK,) and time, (Msb,) and the affair, (A, Mgh,) passed; &c. (A, Mgh, Msb, TK.) The saying in the Kur, [vii. 189,] Hamalato HamolFA xafiyfFA famarRato bihi signifies i. q. bh AstmrRt↓, (A, K,) which is another reading, (Bd,) i. e., [She bore a light burden in her womb, and] went with it, and moved from place to place, and rose and sat, not being oppressed by its weight: (A:) [or went on with it in the same course or manner:] or went and came with it, by reason of its lightness: (Jel:) or rose and sat with it, (Zj, Bd,) not being oppressed by its weight: (Zj:) so accord. to both the readings mentioned above: (Bd:) by the burden being meant the impregnating fluid. (Bd, Jel, TA.) ― -b2- [It is also said of water, meaning It ran, or flowed. And one says, marRati AlrRiyHu The wind passed along, or blew.] ― -b3- marRa bihi, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) and marRa Ealayohi, (S, A, Msb,) but the former is more common than the latter, (Mughnee, voce bi,) for which the BenooYarbooa say, mirRa Elyh, with kesr, (TA,) and marRahu, [respecting which see what follows the explanation,] (M, K,) aor.
marura
, (S,) inf. n. marRN and mamarRN (S, A, Msb) and muruwrN; (A, Msb;) and bihi AimotarRa↓, and AimotarRa Ealayohi; (M, K;) He passed, or went, by him, or it; syn. AijotaAza, (S, Msb,) or jaAza Ealayohi, (M, K,) or jaAwazahu wacahaba. (A.) marRa may be a verb trans. by means of a particle and without a particle: or in marRahu the particle may be suppressed: Jereer says,
tamurRuwna AldRiyaAra walamo taEuwjuwA
kalaAmukumu EalaIRa UicFA HaraAmu
[Ye pass by the dwellings without turning aside and alighting: the speaking to you is therefore forbidden to me]: but it is said that the true reading is mararotumo biAldRiyaAri [Ye have passed by the dwellings]: which shows that he feared to make the verb trans. without a particle: IAar says, that marRa zayodFA signifies the same as marRa bihi [He passed by Zeyd], without being elliptical, but as being properly trans.; but IJ, allowing this, says that it is not a phrase commonly obtaining. (M, TA.) ― -b4- [marRa Ealayohi also signifies He, or it, passed, or went, along, or over, or across, it. You say, marRa EalaI Aljisori He passed, or went,
along, or over the bridge, or dyke.] And marRa AlsRikRiynu EalaI Haloqi AlXRaApi The knife passed across the throat of the sheep, or goat. (Msb.) ― -b5- [Also, It (a period of time) passed over him, or it: and it (a calamity) came upon him: see an ex. of the latter signification below, voce murRN.] ― -b6- marRa bihi as syn. with OamarRahu↓, trans. of marRa: see 4. ＝ -A2- marRa, aor.
marara
and
marura
: see 4. ― -b2- marRahu, as trans. of marRa, of which the aor. is
marara
: see 2. ― -b3- murRa His bile, or gall, became roused. (A.) You say murirotu [I suffered an attack of bile], from AlmirRapu, (T,) or murirotu bihi, (Lh, M, K,) aor. OumarRu, inf. n. marRN and mirRapN, (Lh, T, M, K,) the latter of which [in the CK written marRap, but in the T, M, &c. mirRap, and expressly said in the TA to be with kesr,] is also a simple subst., (T,) or, as Lh says in one place, mirRN is the inf. n. and mirRapN is a simple subst., (M, TA,) Bile, or gall, overcame me [by reason of it: app. referring to food]. (K.)

2 mrRrhu c
2. mrRrhu, (inf. n. tamoriyrN, TA,) He, or it, made it bitter; (S, K;) as also AmrRhu↓: (IAar, S:) or marRahu↓, aor.
marura
, has this signification, and the first verb has an intensive signification [he, or it, made it very bitter]. (Msb.)

3 mArRhu c
3. mArRhu, (inf. n. mumaArRapN and miraArN, TA,) He passed, passed by or beyond, went, went away, or passed away, (marRa,) with him. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also 4, in five places.

4 AmrRhu c
4. AmrRhu, (inf. n. UimoraArN, TA,) He made him, or it, to pass, pass by or beyond, go, go away, or pass away; (A, Msb, TA;) as also bihi marRa↓. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AmrR AlXRiEora [(assumed tropical:) He recited the poetry, especially, with fluency]. (K, art. cbr.) ― -b3- AmrRhu bihi (in some copies of the K, AmtrR bh, but the former is the right reading, TA) [and Ealayohi] He made him, or it, to pass, or go, by him, or it, (K.) ― -b4- AmrRhu EalaI Aljisori He made him to pass, or go, along, or over, the bridge, or dyke. (Lh, K.) AmrR Ealayohi yadahu [He passed his hand over him, or it]. And AmrR Elyh Alqalama [He passed the pen over it, or across it]. (A.) Oamorarotu AlsRikRiyna EalaI Haloqi AlXRaApi I passed the knife across the throat of the sheep, or goat. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., respecting the sound that is heard by the angels when a revelation is sent down, kaUimoraAri AlHadiydi EalaI AlTRaXoti, meaning, Like the dragging, or drawing, (in a trans. sense,) of the iron over the copper basin: and in another trad., Sawota UimoraAri AlsRilosilapi [the sound of the dragging, or drawing, of the chain]: or, accord. to the more common relation, Sawota miraAri AlsRilosilapi EalaI AlSRafaA, meaning, the sound of the dragging, (in an intrans. sense) and continuous running, of the chain upon the [smooth] rocks: (IAth, TA:) for maArRa↓, inf. n. miraArN, signifies it (a thing) dragged, or became drawn along. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- AmrRhu He twisted it tightly; namely, a rope, (S, A, Msb,) and a thread. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AldRahoru cuw naqoDK waUimoraArK (tropical:) [Time, or fortune, as it were, untwists and twists tightly]. (A. TA.) [See art. nqD.] ― -b3- Hence also, AmrRhu (tropical:) He struggled, or strove, with him, (S, A,) and twisted about him, (S,) or twisted his neck, (A,) to throw him down; (S, A;) as also mArRhu↓: (S:) or this latter signifies he twisted himself about him, and turned him round, to throw him down; (K,) [for yudiyruhu, in the K, we find in the L yuriyduhu, which latter is preferred by SM; but I prefer the former; for it also signifies] he turned him round, (namely, a camel,) in order to throw him down: (M:) or mArRhN↓ signifies he struggled, or strove, with him, and twisted his neck, (A,) to throw him down, (AHeyth, T, A,) (AHeyth, T, A,) the latter desiring to do the same; and the inf. n. is mumaArRapN and miraArN: (AHeyth, T:) and UimoraOatuhu tumaArRuhu↓ his wife opposes him, and twists herself about him: (A, TA:) and miraAru↓ AlHrobi is explained by As as signifying the striving to obtain the victory in war. (M.) ＝ -A3- AmrR, (inf. n. UimoraArN, A,) It was, or became, bitter; (Ks, Th, S, M, A, Msb, K;) as also marRa↓, (Th, S, M, A, Msb, K,) but this was not known by Ks, and Th says that the former is the more common, (M,) aor.
marara
(S, M, Msb, K) and
marura
, (Th, M, K,) [whence it seems that the see. pers. of the pret. is both marirota and marurota,] inf. n. maraArapN, (S, M, A, K,) or this is a simple subst.: (Msb;) and AstmrR↓ (A, Sgh, TA.) You say, qado OamarRa hacaA AlTRaEaAmu fiI famiI This food has become bitter in my mouth: and in like manner you say of anything that becomes bitter. (TA.) You say also, OamarRa Ealayohi AlEayoXu, and Ealayohi marRa↓, (tropical:) [Life became bitter to him]. (A.) And Th cites,
tumirRu EalayonaA AlOaroDu mino Oano naraI bihaA
OaniysFA wayaHolawoliI lanaA Albaladu Alqaforu
[(tropical:) The land is displeasing to us from our seeing in it man, and the desolate country is pleasing to us]: the poet makes tumirRu trans. by means of ElI, because it implies the meaning of taDiyqu [which is made trans. by means of the same particle]. (M, TA) You say also, OamarRu waOaHoluw, and OamurRu waOaHoluw, meaning (tropical:) I am bitter at one time, and I am sweet at one time. (IAar, M.) [See also 1 in art. Hlw.] ― -b2- But maA OamarRa wamaA OaHolaI signifies (tropical:) He said not. (IAar, S, M,) and he did not, (IAar, M,) a bitter thing, and he said not, (IAar, S, M,) and he did not, (IAar, M,) a sweet thing. (IAar, S, M.) You say, XatamaniI fulaAnN famaA Oamorarotu walaA OaHolayotu (tropical:) Such a one reviled me, and I did not say a bitter thing, nor did I say a sweet thing. (Lh, T.) And fulaAnN maA yumirRu wamaA yuHoliI (tropical:) Such a one does not injure nor does he profit. (M, K. *) ― -b3- AmrRhu as syn. with marRarahu: see 2.

6 tamaArRaA c
6. tamaArRaA They two struggled, or strove, each with the other, and each twisted the other's neck, to throw him down. (A, TA.)

8 AmtrR bihi c
8. AmtrR bihi, and Ealayohi: see marRa bihi.

10 AstmrR c
10. AstmrR: see 1, first signification, in three places. ― -b2- Also. It (a thing, M) went on in one [uniform] course or manner: (M, K:) it (an affair, A, or anything, Mgh) had a continuous course, or manner of being, &c.; (A, Mgh;) it continued in the same state; (Mgh:) it (a thing) continued, or obtained: (Msb:) it (said of blood) continued in a regular, uniform, or constant, course. (Mgh.) [And it is often said of a man.] ＝ -A2- [It also seems to signify It (a rope) became tightly twisted. ― -b2- And hence, (assumed tropical:) He, or it, became strong, or firm, like a rope tightly twisted: as in the following phrases.] AstmrR biAlXRaIoCi (assumed tropical:) He became strong to bear the thing. (M, K. [See an ex. in a verse cited voce OaSomaEu.]) AstmrR mariyruhu (tropical:) He became firm; as also AstmrRt mariyratuhu: (A:) or his resolution, or determination, became firm, or strong; (S:) or he became strong, after being weak: and AstmrRt mariyratuhu his resistance (Xakiymap) became firm. (TA.) You say also, AstmrRt mariyratuhu Ealayohi (tropical:) He became firm against him, or it: and his resistance (Xakiymap) against him, or it, became strong: (K, TA:) and he became accustomed, or habituated, [or inured,] to him, or it: a tropical signification, from the twisting of a rope. (TA.) ― -b3- [And hence, app.,] AstmrR also signifies (assumed tropical:) His case, or state of affairs, became right, after having been bad or corrupt: (ISh, T, TA) he repented, and became good, righteous, or virtuous. (A [but not given as tropical].) ＝ -A3- As syn. with OamarRa and marRa, said of food, &c.: see 4.

R. Q. 1 maromara c
R. Q. 1. maromara, [inf. n. maromarapN, He murmured; grumbled; as also tamaromara↓: so in the present day; and probably the primary signification:] he was angry. (IAar, K.) ＝ -A2- He made water to pass, or go, upon the surface of the ground. (K.)

R. Q. 2 tamaromara c
R. Q. 2. tamaromara: see 1. ＝ -A2- It (the body of a woman, TA) shook; (S, K;) quivered; quaked: (K:) or became in a state of commotion: (Sgh:) or became smooth like [the kind of marble called] maromar. (IKtt.) It (sand) moved from side to side, or to and fro. (A, K.)

marRN c
marRN: see marRapN.

murRN c
murRN Bitter; (S, A, Msb, K;) contr. of HulowN; (K;) as also mariyrN↓ and mumirRN↓: (A:) fem. murRapN: (Msb, TA:) pl. masc. OamoraArN, (T, S, M,) and pl. fem. maraAYiru, contr. to rule, (Msb,) because murRapN means xabiyvapu AlTRaEomi [bad-tasted; and the pl. of xbyvp is xabaAYivu]. (Msb, voce HurRN.) You say baqolapN murRapN [A bitter leguminous plant]: and hacihi Albaqolapu mino OamoraAri Albuqowli [This leguminous plant is one of the bitter leguminous plants]. (T.) And XajarapN murRapN [A bitter tree]: pl. XajarN maraAYiru: the only instance of the kind except HaraAYiru as pl. of HurRapN. (Suh, in Msb, art. Hr.) ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] riEoIu bnI fulaAnK AlmurRataAni, (so in two copies of the S,) or AlmurRayaAni↓, (as in the K,) The pasturage of the sons of such a one is the [bitter tree called] OalMC and the [bitter plant called] XiyH. (S, K.) [For another application of AlmurRataAni, see OamarRa.] ― -b3- Hence also, (TA,) AlmurRu [Myrrh;] a certain medicine, (K,) like AlSRabir [or aloes], (TA,) useful for cough, (K,) when sucked (UisotiHolaAbFA) in the mouth, (TA,) and for the sting of the scorpion, (K,) when applied as a plaster, (TA,) and for worms of the intestines, (K,) when taken into the mouth in a dry state, or licked up from the palm of the hand: (TA:) also said to be the same as AlSRabiru: (TA:) pl. OamoraArN. (K.) ― -b4- EyX murRN (tropical:) [A bitter life]: like as one says [of the contr.], HulowN. (TA.) ― -b5- marRato Ealayohi OamozaArN (tropical:) Afflictions or calamities [came upon him]. (TA.) ― -b6- nafosN murRN (tropical:) A loathing mind, or stomach; syn. xabiyvapN kaArihapN. (TA.) ― -b7- Oabuw murRapa A surname of Iblees, (S, K,) said to be from a daughter of his named murRapu [Bitter]. (TA.)

marRapN mr mrh mrp
marRapN A time; one time; [in the sense of the French fois;] syn. taArapN: (Msb:) one action; a single action or act; (M, K;) as also marRN↓: (M, K: [but see what follows:]) [a bout; an instance; a case; and a single temporary offection or attack; a fit; as, for instance, of hunger, thirst, disease, and the like:] pl. marRaAtN (A, Msb) and miraArN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and mirarN and marRN↓ [or rather this is a coll. gen. n. of which marRapN is the n. un.] and muruwrN; (M, K;) the last on the authority of Aboo-'Alee, and occurring in the following verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb:
tanakRarota baEodiI Oamo OaSaAbaka HaAdivN
mino AldRahori Oamo marRato Ealayoka muruwru
[Hast thou become altered since I saw thee, or hath an accident of fortune befallen thee, or have vicissitudes come upon thee?] but Es-Sukkaree holds that mrwr is an inf. n.; and IJ says, I do not think this improbable, and that the verb is made fem. because the inf. n. implies muchness and genus. (M.) You say faEalotuhu marRapF [I did it once], (A, Msb,) and marRaAtK and miraArFA [several times]. (A.) [And biQlomarRapi At once.] And laqiyahu caAta marRapK [He met him once]: only used adverbially: (M, K:) so says Sb. (M.) And laqiyahu caAta AlmiraAri He met him many times: (M, K:) [or this has a different signification; for] you say fulaAnN yaSonaEu celika AlOamora caAta AlmiraAri meaning Such a one does that thing sometimes, and sometimes he leaves it undone. (ISk, S.) Also, jiYotuhu marRFA Oawo marRayoni, i. e., marRapF Oawo marRatayoni [I came to him once or twice]. (M, K.)

murRapN c
murRapN: see murRN.

mirRapN c
mirRapN a subst. from marRa, and marRa bihi and Ealayohi, and OamarRahu EalaI Aljisori, [The act of passing, passing by or beyond, going, going away, passing away, &c.] El-Aashà says,
OalaA qulo litayRaA qabola mirRatihaA QsolamiI
[Now say to this damsel, or this little female, (see taA,) before her passing, Be thou safe]. (M.) ＝ -A2- A firm, or strong, twisting. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) (tropical:) Strength: (ISk, S, A, K:) strength of make: (K:) pl. mirarN (ISk, K) and OamoraArN. (K.) In the Kur, [liii. 6,] cuw mirRapK is applied to (assumed tropical:) [The angel] Jibreel [or Gabriel]: (Fr, K, * TA:) whom God hath created endowed with great strength. (TA.) You say also rajulN cuw mirRapK (tropical:) A strong man. (A.) And it is said in a trad., laA taHilRu AlSRadaqapu liEiniIRK walaA liciI mirRapK sawiIRK (tropical:) The giving of alms to one who possesses competence, or riches, is not allowable, nor to him who has strength and is sound in limbs. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] (tropical:) Intellect: (K:) or strength of intellect: (S:) and sound judgment: and firmness; syn. UiHokaAmN, (K,) and mataAnapN. (TK.) You say UinRahu lacuw mirRapK (tropical:) Verily he is possessed of intellect and sound judgment and firmness. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, A strand, or single twist, of a rope; and so mariyrapN↓: (L, * TA:) pl. mirarN. (TA.) ＝ -A3- AlmirRapu [The gall, bile, or choler;] one of the humours of the body; (M, Msb, K;) which are four; (S, TA;) what is in the maraArap: (S:) or [rather] AlmirRataAni denotes two of the four humours of the body; [namely, the yellow bile (AlSRaforaMCu) and the black bile (AlsRawodaMCu);] the other two humours being the blood (AldRamu) and the phlegm (Albalogamu): (TA, art. mzj:) pl. miraArN. (Msb.)

muraArN c
muraArN [a coll. gen. n.] A kind of tree; (Msb;) a kind of bitter tree; (S, A, K;) or a kind of sour tree; (TA;) of the best and largest of herbs; (K;) when camels eat of it, their lips become contracted, (S, Msb, K,) and their teeth appear: (K:) n. un. with p. (S.)

mariyrN c
mariyrN A rope that is slender (S, K) and long and strongly twisted: pl. maraAYiru: (ISk, S:) or that is twisted of more than one strand; as also p↓: pl. of both as above: (TA:) or mariyrapN↓ signifies a strongly twisted rope: or a long and slender rope: (K:) and a strand, or single twist, of a rope; as also mirRapN↓. (K, * TA.) [See an ex. voce saHala.] See also mumarRN. ― -b2- [Hence,] rajulN mariyrN (assumed tropical:) A strong man. (S.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] mariyrN and maryraipN↓ (assumed tropical:) Resolution, or determination: (S, K;) and ↓the latter, strength (EizRap) of mind. (K.) See also 10. ＝ -A2- See also murRN.

maraArapN c
maraArapN (a subst., Msb) Bitterness. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, maraArapu AlnRafos (tropical:) A loathing (xubovN wakaraAhapN) of the mind or stomach. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [The gall-bladder;] that in which is the mirRap; (S;) a certain thing adhering to the liver, (K,) and serving to render the food wholesome, or quickly digestible; (TA;) pertaining to every animal except the camel (A, Msb, K) and the ostrich (K) and some few others, as is well known:] pl. maraAYiru. (Msb.) [The camel is really destitute of a gall-bladder, as are several other animals; but] one says of the camel laA maraArapa lahu meaning (tropical:) He has no daring. (S, O voce TaHaAlN, q. v.)

mariyrapN c
mariyrapN: see mariyrN.

murRiIRN c
murRiIRN A certain kind of seasoning, or condiment, eaten with food to render it pleasant or savoury; (S, Msb, K;) like kaAmax; (K;) or also called kAmx; (Msb;) pronounced by the vulgar without teshdeed. (S.)

murRaAnN c
murRaAnN A certain kind of tall tree [or plant of the cane-kind]; (K;) a certain kind of tree [or cane] of which spears are made: (S:) and spears made of canes; (K;) made of this kind of tree [or cane]: (TA:) but the word belongs to art. mrn, (S, L,) being of the measure fuERaAlN. (L.)

maromarN c
maromarN [Marble: or alabaster: in the present day, more commonly the latter:] i. q. ruxaAmN: (S, A, Mgh, K:) i. e., a kind of soft white stone: (Mgh:) or a hard kind of rxAm: (TA:) or a kind of rxAm, but harder and clearer [than what is commonly so called]. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- See also maromaArN.

maromaArN c
maromaArN and muromuwrN↓ [in the L, TA written maromuwrN, which is app. a mistake, as SaEofuwqN is said to be the only Arabic word of good authority that is of this measure, and the fem. is expressly said in the K to be with damm,] and muraAmirN↓ (M, K) A body (M) soft, (K,) and that quivers, or quakes, [by reason of its fleshiness,] (M, K,)
when the person stands up, or rises: (M:) or [simply] soft. (TA.) And maramaArapN and muromuwrapN↓, (S, M, K,) with damm, (K,) [in two copies of the S written maromuwrapN,] applied to a damsel, or girl, (S, K,) or to a woman, (M,) Soft, (S, K,) and quivering, or quaking, in her flesh, (S, M, K,) when she stands up, or rises. (M.)

muromuwrN c
muromuwrN and mromuwrapN: see maromaArN.

muraAmirN c
muraAmirN: see maromaArN.

OamarRu c
OamarRu [More, or most, tightly twisted]. ― -b2- [Hence,] fulaAnN OamarRu EaqodFA mino fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) Such a one is firmer, and more faithful to his compact, than such a one. (S.) ＝ -A2- More, or most, bitter: fem. murRaI: of which the dual is murRayaAni. (TA.) You say, hecaA OamarRu mino caA [This is more bitter than that]. (S.) And xuci AlHalowaI waOaEoTihi AlmurRaI [Take thou the sweeter, or sweetest, and give to him the bitterer, or bitterest]. (S in art. Hlw.) And it is said in a prov., (A,) by a certain Arab woman, (S,) SugoraAhaA murRaAhaA (tropical:) [The youngest of them is the most bitter of them]. (S, A.) See Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 720; where another reading is given, XurRaAhaA for muraAhRaA.] ― -b2- AlOamarRaAni (tropical:) Poverty and decrepitude: (S, K:) or decrepitude and disease. (A.) ― -b3- Also, (tropical:) Aloes (AlSRabiru) and AlvRufRaMCu, (A, K,) i. e., mustard: (TA:) so in a trad. (A, TA.) ― -b4- You say also, laqiytu minohu AlOamarRiyna, (T, S, M, K,) with the pl. n, (T, S,) and with kesr to the r, (K,) and AlOamarRayoni, (IAar, M, A, K,) dual of OamarRu, (M,) with fet-h to the r, (K,) and AlmurRayayoni, dual of murRaI, (M,) or AlmurRatayoni↓, (as in copies of the K,) (tropical:) I experienced from him, or it, calamities: (S, A:) or evil, and a grievous, or distressing, thing. (M, K.)

mamarRN c
mamarRN A place of muruwr [i. e. passing; passing by; &c.; or a place of passage: see 1]. (S.) You say qaEadotu EalaI mamarRihi [I sat at his place of passing]. (A.) ― -b2- It is also an inf. n.: see marRa hi. In the text, the character between ر and ه is missing, although it does have a kasra. (S.)

mumarRu c
mumarRu A rope, (S, Msb,) and thread, (Msb,) tightly twisted: (S, Msb:) a rope well twisted: (TA:) and anything twisted. (M, TA.) See also mariyrN. ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) A man, and a horse, strongly, or firmly, made. (A, * TA.)

mumirRN c
mumirRN: see murRN.

mamoruwrN c
mamoruwrN Overcome by bile; (S;) a man whose bile is roused. (A.)

baEiydu AlmusotamarRi c
baEiydu AlmusotamarRi, with fet-h to the second m, Strong in altercation, not weary of labouring or striving. (S, K.) A'Obeyd cites the following verse:
wajadotaniI OalowaI baEiyda Almusotamaro
OaHomilu maA HumRilotu mino xayorK waXaro
[Thou findest me very contentious, strong in altercation, not weary of labouring or striving, bearing what is imposed on me of good and evil]. (S, T, A.) IB says, that this rejez is commonly ascribed to 'Amr Ibn-'Ás, but it is said to be quoted by him from Artáh Ibn-Suheiyeh: Sgh says, that it is ascribed to El-'Ajjáj, but is not his; and to En-Nejáshee El-Hárithee; and Aboo-Mohammad ElAarábee says, that it is by Musáwir Ibn-Hind. (TA.)

musotamirRN c
musotamirRN act. part. n. of 10, q. v. ― -b2- EaAdapN musotamirRapN A custom constantly obtaining; unvarying. (A, Mgh.) ― -b3- siHorN musotamirRN [in the Kur, liv. 2,] En-chantment going on: or having one continuous course: or continuing in the same manner: or continuing in a regular, uniform, or constant, course: (Mgh:) or passing away, and vain, or ineffectual: or (assumed tropical:) strong: (K:) or bitter. (TA.) ― -b4- fiI yawomi naHosK musotamirRK [in the Kur, liv. 19,] In a day of ill fortune that was lasting, or continual: (Zj, K:) or of which the evil, (K:) or ill luck, (TA,) was continual; (K, TA:) or effective, (K, * TA,) with respect to that which it was ordered and constrained to accomplish: (K:) or (assumed tropical:) potent in its evil fortune: or bitter: or in a Wednesday that did not come round again in the month: (K:) or in the last Wednesday of the month of Safar. (TA.)

1 maruWa AlTRaEaAmu c
1. maruWa AlTRaEaAmu, aor.
maruAa
, inf. n. maraMCapN, epithet mariIoCN; and mariYa, (S, K,) and maraOa, aor.
maraAa
; (K;) and AstmrO↓; (TA;) The food was, or became, wholesome, or approved in its result: (Z:) or easy to swallow, and wholesome, or approved in its result: (K:) or easy to swallow, not attended by trouble: or quick in digesting. (Z.) It is said in the Keshsháf, on ch. iv., v. 3, of the Kur, that haniIoCN and mariIoCN are two epithets from hanaOa AlTRaEaAmu and maraOa, “ the food was easy to swallow; not attended by trouble: ” or the former epithet signifies “ pleasant, or productive of enjoyment, to the eater; ” and the latter, “ wholesome, or approved in its result: ” or the former, food or drink that is “ not succeeded by harm, even after its digestion; ” and the latter, that which is “ quick in digesting. ” (TA.) In conjunction with hanaOaniI, one says maraOaniI (hnOnI AlTRaEaAmu wmrOnI), (Fr. S, K,) aor.
maraAa
, inf. n. maroCN; (Akh, S;) and in conjunction with haniYaniI, mariYaniI; (TA [also mentioned in the S, on the authority of Akh];) and alone, (i. e. not in conjunction with hnOnI or hnYnI,) OamoraOaniI↓, (Fr, S, K,) inf. n. UimoraMCN, (AZ,) [It (food) was wholesome to me, &c. (see above):] it was light to my stomach, and descended thence well. (TA.) But maraOaniI also occurs in this sense without hanaOaniI. (TA.) ― -b2- mariYa AlTRaEaAma, and AstmrOhu↓, [He found the food wholesome, &c.] (S.) (See above.] AlTRaEaAma AstmrO↓, signifies EadRahu mariyoYFA. (MA.) ― -b3- maraOa, aor.
maraAa
, He fed; or ate food. (K.) Ex. maA laka laA tamoraOu What aileth thee, that thou dost not eat? (TA.) ― -b4- maruWati AlOaroDu, inf. n. maraACapN, The land was, or became salubrious, in its air. (K.) ― -b5- maruWa, aor.
maruAa
, (AZ, S, K,) inf. n. muruwoCapN, (K,) epithet mariIoCN, (S, K,) He was, or became, possessed of muruwoCap; (AZ, S, K;) sometimes written and pronounced muruwRap; (S;) i. e., manliness; (S, K;) manly perfection; (TA;) consisting in abstinence from things unlawful, or in chastity of manners, and the having some art or trade; (El-Ahnaf;) or in abstaining from doing secretly what one would be ashamed to do openly; (TA;) or in the habit of doing what is approved, and shunning what is held base; (El-Khafájee;) or in preserving the soul from filthy actions, and what disgraces in the estimation of men; or in good manners, and guarding the tongue, and shunning impudence; (TA;) or in a quality of the mind by preserving which a man is made to persevere in good manners and habits: (Msb:) [in a word, virtue; or rather manly virtue or moral goodness.] ＝ -A2- maraOa Inivit feminam. (K.) ― -b2- mariYa He became like a woman, in external appearance, or in talk. (K.)

4 hecaA yumoriYu AlTRaEaAma c
4. hecaA yumoriYu AlTRaEaAma [This makes the food wholesome, &c.] (AZ.) (See maruWa.)

5 tmrRO c
5. tmrRO He affected, or endeavoured to acquire, (takalRafa,) manliness, muruwoCap: (AZ, S, K:) accord. to some, he became possessed of that quality. (TA.) ― -b2- tmrRO bihimo He sought to acquire the character of manliness (muruwoCap) by disparaging them and vituperating them. (ISk, S, K.) ― -b3- laA yatamarRaOo OaHadukumo biAldRunoyaA (a trad.) [app., Let not any one of you delight himself in the present world]: but accord. to one relation, it is laA yatamaroOaI, from AlrRuWoyapu: [see art. rOI]. (TA.) [See also tahanRaOa.]

10 UisotamoraAa
10: see 1.

maroCN c
maroCN and muroCN↓ (S, K) and miroCN↓ (K) A man, or human being; syn. UinosaAnN: (K:) or a man as opposed to a child or a woman; syn. rajulN. (S, K.) You say maroCN in the nom., maroCFA in the acc., and maroCK in the gen., (S,) agreeably with analogy. (TA.) And some say muroCN in the nom., maroCFA in the acc., and miroCK in the gen.; doubly declining the word. (TA, and some copies of
the S.) And miroC↓ is said to be of the dial. of Hudheyl. It is said that no pl. is formed from mrC; but maroWuwna occurs as its pl. in the following words of a trad.; OaHosinuwA OamolaACakumo OayRuhaA AlmuroWuwna [Amend your manners, O ye men!]; and in the saying of Ru-beh, Oayona yuriydu AlmrWwn [Whither do the men desire to go?]. (TA.) It forms a dual; mairoMni: they say humaA miroMni SaAliHaAni [They are two just men] (S) in the dial. of Hudheyl. (TA.) It also forms a dim., muraIoCN, fem. murayoYapN. (S.) ― -b2- The fem. of maroCN is maroOapN, A woman: [and a wife:] also written and pronounced marapN. (S, K.) ― -b3- mrC is also written with the conjunctive A: you say QmoraON in the nom., QmoraOF in the acc., and QmoraOK in the gen.: also, QmoruWN in the nom., QmoruWFA in the acc., and QmoruWK in the gen.: also, QmoruWN in the nom., QmoraOF in the acc., and QmoriYK in the gen.; doubly declining the word. (S, K, TA.) [The last three forms are the most common in classical works: but in ordinary parlance, in the present day, the word is generally pronounced with fet-h to the r in each case. The final C is also often written without the A or w or I.] Ks and Fr say, that the word is doubly declined, as to the r and C, because the final C is often omitted. (T, TA.) [When the disjunctive A is substituted for the conjunctive, i. e., when the word is immediately preceded by a quiescence, its vowel is kesr: thus you say AimoraON &c.; and thus also in the fem. The name of the famous poet AimorauOu Alqayosi is commonly pronounced Imra-el- Keys and Imr-el-Keys.] ― -b4- The fem. is QmoraOapN, A woman: [and a wife:] but with Al you say AlmaroOapu: AlAimoraOapu [which is authorized by the K] is also said to be established by usage; but most of the expositors of the Fs reject this; and those who allow it to be correct judge it of weak authority: IO mentions also QmoraApN, with soft A after the r. (TA.) ― -b5- QmorauCN is also used in a fem. sense; (S;) though this is extr.: ex. UinRahaA laQmorauCa Sidoq [Verily she is an excellent woman: see SidoqN]. (TA.) And QmoraOapN is used, in a trad., as signifying a perfect woman: laqado tazawRajota QmoraOapF Indeed thou hast married a perfect woman: like as you say fulaAnN rajulN, meaning “ Such a one is a perfect man. ” (TA.) ― -b6- Also, AimoraON or QmoruWN, (S,) or maroCN, (K,) signifies A wolf: (S, K:) or, as Z and others assert, it is tropical in this sense. Yoo says, that the poet means, by QmrW, in the following verse, a wolf:
waOanota QmoruWN taEoduw EalaI kulRi girRapK
fatuxoTiYu fiyhaA marRapF watuSiybu
[And thou art a wolf that assaultest on every occasion of carelessness; and sometimes thou missest therein, and (sometimes) thou attainest thine object]. (TA.) ― -b7- The rel. n. of QmorauCN is maraYiIRN (as in one copy of the S) or muraYiIRN (as in another copy) and OamariIRN. (S, and El-Ashmoonee and others.) [For the last, Golius, from a copy of the S, gives AimoraYiIRN: and in one copy of the S, I find it written OamoraYiIRN: but I have not met with any confirmation of either of these two forms.] maraYiIRN seems to be formed from maroCN; but is extr.; the analogous form being maroYiIRN. (TA.)

maraON c
maraON A giving of food on the occasion of building a house, or marrying. (TA.)

mariIoCN c
mariIoCN [The œsophagus, or gullet of a slaughtered camel, or sheep or goat, (S,) and of a man, (Zj, in his Khalk el-Insán,) the canal through which the food and drink pass; (S, K;) the head of the stomach; (K;) contiguous, (S,) or adherent (K) to the Huloquwm [or windpipe]; (S, K;) through which the food and drink pass, and by which they enter: (TA;) pl. [of pauc.] OamoriYapN (K) and [of mult.] muruWN. (S, K.) It is also written mariIRN. (TA.) ― -b2- yaOotiynA fiI mivoli mariIoCi AlnRaEaAmi [It comes to us as it were through the gullet of the ostrich]: a proverbial expression, from a trad., alluding to paucity of food; the ostrich being particularized because of the slenderness of its neck, whence is inferred the narrowness of its gullet. (TA.) ― -b3- Wholesome, &c. (See maruWa.) ― -b4- haniyoYFA mariyoYFA: see art. hnO and see 1 in the present art. ― -b5- gayovN mariIoCN [A rain productive of good result]. (TA.) ― -b6- kalaON mariIoCN Wholesome herbage. (K.) ― -b7- OaroDN mariyoYapN A land salubrious in its air. (K.) ― -b8- mariIoCN Manly, &c. (See maruWa.)

maraMCapN c
maraMCapN: see maruWa.

muruwoCapN c
muruwoCapN and muruwRapN: see maruWa

QmoraON c
QmoraON and QmoraOapN &c.: see maroCN.

mumoriYN c
mumoriYN act. part. n. of 4, Wholesome food. (S.) [See 4, and mariICN.]

1 maruta c
1. maruta, aor.
maruta
, inf. n. muruwtapN, It (a tract, or land,) was, or became, what is termed marotN. [See muruwtapN.] ― -b2- marata, aor.
marita
, He rendered smooth. (A, K.) ― -b3- marata AlUibila, aor.
marita
, He removed the camels from their place. (K.) ― -b4- marata, [aor.
marita
] inf. n. marotN, He broke [a thing]. (TA.) ― -b5- marata Alxuboza fiI AlmaACi i. q. marada: (Yaakoob:) or it is written mrv. (TA.)

marotN c
marotN A waterless desert in which is no herbage: (S, K:) or a land in which no herbage grows: or, in which there is neither little [herbage] nor much: (TA:) or a land of which the soil does not become dry, and of which the pasture-grounds, or fields, do not produce herbage: (K:) or land in which is no herbage; even if it be rained upon: (TA:) as also maruwtN↓; and OaroDN mamoruwtapN: pl. of marotN, OamoraAtN and muruwtN. (K.) ― -b2- OaroDN marotN, (TA,) and makaAnN marotN, (S, TA,) A land, and a place, that is desert, without water and without herbage. (TA.) You say OaroDN marotN and ArD maruwtN↓: but land that has been rained upon in the winter is not termed mrt, because the rain gives hope of its producing herbage. (TA.) ― -b3- marotN, (K,) or marotN AlHaAjibi, (S,) A man having no hair upon his eyebrows. (S, K.) ― -b4- marotu Aljasadi Having no hair upon his body. (TA.)

maruwtN c
maruwtN: see marotN.

muruwtapN c
muruwtapN (a subst. K.) [The condition of a land, or tract, such as is termed marotN]: (S, K:) [or, accord. to Ibn-Maaroof, as stated by Golius, it is an inf. n.: if so, its verb is maruta].

xirRiytN mirRiytN c
xirRiytN mirRiytN: see art. xrt.

maAruwtu c
maAruwtu [A certain fallen angel,] the companion of haAruwtu: (TA:) a foreign word; or from Almuruwtap; (K;) or from Almarotu as signifying Alkasoru. (TA.)

maromariytN c
maromariytN A calamity; a misfortune. (K.) Some say, that it is formed from maromariysN, by the substitution of t for s.

1 marava c
1. marava, (aor.
maruva
, inf. n. marovN, S,) He steeped dates in water, and mashed them (S, K) with the hand; (S;) syn. marasa: (S, K;) sometimes maraca is also used in this sense. (S.) ― -b2- marava, (aor.
maruva
, inf. n. marovN, TA,) He made a thing soft, (K,) so that it became of such a subsistence that it might be supped, and then supped it. (TA.) ― -b3- marava, (aor.
maruva
, and
mariva
, inf. n. marovN, TA,) He steeped, soaked, or macerated, a thing in water: (K:) he soaked bread in water; as also maraca. (Sh, As.) marava He steeped medicine &c. in water until it became altered. (A.) ― -b4- marava, [aor.
maruva
,] He (a child, S,) mumbled, or bit softly, his finger: (S, K:) he (a child) bit with his gums: he (a child) bit and sucked a necklace, or string of beads, such as is called saxaAbN. (TA.) ― -b5- marava, aor.
maruva
, and
mariva
, (inf. n. marovN, TA,) He [a child] sucked the kind of shells called cowries. (K.) ― -b6- He sucked. (IAar.) ― -b7- He (a child) sucked his mother's breast. (IAar.) ― -b8- mariva, aor.
marava
, (inf. n. maravN, (IAar,) He was mild and forbearing, or clement; and patient in bearing altercation. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- marava, [aor.
maruva
,] He beat, or struck, or smote, a man: (K:) or, accord. to A'Obeyd, mrava bihi
AlOaroDa, and mrRv↓, he threw him, or flung him, upon the ground: or, accord. to Fr, the verb is marana. (TA.) ＝ -A3- marava AlsRaxolapa, aor.
maruva
, (L,) and mrRvhA↓, He imparted to the lamb, or kid, a foul smell, of sweat, or grease, or the like, so that its mother would not take to it: (K:) he rendered it foul and greasy with his hand, so that its mother would not suckle it: (Ibn-Jo'eyl El-Kelbee:) he befouled it by stroking it with hands defiled by the smell of flesh-meat or fish, so that its mother would not take to it. (El-Mufaddal Ed-Dabbee.) ― -b2- Also, marava He defiled water, by putting into it his hands foul with flesh-meat, or grease, or the like. (TA, from a trad.)

2 mrRv c
2. mrRv, inf. n. tamoriyvN, He crumbled, or broke into small pieces, with his fingers. (K.) ＝ -A2- See 1 in two places.

marivN c
marivN: see mimoravN.

marovapN c
marovapN A single suck, by a child, of its mother's breast. (IAar.)

mimoravN c
mimoravN Patient in bearing altercation: (S, K:) mild and forbearing, or clement: as also marivN↓: (IAar, K:) pl. of the former, mamaArivu. (S.)

OaroDN mumarRavapN c
OaroDN mumarRavapN A land watered by a weak rain, (K,) and so rendered soft, and dissolved. (TA.)

1 maraja c
1. maraja, aor.
maruja
, inf. n. marojN, He (a beast of carriage) fed in a pasture. (Msb.) ― -b2- maraja, (aor.
maruja
, S,) inf. n. marojN, He sent a beast of carriage to pasture: (S, K:) or left it [app. to pasture wheresoever it would]: (Kt:) he pastured it; (TA;) and so Oamoraja↓: (Kt, K:) or the latter signifies he left it to go wheresoever it would [app. to pasture]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- maraja, inf. n. marojN, (tropical:) He mixed [a thing with another thing, or two things together]. (K.) ― -b2- maraja AlbaHorayoni, [Kur., xxv., 55; and lv., 19,] (tropical:) He hath mixed the two seas, (Zj, K,) so that they meet together, the sweet and the salt, yet so that the salt does not overpass its bounds and mix itself with the sweet: (Zj:) or He hath sent them forth so that they afterwards meet together: but this is only said by the people of Tihámeh: (Fr:) or, as also Oamoraja↓, (this latter form is used by some, Akh, S, and is the form used by the grammarians, TA,) He hath let them flow freely, yet so that one does not become mixed with the other: (S, K:) He hath made them flow. (IAar, with reference to the former verb.) ― -b3- maraja, aor.
maruja
, (assumed tropical:) He marred, or spoiled, his affair. (TA.) ― -b4- mrija, aor.
maraja
, inf. n. marajN, (tropical:) It (e. g. a deposit, S, and a covenant, and religion, TA) became corrupt; impaired; spoiled; marred; or disordered. (S, K.) ― -b5- marija, aor.
maraja
, inf. n. marajN; (S, K;) and maraja; but the former is the more approved; (TA;) It (a ring, on the finger, S, and an arrow, TA) became unsteady; (S, K,) like jarija. (S.) ― -b6- marija, aor.
maraja
, inf. n. marajN, (tropical:) It (religion, and an affair, S, and a covenant, TA) became in a confused and disturbed state, (S, K, TA,) so that one found it difficult to extricate himself from perplexity therein. (TA.) It (a covenant), was in a confused state, and little observed. (TA.) ― -b7- marija AlnRaAsu The people became confused. (TA.)

4 Oamoraja
4: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- Amrjt She (a camel) ejected her embryo, (S, K,) or the seed of the stallion, (M,) in a state consisting of, (K,) or after its becoming, (S, M,) what is termed giros [or matter resembling mucus] and blood. (S, M, K.) ― -b3- Amrj (tropical:) He violated a covenant, (K,) and religion. (TA.)

marojN c
marojN A pasture, pasturage, pasture-land, or meadow; a place in which beasts pasture; (S, K, Msb, TA;) an ample tract of land abounding with herbage, into which beasts are sent to pasture: (T:) also a wide, open tract of land: (TA:) pl. muruwjN. (Msb.)

harojN wamarojN c
harojN wamarojN; the latter being written thus, with the r quiescent, only to assimilate it to the former; (S, K;) and signifying (tropical:) Confusion, and disturbance, in an affair or the like: (S, K:) or intricate disorder, discord, trouble, or the like. (L.)

marajN c
marajN A camel, and camels, (or a beast, or beasts, TA,) pasturing without a pastor. (K.)

marojaAnN c
marojaAnN, a coll. gen. n.; n. un. with p; (L;) Small pearls: (AHeyth, T, S, K:) or the like thereof: or large pearls: (El-Wáhidee:) or coral, busRacN, which is a red gem: or red beads; which is the meaning assigned to the word by Ibn-Mes'ood, and is agreeable with the common acceptation thereof; or, accord. to Et-Tarasoosee (or, as in the TA, Et-Turtooshee, and so correctly accord. to MF) certain red roots that grow up in the sea, like the fingers of the hand: [vulgarly pronounced murojaAn:] the n is said to be an augmentative letter, because there is no Arabic word of the measure faEolaAlN, except such as are reduplicative, like xaloxaAlN: but Az says, I know not whether it be a triliteral-radical word or a quadriliteral: (Msb:) IKtt asserts it to be of the measure faEolaAlN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A leguminous plant that grows in the season called AlrRabiyE, (K,) rising to the height of a cubit, with red twigs, and broad round leaves, very dense, juicy, satisfying thirst, and having the property of making the milk of animals that feed upon it to become abundant: (TA:) n. un. with p. (K.)

OamorN mariyjN c
OamorN mariyjN, (S, K,) and maArijN↓, (TA,) (tropical:) A confused affair, or case: (Zj., S, K:) or error: so the former signifies in the Kur, l., 5. (TA.)

sarRaAjN marRaAjN c
sarRaAjN marRaAjN: see sarRaAjN.

maArijN c
maArijN (tropical:) Mixture, syn. xaloTN: (L:) [as though one of the few inf. ns. of the measure faAEilN, like qaAYimN: but it is said in the L to be a subst., like kaAhilN and gaAribN, and evidently signifies a mixture, or that which is mixed; syn. xiloTN]. ― -b2- maArijN mino naArK, as occurring in the Kur., [lv., 14,] (tropical:) A mixture (xiloTN, L) of fire: (A'Obeyd:) or flame mixed with the black substance of fire: or flame of fire: (TA:) or fire without smoke, (S, K,) whereof was created El-Jánn, (S,) i. e., Iblees, the father of the Jinn, or Genii, (Bd, Jel,) or the Jinn collectively: (Bd:) or fire dwn AlHjAb, [app. meaning below the veil, or that which conceals the lowest heaven, and the angels, from the jinn, or genii, who when they attempt to overhear the conversation of the angels, are smitten by the angels pursuing them with thunderbolts,] of which the thunderbolts consists. (Fr.) ― -b3- See mariyjN.

mimoraAjN c
mimoraAjN: see mumorijN. ― -b2- Also, A man who mars, or spoils, his affairs, (K, TA,) and does not execute them soundly. (TA.)

mumorijN c
mumorijN A she-camel ejecting her embryo, or the seed of the stallion, in a state consisting of, or after its becoming, what is termed giros [or matter resembling mucus] and blood. (TA.) A camel that usually does so is termed mimoraAjN↓. (K.)

1 mariHati Alqirobapu c
1. mariHati Alqirobapu, aor.
maraHa
, inf. n. maraHaAnN, The water-skin leaked, or let out its water through the punctures made in sewing it. (L.) ― -b2- mariHa AlsRaHaAbu The clouds poured forth rain. (L.) ― -b3- mariHa, (L,) inf. n. maraHaAnN, (L, K,) He, or it, became weak. (L, K.) You say mariHato Eayonuhu His eye became weak. (L.) Also, mariHato Eayonuhu, inf. n. maraHaAnN, His eye flowed much; (L, K;) and became in a corrupt, or vitiated, or disordered, state; (S, L, K;) and became inflamed, syn. haAjat: (S, L:) or poured forth tears: (L:) or shed many tears. (Sh.) ― -b4- mariHa, aor.
maraHa
, inf. n. maraHN, (assumed tropical:) He exulted; or rejoiced overmuch, or above measure; or he exulted greatly, or excessively; and was exceedingly brisk, lively, or sprightly: (L:) or he exulted; or exulted greatly; or excessively; and behaved insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully; syn. OaXira and baTira: or he was very joyful or glad; (S, Msb;) and very brisk, lively, or sprightly: (S:) or he was joyful, or glad: (Msb:) or it signifies also, he became joyful, or glad, (K,) and light, (TA,) and the inf. n. in this sense is maraHaAnN: (K, TA:) and he was brisk,
lively, or sprightly. (K.) ― -b5- marIHA, aor.
maraHa
, (inf. n. maraHN, L,) (assumed tropical:) He was proud and self-conceited: and he walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side. (L, K.) So in the Kur, xvii., 39; and xxxi., 17. (L.) [See also a verse cited voce SaAEN.]

2 mrRH Alqirobapa c
2. mrRH Alqirobapa, (inf. n. tamoriyHN, L,) (tropical:) He filled the water-skin with water in order that the punctures of the stitches might close up; i. q. sarRabahaA. (S.) ― -b2- Also, (tropical:) He rendered the water-skin sweet, when it was new, with Uicoxir or with XiyH The rendering it sweet with loam or clay is termed taXoriybN. (IAar.) ― -b3- mrRH AlmazaAdapa (tropical:) He filled the mzAdp with water, when it was new, in order that the punctures in it, made in sewing, might close up. (T, K.) ― -b4- mrRH Aljiloda (assumed tropical:) He anointed the skin with oil. (K.)

4 AmrHhu c
4. AmrHhu He made him to exult, or rejoice above measure; and to be exceedingly brisk, lively, or sprightly: or made him to exult; or to exult greatly, or excessively; and to behave insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: (L:) or he made him to be very joyful or glad; and to be very brisk, lively, or sprightly: (S:) [&c.: see 1]. ― -b2- AmrHhu It (pasture) made him (a horse) brisk, lively, or sprightly. (S, L, K. *)

maraHN c
maraHN, a subst., The leaking of a water-skin, or its letting out its water through the punctures made in sewing it. (L.) You say cahaba maraHu AlmazaAdapi The leaking of the mzAdp has ceased, when the punctures made in sewing it become closed up. (L, A, K.)

mariHN c
mariHN and mirRiyHN↓ (S, L, K) Exulting, or rejoicing overmuch, or above measure; and exceedingly brisk, lively, or sprightly: or exulting; or greatly, or excessively, exulting; and behaving insolently, and unthankfully, or ungratefully: (L, K: *) or very joyful or glad; and very brisk, lively, or sprightly: (S:) [&c.: see 1:] pl. (of the former, L) maroHaI and maraAHaI, and (of the latter, which has no broken pl.,) mirRiyHuwna. (L, K.)

maroHaI c
maroHaI A word that is said to one when he hits the mark in shooting or casting; (S, K;) expressing admiration; (S;) as also maraHayRaA: (K:) [in the CK maraHayRFA, which is wrong]) like as baroHaI is said to one who misses the mark. (S.)

mazaAdapN mariHapN c
mazaAdapN mariHapN A mzAdp that leaks, or does not retain its water. (AHan.) [See mariHati Alqirobapu.]

miraAHN c
miraAHN, subst. from mariHa, (S, L, K,) Exultation, or joy, above measure; and exceeding briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness: or exultation; or great, or excessive, exultation; and insolent and unthankful, or ungrateful behaviour: (L, K: *) or great joy or gladness; and great briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness: (S:) [&c.: see 1].

maruwHN c
maruwHN and mimoraAHN↓ (S, K) and mimoraHN↓. (K.) A brisk, lively, or sprightly, horse, (S, L, K, *) and she-camel. (L.) ― -b2- maruwHN Wine; so called because of its briskness in the vessel. (ISd, L.) EuqaArN maruwHN Wine that affects the head, and makes the drinker very joyful and brisk. (S.) ― -b3- qawosN maruwHN (tropical:) A bow at the beauty of which the beholders rejoice exceedingly (K) when they turn it about and examine it: (TA:) or, as though it rejoiced exceedingly, or greatly, at the beautiful manner of its shooting the arrow. (S, K.) ― -b4- TaruwHo maruwHo tuEojilu AlZRaboIa Oano yaruwHo [A bow that sends the arrow far, that makes those who behold and examine it to rejoice exceedingly, that makes the antelope hasten to go]. A saying of the Arabs. (L.)

mirRiyHN c
mirRiyHN: see mariHN.

mimoraHN c
mimoraHN: see maruwHN.

EayonN mimoraAHN c
EayonN mimoraAHN (tropical:) An eye that sheds copious tears: (S, K:) an eye that is quick to weep. (TA.) See maruwHN.

timoraAHapN c
timoraAHapN Very brisk or lively or sprightly; or exceedingly so. (IAth, L, from a trad.)

1 maraxa jasadahu c
1. maraxa jasadahu, (S, K,) aor.
maraxa
, (K,) inf. n. maroxN; (S;) and mrRxhu↓, (S, K,) inf. n. tamoriyxN; (S;) He anointed his body (K) with oil (S, K) &c. (K.) And maraxa UidaAwatahu He smeared with clay his UidaAwap [or small vessel of skin, for water,] in order that its odour might become good. (IAar, TA in art. crH.)

2 marRaxa
2: see 1.

4 Oamoraxa
4: Amrx He made dough, or paste, thin, (S, K,) by putting much water to it. (S.)

5 tmrRx biAldRuhoni c
5. tmrRx biAldRuhoni He anointed himself with oil. (L.)

maroxN c
maroxN [a coll. gen. n.] A certain kind of tree that quickly emits fire: (S, K:) it is of the kind called EiDaAh, and spreads, and grows high, so that people rest in its shade: it has neither leaves nor thorns, its branches being bare and slender twigs; and it grows in [small water-courses such as are termed] XuEab, and in hard grounds: of it are made the wooden instruments for producing fire which are called zinaAd: the n. un. is with p (AHn, L) its shade is thin: (L:) there is no tree that surpasses the mrx in yeilding fire: sometimes these trees are clustered and tangled together, and the wind blowing, and striking one part of them against another, they emit fire, and burn the valley: Aboo-Ziyád:) [the cynanchum viminale. (Spreng. Hist. rei. herb., p. 252: as mentioned by Freytag.)] It is said in a proverb, fiI kulRi XajarK naAro waQsotamojada Almaroxu waQloEafaAro [In all trees is fire; but the markh and 'afár yield much fire]: (S:) accord. to AHn, the meaning is, endeavour to strike fire with gentleness; for that will be sufficient if the zinaAd be marox. (L.) See also EafaArN, and Astmjd. The EfAr is the zanod, which is the upper [piece of the two which compose the zanaAd]; and the marox is the lower. (S, L.) [See also another proverb at the end of art. dfl.] ― -b2- Oaroxi yadayoka waQsotaroxi UinRa AlzRinaAda min mRaroxi [Relax thy hands, and relax thyself, for the wooden instrument for striking fire is of markh]. A saying used with reference to a generous man who requires not to be importuned. (IAar, TA.)

marixN c
marixN (K) and mirRiyxN↓ (L) A man who anoints himself much, (L, K,) and perfumes himself much. (TA.)

maruwxN c
maruwxN Oil, &c., with which the body is anointed. (K.)

mirRiyxN c
mirRiyxN: see marixN. ＝ -A2- A long arrow, having four feathers, (S, K,) with which one shoots to the utmost distance: (S:) or an arrow which they make for lightness, and which they mostly shoot to the utmost distance [to measure the ground] for the purpose of making horses run when they contend in a race. (Aboo-Ziyád.) ― -b2- AlmirRiyxu, (S K,) and mirRiyxN, without Al, which, however, is understood, (IAar,) [The planet Mars]; one of the stars called AlxunRasu, (S, K,) in the fifth heaven, (S,) also called bahoraAmu.

1 marada c
1. marada, (aor.
maruda
, inf. n. marodN, S, L,) He steeped bread, (S, L, K,) or corn, (Msb,) in water, and mashed it with his hand, so as to soften it: (S, L, Msb, K:) or he soaked bread in water; (M, L;) and so marava, and maraca, with the dotted c; or he softened bread in water, and crumbled it with his fingers. (As, L.) ― -b2- maradahu He rubbed it (a thing) in water. (TA.) ― -b3- maradahu, inf. n. marodN, He crumbled it [namely bread &c.], or broke it into small pieces, with his fingers; syn. varadahu. (TA [but only the inf. n. is there mentioned.]) ― -b4- maradahu, aor.
maruda
, inf. n. marodN, He made it (a thing) soft. (L.) ― -b5- maradahu and mrRdhu↓ He made it (a thing) soft and smooth; he polished it. (L.) See also 2. ― -b6- marada, (inf. n. marodN, S, L,) He (a child, S, L) mumbled (marasa) the breast (S, * L, *
K) of his mother: (S, L:) or sucked it. (IKtt.) ― -b7- marida, aor.
, He continued to eat mariyd, i. e., dates soaked in milk until rendered soft. (K.) ― -b8- marida (tropical:) It (a branch) was, or became, destitute of leaves. (IAar, L.) ― -b9- maridati AlOaroDu, inf. n. maradN, (tropical:) The land was, or became, destitute of herbage, excepting a small quantity. (TA.) ― -b10- marida He (a horse) was, or became, without hair upon the fetlock. (IKtt.) ― -b11- marida, aor.
marada
, (L, Msb, K,) inf. n. maradN (S, L, Msb, K) and muruwdapN; (L, K;) and tmrRd↓; (S, A, L, K;) He (a youth, or young man,) was as yet beardless: (Msb:) or had no hair upon his cheeks: (IAar, L:) or remained to a late period without his beard having grown, (L, K,) or without the hair of his face having grown forth. (S, L, Msb) ＝ -A2- marada aor.
maruda
, (A, L, Msb, K,) inf. n. muruwdN (A, L, K) and marodN; (IAar, L;) and maruda, aor.
maruda
, (S, L, Msb, K,) inf. n. maraAdapN (S, L, K) and muruwdapN; (TA, and some copies of the K;) and tmrRd↓; (A, L;) He exalted himself, or was insolent and audacious, in pride and in acts of rebellion or disobedience; (IAar, L;) he was hold, or audacious; (M, L, K;) and immoderate, inordinate, or exhorbitant; or excessively, immoderately, or inordinately, proud, or corrupt, or unbelieving, or disobedient or rebellious; or exalted himself and was inordinate in infidelity; or was extravagant in acts of disobedience and in wrongdoing; or was refractory, or averse from obedience: (S, M, A, L, Msb, K:) or he went to such an extreme as thereby to pass from out of the general state [or category] of that species [to which he belonged]. (M, L, K.) ― -b2- So in the phrase mrd EalaI AlOamori He was bold or audacious, and immoderate, &c., in the affair: (M, L:) and in like manner, ElI AlXRarRi, in evil, or mischief: EalayonaA tmrRd↓ He acted immoderately, inordinately, or exorbitantly, &c., towards us, or against us. (L.) ― -b3- Some explain maruda as syn. with xabuva [signifying He was bad, evil, wicked, malignant, noxious, corrupt, &c.]. (MF.) ― -b4- maAridN waEazRa AlOabolaqu tamarRada↓ (tropical:) [Márid hath resisted the attempt to take it, and El-Ablak hath proved strong]: a proverb: (S:) originally said by Ex-Zebbà, the Queen of the Arabs, with reference to two fortresses which she had failed to take. (TA.) ＝ -A3- marada, (L,) inf. n. marodN, (L, K,) He (a sailor) pushed, or propelled, a ship or boat, with a murodiIR. (L, K.) ― -b2- He drove vehemently. (L, K.) ＝ -A4- marada EalaI XaIoCK, [aor.
maruda
,] (K,) inf. n. muruwdN; (S, L;) and tmrRd↓; (L.) (tropical:) He became accustomed, habituated, or inured, to a thing. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- maraduwA EalaI AlnRifaAqi [Kur., ix., 102,] (tropical:) They have become accustomed, habituated, or inured, to hypocrisy: (Fr., A, L:) or they have exalted themselves, or become insolent and audacious, in hypocrisy: (IAar:) accord. to Er-Rághib, it is from XajarapN marodaMCu “ a tree without leaves; ” meaning, (assumed tropical:) they have become destitute of good. (TA.) ― -b3- marada EalaI AlkalaAmi (tropical:) He became accustomed, or habituated, to what was said, so that he cared not for it. (L.)

2 mrRdhu c
2. mrRdhu, inf. n. tamoriydN, (tropical:) He stripped it (a branch) of its leaves. (S, A, L.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He stripped it (a branch) of its peel; as also maradahu. (TA.) See 1. ― -b3- mrRdhu, (A, L,) inf. n. tamoriydN, (S, L, K,) He made it (a building) smooth (S, A, L, K) and even (L, K) and tall or long; (A;) and plastered it with mud. (L.)

5 tamarRada
5: see 1 in five places.

marodN c
marodN [Coll. gen. n.] Bread crumbled, or broken into small pieces, with the fingers, and then moistened with broth; syn. variydN. (T, L.) ― -b2- What is fresh and juicy of the fruit of the OaraAk: (T, S, L, K:) what is ripe thereof is called kabaAvN: (T, L:) or [in the CK, and] what is ripe thereof: (L, K:) what has become black being called kbAv: (TA in art. brm:) or certain red and large things pertaining thereto: n. un. with p. (AHn, L.)

maradaI c
maradaI: see maraTaI.

murodiIRN c
murodiIRN a pole with which a ship, or boat, is pushed, or propelled: (L, K:) or an oar; syn. mijocaAfN. (IKtt.)

maraAdN c
maraAdN (S, L, K:) and marRaAdN↓ (K) The neck: (S, L, K:) pl. [of the latter] maraAriydu. (K.)

maruwdN c
maruwdN: see maAridN.

mariydN c
mariydN Bread steeped in water, and mashed with the hand: or soaked in water. (L.) ― -b2- Dates soaked in milk until they become soft: (S, L, K:) or dates thrown into milk to become soft, and then mashed with the hand: (As, L:) or moistened, and rubbed and pressed with the fingers till soft, in water or in milk; as also mariysN. (Mgh, art. mrs.) ― -b3- Water with milk. (K.) ― -b4- Anything rubbed and pressed with the hand until it becomes flaccid. (As, L.) ＝ -A2- See maAridN.

marRaAdN c
marRaAdN: see maraAdN.

mirRiydN c
mirRiydN: see maAridN.

maAridN c
maAridN [from marada] and mariydN↓ [from maruda] (S, M, A, L, Msb, K) and mutamarRidN↓ (A, K) [One who exalts himself, or is insolent and audacious, in pride and in acts of rebellion or disobedience; an insolent and audacious rebel or unbeliever; see 1;] bold or audacious; (M, L, K;) and immoderate, inordinate, or exorbitant; or excessively, immoderately, or inordinately, proud, or corrupt, or unbelieving, or disobedient or rebellious; &c.; see 1; (S, M, A, L, Msb, K;) and strong: (L:) these epithets are applied to evil beings of mankind and of the jinn, (L,) and to any animal: (M, L:) the first is said to be applied to an evil jinnee of the most powerful class: (Mir-át ez-Zemán, &c.) pl. (of the first, M, L,) maradapN (M, L, K) and murRaAdN; (A;) and (of the second, M, L) muradaMCu. (M, L, K.) mirRiydN↓ signifies the same in an intensive degree. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- maAridN Lofty, high: (L, K:) applied to a building. (TA.) ― -b3- maAridN and maruwdN↓ One who often goes and comes, by reason of his briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness. (L.)

Oamoradu c
Oamoradu. ― -b2- XajarapN marodaMCu (tropical:) A tree having no leaves upon it: (Ks, A, L, K:) or, of which the leaves have altogether gone: (AHn, L:) and in like manner, guSonN Oamoradu (tropical:) a branch having no leaves upon it: (Ks, S, L:) or the latter expression is not used. (T, L.) ― -b3- ramolapN marodaMCu (tropical:) A sand that is plain (L) and produces no plants: (S, A, L, K:) pl. maraAdK, as though it were a subst. (M, L.) ― -b4- OaroDN marodaMCu (tropical:) An expanse of sands in which nothing grows: pl. maraAdiI [or maraAdiIRu]. (As, T, L.) ― -b5- Oamoradu A youth, or young man, as yet beardless: (Msb:) or having no hair upon his cheeks: (IAar, L:) or who has remained to a late period without the hair of his face having grown forth: (S, Msb:) or whose mustache has grown forth, but not his beard, (L, K,) he having attained the usual age at which the beard grows: (L:) pl. murodN: (L:) dim. Oumayoridu. (A.) You do not apply the epithet marodaMCu to a girl [in the sense above explained]. (S, L.) It is said in a trad., Oaholu AljanRapi jurodN murodN [The people of paradise are without hair upon their bodies, and beardless]. (L.) ― -b6- marodaMCu A woman having no hair upon her pubes. (M, L, K.) [In some copies of the K, for laA Uisoba lahaA, we find lA Ast lhA: and the like is found in copies of the A.] ― -b7- Oamoradu A horse having no hair upon the fetlock. (S, L.)

mumarRadN c
mumarRadN A building made smooth, and tall or long: (A:) or made smooth: (L:) or made tall or long. (A 'Obeyd, L, K.)

jabalN mutamarRidN c
jabalN mutamarRidN (tropical:) [A mountain that opposes obstacles to one's ascent]: pl. jibaAlN mutamarRidaAtN. (A.) ― -b2- See maAridN.

murodaAsanojN c
murodaAsanojN: see marotakN in art. rtk.

marodaquwXN c
marodaquwXN [Marjoram; sweet marjoram; so called in the present day;] i. q. marozanojuwXN [q. v.]: (S, K:) an arabicized word, (AHeyth, K,) [thought to be so by J,] from [the Persian]
murodaho kuwXo, (K) meaning “ having a dead ear, ” (TA,) or “ having a soft ear, ” [which is given in the K as one of the significations of the arabicized word,] (AHeyth, TA,) because what is flaccid is as though it were dead: (TA:) or [so accord. to the S, TA; but accord. to the K, and] saffron: (S, K:) and a certain perfume which a woman puts upon her comb, inclining to redness and blackness. (K.) The vulgar [generally] say barodaquwX. (TA.)

marozanojuwXN c
marozanojuwXN, (S, and so in the K in art. mrdqX &c., in some copies of the K in the present art.,) or marozajuwXN, (so in some copies of the K in the present art.,) or both, the latter being of the measure faEolaluwlN, like EaDorafuwTN, (TA,) [Marjoram; sweet marjoram; called by the former name in the present day;] i. q. marodaquwXN: (S, K:) an arabicized word, from [the Persian] marozanokuwXo [lit. “ mouse-ear ”: but see marodaquwX]: in [genuine] Arabic, samosaqN: beneficial for dysury, and colic, and the sting of the scorpion, and pains arising from cold, and melancholy, and inflation, or flatulence, and the disease called laqowap [which distorts one side of the face], and flow of saliva from the mouth, and it is strongly diuretic, and dries up humours of the stomach and bowels. (K.)

1 marasahu c
1. marasahu, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) fI AlmaMCi, (S, M, A, K.) aor.
marusa
, (M, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. marosN, (M, Mgh, Msb,) He macerated, steeped, or soaked, it, (namely, a quantity of dates, S, K, or other things, S, or medicine, M, A, and bread, M,) in water, (S, M, K,) and mashed it with the hand: (S, K:) so says ISk: (TA:) he rubbed and pressed it, (namely, a quantity of dates,) with the hand, in water, so that it became mashed: (Msb:) he moistened it, (namely, bread, or the like,) in water, and rubbed and pressed it with the fingers until it became soft. (Mgh.) marosN also signifies the rubbing and pressing with the hand: and mixing; or moistening with water or the like. (TA.) ― -b2- marasa UiSobaEahu, aor.
marusa
, (S, K,) inf. n. marosN, (TA,) He (a child) mumbled, or bit softly, his finger; i. q. maravahaA, (S, K,) of which it is a dial. form; or it is an instance of mispronunciation. (S.) See also marada. ― -b3- marasa yadahu biAlminodiyli (assumed tropical:) He wiped his hand with the napkin. (ISk, S, K.) See also 5. ＝ -A2- marisa: see 3. ＝ -A3- marisa AlHabolu, (S, M,) aor.
marasa
, (S,) inf. n. mrasN; (S, M;) or marasa, aor.
marusa
, (K,) inf. n. marosN; (TA;) The rope fell on one of the two sides of the sheave of the pulley: (S, K:) or fell between the sheave of the pulley and the bent piece of iron which is on each side thereof and in which is the pin whereon the sheave turns. (M.) And marisati Albakorapu, aor.
marasa
, inf. n. marasN, The sheave of the pulley had its rope sticking fast between it and the qaEow [or cheek]. (S, K.)

3 mArs c
3. mArs, (M, TA,) inf. n. mumaArasapN and miraAsN, (S, M,) He laboured, exerted himself, strove, struggled, contended, or conflicted, to prevail, overcome, gain the mastery, or effect an object, syn. of the inf. n. muEaAlajapN: (S:) or he did so vehemently; as also marisa↓, [aor.
marasa
,] inf. n. marasN: (M, TA:) [and maraAsapN is also, perhaps, an inf. n. of the latter verb, though by rule its verb should be marusa.] You say, faHolN cuw miraAsK A stallion possessing strength: (K:) or possessing strength, or vehemence, of labour or exertion; (TA;) and fulaAnN cuw miraAsK, and marasK↓, Such a one is a possessor of hardiness and strength, (A,) and rajulN bayRinu Almarasi, (S, TA,) and AlmaraAsapi, (K, * TA,) A man bearing evidence of strength: (K, * TA:) or of strength, or vehemence, of labour or exertion. (S.) ― -b2- mArshu, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He laboured, exerted himself, strove, struggled, contended, or conflicted, with him, or it, to prevail, overcome, or gain the mastery or possession, or to effect an object: he laboured, or worked, at it, or upon it: syn. EaAlajahu, and zaAwalahu. (K.) You say, mArs qironahu He strove, contended, or conflicted, with his adversary; syn. EaAlajahu. (A.) And mArs EamalFA He exercised, or practised, diligently, or plied, a work, or an occupation; he laboured. (L, voce EaAlaja.) And mArs AlARumuwra [He laboured, exerted himself, or exercised himself diligently, in the management, or transaction, of affairs]. (A.) And mArs ZahorFA [He plied, worked, or put to labour, a camel for riding, or carriage]. (L, art. Elj.) ― -b3- mArs, inf. n. mumaArasapN, also signifies He played, or sported, with another, or others; as, for instance, with women; used in this sense in a trad. (TA.) See also 5, in two places.

4 Amrs AlHabola c
4. Amrs AlHabola, (inf. n. UimoraAsN, TA,) He restored the rope to the place [or groove of the sheave] in which it ran. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- Also, He removed the rope from the place in which it ran; (TA;) he made the rope to stick fast between the sheave of the pulley and the qaEow [or cheek]. (S, K, TA.) Thus it bears two contr. significations, on the authority of Yaakoob. (S.)

5 tmrRs c
5. tmrRs It was, or became, strongly twisted and adhering. (M.) See marasapN. ― -b2- tmrRs bihi He kept to it constantly, or assiduously; he accustomed himself to it; syn. Dariyahu [app. for DariIa bihi]. (M.) ― -b3- He rubbed, or scratched, himself against it; (S, A, K;) as, for instance, a camel against the trunk of a palm-tree, (A,) or any tree, on account of the mange or an itching; (TA;) as also bh Amtrs↓. (S, K.) You say also, Albaqarapu tamarRasu biAlXRajari The cow rubs her horns against the trees to sharpen them. (A. [In my copy of the A, I find here tamorusu; but this is evidently a mistake of the copyist for tamarRasu, or its original form tatamarRasu.]) ― -b4- [Hence, app., (assumed tropical:) He made use of him.] You say, laA yatamarRasu bihi OaHadN liOanRahu SulobN laA yusotagalRu minohu XaIoCN (assumed tropical:) [No one makes any use of him; for he is hard: nothing, meaning no profit, or advantage, is reaped, or obtained from him]. (L.) [See also mutamarRasN.] ― -b5- (tropical:) He (a camel) ate of it (a tree) time after time. (A, TA.) It is said in a trad. respecting the signs of the resurrection yatamarRasu AlrRajulu bidiynihi kamaA yatamarRasu AlbaEiyru biAlXRajarapi (A, TA *) meaning, (tropical:) The man will play, or sport, with his religion, [like as the camel eats time after time of the tree; or, accord. to another explanation, like as the camel rubs, or scratches, himself against the tree:] or the meaning is, will strive and contend in dissensions or seditions. (TA.) ― -b6- (tropical:) He set himself against him to do evil, or mischief. (A, TA.) ― -b7- (tropical:) I. q. maArasahu; whence the saying, fulaAnN tamarRasa biAlnRawaAYibi waAlxuSuwmaAti [app. meaning, (tropical:) Such a one strove against calamities and contentions, to gain the mastery]. (A.) ― -b8- (tropical:) He besmeared himself with it; namely, with perfume. (A, TA.) ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) He wiped himself with it. (TA.) ― -b10- See also what next follows.

6 tmArswA c
6. tmArswA [They laboured, strove, struggled, contended or conflicted, one with another, to prevail, overcome, gain the mastery, or effect an object:] they contended together, smiting one another, syn. taDaArabuwA, (A, K,) fiI AlHarobi in war: (A:) and [in like manner] you say also, tmrRswA↓ fI AlHrb, (K in art dEk,) or, of two men, tmrRsA fI AlHrb. (S in that art.) ― -b2- tamaArasaA AlXRarRa bayonahumaA [They two laboured, or strove, each with the other, to do evil, or mischief]. (S, art. kwH.)

8 Amtrs bihi c
