8. Amtrs bihi: see 5. ― -b2- Amtrsti AlOalosunu fiI AlxuSuwmaAti (tropical:) The tongues persisted in wranglings, or contentions, (S, M,) and assailed one another. (M, A.) ― -b3- Amtrst bihi, occurring in a poem of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, is said of wild asses that had drawn near to the hunter as one that would rub himself against a thing: (S, TA:) or, accord. to Es-Sukkaree, of a wild she-ass, and meaning, She began to strive with him to circumvent him and gain the mastery (jElt tkArRuh wtuEaAlijuhu [as written in the TA; but I doubt not that tkArRuh is a mistranscription for tukaAyiduhu, which is much like tEAljh in signification; and therefore I have thus rendered it]): or the meaning is, she had his arrow sticking fast in her. (TA.)

marasN c
marasN: see marasapN, and 3.

marisN c
marisN A strong man: (TA:) or a man (S) strong, or vehement, in labour or exertion: (S, M:) and strong, experienced in affairs, and who has laboured, or exerted himself, in the management, or transaction, thereof: pl. OamoraAsN. (TA.) You say also, UinRahu lamarisN HacirN, meaning, Verily he is strong in the waging of wars. (TA.) ＝ -A2- humo EalaI marisK waAHidK They are alike in dispositions. (S, TA.)

marasapN c
marasapN, (S, K,) or marasN↓, (A,) or both, the latter being sometimes used as a sing., (M,) A rope: (S, M, K:) so called because of the strong twisting and adhering (tamarRus) of its strands, one upon another: (TA:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of the former, marasN; (S, M, K;) and pl. pl., (M, K,) [i. e.] pl. of marasN, (S, A, *) OamoraAsN. (S, M, A * K.) ― -b2- Also, the former, A dog's rope: pl. as above. (M.)

marosiynN c
marosiynN The myrtle-tree; (Xajarapu AlMsi;) also called riyoHaAnu Alqubuwri: of the dial. of Egypt: but perhaps the n is a radical letter. (TA.)

bakorapN maruwsN c
bakorapN maruwsN A sheave of a pulley that is wont to have its rope stick fast between it and the qaEow [or cheek]. (S, * M, * K, * TA.)

mariysN c
mariysN Dates macerated, or steeped, or soaked, and mashed with the hand, (A, * K,) or moistened, and rubbed and pressed with the fingers till soft, (Mgh,) in water or in milk. (A, O, Mgh.) In the copies of the K, the words fiI AlmaMCi are omitted; and immediately after their place follows OawiAllRabanu [as though meaning, “ or it signifies milk]. ” (TA.) Also, i. q. vriydN, q. v. (K.)

mariysiyRapN c
mariysiyRapN [in the modern Egyptian dial. mariysiI] The south wind, that comes from the direction of mariysN, which, says AHn, is the lowest part of the country of the Nubians, next to the district of OusowaAn. (M.)

faHolN marRaAsN c
faHolN marRaAsN A strong stallion: (K:) or a stallion strong, or vehement in labour or exertion. (M, Sgh.) ― -b2- layolapN marRaAsapN (tropical:) A night's journey in which is no remissness or languor; (M;) i. e., (M,) a hard and fatiguing and long night's journey. (IAar, M, K.)

maArasotaAnN c
maArasotaAnN A hospital for the sick: and arabicized word [from the Persian]: (Yaakoob, S, K:) originally biymaArisotaAno: (Yaakoob, TA.)

Oamorasu c
Oamorasu [an imitative sequent and corroborative of Oaxorasu, as is shown in the M, art. mrs, see Oaxorasu.]

mutamarRasN c
mutamarRasN [originally A place where one rubs or scratches himself against a thing. Hence, app., the saying,] ― -b2- maA bifulaAnK mutamarRasN (tropical:) [Nothing can be done with, or got from, such a one]: said of him from whom the enemy can obtain no advantage: (A:) or of him who is hardy and strong, so that he who strives with him cannot withstand him, because he has striven against calamities and contentions: (TA:) and of the avaricious man, from whom he who is in want cannot obtain anything. (A, TA.)

1 mariDa c
1. mariDa, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
maraDa
, inf. n. maraDN and maroDN, (Msb, K,) which latter is a dial. form rarely used, (Msb,) He (a man, S, or an animal [of any kind], Msb) was, or became, [diseased, disordered, distempered, sick, or ill; i. e.] in the state termed maraDN (S, Msb, K) denoting that change of the constitution or temperament which is described in the explanation of this term below; (K;) as also AmrD↓, expl. by SaAra caA maraDK. (K, TA; but not in the CK.) ― -b2- [Hence, mariDati AlEayonu (tropical:) The eye became languid; or languishing; or weak: (see mariyDN:) or, as Golius says, on the authority of Ibn-Maaroof, was weak from much, and too much, looking.] ― -b3- And mariDati AllRayolapu (tropical:) The night became dark. (Th, O.) ― -b4- [The verb probably has several other tropical significations agreeable with explanations of maraDN and mariyDN which will be found below.]

2 mrRDhu c
2. mrRDhu, (S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. tamoriyDN, (S, Msb, K,) He took care of him in his sickness; (Sb, S, Mgh;) and treated him medically, to remove his disease; the measure faERala in this instance having a privative quality, though its quality is in most instances confirmative: (Sb:) or he took good care of him, namely a sick person: (K:) or he undertook, or managed, or superintended, the medical treatment of him. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- mrRD fiI AlOamori, (IDrd, A,) [and marRaDahu, (O, K voce DahoyaOa,)] inf. n. as above, (S, K,) (tropical:) He fell short of doing what he ought to have done, or was remiss, in, or with respect to, the affair: (S, A:) or he did not exert himself to the full, or to the utmost, or beyond what is usual, in it: (IDrd:) or he did it weakly, or feebly, (K, * TA,) not firmly or soundly: (TA:) as also fiyhi mArD↓. (TA.) [See also 5.] And mrRD fulaAnN fiI HaAjatiI (tropical:) Such a one was deficient in activity in accomplishing my want. (TA.) And mrRD fiI kalaAmihi (tropical:) He was weak in his speech. (IDrd.) ― -b2- [HakaAhu biSiygapi AltRamoriyDi, probably a post-classical phrase, signifies (assumed tropical:) He mentioned it, or related it, in a manner implying that it was doubtful, or was a mere assertion; as when the word qiyla is used.]

3 mArD fiI AlOamori c
3. mArD fiI AlOamori: see 2. ― -b2- maAraDotu raOoyiI fiyka (tropical:) I deceived myself, or endeavoured to deceive myself, respecting thee. (A, TA.)

4 AmrD c
4. AmrD: see 1. ― -b2- He had a bane, or murrain, (Yaakoob, S,) or a disease, or distemper, (A, TA,) in his beasts, (Yaakoob, S, A,) or camels. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AmrDhu He (God, S, Msb) rendered him mariyD [or diseased, &c.]. (Sb, S, * Msb, K.) You say also, Oakala maA lamo yuwaAfiqohu faOamoraDahu (A, TA) [He ate what did not agree with him, and] it caused him to fall into AlmaraD [or disease, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] UimoraADu AlOjofaAni (S, voce UisojaAdN) (tropical:) The lowering of the eyelids [in a languid, or languishing, manner: see mariyDN]. (TK, voce UisojaAdN.) ― -b3- AmrDhu also signifies He found him to be mariyD [or diseased, &c.]. (K.) ＝ -A3- Also AmrD (assumed tropical:) He was near to being right in opinion, (S, L, K, *) though not altogether right. (L.) In the K, this signification is wrongly assigned to AmrDhu. (TA.) A poet says, (S,) namely El-Ukeyshir El-Asadee, praising 'Abd-el-Melik Ibn-Marwán, (TA.)
walekino taHota caAka AlXRayobi HazomN
UicaA maA ZanRa OamoraDa Oawo OaSaAbaA
[But beneath that hoariness is good judgment: when he forms an opinion, he is nearly right, or he is right]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Also, AmrDhu fulaAnN (tropical:) Such a one was near to attaining the object of his [another's] want. (A, TA.)

5 tmrRD c
5. tmrRD (tropical:) He was weak, or feeble, in his affair. (A, * K, TA.) [It seems to be indicated in the A that tmArD↓ also has this signification; like as mArD in nearly the same sense is syn. with mrRD, q. v.: or perhaps tmArD signifies (tropical:) he feigned, or made a false show of, weakness, or feebleness, in his affair: it is said, in the A, to be used tropically as well as properly.]

6 tmArD c
6. tmArD He feigned, or made a false show of, maraD [or disease, &c.] in himself. (S, A. *) ― -b2- See also 5.

maroDN c
maroDN: see 1: and see what here next follows, in six places.

maraDN c
maraDN (IDrd, S, O, Msb, K) and maroDN↓: (Msb, K:) see 1: i. q. suqomN [Disease, disorder, distemper, sickness, illness, or malady]; (IDrd, S;) which is the contr. of SiHRapN; and affects man and the camel [&c.]: (IDrd:) or a certain state foreign to the constitution or temperament, injurious to the intellect; whence it is known that pains and tumours are accidents arising therefrom: or, as IF says, that whereby a man passes beyond the limit of health or soundness or perfection or rectitude, whether it be disease (EilRap),
or (assumed tropical:) hypocrisy, or (assumed tropical:) a falling short of doing what he ought to do in an affair: (Msb:) or a dark and disordered state of the constitution or temperament, after a clear and right state thereof: (O, K:) or maroDN↓ is (assumed tropical:) [a disease] of the heart: (K:) Aboo-Is-hák says, maraDN and suqomN are said to be in the body and (assumed tropical:) in religion, like as SiHRapN is said to be in the body and in religion; and maroDN↓ is in the heart, applying to (assumed tropical:) everything whereby a man quits a state of soundness or perfection or rectitude in religion: (TA:) and As says, I recited to Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà [the words of the Kur, ii. 9, &c.,] fiI quluwbihimo maraDN and he said to me ↓“ maroDN, O boy ”: (AHát, IDrd, Msb:) and maraDN, or this and maroDN↓ also, signifies (assumed tropical:) doubt: and (assumed tropical:) hypocrisy: (K:) and (assumed tropical:) weakness of belief: (TA:) and the former, (TA,) or ↓both, (K,) (assumed tropical:) languor, or languidness, or weakness: (K:) and (assumed tropical:) darkness (IAar, K) in the heart: (IAar:) and (assumed tropical:) defectiveness; deficiency; or imperfection; (IAar, K;) which last is said by IAar to be the primary signification: (TA:) or maraDN in the body is a languor, or languidness, or weakness, of the limbs, or members: and in the eye, (assumed tropical:) weakness of sight: and in the heart, (assumed tropical:) a flagging, or remissness, in respect of the truth: (Ibn-'Arafeh:) or it properly signifies an accidental affection of the body, which puts it out of the right state proper to it, and necessarily occasions interruption, or infirmity, in its actions: and tropically, (tropical:) affections of the mind, which interrupt, or mar, its integrity; such as (tropical:) ignorance; and (tropical:) evil belief; and (tropical:) envy; and (tropical:) malevolence, or malice; and (tropical:) love of acts of disobedience; for these prevent from the attaining of excellences, or lead to the cessation of true eternal life: (Bd, ii. 9:) it is a gen. n.: (IDrd:) and the n. un. is maroDapN↓: (A, TA:) it is one of the inf. ns. which have pls., like XugolN and EaqolN; the pls. of these three being OamoraADN and OaXogaAlN and EuquwlN. (Sb.) fiI qulowbihimo maraDN, in the Kur, [ii. 9, &c.,] means (assumed tropical:) In their hearts is doubt: (AO:) or (assumed tropical:) doubt and hypocrisy. (TA.) And AlRaciI fiI qalobihi maraDN, in the same, [xxxiii. 32,] (assumed tropical:) In whose heart is darkness: or (assumed tropical:) flagging, or remissness, in respect of what is commanded and what is forbidden: or (assumed tropical:) love of adultery or fornication: (TA:) or hypocrisy. (A.)

mariDN c
mariDN: see mariyDN.

maroDapN c
maroDapN [A single disease, &c.]: see maraDN, near the end of the paragraph.

muraADN c
muraADN A disease [or blight or the like] which affects fruits, and destroys them. (K.)

mariyDN c
mariyDN [Diseased; disordered; distempered; sick; or ill;] in the state termed maraDN (Msb, K) denoting that change of the constitution or temperament which is described in the explanation of the latter word above; (K;) as also mariDN↓ (K,) and maAriDN↓, (IB, Msb, K,) the first [and second] being from the verb of which the inf. n. is maraDN, and the third from that of which the inf. n. is maroDN, (Msb,) and mamoruwDN↓, and mutamarRiDN↓: (TA:) or, applied to a body, it signifies deficient in strength: (IAar:) pl. miraADN (A, K, TA:) and maroDaI (IDrd, Msb, K) and maraADaI (IDrd, K) and muraDaMCu; (TA;) or miraADN may be pl. of maAriDN (TA) [or of mariDN]. Accord. to Lh, you say, Eudo fulaAnN faUinRahu mariyDN [Visit thou such a one, for he is sick]: and laA taOokulo hecaA Uino Oakalotahu AlTRaEaAma faUinRaka maAriDN↓ meaning tamoraDu [i. e. Eat not thou this food, for thou wilt be sick if thou eat it]. (TA.) [mariyDN has also several tropical significations.] You say also, EayonN mariyDapN (tropical:) An eye in which is languor, or languidness, or weakness: (S, TA:) pl. OaEoyanN miraADN, and maroDaI. (A, TA.) And UimoraOapN mariyDapu AlOaloHaAZi and mryDpu AlnRaZari (assumed tropical:) A woman weak in sight. (IDrd.) And qalobN mariyDN (assumed tropical:) A heart deficient in religion. [IAar.) And XamosN mariyDapN (tropical:) A sun having a feeble light; (A, K; *) not clear, (S, TA,) and not beautiful. (TA.) And OaroDN mariyDapN (tropical:) A land in which are frequent seditions, or factions, or conflicts, or dissensions, (A, TA,) and wars, (A,) and slaughters: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) in a weak condition: (K:) or straitened with its inhabitants: or (assumed tropical:) in which the wind is still, and the heat intense: or that causes disease; meaning (assumed tropical:) corrupt in its air. (TA.) And riyHN mariyDapN (A, K) (tropical:) A weak wind: (K:) or (tropical:) a still wind: or (tropical:) a wind intensely hot, and blowing feebly. (TA.) And layolapN mariyDapN (tropical:) A night in which no star shines; (A;) in which the sky is clouded, so that there is no light. (TA.) And raOoIN mariyDN (A, TA) (tropical:) An opinion deviating from what is right. (TA.)

maAriDN c
maAriDN: see mariyDN, in two places.

mumoriDN c
mumoriDN A man having diseased camels: so in the following trad.: laA yuwridu mumoriDN EalaI muSiHRK [One having diseased camels shall not bring them to water immediately after one whose camels are in a healthy state]: the prohibition being not because of the transition of disease by contagion; but because sometimes disease may befall the healthy beasts, and it may come into the mind of the owner that that is from contagion. (TA.) [See also muSiHRN.]

mimoraADN c
mimoraADN A man frequently diseased or sick. (S, K.)

mamoruwDN c
mamoruwDN see mariyDN.

mutamarRiDN c
mutamarRiDN: see mariyDN. ― -b2- Also, (tropical:) A man weak, or feeble, in his affair. (TA.)

1 mariTa c
1. mariTa, aor.
maraTa
, (K,) inf. n. maraTN, (S, Mgh,) He (a man, S) had little, scanty, or thin, hair upon the sides of his face, or of his cheeks; (S;) or upon his body, and eyebrow, and eye, in consequence of a weakness of this last, and of frequent shedding of tears: (K, TA:) or most of his hair fell off. (Mgh.) [See also mrt and mrd]. ＝ -A2- maraTa, aor.
maruTa
, (S,) inf. n. maroTN, (K,) He plucked out hair (S, K,) as also mrRT↓, (K,) inf. n. tamoriyTN, (TA,) and feathers, and wool, from the body. (TA.)

2 marRaTa
2: see 1: ― -b2- and 8. ＝ -A2- mrRT AlvRawoba, inf. n. tamoriyTN, He shortened the sleeves of the garment, and made it into a miroT. (K.)

3 mArThu c
3. mArThu, (K,) inf. n. mumaAraTapN and miraATN, (TA,) He plucked out his hair, and scratched him with his nails. (K.)

4 AmrT AlXRaEaru c
4. AmrT AlXRaEaru The hair attained to the time at which it should be plucked out; it was time for it to be plucked out. (S, K.) ― -b2- AmrTt AlnRaxolapu (assumed tropical:) The palm-tree dropped, or let fall, its ripe dates (Jm, K) in a juicy, or sappy, state. (Jm.) ＝ -A2- AmrTt AlnRAqapu waladahaA The she-camel cast her fœtus in an imperfect state, with no hair upon it. (IDrd.)

5 tmrRT AlXRaEaru c
5. tmrRT AlXRaEaru, (S, K,) quasi-pass. of marRaTahu, (TA,) The hair fell off by degrees; became scattered; (S, * K;) as also UimRaraTa↓, of the measure UifotaEala, [originally AmtrT,] (K,) or, [rather,] as in the TS, of the measure UinofaEala, [originally UinomaraTa,] quasi-pass. of maraTahu. (TA.) [In like manner] you say also, tmrRTt OawobaAru AlUibili The fur of the camels became scattered. (TA.) And qucacu AlsRahomi UimRaraTato↓ The feathers of the arrow fell off. (TA, from a trad.) And tmrRT AlcRiYobu The hair of the wolf fell off until little thereof remained upon him. (TA.) [See also mariTa.]

7 UimRaraTa c
7. UimRaraTa [said in the TS to be of the measure AnfEl]: see 5, in two places.

8 AmtrThu c
8. AmtrThu He seized it, took it hastily, or snatched it unawares, (K, TA,) from his hand: (TA:) or he collected it together, (K, TA,) namely, a thing that he had found; as also mrRThu↓. (TA.) ＝ -A2- UimRaraTa [said in the K to be of the measure AftEl]: see 5, in two places.

miroTN c
miroTN A [garment of the kind called] kisaMC, of wool, or of xazR [q. v.], (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) or of linen, (TA,) and (tropical:) of hair-cloth, being
tropically applied to one of this last description in a trad. of 'Áïsheh, (MF,) used as an UizaAr, [i. e. a waist-wrapper,] (S, Mgh, Msb,) in former times, (S,) and sometimes a woman throws it over her head, (Mgh,) and wraps herself in it: (Mgh, Msb:) or a green [perhaps meaning gray as is often the case] garment: or any garment that is not sewed: (TA:) [see 2:) pl. muruwTN. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.)

muruTN c
muruTN: see OamoraTu, in two places.

miroTaAwaAni c
miroTaAwaAni: see murayoTaMCu.

miraATN c
miraATN: see OamoraTu.

mariyTN c
mariyTN: see OamoraTu.

muraATapN c
muraATapN What falls, of hair, when it is plucked out; (S, K; *) or when it is combed: (K, * TA:) or what is plucked out from the arm-pit. (Lh.)

murayoTaI c
murayoTaI The uvula. (Hr, K.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

murayoTaMCu c
murayoTaMCu; so accord. to As (S, TA) and AO; accord. to El-Ahmar, murayoTaI↓; but As disputed this with him, and overcame him; (TA;) [dim. of maroTaMCu, fem. of OamoraTu;] only used in the dim. form; (TA;) or it has the form of the dim. of maroTaMCu: (Mgh:) The part between the navel and the pubes: (As, S, Mgh, K:) or between the breast and the pubes: (Lth, K:) or a thin skin between the navel and the pubes, (IDrd, K, *) on the right and left, where the hair is plucked out, extending to the groins; (IDrd;) as also murayoTaI↓: (TA:) or a thin skin in the belly: (Mgh:) or [the dual] murayoTaAwaAni signifies the two sides of the pubes of a man, which have no hair upon them: (Mgh, TA; *) or the sing., (accord. to the K,) or the dual, (accord. to the TA,) two veins (K, TA) in the soft parts of the belly, (TA,) upon which he who cries out vehemently bears: (K, TA:) and (the dual, accord. to the TA) the bare part of the lower lip, over which is the sabalap (K, TA) next the nose: (TA:) and (the dual again, accord. to the TA) the parts on either side of the tuft of hair between the lower lip and the chin; as also miroTaAwaAni↓, with kesr. (K.) ― -b2- The arm-pit. (K.) ＝ -A2- A thing with which one ties, binds, or makes fast. (Hr, TA.)

maAriT c
maAriT: see OamoraATu, in two places.

OamoraTu c
OamoraTu A man having little, or scanty, or thin, hair upon the sides of his face, or of his cheeks; (S;) or upon his body, and eyebrow, and eye, in consequence of a weakness of this last, and of frequent shedding of tears; (K, TA;) [in the CK, the word XEr is omitted in this explanation;]) or upon his body and breast; when all the hair has gone, he is said to be OamolaTu: (TA:) pl. muroTN and miraTapN; (K;) the former regular; the latter, extr., and thought by ISd to be a quasi-pl. n. (TA.) [The fem.] maroTaMCu signifies A woman having no hair upon her pubes and what is next to it. (IDrd.) You say also hiIa maroTaMCu AlHaAjibayoni She has little, or scanty, or thin, hair in the eyebrows: the mention of the eyebrows being indispensable. (TA.) And HaAjibN OamoraT An eyebrow of which most of the hair has fallen off. (Mgh.) See also OaToraTu. ― -b2- A wolf of which some of the hair has fallen off; (Az, TA;) or whose hair has been plucked out. (K.) ― -b3- And hence, as being likened thereto, (Az, TA,) (tropical:) A thief, or robber; (As, AA, T, S, K;) as also EumoruwTN. (As, T.) ― -b4- An arrow of which the feathers have fallen off: (S:) or an arrow having no feathers; (K;) as also mariyTN↓ and miraATN↓ (K) and maAriTN↓ (L, TA) and muruTN↓, (S, K,) as in the phrase muruTu AlqicaAci, in a verse [cited voce maSonaEN, wrongly asserted to be] of Lebeed, though we may read muroT, which is pl. of OamoraTu, as this may be correctly applied as an epithet to the sing. because of the pl. which follows it: (S:) the pl. of mArT↓ is murRaTu and mawaAriTu; (L, TA;) and the pl. of muruTN↓ is OamoraATN [a pl. of pauc.] (K, TA) and miraATN. (S, K.) ― -b5- XajarapN maroTaMCu (assumed tropical:) A tree having no leaves upon it. (TA.)

naxolapN mumoriTN c
naxolapN mumoriTN A palm-tree dropping, or letting fall, its ripe dates (Jm, K) in a juicy, or sappy, state. (Jm.) And mimoraATN↓ One that usually does so. (Jm, K.) ＝ -A2- naAqapN mumoriTN A she-camel casting her fœtus in an imperfect state, with no hair upon it. (Jm.) And mimoraATN↓ One that usually does so. (Jm.) [See mumorijN.]

mimoraATN c
mimoraATN: see mumoriTN, in two places.

1 mazRa c
1. mazRa, [sec. pers. mazuzota aor.
mazuza
,] inf. n. mazaAzapN, It had, or acquired, a taste between sweet and sour. (TA; but only the inf. n. of the verb in this sense is there mentioned.) AZ also mentions, as heard from the Kilábees, the saying, qaco mazRa XaraAbukumo OaqobaHa AlmazaAzapi, and Almuzuwzapi, as meaning, [Your beverage, or wine,] hath become very sour. (TA.) ＝ -A2- mazRahu, (S, A, K,) aor.
mazuza
, (S,) inf. n. mazRN, (S, TA,) [and accord. to one copy of the S, mazaAzapN, but this I regard as a mistake of a copyist,] He sucked it; i. q. maSRahu. (S, A, K.)

5 tamazRaRa
5: [He sipped:] see 10 in art. dbr.

R. Q. 1 mazomazahu c
R. Q. 1. mazomazahu, (S, K,) inf. n. mazomazapN, (S,) He put him, or it, in motion, or into a state of commotion; or shook him, or it; (S, K;) and moved him, or it, forwards and backwards: (S, TA:) or he put him, or it, in violent motion, or into a state of violent commotion; or shook him, or it, violently: (Mgh, art. tr; and TA:) as, for instance, a drunken man, in order that he might recover from his intoxication. (S, * TA.) See also tarotarahu.

R. Q. 2 tamazomaza c
R. Q. 2. tamazomaza He ate, and drank, what had a taste between sweet and sour. (TA.) ＝ -A2- He, or it, was, or became, put in motion, or in a state of commotion, or shaken, (K, TA,) and moved forwards and backwards: or in violent motion, or into a state of violent commotion, or shaken violently. (TA.) ― -b2- tamazomaza liloqiyaAmi He raised himself, (K,) or put himself in motion, (TA,) to stand. (K, TA.)

mazRN c
mazRN: see its fem. mazRapN.

muzRN c
muzRN, applied to beverage, or wine, (S, K,) and to a pomegranate, (Lth, S, K,) Having a taste between sweet and sour: (Lth, S, K:) fem. with p. (A.) AZ mentions its signifying Very sour beverage or wine; as heard from the Kilábees. (TA.) You say also xamorapN muzRapN, meaning, Wine, or a wine in which is a taste between sweet and sour; said to be from mixing unripe and ripe dates [in making it]: (TA:) or wine in which is a sour taste, (S, K,) and in which is no goodness. (S.) See also mazRapN.

qahowapN mazRapN c
qahowapN mazRapN Wine having a pleasant, delicious, or sweet, taste: (S, K, * TA:) so called because it bites, or burns, the tongue; (S, TA;) as also muzRN↓, (K, TA,) which, however, is [not an epithet but] a subst.: (TA:) or the former signifies lcycp AlmqTE [app. meaning having a pleasant sharpness, or acidity]: (so in the L, TA:) J says, that one should not say mizRapN↓, but this form is said to occur in one relation of a verse or El-Aashà. (TA.) See also muzRN. ＝ -A2- Also mazRapN A single suck or sucking. (S, A, K.) It is said in a trad. laA tuHarRimu AlmazRapu walaA AlmzRataAni [The sucking once will not render marriage unlawful, nor will the two suckings], meaning, in drawing milk from the breast. (S.) [See a similar saying voce EayofapN.]

mizRapN c
mizRapN: see mazRapN.

1 mazaja c
1. mazaja, (S, K,) aor.
mazuja
, (L Msb,) [not
mazaja
, as in the lexicons of Golius and Freytag,] inf. n. mazojN, (K, &c.,) He mixed, mingled, incorporated, or blended, (S, K,) a thing with (bi) water; (Msb;) or beverage, or wine, (XaraAb,) with
something else. (S.) ― -b2- mazaja (tropical:) He exasperated, or irritated. (K.) mazajotuhu EalaI SaAHibihi I enraged him, and exasperated him, or irritated him, against his companion. (A.)

2 mzRj c
2. mzRj, inf. n. tamoziyjN, He gave. (K.) Ex. mzRj AlsRaAYila He gave the beggar something. (ISh.) ＝ -A2- mzRj, inf. n. tamoziyjN, It (an ear of corn, K, and a grape, TA,) became changed in colour from green to yellow. (T, K.)

3 mAzjhu c
3. mAzjhu, inf. n. mumaAzajapN, It mixed, mingled, commingled, intermixed, intermingled, or became incorporated or blended, with it; as some does with water. (TA.) ＝ -A2- mAzjhu, (tropical:) He contended with him, or disputed with him, for glory, or honour, or glorious or honourable qualities, and the like. (K.)

8 tmAzxA c
8. tmAzxA and AmtzjA↓ They two mixed, or mingled, or became mixed or mingled, each with the other. (TA.)

8 Amtzj c
8. Amtzj It was, or became, mixed with (bi) another thing. (TA.) See 6.

XaraAbN mazojN c
XaraAbN mazojN i. q. mamozuwjN↓, Mixed mine, or beverage. (TA.) ― -b2- See mizojN.

mizoju XaIoCK c
mizoju XaIoCK, and mizaAjuhu↓, What is mixed, or mingled, with a thing; its admixture. (TA.) ― -b2- AlXRaraAbi mizaAju↓ What is mixed with mine, or a beverage. (S, K.) Alxamori kaAfuwrN mizaAju↓ [see Kur, lxxvi., 5,] The odour, not the taste, of the wine is [like] camphor. (TA.) ― -b3- Albadani mizaAju↓ [The constitution, or temperament, of the body;] the aggregate natural constituents (TabaAYiEu) with which the body is composed; (S, K;) i. e. the four humours of the body; namely, black bile [AlsRawodaMCu], yellow bile [AlSRaforaMCu], (AlmirRataAni), phlegm (Albalogamu), and blood (AldRamu). (TA) Pl. OamozijapN. (Msb.) You say, huwa SaHiyHu AlmizaAji↓, and faAsiduhu, He is of sound, and of unsound, constitution, or temperament: meaning the humours of the body. And Oamozijapu AlnRisaMCi muxotalifapN The constitutions, or temperaments, of women are discordant, or various. (A.) ― -b4- mizojN (As, K, &c.) and mazojN↓, (Az, S, &c.,) or the latter is erroneous, or a word of weak authority, (K,) Honey: (S, K:) or honey in the comb; syn. XahodN: (T:) so called because every sweet beverage is mixed with it. (AHn.) ― -b5- Also, Water with which wine is mixed. (TA.) ― -b6- mizojN The bitter almond; as also maziyjN↓: see lawozN (K:) but IDrd doubts of its correctness; and it is said to be correctly munoj [which is Persian]. (TA.)

mizaAjN c
mizaAjN: see mizojN.

mawozajN c
mawozajN A boot, (K,) worn by women: (A:) an arabicized word, (S, K,) from the Persian muwzaho: (S:) pl. mawaAzijapN (because it is a foreign word, S) and mawaAziju. (S, K.)

maziyjN c
maziyjN: see mizojN.

rajulN mazRaAjN c
rajulN mazRaAjN, and mumazRijN↓; A man who continues not of one disposition, or temper, but varies in disposition, or temper: or a liar, who confounds, or confuses, things. (IAar.)

mamozuwjN c
mamozuwjN: see mazojN.

mumazRijN c
mumazRijN: see mazRaAjN.

TaboEu EuTaArida mutamazRijN c
TaboEu EuTaArida mutamazRijN [The nature of the planet Mercury is various]. (A.)

1 mazaHa c
1. mazaHa, aor.
mazaHa
, inf. n. mazoHN, (S, K,) and quasiinf. n. muzaAHN and muzAHapN, (K,) [the latter like its syn. duEaAbapN,] but Fei says that this last is mazaAHapN, (TA,) [and he mentions it as an inf. n.,] He jested or joked; (S, Msb, K;) contr. of jadRa [which signifies “ he was serious, or in earnest ” ”]: (M:) or he talked or behaved in a free and easy manner, with the view of blandishing and conciliating, without annoying; so that it excludes the meaning of mocking or ridiculing or deriding. (MF.)

3 mAzHhu c
3. mAzHhu, inf. n. mizaAHN (S, K) and mumaAzaHapN, (K,) He jested, or joked, with him. (S, K.)

6 tamaAzaHaA c
6. tamaAzaHaA They two jested, or joked, one with the other. (S, K.)

mazoHapN c
mazoHapN A jest, or joke; a single act of jesting, or joking. (Msb.)

muzaAHN c
muzaAHN and muzaAHapN, substs., A jesting, or joking. (S, K.) [See 1.]

rajulN mazRaAHN c
rajulN mazRaAHN A man who is a great jester, or joker. (A.)

1 mazada c
1. mazada, &c.: see art. mSd.

mizorN c
mizorN A certain kind of beverage, (S, Mgh,) or nbyc, (A, K,) made of curap [a kind of millet]: (A, Mgh, K:) [it is now called in Egypt and Nubia buwzha and buwZh: see De Sacy's “ Abdallatif, ” pp. 324 and 572; and my “ Modern Egyptians, ” vol. i. ch. iii.:] and of barley: (Mgh, K:) or of wheat: (Mgh:) and of [other] grains: (TA:) A'Obeyd mentions that the Ibn- 'Omar explains the various kinds of nabiyc thus: bitoEN is nbyc of honey: and jiEapN is nbyc of barley: and mizorN, of curap: and sakarN, of dried dates: and xamorN, of grapes: and sukurokapN is the wine of the Abyssinians; Aboo-Moosà El-Ash'aree says that it is of curap, and it is also called suquroqaEN, app. arabicized from sukurokap, which is Abyssinian: (S:) mizorN and sukurokahN are the same. ― -b2- See Supplement.

1 masRahu c
1. masRahu, (A, Mgh,) first pers. masisotuhu, (S, M, Msb, K,) for which they sometimes say misotuhu, rejecting the first s, (Sb, * S, M, * K,) and transferring the kesreh thereof to the m (Sb, * S, M, *) contr. to general rule, (Sb, M,) and some do not transfer the kesreh, but leave the m with its fethah, [saying masotuhu,] like Zilotumo and Zalotumo for Zalilotumo, an irregular contraction, (S,) aor. yamasRuhu, (S, Msb, K,) [and yamosasohu when mejzoom, accord. to rule,] inf. n. masRN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and masiysN, (S, * M, A, K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) and misRiysaI; (S, * K;) and [masRahu,] first pers. masasotuhu; aor. yamusRuhu, (AO, S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. masRN; (Msb;) the former of which two verbs is the more chaste; (S, TA;) He touched it, or felt it, [generally the former,] syn. lamasahu, (M, A, K,) with his hand: (TA: as from the K [but wanting in a MS copy of the K and in the CK:]) or he put his hand to it without the intervention of anything: (Msb:) or masRN is like lamosN; excepting that the latter is [sometimes] used to signify the seeking for [or feeling for] a thing, even though it be not found; whereas the former is [only] said of that [action] with which is perception by the sense of lms: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [see also lamasahu:] and [in like manner you say,] maAsRa AlXRaIoCu AlXRaIoCa, inf. n. mumaAsRapN and misaAsN, (M, A, *) meaning, the thing met [or touched] the thing with its substance. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] masRahaA, (M, A, Msb,) first pers. masisotuhaA, aor. yamasRuhaA, (Msb,) inf. n. masRN and masiysN, (Mgh, Msb,) (tropical:) Inivit eam; scil. mulierem; (M, A, Msb;) as also maAsRahaA↓, (M, A, Msb,) inf. n. mumaAsRapN (S, Msb) and misaAsN: (Msb:) the former is used in this sense in several places in the Kur, and is said by some to be preferable to the latter: (TA:) and tamaAsRN is also used metonymically for [the coming together, in the sense of] mubaADaEapN, as well as mumaAsRapN. (S.) ― -b3- masRa AlmaMCu Aljasada, inf. n. masRN, (tropical:) The water wetted the body. (Msb.) ― -b4- masRa also signifies (tropical:) He, or it, struck, or smote; because striking, or smiting, like touching, is with the hand. (TA.) You say, masRahu
biAlsRawoTi (tropical:) He struck him with the whip]. (A.) ― -b5- And it is said of anything annoying or hurtful that befals a man. Thus in the Kur, [ii. 74, and iii. 23,] lano tamasRanaA AlnRaAru (tropical:) [The fire of hell will not smite us; or here it may be rendered touch us]. And [ii. 210,] masRatohumu AlbaOosaMCu [Distress, or misfortune, smote, or afflicted, or befell, them]. And in other instances; all which are similar to the saying in the same, cuwquwA masRa saqara. (TA.) [See masRN below.] You say also, masRahu AlmaraDu (tropical:) [Sickness smote him, or befell him]: and masRahu AlEacaAbu (tropical:) [Punishment befell him]: and masRahu Alkibaru (tropical:) [Old age came upon him]. (A.) And masRatohu AljinRu (tropical:) [lit. The jinn, or genii touched him; meaning, affected him with madness, or insanity]: (TA:) [whence,] musRa, [in the TA, musRa bihi, app. meaning, from what immediately precedes, musRa biAljunuwni, inf. n. masRN,] He was, or became, [touched with madness, or insanity: or] mad, or insane: (K:) as though the jinn had touched him. (TA.) And masRahu biEacaAbK (tropical:) He punished him. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b6- [Hence, app.,] masRato Uilayohi AlHaAjapu, (S, K,) inf. n. [masRN and] masiysN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) [which seems to signify either The want of him, or it, was difficult of accomplishment, or distressing; or the want was difficult of accomplishment, or distressing, to him]. (S, K,. [In both these lexicons, the meaning is left to be inferred only from the fact that this phrase immediately follows the explanation of HaAjapN maAsRapN, q. v.]) ― -b7- [masRa is also said of what is good, as well as of what is evil; as in the following instance:] masRatohu mawaAsRu Alxayori waAlXRarRi (tropical:) [The haps of good fortune, and of evil,] happened to him, or betided him. (TA.) ― -b8- [As touching implies proximity,] masRato bika raHimu fulaAnK signifies (tropical:) The relationship of such a one is near to you. (S, K, * TA.) ― -b9- And as masRa originally signifies “ he touched or felt with the hand, ” it is used metaphorically as meaning (tropical:) He took a thing; as, for instance, (in a trad.,) water from a miyDaOap. (TA.) ＝ -A2- masRa is made doubly trans. by means of the prep. bi prefixed to the second objective complement. (Msb.) See 4, in two places.

3 maAosasa
3: see 1, in two places: and see laA masaAsi.

4 UmsRhu AlXRaIoCa c
4. UmsRhu AlXRaIoCa He made him, or caused him, to touch the thing: (S, * IJ, M, A: *) he enabled him to touch it. (Mgh.) ― -b2- OamasRa Aljasada maMCF, and Aljasada bimaMCK masRa↓, (tropical:) He wetted the body with water; or caused water to wet the body. (Msb.) And OamasRa wajohahu AlTRiyba (tropical:) He smeared his face with the perfume. (Mgh.) And OamasRatohu EaAriDayohaA, and biEaAriDayohaA masRatohu↓, (tropical:) She smeared the sides of her cheeks with it; namely, perfume. (Mgh.) ― -b3- OamasRahu XakowaI (tropical:) He made a complaint to him. (M, TA.)

6 tmAsRA c
6. tmAsRA They (two bodies) touched each other; were, or became, in contact. (M, A, * K, *) ― -b2- Hence, (K,) (tropical:) They two came together in the way of mubaADaEap: (S, Msb, * K: *) in this sense the verb is used in the Kur, lviii. 4 and 5. (S, TA.) See also masRahaA.

masRN c
masRN: see 1. ― -b2- It is used to denote [the first sensible effect of] anything annoying or hurtful that befalls a man. (TA.) Thus in the Kur, [liv. 48,] (TA,) cuwquwA masRa saqara (tropical:) Taste ye the first effect upon you of the fire of hell: (K, TA:) or the stroke thereof: (Jel:) or the heat and pain thereof. (Bd.) In like manner you say, (K,) wajada masRa AlHumRaI (M, K) (tropical:) He felt the commencement, or first touch, [or access,] of fever, before its taking him forcibly, and becoming apparent. (M, L.) And lamo yajido masRFA mina AlnRaSabi (tropical:) He did not feel the first sensation of fatigue. (TA, from a trad.) [And hence,] bihi masRN mina Aljunuwni (tropical:) [In him is a touch, or stroke, of madness, or insanity, or diabolical possession]: (S, TA:) and masRN, alone, signifies madness, or insanity, or diabolical possession: (M, A, * Mgh, K:) as in the Kur, ii. 276: (TA:) and you say bihi masRN in him is madness, &c.: (A, * Mgh:) for they assert that the devil touches one and his intellect in consequence becomes confused. (Mgh.) ― -b3- You say also, huwa Hasanu AlmasRi fiI maAlihi (tropical:) He has the impress of a good state, or condition, in his camels, or sheep, or goats: and raOayotu lahu masRFA fiI maAlihi (tropical:) I saw him to have an impress of a good state, or condition, in his camels, &c.: like as you say UiSobaEFA. (A, TA.)

laA masaAsi c
laA masaAsi, (S, M, K,) like qaTaAmi, (S, K,) indecl., with kesr for its termination, because altered from the inf. n. masRN, (S,) signifies [properly There shall be no touching: or] touch not thou: (K:) or touch not thou me: (M:) and some read thus in the Kur, [xx. 97:] (M, K:) it is a saying of the Arabs: (S:) and sometimes one says masaAsi [alone], in the sense of an imperative, [affirmatively,] like daraAki and nazaAli: (K:) but laA misaAsa↓, in the Kur, [ubi supra,] (S, M, K,) accord. to the reading of others, (M,) signifies There shall be no mutual touching: (M:) or I will not touch nor will I be touched. (S, K.)

laA misaAsa c
laA misaAsa: see laA masaAsi.

masuwsN c
masuwsN (tropical:) Water that is reached by the hands; or taken with the extended hands: (M, K, * TA:) in the K, naAlatohu is put by mistake for tanaAwalatohu [which is the reading in the M]: (TA:) accord. to which explanation, it has the signification of a pass. part. n.: (M:) or, [in the K and,] (tropical:) wholesome water, (A, TA,) that removes thirst, or the heat of thirst, as soon as it touches it: (M, A, * K, * TA:) accord. to which explanation, it has the signification of an act. part. n.: (M:) and (assumed tropical:) anything that cures thirst, or the heat of thirst: (IAar, K:) or, [in the K, and,] (assumed tropical:) water between sweet and salt: (S, K:) or, [in the K and,] (assumed tropical:) sweet and clear water: (As, K:) and (assumed tropical:) salt, or bitter and thick and undrinkable, water, that burns everything by its saltness. (M.) You say also riyqapN masuwsN (tropical:) Some saliva that takes away thirst. (IAar, M.) And kalaON masuwsN (assumed tropical:) Herbage that has a fattening and beneficial effect upon the animals that pasture on it. (AHn, M.) ― -b2- Also, i. q. faAdozahorN [The bezoar-stone]: (K:) or tiroyaAqN [an antidote against poison]: (M:) or both these words by which it is explained mean the same thing. (TA.)

masRaAsapN c
masRaAsapN: see maAsRahN.

HaAjapN maAsRapN c
HaAjapN maAsRapN (assumed tropical:) A want difficult of accomplishment; or pressing; syn. muhimopN. (S, K.) ― -b2- raHimN maAsRapN (tropical:) Near relationship; (S, M, A, * K;) as also masRaAsapN↓. (TA.) ― -b3- [Also, as a subst., sing. of mawaAsRN, of which an ex. has been given above, (see 1,) signifying Haps of good fortune, and of evil.]

mamosuwsN c
mamosuwsN A man in whom is a touch, or stroke, (masRN,) of madness, insanity, or diabolical possession: (S, TA:) or mad, insane, or possessed by a devil. (AA, M, A, Mgh, K.)

1 masaOa AlTRariyqa c
1. masaOa AlTRariyqa He went along the middle of the road; (K;) or the hard and elevated part (maton) of the road. (TA.) ― -b2- masaOa He was slow, or tardy. (K.) ― -b3- masaOa HaqRahu He delayed giving him his due. (K, TA.) ― -b4- masaOa Alqidora He stilled, or allayed, the boiling of the pot. (K.) ― -b5- masaOahu biAlqawoli He soothed, or softened, him by words. (K.) ― -b6- masaOa He beguiled, or deceived. (K.) ― -b7- masaOa EalaI XaIoCK, (K,) inf. n. masoCN, (TA,) He became accustomed, or inured to a thing. (K.) ＝ -A2- masaOa bayonahumo and AmsO↓, He excited discord between them. (K, TA.) ― -b2- masaOa, (S, K,) aor.
masaAa
, (K,) inf. n. masoCN (S, K) and musuwCN, (K,) He was hard, or impudent, and rude; not caring for what one said, or did to him. (AZ, S, K.)

4 OamosaAa
4: see 1.

5 tmsRO c
5. tmsRO It (a garment) rent, or became ragged and worn out. (IB, K.)

masoCN c
masoCN The middle of a road. (K.) [See 1, and see misoHN.]

maAsiYN c
maAsiYN Hard, or impudent, and rude; not caring for what one says or does to him. (AZ, S.) Perhaps maAsK is from this: (see art. msI:) or perhaps it is formed by transposition from maAYisN: see art. mys. (AM.)

1 masaHa XayoYFA c
1. masaHa XayoYFA, aor.
masaHa
, inf. n. masoHN; and msRHhu↓, inf. n tamosiyHN; He wiped a thing that was wet or dirty, with his hand, or passed his hand over it to remove the wet or dirt that was upon it: (L:) masoHN and tamosiyHN and tamasRuHN↓ signifying the passing the hand over a thing that is flowing [with water or the like], or dirtied, soiled, or polluted, to remove the fluid or dirt, or soil or pollution; (L, K;) as when one wipes his head with his hand to remove water; and his forehead, to remove sweat. (L.) [It often signifies He stroked a thing with his hand; as, for instance, the Black Stone of the Kaabeh; see below.] ― -b2- masaHa raOosahu mina AlmaMCi; and jabiynahu AlrRaXaHi; He wiped his head with his hand to remove the water that was upon it; and his forehead to remove the sweat. (L.) ― -b3- masaHa biraOosihi (S) He wiped with his hand, or passed his hand closely over, his head, or a part thereof, without making any water to flow upon it: so in the Kur, v. 8; where it is said, faQgosiluwA wujuwhakumo waOayodiyakumo UilaI QlomaraAfiqi waQmosaHuwA biruWuwsikumo waOarojulakumo UilaI QlokaEobayoni: here Oarojulakumo is in the acc. case as an adjunct to Aydykm; [i.e., as a third objective complement to the verb AgslwA; not as an adjunct to rWwskm;] but some read Oarojulikumo, putting it in the gen. case because of its proximity to rWwskm; (Jel;) [in like manner as xaribK is put in the gen. case in the phrase hecaA juHoru DabRK xaribK, an ex. given by many of the grammarians, showing that this is allowable in prose,] notwithstanding that it is said, by Aboo-Is-hák the grammarian, that the putting a noun in the gen. case because of its proximity to a preceding noun in that case is not allowable except in poetry, when necessity requires it: (L:) the head, which is wiped, is mentioned between the arms and the feet, which are washed, to show the order which is to be observed in the purification. (Jel.) But masaHa signifies both he wiped with the hand, and also he washed: so says IAth: (L:) and AZ and IKt say the like: (Msb:) you say masaHotu yadaIRa bAlmaMCi, meaning I washed my hands with water. (AZ, Msb.) ― -b4- masaHa XayoYFA biAlmaMCi He wiped a thing with his hand wetted with water; passed his hand, wetted with water, over a thing. (Msb.) ― -b5- masaHa Albayot He compassed the House [of God, i.e. the Kaabeh: because he who does so passes his hand over the corner in which is the Black Stone]. (L.) ― -b6- masaHa QllRehu Eanoka maA bika May God remove that which is in thee! (L;) or, wash and cleanse thee from thy sins! (TA, art. mSH.) A prayer for a sick person. (L, from a trad.) ― -b7- masaHahu He anointed him or it with oil. (A.) ― -b8- musiHa biAlkarami, inf. n. masoHN, (tropical:) He was characterized by somewhat, or by some sign or mark, of nobility. (L.) [See masoHapN.] ― -b9- masaHa, inf. n. masoHN, He combed and dressed hair; syn. maXaTa. (K.) ― -b10- masoHu AllRuHiIa [The stroking of the beards] was a sign of reconciliation. (S, O, in art. Eq: see Eaqu biAlsRahomi.) ― -b11- masaHahu, or masaHahu biAlmaEoruwfi, i. e. bAlmErwf mina Alqawoli, (L,) inf. n. masoHN; (L, K;) and msRHhu↓, (L,) inf. n. tamosiyHN; (L, K;) He spoke to him good words, deceiving, or beguiling, him therein, (L, K,) and giving him nothing. (L.) ― -b12- fulaAnN yamosaHu raOosa zayodK (tropical:) Such a one beguiles, or deceives, Zeyd. (A.) [See also 3.] ― -b13- masaHa, inf. n. masoHN and tamosaAHN He lied; uttered what was false. (K.) ― -b14- masaHa fiI AlOaroDi, inf. n. musuwHN, He set forth journeying through the land, or earth: (A'Obeyd, K: *) as also maSaHa. (TA.) ― -b15- masaHahumo (tropical:) He passed lightly by them, or brushed by them, without remaining by them. (L.) ― -b16- masiHa, [aor.
masaHa
,] inf. n. masaHN, The inner sides of his (a man's, S) thighs rubbed together, (S, L, K,) so as to become sore and chapped: (L:) or he had the inner side of his knee inflamed by the roughness of his garment. (L, K.) ― -b17- masaHa AlUibila, inf. n. masoHN (tropical:) He made the camels to journey all the day long: and he made the backs of the camels to be wounded by the saddles, and emaciated them; as also masRaHahaA↓, inf. n. tamosiyHN: (K:) and in the latter sense you say masaHa AlnRaAqapa, and msRHhA↓. (TA.) ― -b18- masaHati AlUibilu yawomahaA (tropical:) The camels journeyed all the day. (S.) masaHati AlUibilu AlOaroDa yawomahaA daOobFA (tropical:) The camels journeyed all the day laboriously. (TA.) ＝ -A2- masaHa, (S,) inf. n. masoHN (K) and misaAHapN, (S, K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) (tropical:) He measured land. (S, K.) ＝ -A3- masaHa, inf. n. masoHN, (tropical:) He cut, or severed: and he struck, or smote: (K:) he severed the neck, and the arm. (TA.) masaHa Eunuqahu and biEunuqihin, aor.
masaHa
, inf. n. masoHN, He smote his neck: or, as some say, severed it, or cut it through. Agreeably with both these significations masoHFA is rendered in the Kur, xxxviii. 32: some say that what is here meant is the wiping with the hand wetted with water: accord. to IAth, Solomon is here said to have smitten the necks and hock-tendons of the horses. (L.) [See art. Tfq.] masaHahu biAlsRayofi He smote him with the sword: (L:) and he cut him with the sword: (S, L:) or masaHahu signifies he struck him gently with a staff, or stick, and with a sword. (TA in art. dhn.) ― -b2- See 8. ― -b3- Also masaHahumo He slew them. (L.) ＝ -A4- masaHahu, (inf. n. masoHN, K,) He (God) created him blessed, (AHeyth, K,) and goodly: (AHeyth:) ― -b2- and, contr., created him accursed, (AHeyth, K,) and foul, or ugly. (AHeyth.) ＝ -A5- masaHa, (S,) inf. n. masoHN, (K,) (tropical:) Inivit feminam. (S, K.)

2 masRaHa
2: see 1, in four places.

3 mAsHhu c
3. mAsHhu (tropical:) He took him by the hand; applied the palm of his hand to the palm of the other's hand. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He made a compact, or covenant, with him. (TA.) ― -b3- maAsaHaA (tropical:) They used blandishing, soothing, or wheedling, words, one to the other, deceiving thereby; (K;) their hearts not being sincere. (TA.) You say gaDiba famaAsaHotuhu HatRaI laAna (tropical:) He was angry, and I coaxed, or wheedled, him until he became gentle, or mild. (TA.) [See also 1.]

5 tmsRH biAlmaMCi c
5. tmsRH biAlmaMCi He washed himself with water. (A, Z.) ― -b2- tmsRH (tropical:) He performed the ablution called AlwuDuwoC. (IAth.) ― -b3- tmsRH biAlOaroDi (S, L) (tropical:) He performed the action termed AltRayamRum: or he made his forehead to touch the ground in prostration, without anything intervening. (L.) ― -b4- fulaAnN yutamasRaHu bivawobihi (tropical:) Such a one has his garment passed over men's persons as a means of their advancing themselves in the favour of God: (L:) [i.e., he is a holy man, from the touch of whose garment a blessing is derived: see St. Matthew's Gospel, ix., 20 and 21]. fulaAnN yutamasRaHu bihi (tropical:) Such a one is a person by means of whom one looks for a blessing (butabarRaku bihi,) by reason of his excellence, (K,) and his devotion; (TA;) as though one advanced himself in the favour of God by approaching him. (L.) [See also an ex. voce rukonN.] ― -b5- fulaAnN yatamasRaHu (tropical:) Such a one has nothing with him, or in his possession; as though he wiped his arms with his hands: (K:) [for it is a custom of the Arabs to do thus as an indication of having nothing.] ― -b6- tmsRH He wiped himself, mino XaIoCK to remove a thing, and biXaIoCK, with a thing. (L.) [See also 1.]

6 tamaAsaHaA c
6. tamaAsaHaA (tropical:) They acted in a friendly or sincere manner, one to the other; syn. taSaAdaqaA: or they made a contract, or bargain, one with the other, and each struck the palm of the other's hand with the palm of his own hand [to confirm it], (K,) and swore to the other. (TA.) ― -b2- tamaAsaHuwA (tropical:) They took one another by the hand. (TA.)

8 AmtsH c
8. AmtsH He drew a sword (K) from its scabbard; as also masaHa↓. (TA.)

masoHN c
masoHN i. q. balaAsN; (S, K;) i.e., A garment of thick, or coarse, hair-cloth: so in the T: and a piece of such stuff as is spread in a house or tent: (TA:) a blAs such as is worn by monks: (Mgh:) a kisaMC of hair-cloth: (L:) an old and worn-out garment: (Kull:) pl. OamosaAHN and musuwHN; (S;) the former a pl. of pauc., and the latter a pl. of mult. (L.) ― -b2- misoHN The main part, and middle, of a road; syn. jaAdRapN: (K:) pl. OamosaAHN (TA) and musuwHN. (K.)

masaHN c
masaHN, a subst., Paucity of flesh in the posteriors and thighs; or smallness of the buttocks, and their sticking together; or paucity of flesh in the thighs; syn. rasaHN. (L.)

EalaI fulaAnK masoHapN mino jamaAlK c
EalaI fulaAnK masoHapN mino jamaAlK, (S, K,) or misoHapN↓, (L,) (tropical:) Upon such a one there appears somewhat of beauty; (L, K;) or, some sign, or mark, or trait, of beauty: (L:) and msHpu karamK, some sign, or mark, trait, or indication, of nobility; and the like: a mode of expression said, by Sh, to be used only in praise; so that you do not say Ealayohi msHpu quboHK: (L:) but you say also bihi msHpN mino huzaAlK in him is somewhat, or some sign, or mark, of leanness; (L, K;) which is a phrase of the Arabs mentioned by Az. (L.) ― -b2- masoHapN in the cheek of a horse: see SifaAHN.

misoHapN c
misoHapN: see masoHapN.

masiyHN c
masiyHN Anointed: wiped over with some such thing as oil. (K.) ― -b2- A king. (El-'Eynee.) ― -b3- AlmasiyHu [The Messiah, the Christ, the Anointed,] Jesus, on whom be peace! (S, Msb, K,) [correctly] an arabicized word, [from the Hebrew,] originally maXiyHaA, with X: (T, Msb:) but the learned differ as to this word, whether it be Arabic or arabicized: F relates, in the K, his having mentioned, in his Expos. of the Meshárik el-Anwár, fifty opinions respecting the derivation of it; and in another work he has made the number fifty-six. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, (K,) or AlmasiyHu AlkacRaAbu, (S,) or AlmisRiyHu↓, (K,) [The Messiah, or Christ, surnamed the Great Liar; the False Christ; Antichrist; also called] EdDejjál, AldRajRaAlu: (S, K:) it is not allowable, however, to apply to him the appellation AlmasiyHu without restriction; wherefore one says AlmasiyHu AldRajRaAlu [or AlkacRaAbu]; (TA;) [unless in a case like the following, in which] a poet says
UicaA AlmasiyHu yaqotulu AlmasiyHa
[When the true Messiah shall slay the false Messiah] (Msb.) [Many opinions respecting the derivation of the appellation thus applied are also mentioned by various authors.] ― -b5- masiyHN Sweat: (T, S, K:) so called because it is wiped off (yumosaHu) when it pours forth. (T.) ― -b6- masiyHN (tropical:) A dirhem [or silver coin] of which the impression is obliterated; syn. OaTolasu; (S, Msb, K;) having no impression. (Msb.) ― -b7- masiyHN (S, K) and masiyHapN↓ (TA) A piece of silver. (As, S, K.) ― -b8- masiyHN. (tropical:) i. q. mamosuwHu Alwajohi, (K,) i.e., A man having one side of his face plain, without eye or eyebrow: said to apply in this sense to EdDejjál, among others. (IF, L.) ― -b9- One-eyed. (Az.) [See also OamosaHu.] ― -b10- masiyHN A rough napkin, or kerchief, with which one wipes himself: (L, K:) so called because the face is wiped with it, or because it retains the dirt. (TA.) [A dusting-cloth, or dish-clout, or the like, is now called mimosaHapN↓.] ― -b11- masiyHN Beautiful in the face. (TA.) ― -b12- masiyHN One who journeys or goes about much for the sake of devotion, or as a devotee; as also misRiyHN↓ (K,) and OamosaHu↓, (TA,) the fem. of which is masoHaMCu. (K, TA.) See masRaAHN. ＝ -A2- masiyHN (tropical:) Multum coiens; as also maAsiHN↓. (K.) ― -b2- masiyHN Erring greatly. (TA.) ― -b3- masiyHN A great liar; one who lies much; as also maAsiHN↓ and mimosaHN↓ (K) and timosaHN↓ (Lh, K) and OamosaHu↓, (TA,) the fem. of which last is masoHaMCu. (K, TA.) See maAsiHN. ＝ -A3- masiyHN Very veracious; syn. SidRiyqN: (K, L, TA: in the CK SadiyqN:) a meaning unknown to many of the lexicologists, and probably obsolete in their time. (L.) ＝ -A4- masiyHN Created blessed, and goodly; (L;) created (mamosuwHN) with blessing, or prosperity: (K:) ― -b2- and, contr., created accursed, and foul, or ugly; (L;) created with unfortunateness. (K.)

misaAHapN c
misaAHapN (tropical:) Mensuration of land. (Msb.) [See also 1.] ― -b2- See also takosiyrN.

masiyHapN c
masiyHapN i. q. cuWaAbapN, [a portion, or lock, of hair hanging down loosely from the middle of the head to the back; or the hair of the fore part of the head; the hair over the forehead; or the part whence that hair grows; or a plait of hair hanging down; &c.]: (S, L, K:) or hair that is left without its being dressed with oil or anything else: or that part of a man's head that is between the ear and the eyebrow, rising to the part below that where the sutures of the scull unite: or that part of the side of the hair upon which a man puts his hand, next to his ear: or the hair of each side of the head: pl. masaAYiHu: or msAYH signifies the place which a man wipes with his hand: or, accord. to As, the hair: or, accord. to Sh, the hair which one wipes with his hand, upon his cheek and his head. (L.) ― -b2- See masiyHN. ＝ -A2- masiyHapN A bow: (S, K:) or an excellent bow: (L.) pl. masaAYHu. (S, K.)

masRaAHN c
masRaAHN (tropical:) A measurer of land; (TA;) as also masiyHN↓. (L.)

misRiyHN c
misRiyHN and AlmisRiyHu: see masiyHN.

bihi maAsiHN c
bihi maAsiHN He (a camel) has a fretting of the edge of the callosity upon his breast, produced by his elbow, without making it bleed: if he make it bleed, you say bihi HaAzRN: (S, L:) and he has a chafing of his arm-pit produced by his elbow, but not violent, by reason of the disease called DaAgiT. (L.) ― -b2- See masiyHN. ― -b3- maAsiHN and masiyHN↓ A great slayer; one who slays much, or many. (Az, L.)

maAsiHapN c
maAsiHapN A woman who combs and dresses hair; syn. maAXiTapN. (S.)

OamosaHu c
OamosaHu A flat place, with small pebbles, and without plants, or herbage. (S.) ― -b2- masoHaMCu A plain tract of land, with small pebbles, (S, K,) and without plants, or herbage: (S:) [ex.] mararotu bixariyqK mina AlOaroDi biyona masoHaAwayoni [I passed by a depressed tract of land containing herbage between two plain tracts containing small pebbles and without herbage]: (Fr, S:) or a piece of flat ground, bare, abounding with pebbles, containing no trees nor herbage, rugged, somewhat hard, like a flat place in which camels &c. are confined, or in which dates are dried, not what is termed qufR, nor what is termed saholap: (ISh:) pl. masaAHK and masaAHI [i. e. masaAHaI or masaAHiIRu]; pl. forms proper to substs.; as it is an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (L.) ― -b3- Also masoHMCu Red land. (K.) ― -b4- masoHaMCu A woman having little flesh in her posteriors and thighs; or foul, ugly, or unseemly; syn. rasoHaMCu. (S.) [In the K., AlOaroDu AlrRasoHaMCu, given as an explanation of AlmasoHaMCu, is an evident mistake for AlmaroOapu AlrRasoHaMCu, as observed by Freytag.] ― -b5- OamosaHu, or OamosaHu Alqadami, A man having a flat sole to his foot, without any hollow: (L:) fem. masoHaMCu: (L, K:) and masiyHN↓, or Alqadamayoni masiyHu↓, signifies the same: and also having smooth and soft feet, without fissures or chaps, so that they repel water when it falls upon them. (L.) ― -b6- Also masoHaMCu, (K,) or msHMCu AlvRadoIi, (L,) A woman whose breast has no bulk. (L, K.) ― -b7- Also masoHaMCu A one-eyed woman: [see also masiyHN:] and such as is termed bixoqaMCu, whose eye is not mulawRazap: so in [most of] the copies of the K., but in some, bilRaworap: (TA:) [the meaning seems to be whose eye has no crystalline humour]. ― -b8- OamosaHu A man having little flesh in his posteriors and thighs; or having small buttocks sticking together; syn. ArsH: fem. masoHaMCu: pl. musoHN. (L.) ― -b9- OamosaHa A man (S) having the inner sides of his thighs rubbing together (S, L, K)
so as to become sore and chapped: (L:) or having the inner side of his knee inflamed by the roughness of his garment: (L, K:) fem. masoHaMCu, and pl. musoHN. (L.) ― -b10- gaArapN masoHaMCu (tropical:) A hostile attack, or incursion, by a troop of horse, in which the attacking party passes lightly by the party attacked, or brushes by them, without remaining by them. (L, from a trad.) ― -b11- See masiyHN.

OamosaH c
OamosaH [app. used as a subst., and therefore with, or without, tenween,] A flat tract of land: pl. OamaAsiHu. (TA.) ― -b2- A smooth desert; or smooth waterless desert. (Lth.)

OumosuwHN c
OumosuwHN Any long piece of wood in a ship: (K:) pl. OamaAsiyHN. (TA.)

mimosaHN c
mimosaHN and mimosaHapN: see masiyHN.

mamosuwHu AlOaloyatayoni c
mamosuwHu AlOaloyatayoni Having the buttocks cleaving to the bone, and small. (L.) ― -b2- mamosuwHN A eunuch whose testicles have been extirpated. (TA.) ― -b3- EaDudN mamosuwHapN An arm, from the shoulder to the elbow, having little flesh. (TA.) ― -b4- mamosuwHu A thing foul, or ugly, and unfortunate, and changed from its proper form, or make. (TA.) [See art. msx.]

timosaHN c
timosaHN A dissembler; a deceiver; (K;) one who blandishes, soothes, or wheedles, one with his words, and deceives him. (TA.) ― -b2- timosaHN An audacious, or insolent, and wicked, or corrupt, man: (L, K:) or a great liar, who, if asked, will not tell thee truly whence he comes; who lies to thee even as to the place whence he comes. (L.) [See also masiyHN.] ― -b3- See timosaAHN.

timosaAHN c
timosaAHN, (S, Msb, K,) and timosaHN↓, (Msb, K,) the latter app. a contraction of the former, (Msb,) [The crocodile]; a well-known aquatic animal, (S,) a creature like the tortoise, of great size, found in the Nile of Egypt and in the river Mihrán, (K,) which is the river of Es-Sind; (TA;) or [rather] resembling the waral about five cubits long, and less; that seizes men and oxen, and dives into the water with them and devours them: pl. of the former tamaAsiyHN, and of the latter tamaAsiHu. (Msb.)

1 masaxahu c
1. masaxahu, (S, K,) aor.
masaxa
, (K,) inf. n. masoxN, (S,) He transformed him, or metamorphosed him, (S, Msb, K,) into a worse, or more foul, or more ugly, shape. (S, K.) Ex. masaxahu QllRehu qirodFA God transformed him into an ape. (S, K.) [See Kur, xxxvi. 67.] ― -b2- masaxa XiEorFA He took and transformed poetry; accord. to the most common usage, by the substitution of what is synonymous with the original, wholly or partly; but sometimes by altering the meanings. (M, F.) See 1 (last sentence) in art. slx. ― -b3- masaxa AlkaAtibu The writer corrupted what he wrote by changing the diacritical points and altering the meaning. (Msb.) ― -b4- masaxa AlnRaAqapa, (L, K,) aor.
masaxa
, inf. n. masoxN, (L,) (tropical:) He rendered the she-camel lean, and wounded her back, by fatigue and use: (A'Obeyd, L, K:) as also masaHa. (L.) ― -b5- masuxa, [aor.
masuxa
,] inf. n. masaAxapN (assumed tropical:) It (flesh-meat, and fruit,) was, or became, tasteless, or insipid: it (food) had no salt nor colour nor taste: and, sometimes, it was between sweet and bitter. (L.) ― -b6- masaxa TaEomahu (assumed tropical:) It caused its taste to depart; took away its taste. (S.)

4 Amsx c
4. Amsx It (a humour) became dissolved. (L, K.)

7 UimRasaxati AlEaDudu c
7. UimRasaxati AlEaDudu, [or Uinomasaxat, the original form,] The arm, between the shoulder and the elbow, became lean. (L.) UinomisaAxu HamaApi Alfarasi Lankness of the muscle of the thigh (sAq) called] the HmAp of the horse (S, K) is disliked. (S.) [In some copies of the S, this is omitted.]

masoxN c
masoxN and masiyxN↓, (L, K,) [the former originally an inf. n., and therefore used as sing. and dual and pl. without alteration, though musuwxN is used as a pl. by late writers, (see De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., ii. 273,)] the latter of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (L,) Transformed, or metamorphosed, into a worse, or more foul, or more ugly, shape. (L, K.) Ex. AljaAnRu masoxu AljinRi The Jánn, which are slender serpents, are the transformed of the Jinn, or Genii; like as certain persons of the Children of Israel were transformed into apes. [See Kur, ii. 61.] (L, from a trad.) ― -b2- Also, the ↓latter, Deformed; rendered ugly in make, or form. (K.) Hence, some say, the appellation of AldRajRaAlu Almasiyxu↓ [more commonly AlmasiyHu AldRjRAn, q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, the same, (tropical:) A man having no beauty. (S, K.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) Weak and stupid: (K:) also an epithet applied to a man. (TA.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) Flesh-meat, (S, L, K,) and fruit, (L, K,) that has no taste; tasteless; insipid: (S, L, K:) or, applied to food, that has no salt nor colour nor taste: and sometimes, that is between sweet and bitter. (L.) El-Ash'ar Er-Rakabán, of the tribe of Asad, a Jáhilee, says, addressing a man named Ridwán, (L,)
masiyxN maliyxN kalaHomi AlHuwaA
ri laA Oanota HulowN walaA Oanota murRN
[Tasteless, insipid, like the flesh of a new-born camel, thou art not sweet nor art thou bitter]. (S, L.)

masaxN c
masaxN Leanness of the arm, between the shoulder and the elbow. (L.)

masiyxN c
masiyxN: see masoxN.

maAsixiIRN c
maAsixiIRN A bow-maker. (S, L, K.) AHn says, that maAsixapu, a man of the tribe of Azd, of Es-Saráh, is asserted to have been a bowmaker: and Ibn-El-Kelbee says, that he was the first of the Arabs who made bows; that the people of Es-Saráh who made bows and arrows were numerous, because of the abundance of trees in their district, and hence every bowmaker in after times received the above appel-lation. (L.) ― -b2- maAsixiyRapN (L, K) and maAsixiyRaAtN (S, L) Bows: so called in relation to the abovementioned bow-maker, Másikhah of the tribe of Azd: (S, L, K:) Másikhah was his surname, and his name was Nubeysheh the son of El- Hárith, one of the sons of Nasr the son of Azd. (TA.)

huwa Oamasaxu mino laHomi AlHuwaAri c
huwa Oamasaxu mino laHomi AlHuwaAri [He, or it, is more tasteless, or insipid, than the flesh of the newborn camel]: i.e., he, or it, has no taste. A proverb. (S.)

mamosuwxN c
mamosuwxN A horse, having little flesh in the rump, or buttocks: and mamosuwxapN AlEajuzi A woman having little flesh in her posteriors: (K:) but the more approved pronunciation is with H. (TA.)

1 masada c
1. masada, aor.
masuda
, (S, M, L,) inf. n. masodN, (S, M, L, K,) He twisted a rope: (M, L, K:) or he twisted it well. (ISk, S, L.) ― -b2- masada, aor.
masuda
, (M, L,) inf. n. masodN, (S, M, L, K,) He pursued a journey laboriously, or with energy; or he held on, or continued, the journey; syn. OadoOaba AlsRayora, (S, M, L, K,) by night: (S, M, L:) or he journeyed on continually, whether by night or by day: (M, L:) because the so journeying renders an animal lean, or lank. (Lth, L.) ― -b3- masada, aor.
masuda
, [inf. n. masodN,] (tropical:) It (leguminous herbage, A, or continued travel, Lth) rendered an animal lean, lank, light of flesh, slender, or lank in the belly. (Lth, A, L.) El-'Abdee says, describing a she-camel, and likening her to a wild bull,
yamosuduhu Alqaforu walayolN sadiI
The bare and waterless desert renders him lean, &c., and dewy night. (L.) ― -b4- musida, inf. n. masodN, (tropical:) It (the belly) was, or became, soft, of small dimensions, even, and without any ugliness. (M, L.) ― -b5- The following expression of Ru-beh,
yamosudu OaEolaI laHomihi wayaOorimuhu
means (tropical:) It (the milk of camels) strengthens the
upper parts of his flesh, (referring to a pastor, not to an ass, as J says, IB, L,) and renders it, firm. (L.) ― -b6- Hasanapu Almasodi, applied to a damsel, (tropical:) i. q. mamosuwdapN, q. v. (S, L.)

masadN c
masadN The fibres that grow at the roots of the branches of the palm-tree; syn. liyfN: (S, A, L:) you say HabolN mino masadK a rope, or halter, of those fibres: (S, A:) also, masadN alone signifies a rope of those fibres: (S, M, L, K:) or, of those of the [kind of palm-tree called] muqol: (Zj, L, K:) or, of the leaves of the palm-tree: or, of the soft hair of the camel: (S, M, L: [see an ex. voce zaAhiqN:]) or, of other hair: or, of wool: or, of hides: (M, L:) or, of camels' hides: (S, L:) or, of plants: or, of the bark of a tree: (L:) or, of any thing: (M, L, K:) or a plaited rope, firmly twisted, (M, L, K,) of any of the materials above mentioned: (M, L:) applied to a rope, it is for mamosuwdN; and is thus similar to nafoDN, meaning mA nufiDa: (L:) pl. OamosaAdN and misaAdN. (M, L, K.) HabolN mino masadK in the Kur, cxi., last verse, is said to mean A chain seventy cubits in length, whereby the woman upon whose neck it is to be put shall be led into hell, (Zj, T, M, L,) firmly twisted of iron; as though it were a rope of iron strongly twisted. (L.) ― -b2- masadN mugaArN (tropical:) A back compact like a rope strongly twisted. (M, L.) ― -b3- masadN An iron axis of a pulley. (M, L, K.)

misaAdN c
misaAdN, a dial. form of misoOabN; (S, L, K;) i. e., A skin for clarified butter: and one for honey: (S, M, L:) a black skin for wine &c. (AA, L.)

saAqN masodaMCu c
saAqN masodaMCu (tropical:) An even, and a goodly, or beautiful, shank. (M, L.)

mamosuwdN c
mamosuwdN (tropical:) A man of well-turned, compact, and slender, make; syn. majoduwlu Alxaloqi; (S, L, K;) i. e., light of flesh; or tall and slender; or of goodly stature; syn. mamoXuwqN; as though twisted; (TA:) a belly soft, of small dimensions, even, and having in it no ugliness. (M, L.) mamosuwdapN, applied to a damsel; (S, K;) the same as the masc. applied to a man; (L, K;) slender; or light of flesh; or tall and slender; or of goodly stature: (L, M:) and, applied to a woman, compact in make; of well-knit frame. (L.)

1 maXRa c
1. maXRa, (S, A,) aor.
maXuXa
, (S,) inf. n. maXRN, (S, A, K,) He wiped his hand with a thing, (S, A, K), or with a rough thing, (As, S,) and with a napkin, (A,) to cleanse it, (S, A, K,) and to remove its greasiness. (As, S, A, K.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce muDahRabN.] You say also, maXRa Oucunahu, and biOucunihi, He wiped his ear. (TA.) And OumoXuXo muxaATaka Wipe thou away the mucus of thy nose. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He wiped an arrow, and a bow-string, with his garment, to make it soft. (A, TA. *) ＝ -A2- maXRa, (Lth, A, Mgh,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (K,) He sucked, (Lth, A, Mgh,) a bone, (A,) or the heads, or extremites, of bones, (Mgh, K,) [i. e.] what are termed muXaAX, they being chewed; (Lth;) as also tmXRXhu↓, (Lth, A, K,) and AmtXRhu↓, and maXomaXahu↓, of which last the inf. n. is maXomaXapN: (TA:) and (TA) AlEaZoma tmXRX↓ he ate the muXaAX [q. v.] of the bone: or he sucked the whole of it; or extracted its marrow; syn. tamakRakahu: (S, TA:) and mXRXhu↓, (TK,) inf. n. tamoXiyXN, (K,) he extracted its marrow; (K, * TA;) as also AmtXRhu↓. (TA.) ― -b2- maXRa AlnRaAqapa, (S,) inf. n. as above, (K,) (assumed tropical:) He milked the she-camel leaving some of the milk in the udder: (S, K: *) and maXRN also signifies (assumed tropical:) the milking to the uttermost; and so UimotiXaAXN↓: (TA:) you say, maA fiI AlDRaroEi AmtXR↓ (assumed tropical:) he took, (K,) i. e. milked, (TA,) all that was in the udder. (K, TA, from Ibn-'Abbád.) ― -b3- huwa yamuXRu maAla fulaAnK, (A, TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) (tropical:) He takes the property of such a one, thing after thing; (A, K, TA;) as also yamuXRu mino maAlihi: (TA:) or the latter, (accord. to one copy of the S,) or mn mAlh yamotaXRu↓, (accord. to other copies of the S, and the TA,) he obtains of his property. (S, TA.)

2 maXRaRa
2: see 1.

4 AmXR c
4. AmXR, (K,) inf. n. UimoXaAXN, (TA,) It (a bone) had in it what might be sucked, or extracted; i. e., (TA,) had in it marrow. (K, TA.)

5 tamaXRaRa
5: see 1, in two places.

8 AmtXR c
8. AmtXR: see 1, in five places. ― -b2- Also, (tropical:) He performed the purification termed UisotanojaMC (IAar, A, K) with a piece of stone or a lump of dry clay or loam. (IAar, K.)

R. Q. 1 maXomaXa c
R. Q. 1. maXomaXa: see 1.

muXaAXN c
muXaAXN The heads of bones, (S, Mgh, K,) that are soft, (S,) that may be chewed, (S, K,) or that are sucked: (Mgh:) or soft bones: (A:) or the heads of bones such as the knees and elbows and shoulder-bones: (A'Obeyd:) and the bone within a horn: (Mgh:) sing. [or rather n. un.] with p: (S, K,) which is also said to signify the prominent part of the shoulder-bone. (TA.) rajulN haXRu AlmuXaAXi rixowu Almagomazi (tropical:) [lit. A man soft, or fragile, in the heads of the bones, flabby where he is felt or pressed,] denotes dispraise. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) The soul, or spirit; syn. nafosN. (S, K.) You say fulaAnN TayRibu AlmuXaAXi (tropical:) Such a one is generous in soul, or spirit. (S, A. *) nahiXu AlmuXaAXi, applied by Aboo-Dhu-eyb to a horse, means (tropical:) Light, or quick, in spirit, or in the bones, or in the legs. (S, TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) Natural disposition. (K, TA.) You say, fulaAnN layRinu AlmuXaAXi (tropical:) Such a one is good in natural disposition; one who abstains from coveting. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) Origin. (K, Ibn-'Abbád.) So in the saying Anh lkrym AlmuXaAXi (tropical:) Verily he is of generous origin: (Ibn-'Abbád, TA:) or this means (tropical:) verily he is a lord, or chief. (A, TA.) [And similar to this is the saying] huwa fiI muXaAXapi↓ qawomihi (tropical:) He is among the best of his people. (A, * TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) Light, sharp, or quick, and who does much service in journeying and at home: (K:) or (assumed tropical:) light in spirit: or (assumed tropical:) one who is a light burden (xafiyfu AlmaWuwnapi) to him who consorts with him: or (assumed tropical:) sharp or quick in motions: and, as some say, xafiyfu AlmaXaAXi means (assumed tropical:) one who does much service in journeying and at home: so accord. to Ibn-'Abbád. (TA.)

maXuwXN c
maXuwXN A napkin, (S, A,) or rough napkin, (TA,) or thing with which to wipe the hand. (S, K.) See 1, first signification.

muXaAXapN c
muXaAXapN: see muXaAXN, in two places.

miXomiXN c
miXomiXN, (S, K,) in the dial. of El-Basrah, (TA,) and maXomaXN↓, (AO, S, K,) in the dial. of El-Koofeh, (TA,) [The apricot;] a certain thing that is eaten; (S;) a well-known fruit; (K;) called in Persian zarodN Aluw [or zarodo Mluw]; (TA.) than which few things are found more productive of cold, or coolness, to the stomach, and befouling, and weakening: (K:) some, (K,) namely, the people of Syria, (TA,) apply this appellation to the UijRaAS [which with others signifies the plum; but with them, the pear]: (K:) so says Lth: and some of the people of Syria pronounce it [muXomusN,] with damm. (TA.)

muXotN c
muXotN [The fist; the hand clinched: a Persian word arabicized]. (Mgh, in art. nXr.) [See an ex. voce tawRN, where it has a redundant n affixed to it.]

1 maXaja c
1. maXaja, aor.
maXuja
, inf. n. maXojN, He mixed, or confused, syn. xalaTa, (K,) one thing with (bi) another. (TK.) ― -b2- maXaja bayonahumaA He made a confusion, or disturbance, (xalaTa,) between them two. (S.)

miXojN c
miXojN and maXajN and maXijN: see maXiyjN.

maXiyjN c
maXiyjN (S, K) and maXaja↓ (K) and like ktf in its two dial. forms, (fiI lugatayohi, K accord. to the
TA,) i. e., maXijN↓ and miXojN↓, or like katifN in a dial. of little authority, (fiI lugayRapK, CK and a MS. copy of the K.) [See maXoyuwHaMCu, in art. Xyj.] A thing mixed, or confused: (S, K:) or any two things mixed together: or any two colours mixed together: or what is a mixture of red and white: (TA:) pl. (of all the above forms, TA) OamoXaAjN. (S, K.) ― -b2- nuTofapN OamoXaAjN, occurring in the Kur, lxxvi. 2, [A drop consisting of] mixtures; meaning the sperma genitale, because it is a mixture of various kinds: (ISk:) or [a drop consisting of] mixtures of sperma genitale and blood: (Zj:) or [a drop consisting of] the sperma genitale of the man mixed with that of the woman and with her blood. (S, K.) ― -b3- Also OamoXaAjN What collect together in the navel. (K.)

1 maXaTa AlXRaEara c
1. maXaTa AlXRaEara, aor.
maXuTa
and
maXiTa
, (M, Msb,) inf. n. maXoTN, (M, Msb, K,) He combed the hair; loosed and separated it with the comb; or combed and dressed it; syn. rajRalahu, (M, K, *) or sarRaHahu: (Msb:) and mXRThu↓ signifies he did so much. (Msb.) You say also maXaTati AlmaAXiTapu AlmaroOapa, aor.
maXuTa
, inf. n. as above, [The mAXTp combed, or combed and dressed, the woman's hair.] (S, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) daAYimu AlmaXoTi is applied to (tropical:) A blandisher, or coaxer. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- maXoTN also signifies The act of mixing. (Fr, K.) You say, maXaTa bayona AlmaMCi waAllRabani [He mixed together the water and the milk]. (TA.)

2 maXRaTa
2: see 1.

8 AmtXT c
8. AmtXT He combed, or combed and dressed, his hair: (Msb, K: *) [and in like manner,] you say of a woman, AmtXTt. (S, TA.)

maXoTN c
maXoTN: see what next follows.

muXoTN c
muXoTN (S, Msb, K,) and miXoTN↓, (Msb, K,) but the latter disapproved by IDrd, (TA,) and maXoTN↓, (K,) and accord. to some with each of the three vowels to the X, but this requires consideration [in other cases than those here following], (MF,) and muXuTN↓ (Ks, K) and muXuTRN↓ (AHeyth, K) and maXiTN↓ (K) and mimoXaTN↓, (IB, K,) of all which the first is the most chaste, (TA,) A comb: pl. OamoXaATN (S, Msb, K,) and miXaATN. (IB, K.) ― -b2- muXoTN mina AlHadiydi A curry comb (miHasRapN): so called by a poet because it has teeth like the muXoT. (TA, art. nmS.) ― -b3- Also muXoTN (tropical:) [An upright loom;] a loom with which one weaves, set upright: (K, TA:) pl. OamoXaATN. (TA.) You say Daraba AlnRaAsiju bimiXoTihi and OamoXaATihi (tropical:) [app. meaning The weaver wove with his upright loom and his upright looms]. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) [The metatarsal bones;] the sulaAmayaAt of the upper part of the foot; (S, K;) i. e. the slender bones spread upon the foot, exclusive of the toes; [also called, more particularly, or perhaps only called, muXoTu Alqadami or muXoTu AlrRijoli:] pl. OamoXaATN. (TA.) You say, Ainkasara muXoTu qadamihi (tropical:) [His metatarsal bones broke]. (TA.) And qaAmuwA EalaI OamoXaATi Oarojulihimo (tropical:) [They stood upon their metatarsal bones]. (TA.) ― -b5- muXoTu Alkatifi (assumed tropical:) The wide bone of the scapula: (S:) or a wide bone thereof: (K:) or the wide flesh thereof: (T, TA:) ― -b6- muXoTN also signifies (assumed tropical:) A certain mark made with a hot iron upon camels, (K,) in the form of a comb, (Sb, TA,) upon the body, and the neck, and the thigh. (Aboo-'Alee, TA.)

miXoTN c
miXoTN: see muXoTN.

maXiTN c
maXiTN: see muXoTN.

muXuTN c
muXuTN: see muXoTN.

muXuTRN c
muXuTRN: see muXoTN.

miXoTapN c
miXoTapN A mode, or manner, of combing, or of combing and dressing the hair. (S, * TA.)

limRapN maXiyTN c
limRapN maXiyTN A lock of hair descending below the lobe of the ear combed, or combed and dressed; i. q. mamoXuwTapN↓. (S, TA.)

muXaATapN c
muXaATapN What falls, of hair, on the occasion of combing, or combing and dressing it. (S, * Msb, K. *)

miXaATapN c
miXaATapN The art, or occupation, of the maAXiTap. (K.)

maXRaATN c
maXRaATN A comb-maker. (TA.) ― -b2- See also maAXiTapN, in two places.

maAsiTapN c
maAsiTapN [A female comber, or comber and dresser, of the hair;] (S;) a female who combs the hair, or combs and dresses it, well; (K;) and [in like manner] maXRaATapN↓ a girl who performs well the art of combing, or combing and dressing, the hair. (TA.) And one of the post-classical writers has used in his poetry the epithet maXRaATN↓ [applied in like manner to a man or boy]. (TA.

OamoXaTu c
OamoXaTu: see mamoXuwTN.

mimoXaTN c
mimoXaTN: see muXoTN.

mamoXuwTN c
mamoXuwTN: fem. with p: see maXiyTN. ― -b2- baEiyrN mamoXuwTN. (assumed tropical:) A camel marked with the mark termed muXoT; (K;) as also OamoXaTu↓. (TA.)

1 maSRahu c
1. maSRahu, (A, Msb,) first pers. maSiSotu, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor. yamaSRu; (S, Msb, K;) and first pers. maSaSotu, aor. yamuSRu; (Msb, K;) but the former is the more chaste; (T, Msb, TA,) inf. n. maSRN; (S, M, Msb;) [He sucked it; or sucked it in; or sipped it, i. e.] he drank it (namely water, A, or a thing, S, M,) with a minute draught, (XurobFA raqiyqFA: so in a copy of the A, and in the CK,) or with a gentle draught: (XurobFA rafiyqFA: so in some copies of the K, and in the TA:) or he took it (namely a small quantity of a fluid) by drawing in the breath: and whether Xariba may be used to denote this, as it is in the K, requires consideration: (MF:) or i. q. raXafahu: (S, K, art. rXf:) or i. q. taraXRafahu: (M:) raXofN signifies the “ taking ” water “ with the lips; ” and is more than maSRN: (Msb, art. rXf:) and AmtSRhu↓ signifies the same; (S, M, A, Msb, K;) and so tmSRShu↓: (M, A:) or the last signifies he did so leisurely. (S, K.) You say, AlrRumRaAna AmtSR↓, i. e. maSRahu [He sucked the pomegranate]; and so of other things. (TA.) And maSRa AljaAriyapa He sucked the damsel's saliva from her mouth. (IAar, in L, art. mSd.) And maSRa mina AldRunoyaA (tropical:) He obtained a little of worldly goods. (TA.)

4 AmSRhu c
4. AmSRhu [He made him to suck: or he gave him to suck]. (S, A, K.) You say OamoSaSotuhu AlmaMCa (A) or AlXRaIoCa (S) [I made him to suck, or I gave him to suck, the water, or the thing]. ― -b2- (tropical:) He said to him yaA maSRaAnu, q. v. (S, * A, TA.) You say, huwa yumiSRuhu wayubaZRiruhu. (K, art. bZr, which see in the present work.)

5 tamaSRaRa
5: see 1, in which two explanations of it are given.

8 UimotaSaSa
8: see 1. in two places.

R. Q. 1 maSomaSa c
R. Q. 1. maSomaSa, (S, A,) or maSomaSa faAhu, (M, TA,) inf. n. maSomaSapN, (S, M, K,) [He rinsed his mouth with water; he agitated water in his mouth; syn. maDomaDa: (M:) or he did so with the extremity of his tongue, (S, M, K,) or with the fore parts of his mouth; (A;) whereas the latter signifies he did so with his mouth altogether; (S, M, A;) the difference between maSomaSapN and maDomaDapN being similar to that between qaboSapN and qaboDapN: (S, M:) the former is mentioned in a trad. as being done after drinking milk; but not after eating dates. (S.) You say also, maSomaSa AlUinaMCa He washed the vessel; (ISk, S, M;) as also maDomaDahu: (ISk, Yaakoob, M:) or he washed out, or rinsed, the vessel; he put water into the vessel, and shook it, to wash it; (As, TA;) he poured water into the vessel, and then shook it,
without washing it with his hand, and then poured it out. (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA.) And maSomaSa AlvRawoba He washed [or rinsed] the garment, or piece of cloth. (M, TA.)

muSRapN c
muSRapN: see what next follows.

muSaASN c
muSaASN What is sucked from, or of, a thing; (M, TA;) as also muSaASapN↓. (M, A, TA.) You say, TaAbato muSaASatuhu fiI famiI What was sucked from it, or of it, was good, or sweet, or pleasant, in my mouth. (A.) ― -b2- [And hence,] The pure, or choice, part of anything; (S, K;) as also muSaAmiSN↓: (K:) and (S) the purest, or choicest, (S, M,) of a thing; as also muSaASapN↓ and muSaAmiSN↓. (M.) And AlmaAli muSRapu↓ signifies the same as muSaASuhu, (K, TA,) i. e. The pure, or choice part of property, or of the property. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN muSaASu qawomihi, (S, M,) and muSaASatuhu↓, (M,) Such a one is the purest in race, or lineage, of his people: and in like manner you say of two, and of more, and of a female. (S, M.) And huwa mino muSaASi qawomihi [He is of the purest, or choicest, of his people]. (A.) ― -b3- Also, Pure, or choice, applied to Hasab [or grounds of pretension to respect, &c.]; as also muSaAmiSN↓. (A.) You say also, UinRahu lamuSaAmiSN fiI qawomihi Verily he is distinguished, or characterized, by pure grounds of respect among his people. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- Also, The origin, source, or place of origination, of a thing. (M, TA.) You say, huwa kariymu AlmuSaASi He is generous, or noble, in respect of origin. (TA.) Accord. to Lth, muSaASu Alqawomi signifies The original source of the people: and the most excellent of their middle class. (TA.)

maSuwSN c
maSuwSN A certain kind of food, (S, K,) of flesh-meat, cooked, and steeped in vinegar; (K;) or, as some say, steeped in vinegar, and then cooked: (TA:) or of the flesh of birds particularly: (K:) pronounced by the vulgar with damm to the m: (S:) but what is said in the Nh implies that it is with damm; for it is there said, “ and it may be with fet-h to the m. ” (TA.)

muSaASapN c
muSaASapN: see muSaASN, in four places.

maSuwSapN c
maSuwSapN: see mamoSuwSapN.

maSRaASN c
maSRaASN: see what next follows.

maSRaAnN c
maSRaAnN A cupper; because he sucks; (M, TA;) and so maSRaASN↓: (K, voce HajRaAmN, which is its syn.:) fem. of the former with p.
