(M.) ― -b2- A man who sucks his ewes or she-goats; by reason of his meanness, or ungenerousness: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) i. e. who sucks from their udders with his mouth; lest the sound of the milking should be heard; as also, maASRu↓; (TA;) and so maloHaAnu and makRaAnu. (A'Obeyd, TA.) [But in the TA it is written maSRaAnu, without tenween; and so in two copies of the S.]) ― -b3- yaA maSRaAnu, [said to a man,] and yaA maSRaAnapu, to a female, denote vituperation, meaning (tropical:) O sucker (maASR S, K) of such a thing, (S, TA,) i. e. (TA) of the baZor [q. v.], (K, TA,) of thy mother: (S, K, TA:) or the meaning is O sucker (raADiE) of the ewes or she-goats: (K:) ISk says, (TA,) you should not say yaA maASRaAnu↓: (S, TA:) but Ibn-'Abbád says, (TA,) one says wayoliI EalaI maASRaAni boni maASRaAnK, and maASRaAnapa boni maASRaAnapa↓, (K, TA,) meaning [Alas for me, on account of] the mean, or ungenerous, the son of the mean, or ungenerous! (TA.)

muSRaAnN c
muSRaAnN, with damm, The sugar-cane; [because it is sucked.] (IKh, IB.)

muSaAmSN c
muSaAmSN: see muSaASN, in four places.

maASRN c
maASRN, act. part. n. of 1: see maSRaAnN, in two places.

maASRaAnu c
maASRaAnu and maASRaAnapu: see maSRaAnN.

waZiyfN mamoSuwSN c
waZiyfN mamoSuwSN (tropical:) A slender pastern; (K, TA;) as though it were sucked. (TA.) And mamoSuwSapN (M, A) and maSuwSapN (AZ, ISk, K) (tropical:) A woman emaciated (AZ, ISk, M, A, K) by reason of a disease infecting her; (AZ, ISk, M;) as though she were sucked. (M, TA.)

1 maSata c
1. maSata, ([aor.
maSuta
,] inf. n. maSotN TA,) Inivit puellam: [K:) dial. form of mSada. (TA.) ― -b2- maSata AlnRaAqapa He laid hold upon the womb of the camel, and put in his hand, and extracted the water [i. e. the semen injected into it]. (M, K.) [See also masaTa.] ― -b3- maSata AlmiEaI He squeezed out what was in the intestine, or gut, with his fingers. (TA.) ― -b4- maSata It (herbage) purged cattle; or relaxed them in the bowels. (Marg. note in a copy of the S.) ― -b5- maSata He squeezed an ulcer, so as to express the matter. (Marg. note in a copy of the S) ― -b6- maSata He sucked saliva. (Marg. note in a copy of the S.)

1 maSaHa c
1. maSaHa, aor.
maSaHa
, inf. n. muSuwHN (and maSoHN, TA), He, or it, (a thing, S,) went away; passed away; departed. (S, K.) ― -b2- It finished; came to an end; ceased. (S, K.) ― -b3- It (a garment) became old and worn-out. (S, K.) ― -b4- It (a plant) became faded in its blossoms. (S, K.) ― -b5- Also, inf. n. muSuwHN, It (a blossom) faded; or lost its colour. (AHn.) ― -b6- maSaHa, (inf. n. muSuwHN, TA,) It (the shade) became short. (S, K.) ― -b7- maSaHa, inf. n. muSuwHN, It (an udder) ceased to have milk. (TA.) ― -b8- It (the milk of a camel) ceased; passed away. (S, K.) ― -b9- maSiHa, aor.
maSaHa
, It (shade) became deficient and thin. So accord. to the K; but in other lexicons, the verb, with reference to shade, is maSaHa. (TA.) ― -b10- maSaHa, inf. n. muSuwHN, It (a writing) became obliterated, or nearly so. (TA.) ― -b11- It (a dwelling) became obliterated; or its vestiges became effaced. (TA.) ― -b12- maSaHa bihi, (S, K,) and OamoSaHahu↓, (IB,) He took away, carried off, or went away with, it; or caused it to go, go away, or pass away. (S, IB, K.) ― -b13- maSaHa fiI AlOaroDi, inf. n. maSoHN, He set forth journeying through the land, or earth: as also masaHa. (ISd.)

4 OamoSaHa
4: see 1.

OamoSaHu c
OamoSaHu Deficient and thin shade. (K.)

1 maSaxa c
1. maSaxa, aor.
maSaxa
, (L,) inf. n. maSoxN; and AmtSx↓ and tmSRx↓; (L, K;) He pulled away a thing (L, K) from the inside of another thing, (L,) and took it: (K:) and maSaxa and AmtSx↓ he pulled away an OumoSuwxap of the kind of plant called vumaAm, or of that called naSiIR, (S, L,) from within another AmSwxp thereof, (L,) and took it: (S, L:) and tmSRx↓ he pulled out the white pith called AmSwxp of the barodiIR. (AHn, L.) ＝ -A2- maSaxa, inf. n. maSoxN, a dial form of masaxa, q. v. (L, K. *)

4 AmSx c
4. AmSx It (a plant of the kind called vumaAm) put forth its OamaASiyx [pl. of OumoSuwxap, q. v.] (K.)

5 tamaSRaxa
5: see 1 in two places.

7 UimRaSaxa c
7. UimRaSaxa, inf. n. UimRiSaAxN, It (a child) became disunited from its mother; (K;) i. e., from the belly of its mother. (L, TA.)

8 AmtSx c
8. AmtSx, It (a thing) became disunited from (Eano) another thing. (TA.) ― -b2- See 1 in two places.

maSuwxapN c
maSuwxapN A ewe or she-goat whose udder is flaccid at the base; (T, K;) as though it were disunited (AmtSxt, i. e. AnfSlt,) from the belly. (T, L.)

muSRaAxN c
muSRaAxN A certain plant having coats (quXuwr) like the onion; (K;) of which Az says, I have seen, in the desert, a plant called muSRaAxN and YudRaMCN
having coats (qXwr), one above another; whenever one peels off one OumoSuwxp (or coat) there appears another; and its coats (qXwr) are an excellent fuel: the people of Haráh (hrAp) call it dlyzAc. (L.)

OumoSuwxapN c
OumoSuwxapN A sheath or coat, of a plant, enveloping, or surrounding, another sheath or coat, and the latter another, and so on: (T, L:) a xawSap of the kind of plant called vumaAm, (S, K,) and of that called naSiIR; (S;) what is plucked from the nSIR, like a rod; (AHn;) [i. e., a sheath of the vmAm or the nSIR;] there is a species of the vmAm having no leaves properly so called, its leaves being sheaths (OanaAbiyb) set one into another, each sheath (Ounobuwbap) of which is called AmSwxp, and when it is pulled away it comes forth from the inside of another, as though it were a stopper taken out from a vessel in which collyrium (kuHol) is kept: (Lth:) pl. OumoSuwxN and OamaASiyxu: (S, K:) the former is a lexicological pl., [or rather a coll. gen. n., of which AmSwxp is the n. un.,] and the latter is the proper pl. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, The white pith of the barodiIR. (AHn.)

1 maSadahaA c
1. maSadahaA, aor.
maSuda
, (M,) inf. n. maSodN, (S, M, L, K,) He sucked her breast (Lth, S, M, L, K) in a certain manner. (S, M, L.) You say, qabRalahaA famaSadahaA He kissed her and sucked her breast. (Lth, L.) ― -b2- maSadahaA, (IAar, L,) inf. n. maSodN; (IAar, L, K;) He sucked her (a damsel's) saliva from her mouth; like maSRahaA, and raXafahaA, and rafRahaA: (IAar, L:) and maSada he sucked (IAar, S, L, K) saliva. (IAar, S, L.) ― -b3- maSadahaA, (S, M, L,) aor.
maSuda
, (M,) inf. n. maSodN, (S, M, L, K,) Inivit eam, (S, M, L, K,) quodam modo; (M;) scil, ancillam suam. (L); as also mazadahaA, inf. n. mazodN. (M.) ＝ -A2- maSada, inf. n. maSodN, He brought under; subdued; rendered submissive; syn. calRala. (K.)

maSodN c
maSodN Thunder. (L, K.) ― -b2- maSodN Rain: (L:) and with p, a shower of rain; a rain: you say, maA OaSaAbatonaA AlEaAma maSodapN, (and mazodapN, TA,) Not a rain has fallen on us this year. (M, L, K.) ― -b3- maSodN Intenseness of cold; (Kr, M, L, K;) as also maSadN↓: (K:) or, simply, cold; (Er-Riyáshee, L;) as also maSodapN↓. (S, M.) And, contr., Intenseness of heat: (Kr, M, L, K:) and maSodapN↓, simply, heat. (AZ, L.) You say, maA wajadonaA lahaA AlEaAma maSodapF, (and mazodapF, ISk, S, M, L,) We have not found it (the earth, AZ,) to have, this year, cold (AZ, S, M, L) nor heat: (AZ, L:) or, intenseness of cold nor intenseness of heat. (Kr, M, L.) ― -b4- maSodN and maSadN↓ and maSaAdN↓ A high (M, K) and red (M) hill, or mountain, such as is called haDobapN: (M, K:) or the last, (As, S, M, K,) and the others also, (M,) the upper part, or top, of a mountain: (As, S, M, K:) and the last, a place of refuge: and applied to a man: (A:) pl. of the last, OamoSidapN and muSodaAnN. (S, M, K.) Az holds the m in mSAd to be augmentative, and the pls. to have been formed on the supposition of its being radical. (L.) See also art. Syd.

maSadN c
maSadN: see maSodN.

maSodapN c
maSodapN: see maSodN.

maSaAdN c
maSaAdN: see maSodN.

2 mSRrhu c
2. mSRrhu He made it (namely a town) a miSor, i. e. a limit, or boundary, between two things. (IAar.) ― -b2- maSRaruwA AlmakaAna, inf. n. tamoSiyrN, They made the place, or appointed it to be, a miSor [meaning a city, or town, such as is thus called]. (M, * K.) It is said of 'Omar, maSRara AlOamoSaAra, (TA,) which is a phrase like madRana Almuduna, (S,) [and signifying He appointed the cities, or towns called OamoSaAr: or] mSRr AlAmSAr signifies he built the [cities, or towns, called] AmSAr: (A:) among which AmSAr were El-Basrah and El-Koofeh. (A, TA.)

5 tmSRr c
5. tmSRr It (a place) became a miSor [meaning a city, or town, such as is thus called]. (M, K.)

miSorN c
miSorN A partition, barrier, or thing intervening, between two things: (S, M, K:) as also maASirN↓: (K:) and (S) or limit, or boundary, between two lands: (M, K:) pl. muSuwrN. (S, M.) The people of Egypt, (S,) or of Hejer, (M,) or of both, (TA,) write in their contracts, (S, M, *) UiXotaraI fulaAnN AldRaAra bimuSuwrihaA Such a one bought the house with its limits, or boundaries. (S, M, * K. *) ― -b2- Hence, A great town; syn. baladN EaZiymN; (Bd, ii. 58;). a kuwrap [here meaning city, or provincial city]: (M, K:) or a kuwrap (Lth, IF, Msb) in which the [ordinances of God which are termed] Huduwd are executed, and (Lth, TA) in which the [spoil or tribute termed] faIoC and the [alms termed] SadaqaAt are divided (Lth, IF, Msb) without consulting the Khaleefeh; such is its signification in the language of the Arabs: (Lth, TA:) or that [town] whereof the greatest of its mosques will not hold, or contain, its inhabitants: (KT:) it is masc. and perfectly decl., and fem. and imperfectly decl.: (Msb:) [but this remark seems properly to relate to the word when used as the name of the metropolis of Egypt, and of Egypt itself, agreeably with what is said in the S, M, and K:] pl. OamoSaArN. (S, M, Msb.) The dual, AlmiSoraAni, is applied to El-Koofeh and El-Basrah. (S, M, A, K.)

maSiyrN c
maSiyrN A gut, an intestine, or a bowel, into which the food passes from the stomach; syn. miEFI: (S, M, Msb, K:) or specially, as some say, of a bird, and of an animal which has a soft foot, or xufR, [as the camel,] and of such as have a cloven hoof: (M, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OamoSirapN (M, K) and [of mult.] muSoraAnN, and pl. pl. maSaAriynu: (S, M, A, Msb, K:) the last accord. to Sb; (M;) but some say that it is not established; (A;) and Lth says, that it is a mistake; but Az says, that it is pl. of muSoraAnN, and that the Arabs have given it this form of pl. imagining the m to be a radical letter; (TA;) and some say, that maSiyrN is of the measure mafoEilN, [originally maSoyirN,] derived from SaAr Uilayohi AlTRaEaAmu [“ the food passed to it ”], and they say muSoraAnN in like manner as they say musolaAnN as pl. of masiylu AlmaMCi, likening mafoEilN to faEiylN: (S, TA:) miSoraAnN also is a dial. form of muSoraAnN. (Fr, Sgh, TA.) [See also maSaArR, in art. Sr.] ― -b2- muSoraAnu AlfaArapi, (S, Msb,) or muSoraAnu AlfaOori, (Mgh, K,) (tropical:) A bad kind of dates. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.)

maASirN c
maASirN: see miSorN; and see maOoSirN, in art. ASr.

1 maDRa c
1. maDRa, (A,) or maDiDa, like fariHa, (K) [but maDiDa, being contr. to rule, is probably a mistranscription, and its being said to be like fariHa may be only to indicate the form of the sec. pers. &c.,] sec. pers. maDiDota, (S, Msb, K,) aor. yamaDRu, (S, K,) inf. n. maDaDN (S, Msb, K) and maDiyDN (S, A, K) and maDaADapN, (S, K,) He suffered, or experienced, pain; (S, A, Msb, K;) mina AlXRaIoCi from the thing; (Msb;) or mina AlmuSiybapi from the calamity, or misfortune; (S, * A, K, * TA;) and mina AlkalaAmi from the speech. (A, TA.) And maDiDotu liloOamori I experienced distress from the affair, or event. (TA.) ＝ -A2- maDRahu: see 4, throughout.

4 AmDRhu c
4. AmDRhu, (AO, Th, S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. UimoDaADN; (S;) and maDRahu↓ (AO and the other authorities mentioned above, IDrd, A,) aor.
maDuDa
, (M, Msb, TA,) inf. n. maDRN (IDrd, M, A, Msb, K) and maDiyDN; (M, A, K;) but the latter form of the verb was not known to As, (S,) and is said by Th, (S,) and by Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El- 'Alà, (IDrd,) to be obsolete; (IDrd, S;) or the former is of the dial. of Temeem; (AO;) It (a wound, Th, S, Msb, and disquietude of mind, Msb) pained him: (Th, S, Msb:) it (disquietude of mind, and grief,) burned him, and distressed him: (M, TA:) it (a thing) affected, or distressed, his heart with grief; (A, K;) and both are said also of pain, and of disquietude of
mind, and of a man beating another. (A.) You say also, AlkuHolu yumiDRu AlEayona; (S, Msb, K;) and yamuDRuhaA↓, (A, K,) and yamaDRuhaA↓; (K;) The collyrium pains the eye: (A, K:) or burns it: (S:) or pains and burns it: (TA:) or stings it by its pungency. (Msb.) And maDRa AlxalRu faAhu↓ The vinegar burned his mouth. (IDrd, K.) And OamaDRaniI hecaA Alqawolu This saying distressed me. (TA.) And AmDRhu jiloduhu fadalakahu His skin itched [and he therefore rubbed it]. (M, K.)

R. Q. 1 maDomaDa c
R. Q. 1. maDomaDa, (K,) or maDomaDa AlmaMCa fiI fiyhi, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. maDomaDapN (S, K) and miDomaADN and maDomaADN, (K,) this last is said by As to be allowable, (TA,) [He rinsed his mouth with water;] he agitated water (S, Msb, K) round about (Msb) in his mouth; (S, Msb, K;) lilowuDuwoCi for the wDwC, q. v.; (K;) as also tamaDomaDa↓ llwDwC, (K,) or fiI wuDuwoYihi in his wDwC, (S,) or biAlomaMCi tmDmD↓. (Msb, TA.) [See also maSomaSa.] ― -b2- maDomaDa, (As, Lh,) inf. n. maDomaDapN, (K,) also signifies He agitated a vessel [so as to rinse it, or wash it out, with water]: (As:) or he washed a vessel, (Lh, K,) or other thing; (K;) so, [for instance,] a garment, or piece of cloth; as also maSomaSahu [q. v.] (Lh.) ＝ -A2- [Hence,] maA maDomaDotu EayoniI binawomK (S, A, L) (tropical:) I did not sleep. (S, L.) And maA maDomaDato EayoniI binawomK, (L,) or maA tamaDomaDato↓, (A,) (tropical:) My eye did not sleep. (L.) [The inf. n.] miDomaADN also signifies (tropical:) The state of sleeping. (TA.) And maDomaDa (tropical:) He slept a long sleep. (TA.) And maDomaDa AlnRuEaAsu fiI Eayonihi (tropical:) Drowsiness crept in his eye; (TA;) and [so] AlnRuEaAsu fiI Eayonihi tamaDomaDa↓, (S, TA,) or AlnRawomu sleep. (A.) And tamaDomaDati↓ AlEayonu biAlnRuEaAsi (tropical:) [The eye became infused with drowsiness]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- maDomaDapN also signifies, accord. to El-Fárábee, The making, or uttering, of a sound; or the sound itself; (Sawot;) of the serpent, &c.: or, as some say, its (a serpent's) making motions with the tongue [so as to produce a sound]. (Msb.)

R. Q. 2
R. Q. 2: see R. Q. 1, in five places.

maDRN c
maDRN, applied to collyrium, (L, K,) and to the style, or bodkin, with which it is applied to the eyes, (S, O,) an inf. n. used as an epithet; (O;) Paining; (K;) or burning; (O, L;) or hot. (S.) You say, kaHalahu kuHolFA maDRFA He applied to his eyes burning [or paining] collyrium. (L.) And kaHalahu bimulomuwlK maDRK He applied collyrium to his eyes with a hot, (S,) or burning, (O,) [or paining,] style. (S, O.) ― -b2- rajulN maDRu AlDRarobi A man who beats, or strikes, painfully. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.) ― -b3- UimoraOapN maDRapN A woman who does not bear, or endure, what displeases her, or grieves her; (IAar, K;) as though it pained her, or burned her: (IAar:) or whom a small word pains: or whom a small thing hurts, or annoys. (T, TA.) [It occurs coupled with baDRapN, to which it should not be regarded as merely an imitative sequent.]

maDRapN c
maDRapN: see maDRN: ― -b2- and what next follows.

maDaDN c
maDaDN The pain of a calamity or misfortune. (S, K.) [See 1.] ― -b2- Sour milk; (K;) [so called because it bites the tongue;] and so maDRapN↓, (K,) and baDRapN, of the milk of camels. (Ibn-'Abbád.)

maDaADN c
maDaADN The state of being burned. (TA.)

muDaADN c
muDaADN A pain which affects a man in the eye &c., from a thing that burns: so in the O, on the authority of IAar; but in the TS it is miDomaADN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- Water that is intolerable by reason of saltness. (IAar, K.)

maDiyDN c
maDiyDN The burning of collyrium [&c.: see maDRahu, explained with OamaDRahu]: (L:) and miDomaADN↓ [in like manner] signifies a burning. (K.)

maDRaADN c
maDRaADN Burning: [or rather, burning much:] applied by El-'Ajjáj as an epithet to travel. (TA.)

miDomaADN c
miDomaADN: see muDaADN: ― -b2- and maDiyDN.

1 maDaHa EiroDahu c
1. maDaHa EiroDahu, aor.
maDaHa
, (inf. n. maDoHN; TA;) and OamoDaHahu↓, (inf. n. UimoDaAHN; TA;) He disgraced, or dishonoured, him; blasted his reputation; (El-Umawee, S, K;) imputed to him, or accused him of, a vice, or fault, or the like. (TA.)

4 OamoDaHa
4: see 1.

1 maDara c
1. maDara, aor.
maDura
; (S, A, Msb, K;) and maDira, aor.
maDara
; (A, K;) and maDura, aor.
maDura
; (K;) inf. n. muDuwrN, (S, Msb, K,) of the first, (S, Msb,) and maDorN, [also of the first,] and maDarN, [of the second;] (K;) It (milk, S, A, Msb, K, and [so in the A, but in the K or,] beverage of the kind called nabiyc, A, K) was, or became, sour, or acid: (Msb:) or sour, or acid, biting the tongue: (A:) or such as to bite the tongue; (S, TA;) before becoming raAYib: (TA:) or sour, or acid, and white. (K.)

2 mDRrhu c
2. mDRrhu, inf. n. tamoDiyrN, He referred his lineage, or origin, to muDar [Mudar, the ancestor of most of the Arabs who trace up their genealogy to Ismá'eel, or Ishmael]: (K:) or he made him to be of the race of muDar by referring his lineage, or origin, to them. (A.) ＝ -A2- It is said, of the race of muDar, in a trad., mDRrhA AllReh fiI AlnRaAri, meaning, May God make them to be in the fire [of hell]; the verb being derived from their name: (TA:) or may God collect them together [therein]; like as one says janRada Aljunuwda: (Z, TA:) or destroy them; (K;) from the saying cahaba damuhu xiDorFA miDorFA, in the first of the senses explained below: (TA:) J says, [in the S,] that its origin seems to be from muDuwru AllRabani, meaning “ the biting of the tongue by milk, ” and that it is with teshdeed to denote muchness, or intensiveness. (TA.)

5 tmDRr c
5. tmDRr He asserted himself to be related, or to belong, to the race of muDar. (A, K.) See 2. ― -b2- He entered into a league (taEaSRaba, A: in the copies of the K, tagaDRaba; but the former, with the two unpointed letters, is the right reading: TA:) with, (A,) or for, (K,) the race of muDar. (A, K.) ― -b3- He affected to be like, or imitated, or assimilated himself to, the race of muDar. (S, TA.)

cahaba damuhu xiDorFA miDorFA c
cahaba damuhu xiDorFA miDorFA, (S, A, K,) and xaDirFA maDirFA↓, (K,) His blood went unrevenged, or unretaliated, or unexpiated by a mulct: (S, K:) or so as to occasion no inconvenience or trouble (haniyoYFA mariyoYFA) to the slayer: (A:) mDrA is an imitative sequent: Ks mentions also biDorFA, with b. (S.) ― -b2- You say also, xucohu xiDorFA miDorFA, (K, TA,) and xaDirFA maDirFA↓, (Sgh, TA, and so in the CK,) Take thou it in a fresh, or juicy, state. (K.) See also art. xDr.

maDirN c
maDirN: see maADirN. ＝ -A2- xaDirFA maDirFA: see miDorFA, in two places.

muDaAru AllRabani c
muDaAru AllRabani, (TS,) or muDaArapu AllRabani↓, (K,) What flows from milk (TS, K) when it becomes sour, or acid, and clear. (TS.)

maDiyrN c
maDiyrN: see maADirN.

muDaArapN c
muDaArapN: see muDaAru AllRabani.

maDiyrapN c
maDiyrapN A kind of cooked food made of [sour] milk that bites the tongue: (S:) or a small quantity of broth, or gravy, cooked with milk such as is termed maDiyr, and sometimes mixed with fresh milk: (K:) or a small quantity of broth, or gravy, cooked with milk and other things: (TA:) or, as made by the Arabs, flesh-meat cooked with pure milk that bites the tongue, until the flesh-meat is thoroughly done, and the milk has become thick; and sometimes they mix fresh milk with milk that has been collected in a skin; and in this case it is the best that can be. (AM, TA.)

maADirN c
maADirN (S, A, Msb, K) and maDiyrN↓ (A, Msb, K) and maDirN↓, (IAar, K,) the last thought by ISd to be a kind of relative or possessive epithet,
because the verb is maDara, (TA,) [but it seems that he was unacquainted with, or that he disallowed, the form maDira, of which it is the regular part. n.,] Milk that is sour, or acid, (A, Msb,) biting the tongue: (A:) or such as bites the tongue, (S, TA,) before becoming raAYib: (TA:) or that has become sour, or acid, and white. (K.)

maDoraHN c
maDoraHN and maDoraHiIRN: see art. DrH.

1 maTRahu c
1. maTRahu, (S, K,) aor.
maTuTa
, (S, TA,) inf. n. maTRN, (TA,) He drew it; pulled it; strained it; extended it by drawing or pulling; stretched it; stretched it out; extended it; lengthened it; i. q. madRahu: (S, K:) maTRN and maTowN and madRN are all one [in meaning]. (Az, TA.) You say, maTRa AldRalowa, (K,) or maTRa biAldRalowi, (Lh,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (Lh,) He drew, or pulled, the bucket. (Lh, K.) And maTR HaAjibayohi He extended, or stretched, his eyebrows (S, TA) in speaking. (TA.) This last phrase also signifies (tropical:) He behaved proudly; (S, K, TA;) and so maTRa xadRahu; (K, TA;) syn. takabRara [for which in the CK we find takabRurFA]. (S, K.) You say also, maTRa OaSaAbiEahu He extended his fingers, (K, TA,) as though (TA) talking, or addressing, with them. (K, TA.) And maTRa AlHuruwfa [He lengthened the letters]; for madRahaA. (As, in TA, in remarks on the letter T.) And maTRa xaTRahu, and xaTowahu, He extended, and made wide, his handwriting, and his stepping: and maTRa [alone], aor. and inf. n. as above, [xaTowahu being understood,] he made his stepping wide. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., of Saad, laA tamuTRuwA bMmiyna Ye shall not lengthen [the word] Mmiynu [amen: yet this is done by most, if not by all, of the Muslims in the present day]. (TA.)

2 tamoTiyTN c
2. tamoTiyTN, [inf. n. of mTRT, and app. originally meaning The act of lengthening the tongue overmuch:] (tropical:) the act of reviling. (K, TA.)

5 tmTRT c
5. tmTRT He stretched himself: he walked with an elegant, and a proud, and self-conceited, gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side, and stretching out his arms; syn. tamadRada; (S, K;) as also tamaTRaI; like taZanRayotu from AlZRanRu; tmTRT being the original form. (TA.) It is said in the Kur, [lxxv. 33,] vumRa cahaba UilaI Oaholihi yatamaTRaI Then he went to his family walking with an elegant, and a proud, and self-conceited, gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side; syn. yatabaxotaru; (Fr, Bd, Jel, TA;) from AlmaTRu, because he who so walks extends his steps, so that it is originally yatamaTRaTu; (Bd;) or from AlmaTaA, signifying “ the back, ” because he who so walks twists his back. (Fr, Bd.) ― -b2- It (water, As, TA, and thick sour milk, TA) roped, or drew out, with a viscous, glutinous, cohesive, sticky, ropy, or slimy, continuity of parts; it was, or became, viscous, glutinous, cohesive, sticky, ropy, or slimy. (As, TA.) [See also R, Q, 2.] ― -b3- tmTRT fiI AlkalaAmi He varied (lawRana) in speech. (Sgh, K.)

R. Q. 1 maTomaTa fiI kalaAmihi c
R. Q. 1. maTomaTa fiI kalaAmihi He extended, and lengthened, his speech: (IDrd:) or maTomaTa signifies he flagged in his handwriting, or in his speech. (IAar, Az, K.)

R. Q. 2 tamaTomaTa c
R. Q. 2. tamaTomaTa It (water) became thick. (Sgh, K.) [See also 5.]

muTuTN c
muTuTN [a pl., of which the sing. is probably maTiyTN↓, like as the sing. of its syn. mududN is madiydN,] Tall, or long; applied to any animals. (IAar.)

maTaATN c
maTaATN Thick and sour camels' milk; (Ibn- 'Abbád, K;) such as is termed qaAriS; so called because it ropes, or is ropy. (TA.)

muTaATN c
muTaATN: see what next follows.

miTaATN c
miTaATN Extended; [meaning long;] as also muTaATN↓, and maTaAYiTN↓; applied as an epithet to what is termed SalFA [app. here meaning the “ middle of the back ”]; (K;) and to a camel. (TA.)

maTiyTN c
maTiyTN: see muTuTN.

maTiyTapN c
maTiyTapN thick water, (S,) or turbid and thick water, (K, TA,) remaining (TA) in the bottom of a watering-trough: (S, K, TA:) or slime; or strong, or thick, slime: or, accord. to As, water in which is ropy mud: pl. maTaAYiTu: which, as pl. of the same sing., also signifies places hollowed by the feet of beasts of carriage, in the ground, in which slime, or strong or thick slime, collects. (TA.)

muTayoTaI c
muTayoTaI: see what next follows.

maTiyTaMCu c
maTiyTaMCu: see what next follows.

muTayoTaMCu c
muTayoTaMCu, a dim. n. which has no undiminished form, (Z, in the Fáïk,) The act of walking with an elegant, and a proud, and self-conceited, gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side: and the act of stretching out the arms in walking: (S, K:) as also muTayoTaI↓, (As, Kr, K,) in both these senses, (As, TA,) and maTiyTaMCu↓. (K.) You say, maXaI AlmuTayoTaMCa [He walked in either of the manners above described]. (S, TA.)

muTaAYiTN c
muTaAYiTN: see miTaATu.

1 maTaOa c
1. maTaOa, aor.
maTaAa
, Inivit feminam. (Ibn-ElFaraj, K.)

maTovN c
maTovN: see art. Tv.

1 maTarati AlsRamaMCu c
1. maTarati AlsRamaMCu, aor.
maTura
, inf. n. maTarN, [The sky, or, as it sometimes means, the rain,] rained; as also OamoTarat↓: (T, S, Msb:) but the former is said to relate to that which is sent in mercy, and the latter to that which is sent in punishment. (Msb.) See also what follows. ― -b2- [Both are also trans. You say,] maTaratohumu AlsRamaMCu, (A, K,) aor.
maTura
, (TA,) inf. n. maTorN and maTarN; (K:) and OamoTaratohum↓, (A, TA,) which latter is the worse form, [as will be seen below,] The sky rained upon them. (A, K, TA.) And muTironaA We were rained upon; we had rain. (S. TA,) ― -b3- You say also, maTarahumo xayorN, and XarRN, (tropical:) [Good, and evil, poured upon them; or betided them]. (A.) And maTaraniI bixayorK (tropical:) He did good to me. (K.) And maA maTaraniI bixayorK (tropical:) [He did not any good to me]. (A.) And maA muTira minohu xayorFA, [in the CK, incorrectly, xayorN,] and bixayorK, (tropical:) Good did not betide him from him, or it. (K, TA.) But OamoTarahumu QllRehu↓ is only said in relation to punishment: (K, TA:) as in the saying in the Kur, [xxvi. 173, and xxvii. 59,] Ealayohimo waOamoTaronaA↓ maTarFA fasaMCa maTaru Qlomunocariyna (tropical:) [And we rained upon them a rain, and evil was the rain of the warned people]: and again in the Kur, [xv. 74,] Ealayohimo HijaArapF mino sijRiylK waOamoTaronaA↓ (tropical:) [And we rained upon them stones of baked clay]: the stones being regarded as rain because of their descent from the sky: some, however, hold that maTara and OamaTara↓ are the same in meaning. (TA.) ＝ -A2- marRa Alfarasu yamoTuru, inf. n. maTorN (S, A) and muTuwrN↓; (S;) and yatamaTRaru↓; (S, A;) (tropical:) The horse passed, or went, running vehemently, like the pouring of rain: (A:) or went quickly; or hastened; (S;) as also maTara Alfarasu, (K,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. ns.: (K:) or this last signifies the horse was quick in his passing, or going, and in his running; and so tmTRr↓. (TA.) You say also, bihi farasuhu tamaTRara↓ (A, TA) (tropical:) His horse ran, and hastened, or went quickly, with him. (TA.) And maTarati AlTRayoru, and tmTRrt↓, (tropical:) The birds hastened, or were quick, in their descent. (K.) And Alxayolu tmTRrt↓ (tropical:) The horses came, (K, TA,) and went, quickly, (TA,) outstripping one another. (K, TA.) ― -b2- maTara fiI AlOaroDi, inf. n. muTuwrN; and tmTRr↓; (tropical:) He (a man) went away in, or into, the country, or land; (S, K;) and hastened; as also qaTara. (TA, art. qTr.) ― -b3- cahaba AlbaEiyru famaA OadoriI mano maTara bihi
(S, K *) (tropical:) [The camel has gone away, and I know not who has gone with it, or] has taken it: (K:) and in like manner, cahaba vawobiI Alx (tropical:) my garment has gone, &c. (TA.)

4 OamoTara
4: see 1, in four places. ― -b2- AmTr QllRehu AlsRamaMCa God made the sky to rain. (S, Msb.) ― -b3- AmTr AlmakaAna He found the place rained upon. (Sgh, K.) ― -b4- OamoTaronaA We were in rain. (TA.) ＝ -A2- kalRamotuhu faOamoTara, (Mubtekir El-Kilábee, A, K, *) and UistmTra↓, (Mubtekir, A,) (tropical:) I spoke to him, and he lowered his eyes, looking towards the ground, (OaToraq, Mubtekir, A, K, [which also signifies he was silent, not speaking, but accord. to the TA, (see 10,) should not be so rendered here,]) and his forehead sweated. (A, K.)

5 tmTRr c
5. tmTRr He exposed himself to the rain: (A, K:) or he went out to the rain and its cold. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also 10, in two places. ＝ -A3- See also 1, in five places.

10 AstmTr c
10. AstmTr He asked, or begged, or prayed, for rain; (S, Msb, TA;) as also tmTRr↓. (TA.) You say xarajuwA yasotamoTiruwna QllReha, and yatamaTRaruwnahu↓, [They went forth praying to God for rain.] (A, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AstmTrhu (tropical:) He sought, desired, or demanded, his beneficence, or bounty; (A, TA;) he asked him to give like rain. (S.) ― -b3- [And hence, perhaps,] AstmTr lilsRiyaATi (assumed tropical:) He endured patiently the whips [as though he desired that the stripes should fall like rain upon him]. (TA.) ― -b4- And AstmTr (assumed tropical:) He was silent; he did not speak [when spoken to, as though he desired that words should pour upon him like rain]: in the K, this meaning is assigned to OamoTara, which should not be used in this sense: see also musotamoTirN; and see 4. (TA.) ― -b5- AlmaAlu yasotamoTiru (tropical:) [The camels, or sheep, &c.,] go out to the rain. (A.) See also 5. ― -b6- AstmTr (tropical:) He (a man) sough shelter from the rain. (TA.) ― -b7- AstmTr vawobahu He (a man) put on his garment in the rain. (Ibn-Buzurj.)

maTarN c
maTarN Rain: (A, Msb, K, TA:) pl. OamoTaArN. (S, A, Msb, K.) See maTorapN: and see also ZahorN, p. 1929, a.

maTirN c
maTirN: see maATirN: ― -b2- and see also mamoTuwrN.

maTorapN c
maTorapN [A rain; a shower of rain]. (A; and S, K, voce magorapN, &c.) You say maTorapN mubaArakapN [A blessed rain.] (A.) See maTarN. ＝ -A2- See also maTarapN.

maTarapN c
maTarapN, (Fr, Sgh, K, also mentioned in the L, on the authority of IAar, and in such a manner as implies that it may be also maTorapN↓, TA,) A [skin of the kind called] qirobap: (K, &c.:) applied in the present day to an UidaAwap and the like: (TA:) [I have found it now applied to a large bottle of leather, and of wood: pl. OamoTaArN.]

maTirapN c
maTirapN: see EaTirN.

maToraAnN c
maToraAnN [sometimes pronounced miToraAnN, and muToraAnN, A metropolitan]: see jaAvaliyqN.

maTiyrN c
maTiyrN: see mamoTuwrN: ― -b2- and maATirN.

maTRaArN c
maTRaArN (tropical:) A horse that runs vehemently. (K, TA.)

maATirN c
maATirN. ― -b2- samaMCN maATirapN, (A, Msb,) and mumoTirapN↓, (A,) A raining sky. (A, Msb.) See also mimoTaArN. ― -b3- yawomN maATirN, (A, K,) and mumoTirN↓, (K,) and maTiyr↓, (A,) and maTirN↓, (K,) which last is a possessive epithet, (TA,) (tropical:) A day of rain. (A, K.) ＝ -A2- See also mutamaTRirN.

mamoTarN c
mamoTarN: see what next follows.

mimoTarN c
mimoTarN (S, K) and mamoTarN↓ and mimoTarapN↓ (K) What is worn in rain, to protect one; (S;) a garment of wool, (K,) worn in rain, (TA,) by which to protect one's self from the rain; (K;) from Lh. (TA.)

mumoTirN c
mumoTirN and mumoTirapN: see maATirN.

mimoTarapN c
mimoTarapN: see mimoTarN.

samaMCN mimoTaArN c
samaMCN mimoTaArN A sky pouring down abundance of rain. (A.) See also maATirN.

mamoTuwrN c
mamoTuwrN (tropical:) A place, (K,) and a valley, (A,) rained upon, or watered by rain; as also maTiyrN↓; (A, K, TA;) and maTirN↓, as in a verse cited voce xaTowapN: and so maTiyrN↓ and maTiyrapN↓ applied to a land (OaroDN). (TA.)

xaraja mutamaTRirFA c
xaraja mutamaTRirFA He went forth into the gardens and fields after rain. (A.) ＝ -A2- TaAYirN mutamaTRirN (tropical:) A bird hastening, or going quickly, (S, TA,) in its descent; (TA;) [as also maATirN↓, of which the pl., muTRarN, occurs in the following ex.:] Ru-beh says,
waAlTRayoru tahowiI fiI AlsRamaMCi muTRarFA
[And the birds descend in the sky, hastening]. (TA.) mutamaTRirN is also applied to a horseman, as signifying hastening, or going quickly. (S.)

musotamoTarN c
musotamoTarN (tropical:) A man [from whom beneficence, or bounty, is sought, or desired: and hence,] naturally disposed to beneficence, or bounty. (IAar, TA.) ＝ -A2- (tropical:) A place that is open and uncovered. (A, K.)

musotamoTirN c
musotamoTirN [Asking, begging, or praying, for rain. ― -b2- Hence,] (tropical:) Seeking, desiring, or demanding, beneficence, or bounty, (Lth, K,) from a man. (Lth.) You say, maA OanaA mino HaAjatiI Einodaka bimusotamoTirK (tropical:) I am not covetous of obtaining from thee the object of my want. (IAar.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A place needing rain. (A, K.) ― -b4- (tropical:) Silent; not speaking [when spoken to, as though desiring that words should pour upon him like rain]. (K.) ＝ -A2- [One] on whom rain has fallen. (K.)

maZRN c
maZRN The pomegranate-tree: (K:) or the wild pomegranate, (As, T, S, M,) or the wild pomegranate-tree: (Lth, M, K:) or a sort of pomegranate (IDrd) that grows in the mountains of the saraAp, not producing fruit, but only blossoms, (IDrd, K,) and these in abundance: (IDrd *) in its blossoms is honey, (K,) in abundance, (TA,) and they are sucked: (K:) it produces blossoms, but does not form fruit, and the bees eat them, and yield good honey therefrom: AHn says, it grows in the mountains, and produces many blossoms, but does not mature its produce, (laA yurabRiI,) but its blossoms have much honey: (M:) it has fire-wood of the best quality, the most excellent thereof in yielding fire, and it is made to flame like candles: Es-Sukkaree says, it is the wild pomegranate, which bees eat, and it produces only leaves, having no pomegranates: the n. un. is with p. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, i. q. damu AlOaxawayoni, which is the same as damu AlgazaAli, (AHeyth, K,) called in the present day AlqaATiru AlmakRiIRu (TA) [and qaToru makRapa, i. e. the red, resinous, inspissated juice which we call dragon's blood.] ― -b3- Also, The expressed juice of the roots of the OaroTaI, (K, TA,) which are red, the tree itself being green, and which, when camels eat them, cause their lips to become red. (TA.) ― -b4- [Forskal, in his Flora, page ciii., mentions The dianthera trisulca as called in El-Yemen mD or mZ.]

1 maEata c
1. maEata, aor.
maEata
, (inf. n. maEotN, TA,) He rubbed (K) a skin, or hide. (TA.)

1 maEaja c
1. maEaja, aor.
maEaja
, inf. n. maEojN, He, or it, (a horse, and the wind, S, and a torrent, TA,) went quickly, or swiftly. (S, K.) See art. Emj. ― -b2- marRa yamoEaju He (a horse) went at an easy pace: (S:) and in like manner maEajato she (a camel) went at an easy pace. (Th.) ― -b3- maEajati AlrRiyHu, aor.
maEaja
, inf. n. maEojN, The wind blew gently. (IAth.) ― -b4- AlrRiyHu tamoEaju fiI AlnRabaAti The wind turns over the herbage to the right and left. (IAth.) ― -b5- maEaja fI sayorihi He inclined, in his course in every direction, by reason of his sprightliness. (TA.) ― -b6- maEaja, aor.
maEaja
, inf. n. maEojN, He affected various modes in running: he (a horse) pressed against one of the branches of
the bit, and then against the other, now on the right and now on the left; [inclining in his run now to the right and now to the left, by reason of his sprightliness: see maERaAjN]. (TA.) ― -b7- maEaja AlfaSiylu DaroEa OumRihi, (aor.
maEaja
, inf. n. maEojN, TA,) The young weaned camel struck its head against its mother's udder, and inverted (as in the S, or opened, as in the K) its mouth around it, in order to suck: (S, K,) as also magaja. (TA, arts. mEj and mgj.)

farasN maEuwjN c
farasN maEuwjN A swift horse. (S.) riyHN maEuwjN A wind swift in its course. (TA.) ― -b2- farasN maEuwjN, and mimEajN↓, A horse that often affects various modes in running: that often presses against one of the branches of the bit, and then against the other, now on the right and now on the left; [inclining in his run now to the right and now to the left, by reason of his sprightliness]. (TA.) [In like manner,] HimaArN maERaAjN↓ An ass that inclines in his run to the right and left by reason of his sprightliness. (TA.)

maERaAjN c
maERaAjN and mimoEajN: see maEuwjN.

1 maEadahu c
1. maEadahu, aor.
maEada
, (inf. n. maEodN; L,) and AmtEdhu↓; He snatched it unawares; seized it hastily when its owner was unawares: (L, K:) or he seized it and took it away; snatched it away; took it away quickly by force. (L.) ― -b2- Also, ↓both verbs, He drew, or pulled, it: (L:) or drew, or pulled, it quickly. (S, L, K.) Ex. maEada AldRalowa, and maEada bihaA, and AmtEdhA↓, He drew up, or pulled up, the bucket: or drew, or pulled, it out, or forth, from the well. And maEada AlrRumoHa and AmtEdhu↓, He pulled forth the spear from the place where it was stuck in the ground. And sayofahu AmtEd↓ He drew forth his sword from its scabbard. (L.) ― -b3- maEada bihi, aor.
maEada
, inf. n. maEodN and muEuwdN, He took it (a thing) away; carried it off; went away with it. (K.) ― -b4- Hence, maEada bixuSoyayohi He removed his testicles; (L, TA;) or he pulled them; as also maEada humaA. (Lh, L, TA.) ― -b5- maEadahu He took it (namely, flesh,) with his fore-teeth. (K.) ― -b6- maEadahu He plucked it out; namely, hair; as also magadahu. (L.) ＝ -A2- muEida, (L, K,) and maEida, aor.
maEada
, inf. n. maEodN and maEadN, (IKtt,) He (a man, L,) had a diseased, or disordered, stomach, so that he did not find his food wholesome: (L, K:) or his stomach pained him. (Ibn-T reef.) ― -b2- maEadahu He, or it, hit, or hurt, his maEidap, or stomach. (L, K.) ＝ -A3- maEada fiI AlOaroDi, (aor.
maEada
, inf. n. maEodN and muEuwdN, L,) He went away journeying through the land, or earth. (S, L, K.)

8 UimotaEada
8: see 1 in five places.

R. Q. 2 tamaEodada c
R. Q. 2. tamaEodada He assumed the garb, dress, habit, or external appearance, of the sons of Ma'add: mentioned also in art. Ed [which see for other explanations not repeated here]: (K:) he endured with patience their mode of life in travel and in a fixed residence: (Lth, L:) and he subjected himself to a hard, or difficult life: said to be not derived from any other word. (L.) ― -b2- tamaEodada He became numbered among the sons of Ma'add. (L.) ― -b3- It (a people or party) removed from Ma'add to El-Yemen, and then returned. (Lth, L.) ― -b4- (tropical:) He became big, bulky, gross, or coarse, and fat: (Lh, TA:) (tropical:) he (a boy) became big, bulky, gross, or coarse, and hard, and lost the freshness and tenderness of youth. (A.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) He (an emaciated man) began to become fat. (K.) ― -b6- He (assumed tropical:) (a sick man) became convalescent. (K.)

nazoEN maEodN c
nazoEN maEodN A quick pulling up, or out, of the bucket from a well: (IAar, S, * L:) or a strong pulling up, or out; as though the bucket were pulled up from the bottom of the well: or a pulling up, or out, by means of the pulley, (L,) [and therefore quick]. ＝ -A2- maEodN Bigness; bulkiness; grossness; coarseness. (K.) ― -b2- Big; bulky; gross; coarse; (ISd, L, K,) and strong: (ISd:) applied to a thing. (ISd, L.) ― -b3- A quick, or swift, camel. (S, K.) ― -b4- Fresh, and soft, or tender; applied to a leguminous plant; (L, K;) fresh and juicy; applied to the same, (S,) and to fruit. (L, K.) ― -b5- ruTabapN maEodapN, and mutamaERidapN↓, A fresh and juicy ripe date. (L, K.) ― -b6- In the phrase busorN vaEodN maEodN, mEd signifies Fresh and soft or tender: (S, L:) or it is a mere imitative sequent, (S, L, K,) not used alone. (S, L.) See art. vEd.

maEodapN c
maEodapN, miEodapN, miEidapN: see maEidapN.

maEidapN c
maEidapN and miEodapN (S, L, Msb, K) and maEodapN and miEidapN; (TA;) the first of which is the original form; (Msb, TA;) the second and third being contractions; and the fourth, as well as the others, mentioned by Expositors of the Fs.; (TA;) The stomach of a human being; the place in which is the food before it descends into the lower intesstines, or guts; (L, K;) in a man, what the kariX is in every ruminating animal; (S, L;) or in animals that have cloven hoofs, and such as have feet like those of the camel: (M, L, K:) accord. to ISd, from maEodN, applied to a thing, signifying “ strong, and big, bulky, gross, or coarse: ” (TA:) pl. maEidN (L, K) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n., of which maEidapN is the n. un.,] and miEadN: (L, Msb, K:) the latter as though formed from miEodapN. (L.)

maEadRN c
maEadRN The side (L, K) of a man, &c.: (L:) or, in a horse, the part of each side between the lower portion of the shoulder-blade and the extremity of the ribs, consisting of thick and compact flesh behind the shoulder-blade; the protuberance whereof is approved, because, when that part is narrow, it compresses the heart: (L:) or, in a horse, the part between the head of each shoulder-blade and the hinder extremity of the portion of flesh and sinew next the back-bone: (L, K:) and the flesh that is beneath the shoulderblade, (L, K,) or a little below it; which is the best of the flesh of the side: (L:) and the place of the horseman's heel: (L, K:) or the part of a beast of carriage which is the place of the rider's leg: (Lh, L:) and the belly: (Aboo-'Alee, L, K:) also, a vein in the part of a horse called manosij. (L, K.) See also art. Ed.

maAEidN c
maAEidN: see what follows.

mimoEadN c
mimoEadN (L, K) and maAEid↓ (L) A wolf that runs quickly. (L, K.)

mamoEuwdN c
mamoEuwdN A man having a diseased, or disordered, stomach, so that he does not find his food wholesome: (L:) having a bad stomach. (A.)

mutamaERidapN c
mutamaERidapN: see maEodN.

1 maEira c
1. maEira, [aor.
maEara
, inf. n. maEarN,] said of a man, (S,) and of the head, and of the tail, (TA,) His or its hair fell off; (S, TA;) as also tmERr↓, said of the head: (TA:) and the former said of the head, its hair became little, or scanty. (TA:) and maEirato, said of the forelock, (AlnRaASiyap, K,) or of that of a horse, (TA,) it lost all its hair: (K:) and maEira, said of a solid hoof, it lost the hair that hung down upon it from the fore part of the pastern. (TA.) ― -b2- maEira, (A, K,) aor.
maEara
, (K,) inf. n. maEarN, (S, TA,) said of hair, (S, A, K,) and of plumage, and the like, (K,) It fell off; (S, A;) as also tmERr↓, said of hair: (S, A:) or it became little, or scanty; as also OamoEara↓: (K:) and, said of a finger-nail, or toe-nail, (tropical:) it came out, or fell out, (A, K,) in consequence of something befalling it, or hurting it. (K.) See maEarRapN in art. Er. ― -b3- [Hence,] maEira, (TA,) or maEira mino maAlihi, (A,) (tropical:) He became poor; (A, TA;) as also OamoEara↓, (S, A,) inf. n. UimoEaArN; (TA;) or the latter, he became poor, and his travelling-provisions failed or became exhausted; as also mERr↓, inf. n. tamoEiyrN. (K.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] AlOaroDu OamoEarati↓ (tropical:) The land became destitute of herbage: or its herbage became little, or scanty: (K:) contr. of OamoraEat. (IKtt.)

2 maERara
2: see 1.

4 OamoEara
4: see 1, in the three places. ― -b2- OamoEaronaA (tropical:) We came upon a land destitute of herbage: (A, TA:) or we found dearth, scarcity, drought, or sterility: (TA:) and AmEr Alqawomu the people became afflicted with dearth, scarcity, drought, or sterility. (TA.) ＝ -A2-
AmErt AlmawaAXiI AlOaroDa (tropical:) The beasts pastured upon the land, (i. e., its trees or herbs, TA,) and left no pasturage in it. (TS, L, K.) ― -b2- AmErhu (assumed tropical:) He despoiled him of his property, (K, TA,) and reduced him to poverty. (TA.)

5 tamaERara
5: see 1, in two places.

maEirN c
maEirN A man, (S,) and a head, (A,) whose hair is falling off, or has fallen off; (S, A;) as also OamoEaru↓ and mutamaERirN↓: (A:) or having little hair; (TA;) as also OamoEaru↓: (S:) and the first and second, a camel's foot (xufR) of which the hair (both XaEar and wabar) has gone: and maEoraMCu↓, a forelock (naASiyap, K, or that of a horse, TA,) of which all the hair has gone. (K.) ― -b2- Hair, and plumage, and the like, little in quantity, or scanty; as also OamoEaru↓: and the latter, hair falling off. (K.) ― -b3- [Hence,] (tropical:) A man who is niggardly, or avaricious, having little beneficence; (K;) unpropitious, mean, and hard, or difficult. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A man having little flesh. (TA.) ― -b5- qaAEN maEirN, and OaroDN maEirapN, (tropical:) A plain, and land, destitute of herbage: (A:) or the latter, accord. to Yaakoob, land having little herbage: and makaAnN OamoEaru↓ a place having little herbage. (S.)

OamoEaru c
OamoEaru: fem. maEoraMCu: see maEirN, throughout. ＝ -A2- Also, of a solid hoof, (assumed tropical:) The hair that hangs down upon it (K, TA) from the fore part of the pastern: because it has a disposition to fall off. (TA.)

mutamaERirN c
mutamaERirN: see maEirN.

1 maEiza AlXRaIoCu c
1. maEiza AlXRaIoCu, [and maEizati AlOaroDu, accord. to the explanation of the inf. n. in the S,] aor.
maEaza
, (TK,) inf. n. maEazN, (S, K, TK,) The thing [and the ground] was, or became, hard. (S, * K, * TK.) ＝ -A2- maEiza said of a man: see 4. ＝ -A3- maEazotu AlmiEozaI, waDaOanotu AlDRaOona, aor.
maEaza
, I set apart the goats from the sheep. (K.)

4 AmEz c
4. AmEz He, (a man, A,) or it, (a people, S,) became abundant in goats; his or its, goats became abundant, or numerous; (S, A, K;) as also, maEiza↓, aor.
maEaza
, (K,) inf. n. maEazN. (TK.)

maEozN c
maEozN, and maEazN↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) gen. ns., (S, Msb,) [or rather quasi-pl. ns., signifying Goats;] the kind of ganam opposed to DaOonN; (S, A, K;) the kind of Eanam that have hair; (Msb, TA;) the DOon being those that have wool; (TA;) as also miEozFI↓, (S, Msb, K,) accord. to Sb, (S,) with tenween, (S, Msb,) when indeterminate, (Msb,) and perfectly decl., (S,) the A [which is written I] being a letter of quasicoördination, not a characteristic of the fem. gender, (S, Msb,) for the word is quasi-coördinate to dirohamN, of the measure fiEolalN; for the A of quasi-coördination follows the same rules as a letter belonging to the word itself, as is shown by their saying muEayozK↓ and OurayoTK [originally muEayoziIN and OurayoTiIN] as the dim. forms of miEozFI and OaroTFI with tenween, the letter next after the I of diminution being with kesr, like as they say durayohimN; for if the A were to denote the fem. gender they would not change it into I [in muEayoziIN, the original form of muEayozK,] like as they do not change it in the dims. of HubolaI and OaxoraI [which are HubayolaI and OuxayozaI]: (S:) it is sometimes made fem., [by being written or pronounced miEozaApN,] and sometimes it is made imperfectly decl. [and therefore without tenween]: (K:) Fr says, that it is [itself] fem., but that some make it masc. [and therefore with tenween]: but A 'Obeyd says, that most of the Arabs pronounce ciforaI without tenween, while some of them pronounce it with tenween, whereas all of them pronounce miEozFI with tenween: (S:) IAar says, that it is perfectly decl. when likened to the measure mifoEalN, and imperfectly decl. when held to accord. with the measure fiEolaI: (TA:) accord. to Aboo-'Amr, Ibn-El-'Alà, it is from maEazN, [inf. n. of maEiza,] and in like manner ciforaI is from cafarN: (As, S:) maEiyzN↓ also signifies the same as maEozN, (S, A, K,) or is pl. of maEozN, [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] like as EabiydN is of EabodN; (Msb;) and OumoEuwzN↓ also is syn. with maEozN, (S, K,) and so are miEaAzN↓ (K) and miEozaMCN↓: (Sgh, K:) [respecting OumoEuwzN, see also below:] maEozN [as well as its syns. mentioned above, like all quasi-pl. ns., is sometimes masc., but generally] is fem.: (Msb:) a male is called maAEizN↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) and so a female; (Msb, K;) or a female is called maAEizapN↓ (S, A, TA) [and maEozapN↓ (M, voce XaroqaMCu)] and miEozaAp↓; (TA;) and XaApN [or rather XaApN mina AlmaEozi] is also used as a sing., (Msb,) and is applied to a male and to a female: (Msb, art. Xwh:) [see also ZaboIN:] OamoEuzN is a pl. [of pauc.] of maEozN, like as OaEobudN is of EabodN: (Msb:) the pl. of maAEizN↓, (K,) or of maAEizapN, (S,) is mawaAEizu; (S, K;) and miEaAzN↓ and OumoEuwzN↓ are said to be quasi-pl. ns. (TA.) The goats of the Arabs of the desert have short hair, not long enough to be spun; but the goats of the cold countries, and of the people of the fertile regions, have abundant hair, and of this the Akrád [or Kurds] fabricate their tents. (T in art. bnI.) See also tadomuriIRN in art. dmr; and see DaAYinN in art. DOn.

maEozapN c
maEozapN: see their syn. maEozN.

miEozFI c
miEozFI: see their syn. maEozN.

miEozaMCN c
miEozaMCN: see their syn. maEozN.

miEozaApN c
miEozaApN a fem. sing. of maEozN, q. v. (TA.)

miEaAzN c
miEaAzN: see their syn. maEozN.

maEiyzN c
maEiyzN: see their syn. maEozN.

muEayozK c
muEayozK dim. of miEozoI, syn. of maEozN, q. v. (Sb, S.)

maERaAzN c
maERaAzN A possessor, or master, of miEozFI [or goats]. (S, K.)

maAEizN c
maAEizN and maAEizapN sings. of maEozN, q. v. (S, K. *) ― -b2- The former also signifies Goats' skin. (S, K.)

OamoEazu c
OamoEazu, and its fem. maEozaMCu, applied respectively to a place (makaAnN) and to land or ground (OaroDN), (tropical:) Hard, (S, K,) and abounding with pebbles: (S:) or both, [used as substs.,] rugged and stony ground: (A:) or a place abounding with pebbles, and hard: or the latter, small pebbles: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) thus A 'Obeyd explains a sing. as having a pl. signification: (TA:) or the latter, a desert, (SaHoraMC) in which is elevation and ruggedness, consisting of soil, or clay, and pebbles, mixed together, but hard ground, rough to the tread: (ISh, TA:) pl. muEozN, (K,) [a pl. of each as an epithet, or of each used as a subst.,] because imagined to have the character of an epithet; (TA;) and OamaAEizu, [a pl. of the former,] because the character of a subst. predominates in it; and maEozaAwaAtN, a pl. of the latter. (TA.)

OumoEuwzN c
OumoEuwzN: see its syn. maEozN. ― -b2- It also signifies, (K,) or is said to signify, (S,) A herd of gazelles, (S, K,) in number from thirty to forty; (S, TA;) or from thirty upwards: or a number of buckgazelles collected together: (TA:) or a number of OawoEaAl [or mountain-goats] collected together: (A, K:) or of AwEAl such as are termed vayaAtil: (Az, TA:) pl. OamaAEiyzu and OamaAEizu. (K.)

1 maEiTa c
1. maEiTa, (S, K,) aor.
maEaTa
, (K,) inf. n. maEaTN, (S,) He (a man) was, or became, without hair upon his body: (S:) and in like manner you say of a man's skin: (TA:) and of a wolf, meaning his hair fell off by degrees, or part after part: but you should not say maEiTa XaEaruhu: (S:) [but see 5:] or, said of a wolf, it signifies he was, or became, mischievous, malignant, or foul; syn. xabuva: or his hair became scanty, or little, (K,) and tmERT↓ said of a wolf, his hair fell off: (Mgh, Msb:) and UimRaEaTa↓, (S, K,) of the measure UifotaEala, or
[rather] UinofaEala, (accord. to different copies of the K,) said of a rope, (S, K,) &c., (S,) it became worn smooth. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also 5. ＝ -A2- maEaTa, aor.
maEaTa
, (K,) inf. n. maEoTN, (TA,) He plucked out hair [or wool] (K, TA,) from the head of a sheep or goat. (TA.)

5 tmERT c
5. tmERT It (hair, S, Msb, [in the TA, Alrjl is inadvertently put for AlXEr, and copied in the TK, with the addition of XErh in the explanation,]) fell off by degrees, or part after part, (S, Msb, K, TA,) upon the ground, (TA,) by reason of disease, (S, K, TA,) or the like; (S;) as also AmtET↓, (S,) and UimRaEaTa↓, (S, K,) of the measure UifotaEala, (K,) or [rather] of the measure UinofaEala [originally UinomaEaTa]: (S:) and [accord. to some, but see 1, above,] maEiTa↓, aor.
maEaTa
, (Msb,) inf. n. maEaTN, (Mgh, Msb,) it (hair) fell off. (Mgh, Msb.) You say also, tamaERaTato OawobaAruhu His fur became scattered. (K, TA) ― -b2- See also 1.

7 UimRaEaTa c
7. UimRaEaTa, [said in the S, and in one place in a copy of the K, to be of the measure UinofaEala]: see 1: ― -b2- and 5.

8 AmtET c and UimRaEaTa
8. AmtET UimRaEaTa [which latter is said in one place in the copies of the K, to be of the measure UifotaEala]: see 5: ― -b2- and for the latter, see also 1.

maEiTN c
maEiTN: see OamoEaTu.

Oabuw muEoTapa c
Oabuw muEoTapa The wolf: (K:) a gen. proper name thereof; similar to cuWaAlapu and OusaAmapu and vuEaAlapu. (TA.)

OamoEaTu c
OamoEaTu, applied to a man, Having no hair upon his body; (S, K;) or whose hair has fallen off; fem. maEoTaMCu: (Msb:) [and pl. muEoTN:] and, applied to a wolf, whose hair has fallen off by degrees, or part after part: (S:) or, thus applied, mischievous, malignant, or foul: [see 1:] or whose hair has become scanty, or little: as also maEiTN↓: (K:) and maEoTaMCu, applied to a she-wolf, has the former of the last two significations: and, applied to a ewe, it signifies whose wool has fallen off. (TA.) ― -b2- liSRN OamoEaTu (tropical:) A mischievous, malignant or foul, or wolf-like, thief, or robber; (S, * L;) likened to the wolf termed AmET: pl. muEoTN. (S, L.) ― -b3- OamoEaTu applied to sand, (K,) and maEoTaMCu applied to a tract or collection of sand (ramolapN), (TA,) and to land (OaroDN), (K,) and muEoTN applied to sands (rimaAlN), (K,) also signify (tropical:) Destitute of herbage. (K, TA.) ― -b4- Also OamoEaTu [app. applied to sand or the like], Extended upon the face of the earth or ground. (TA.) ― -b5- And AlmaEoTaMCu, (IAar, K,) as a subst., (IAar,) The pudendum; syn. AlsRawoCapu. (IAar, K.)

1 magava c
1. magava, (S,) aor.
maguva
, (TK,) inf. n. magovN, (K,) He steeped, soaked, or macerated, a thing in water, and rubbed it with the fingers; he steeped it in water, and mashed it with the hand; (TA;) he steeped, and mashed with the hand, medicine in water; syn. marava. (S, K. *) ― -b2- magava AlmaTaru AlkalaOa inf. n. magovN, The rain fell upon the herbage, and rendered it yellow, and bad-tasted, and laid it prostrate. (TA.) ― -b3- magava, [aor.
maguva
,] He submerged, or immersed, him, or it, in water. (K.) ― -b4- mugiva He was affected by a fever. (TA.) ― -b5- magavatohu AlHumRaI The fever attacked him; or pained him. (TA.) ― -b6- magavuwhu, [aor.
maguva
,] (S,) inf. n. magavN, (K,) They beat him lightly, (S, K, *) as though they shook him about (kaOanRahumo talotaluwhu). (S.) ― -b7- magava EiroDahu, (inf. n. magovN, K,) He defamed him; disgraced him; dishonoured him; (S, K;) aspersed him by reviling. (TA.) ― -b8- magavahumo biXarRK He did evil to them. (TA.)

3 maAgavaA c
3. maAgavaA, inf. n. migaAvN and mumaAgavapN, They clashed, and contended, each against the other; syn. HaAkRaA waxaASamaA. (K.)

magovN c
magovN Evil, as a subst. (K.) ― -b2- Conflict, (K,) and engagement of brave men in war, in the field of battle. (TA.) ― -b3- A struggling in wrestling. (TA.) See magivN. ― -b4- Play; syn. EabavN. (K.) One of the additions of F. (TA.)

magivN c
magivN, (S, K,) or magovN↓, (L,) and mumaAgivN↓, (L,) A strong wrestler. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also, the latter, A man pertinacious in altercation. (TA.) ― -b3- magivN and magiyvN↓ An evil, a wicked, or malignant, man: after the manner of a rel. n. [denoting habitual state or action, and the like]. (TA.)

mugaAvN c
mugaAvN The lightest, or slightest, of the diseases incident to camels. (El-Hejeree.) ― -b2- Also, A certain tree, two carats' weight (qiyraATaAni) of the root of which is an emetic and laxative: (K:) or, as in one copy [of the K], a certain plant, in the root of which is a poisonous quality (smyp [i. e., sumRiyRap]); the drinking of a grain of it [in water] causes looseness of the bowels, and vomiting, in an excessive degree. (TA.) But these properties [says SM] are strange, and not mentioned by the physicians. Ibn-El-Kutbee says, in [the book entitled] maA laA yasaEu AlTRabiyba jaholuhu, mgAv is [the name of] roots which are imported, of a hot and moist temperament, in one of the last measures of the second degree, (fI AwAxr AlvAnyp,) [the degrees of heat and cold and dryness and moistness being four,] the best of which are the white and soft, inclining to yellow: it is fattening, strengthening to the limbs or members, of use in cases of fracture and contusion, applied in a bandage, and drunk; also for the gout (niqoris), and spasmodic contraction (taXanRuj); and softens hardness of the joints; and improves the voice, and clears the throat and lungs; and excites to sexual intercourse. Some say, that it is the name of] the roots of the wild pomegranate; but this assertion is not of established authority. Others say, that it is a kind of suwranojaAn; and this is not improbable. The hakeem [Dáood] says, in the Tedhkireh, mgAv is [the name of] a certain plant in El-Kerej (Alkrj) and the parts adjacent; roots extending deep into the earth, and thick, with a rind inclining to black and red, which, when peeled off, discloses a substance, between white and yellow: the best thereof is the heavy, sweet-scented, in taste inclining to sweet, with a slight bitterness. It is said to have rough, or coarse, and wide, leaves, like those of the radish; and a white flower; and seeds resembling the grains of the sumonap, and called qlql: hence it has been imagined to be the pomegranate: and it is said to be a species of swrnjAn: its strength, or virtue, lasts about seven years: and there is a kind of it brought from 'Abbádán, and towards Syria, weak in operation; and it is this which is used in Egypt. (TA.) [M. Rouyer, in the Descr. de l'Egypte, tome 11 of the sec. ed., p. 452, describes it as follows: a root of a whitish colour, mucilaginous, fleshy, or pulpous, and of an aromatic odour: it is nutritive and aphrodisiac: it is taken in the simple substance; and they make of it a sherbet, which should be drunk hot: this root comes from the Indies.]

magiyvN c
magiyvN and mamoguwvN↓ Herbage laid prostrate by rain: (S, K:) herbage that is rained upon, and rendered yellow, and bad-tasted, and laid prostrate by the rain. (TA.) ― -b2- See magivN.

mamoguwvN c
mamoguwvN Affected by a fever. (IAar, K.) ― -b2- See magiyvN.

mumaAgivN c
mumaAgivN: see magivN.

1 magaja AlfaSiylu DaroEa OumRihi c
1. magaja AlfaSiylu DaroEa OumRihi: see mEj.

1 magada c
1. magada, aor.
magada
, (inf. n. magodN, S, L,) He (a child, and a lamb or kid, S, L, and a young camel, L, K) sucked his mother: he (a young camel) struck his mother in her udder with his head, and sucked her: and he (a lamb or kid) took the teat of his mother in his mouth to suck; (L;) as also maEaca, with the unpointed E and the pointed c. (IKtt.) ― -b2- magada He sucked, or sucked in, a thing: (K:) he sucked, or sucked in, the inside of Sarabap, i. e., [a piece of] the gum of the TaloH; for there is sometimes in the inner part thereof what resembles glue and the honey of dates or bees. (S, L.) See
also magodN, below. ― -b3- magada, aor.
magada
, inf. n. magodN; (L, K;) and magida, aor.
magada
, (L,) inf. n. magadN; (L, K;) He, (L,) or it, (the body, K,) became full and fat. (L, K.) ― -b4- magadahu, (aor.
magada
, inf. n. magodN, S, L.) It (a pleasant, or an ample, and easy, life) nourished him: (AZ, IAar, S, L:) or it (a life, or manner of living) nourished him, and rendered him in a state of amplitude and ease. (K.) ― -b5- magada He (a man, L) and it (a plant, L, K, or other thing, K, or anything, L) became tall. (Aboo-Málik, L, K.) ― -b6- magada fiI EayoXK naAEimK, (aor.
magada
, inf. n. magodN, S, L,) a phrase mentioned by Fr, (S,) He (a man) lived, and enjoyed abundant comforts, or luxury, in a pleasant, or an ample and easy, state of life. (K.) ― -b7- magadahu It (youth) caused him still to flourish, or to be in the flower of age. (En-Nadr, L.) ― -b8- magada He became in the full prime of youth. (L.) ＝ -A2- magada, aor.
magada
, inf. n. magoda, He plucked out hair: (L:) as also maEada. (L, art. mEd.) ― -b2- magada mawoDiEa AlgurRapi He plucked out the hair in the place of the blaze, or white mark on the forehead or face, of a horse, in order that it might become gray. (L, K.)

4 Amgdt c
4. Amgdt She (a woman) suckled her child; (S, L, K;) and a she camel, &c., her young one. (S, L.) ― -b2- Amgd, (inf. n. UimogaAdN, L,) He (a man, S, L,) drank much, or abundantly: (S, L, K:) or he drank long. (AHn, L.)

magodN c
magodN The flower, or flourishing period, of youth. (En-Nadr, L.) ― -b2- Soft; tender; delicate: pleasant; easy and ample: syn. naAEimN: (S, L, K:) applied to the period of youth: (S, L:) and to life, or a manner of living. (L.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) or magodu Aljisomi, (L,) Soft and plump: applied to a camel: (L, K:) or (so in the L; in the K, and) big, or bulky; (L, K;) as also maEodN; (L;) and tall: (K:) applied to anything. (L.) ＝ -A2- magodN, applied to the gurRap, or blaze, on the forehead or face of a horse; app. an inf. n. used in the sense of a pass. part. n.; Having the hair plucked out in order that it may become gray: (L:) the term magodN is used with relation to the blaze of a horse when it appears as though it were swollen; for the hair is plucked out in order that it may grow white: (S, L:) and with relation to the forelock, when it is as though burnt. (L.) ＝ -A3- magodN (L, K) and magadN↓ (L) The fruit of the [tree called] tanoDub: or (so in the L; but in the K, and) the [plant called] lufRaAH [q. v.]: (L, K:) or the wild lfRAH: (L:) or, both words, (so in the L; but in the K, and) the [plant called] baAcinojaAn: (L, K:) or a plant resembling the nAcnjAn, growing at the roots of the EiDah: (L:) and the former word, a fruit resembling the cucumber, (Aboo-Sa'eed, L, K,) which is eaten: (Aboo-Sa'eed, L:) or a kind of tree that twines about other trees, more slender than the vine, having long, thin, and soft, leaves, and producing a fruit like that of the banana, but thinner in the peel and more juicy, which is sweet, and is not peeled [to be eaten], with pips like those of the apple; people share this fruit among themselves, taking it by turns, alighting where it grows, and eating it; it appears first green; then becomes yellow; and then, at last, green [again, or probably red; for I think that yxDrR, in the L, from which this is taken, is a mistake for yHmrR]: the word is a coll. gen. n.: and] the n. un. is with p: (AHn, L:) ISd says, I have not heard magadapN; but magadN↓ may be a quasi-pl. n. of magodapN; like as HalaqN is of HaloqapN, and falakN of falokapN. (L.) ― -b2- magodN i. q. SarabapN, meaning as explained above, at 1: (S, L,) also, the gum of the lote-tree, sidor: (Aboo-Sa'eed, L:) or, of the lok-tree of the desert. (S, L.)

magadN c
magadN: see magodN.

2 mgRrhu c
2. mgRrhu He dyed it (namely a garment or piece of cloth) with magorap. (A.)

magarN c
magarN and mugorapN↓ (K, TA) A colour inclining to red: (TA:) or a colour not pure red, (K, TA,) nor inclining to yellow; its redness being like the colour of magorap↓: (TA:) or i. q. XuqorapN [i. e., in a man, ruddiness of complexion combined with fairness, and in a horse, a sorrel colour,] with duskiness, or dinginess. (K.) See also Oamogaru.

magorapN c
magorapN [Red ochre, called in the present day mugorap;] red earth, (S, A, Msb, K,) with which one dyes [and paints]; (TA;) well known; (A;) as also magarapN↓. (S, K.)

mugorapN c
mugorapN: see magarN.

magarapN c
magarapN: see magorapN.

Oamogaru c
Oamogaru i. q. OaXoqaru, (A, Msb,) applied to a man [and signifying Of a ruddy complexion combined with fairness], (A,) and to a horse [and signifying of a sorrel colour]: (A, Msb:) or red in the hair and skin, (S, K,) of the colour of magorap: (S:) and having redness in the face, with clear whiteness: (K:) or white, or white in face: as also OaHomaru: applied to a man: (TA:) and, applied to a horse, of a colour inclining to OaXoqar [or sorrel]; i. e. having his XuqorapN [or sorrel colour] tinged over with duskiness, or dinginess: (S:) and applied to a camel, of the colour of magorap: (K:) and so applied to a horse: or a horse not of a pure red colour, nor of a colour inclining to yellow, but of a red colour, like the colour of magorap, and having the mane and forelock and ears like the [red] colour termed Suhobap, without any whiteness: (TA:) [see also magarN:] the fem. is magoraMCu: and the dim. Oamayogiru. (TA.)

mamogarapN c
mamogarapN Land whence magorap comes forth, or is procured. (TA.)

mumagRarN c
mumagRarN A garment, or piece of cloth, (A,) dyed with magorap. (A, K.)

1 magVSa
1: [magaSahu, inf. n. magoSN, He pierced him with a spear or the like: for] magoSN is syn. with TaEonN; as also magosN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [Hence, perhaps,] mugiSa, (ISk, S, Msb, K,) [of which magoSN, which see below, is app. the inf. n.] and magiSa, (A, Msb, [in a copy of the former of which, instead of the former verb, I find maguSa, but this is probably a mistranscription,]) inf. n. magaSN; (Msb;) He (a man, S, Msb,) had what is termed magoSN as explained below; (ISk, S, A, Msb, K;) as also mugisa and magisa: (IKoot, Msb:) and maEiSa: (TA:) [it is most commonly with g and S; but Z says, that] the original word is with s, from magasahu signifying TaEanahu. (A.)

5 tmgRS baToniI c
5. tmgRS baToniI, and tamagRaSaniI, My belly pained me; as also tmgRs, with s. (TA.) [In the CK, we find tmgRS baTonahu, explained by OawojaEahu, as though signifying It pained his belly: but baTonahu is doubtless a mistake for baTonuhu. In MS. copies of the K, I do not find this verb.] ― -b2- And [hence,] tamagRaSaniI AlXRaIoCu (assumed tropical:) The thing hurt me: and in like manner, tamagRaSotu minohu (assumed tropical:) [I was hurt by it]. (TA.)

magoSN c
magoSN (ISk, S, A, Msb, K) and magaSN; (IDr, A, K;) but the former is the chaste word; (A;) or the latter, accord. to ISk, is vulgar, (S,) and Az pronounces him right in saying so, (Msb,) and Yaakoob disallows the latter word. wherefore the author of the K is wrong in imputing error, in this matter, [if error it be,] to J; (TA;) [Colic; or] pain in the belly, (A, K,) and griping (taqoTiyEN) in the bowels; (A;) or griping (tqTyE) in the bowels, and pain [therein]; (S;) or pain in the bowels, and contortion [therein]; (Msb;) as also magosN. (Yaakoob, TA.)

mamoguwSN c
mamoguwSN A man (S, Msb) having what is termed magoSN as explained above. (S, Msb, K.)

magonaTiysN c
magonaTiysN, (S, K,) or magoniyTisN, (as in some copies of the K and in the TA,) and magoniyTiysN (CK) and magonaATiysN (K) [The magnet;] a certain
stone that attracts iron: arabicized [from the Greek μαγνῆτις]. (S, K.) [Mentioned in S, L, K, in art. gTs; but, as observed in the TA, it should have a separate place.]

maAqiYN c
maAqiYN and muwqiYN The posterior, or, as some say, anterior, part of the eye: (K:) or the inner angle of the eye, next the nose. (K, &c., art. mOq.) Mentioned by most of the lexicographers in art. mOq, q. v. (TA.)

1 maqatahu c
1. maqatahu, (aor.
maquta
, Msb,) inf. n. maqotN (and, accord. to the K, maqaAtapN; but this is the inf. n. of maquta, q. v.; TA) He hated him: (S, K:) as also mqRth↓, (K,) inf. n. tamoqiytN; (TA;) [but this has, probably, an intensive signification;] or he hated him on account of a foul action that he had committed: (Lth:) or he hated him with the most violent hatred, (Zj, M, Er-Rághib, Msb,) on account of a foul action. (Msb.) ― -b2- maquta UilaI AlnRaAsi, aor.
maquta
, inf. n. maqaAtapN, He was hateful, or an object of hatred, to men, on account of a foul action that he had committed: (Lth:) or he was hateful, or an object of hatred, in the utmost degree, (M, Msb,) on account of a foul action. (Msb.)

2 maqRata
2: see 1.

3 maAqatahu c
3. maAqatahu He hated him [or hated him in the utmost degree] reciprocally, on account of some foul, or evil, affair. (A.) ― -b2- maAqatuwA [They bore hatred, one to another.] (TA, art. bht.)

4 maA Oamoqatahu EinodiI c
4. maA Oamoqatahu EinodiI How hated, or hateful, or odious, is he to me! (Sb, K.) ― -b2- maA OamoqataniI lahu How I hate him! (Sb, K.)

5 tmqRt Uilayohi c
5. tmqRt Uilayohi He showed, or manifested, hatred [or the utmost hatred] to him: contr. of tHbRb Alyh. (A.)

6 tmAqtwA c
6. tmAqtwA They hated one another, [or hated one another in the utmost degree,] on account of some foul, or evil, affair. (A.)

nikaAHu Almaqoti c
nikaAHu Almaqoti The marrying the wife of one's father after him; (K;) that is, after his having divorced her or died: (TA:) this was done in the time of paganism, (S,) and was then thus called; maqotN signifying the “ most violent hatred: ” it is forbidden in the Kur, iv. 26. (Zj.)

maqotiIRF c
maqotiIRF A man who has contracted the kind of marriage termed nkAH Almqt: (ISd, K:) or the son of such a man. (Zj, K.)

maqiytN c
maqiytN and mamoquwtN↓ Hated: (S, K:) or the former signifies hateful, and the latter hated: (MF:) [or hateful, and hated, on account of his having committed a foul action: in this sense mqyt is mentioned by Lth: or hateful, and hated, in the utmost degree, on account of a foul action: in this sense mqyt is mentioned in the Msb.]

mamoquwtN c
mamoquwtN: see maqiytN.

maqadiIRN c
maqadiIRN A certain kind of beverage, prepared from honey, (S, L, K,) which the Khaleefehs of the sons of Umeyyeh used to drink: (L:) so called in relation to a town in Syria, (S, L,) called maqadN; or in relation to a town in Syria in the province of El-Urdunn: (L:) or this is a mistake; for the name of the town is with teshdeed [maqadRN]: IB says, that the orthography of the word as best known to the lexicologists is maqadiIRN, without teshdeed; but that A 'Obeyd and others write it with teshdeed; and that IAmb cites in confirmation of its being thus a verse of 'Amr Ibn-Maadeekerib, at the end of which occurs the expression Xagaluwhu Eano Xarobi AlmaqadRi; without I; [app. for maqadRiI;] adding, that it is thus called in relation to maqadRN, a town of Damascus, in the mountain overlooking El-Ghór: (L:) A 'Obeyd says, I hold it to be correctly maqadRiIRN; and I heard Rejà Ibn-Selemeh explain this as signifying “ wine diminished to half its quantity by boiling; ” as though it were divided (qudRa) in halves: (Sh, L:) IB adds, that Aboo-t-Teyyib the lexicologist says, that the word in question is with d without teshdeed; from maqadN; and is only written with teshdeed by poetic licence: and in confirmation of this assertion, IB cites verses in which the name of the town and that of the beverage are written without teshdeed. (L.) ― -b2- vawobN maqadiIRN A certain well-known kind of cloth, or garment: (L, TA:) you say viyaAbN maqadiyRapN. (K. [In the CK, erroneously, maqadRiyRapN.])

1 maqira c
1. maqira, aor.
maqara
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. maqarN, (S, A, Msb, K,) It was, or became, bitter; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also Amqr↓, (ISk, IKtt, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. UimoqaArN: (Msb:) or sour, or acid: (K:) and Amqr↓, said of milk, (AZ, A, K,) it became almost bitter, by reason of its quality of biting the tongue: (A:) or lost its [proper] flavour (AZ, K) by becoming intensely sour or acid. (AZ, TA.) ＝ -A2- maqara Eunuqaha, (ISk, S, A, K,) aor.
maqura
, inf. n. maqorN, (ISk, S,) He bruised his neck: (S, A:) or beat it with a staff or stick, so as to break the bone in pieces, leaving the skin whole. (A, K.) ― -b2- And hence, (A,) maqara AlsRamakapa AlmaAliHapa He macerated the salt fish in vinegar; (A, K;) as also Amqr↓. (K.) And in like manner you say of anything that you macerate. (TA.)

4 Oamoqara
4: see 1, in three places. ＝ -A2- Oamoqarotu lifulaAnK XaraAbFA I made beverage bitter to, or for, such a one. (IDrd.)

maqorN c
maqorN: see maqirN, in three places.

maqirN c
maqirN Bitter; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also maqorN↓ (TA) and mumoqirN↓ (S, A, K) and yamoquwrN↓: (Sgh, K:) or sour; acid; as also mumoqirN↓: (K:) which last also signifies intensely sour or acid; (AZ, Aboo-Málik, S; *) applied to milk: (the same, and K:) or sour, or acid, milk. (Msb.) ― -b2- Aloes; syn. SabirN: (As, S, A, Msb, K:) as also maqorN↓: (S:) or a certain thing resembling it: (IKt, Msb, K:) or poison: as also maqorN↓; (K;) which is said by some to be a form used by poetic license: (TA:) or, accord. to AA, a certain bitter kind of tree: and accord. to AHn, a certain plant, which grows in leaves without branches. (TA.) [See SaqirN.]

mumoqirN c
mumoqirN: see maqirN, in two places.

samakN mamoquwrN c
samakN mamoquwrN Fish macerated in vinegar and salt, so as to become a cold sauce or fluid seasoning: (Az, TA:) or sour, or acid, fish: (IAar, TA:) or fish bruised (yumoqaru) in water and salt: you should not say manoquwrN. (S.)

yamoquwrN c
yamoquwrN: see maqirN.

maAqiTN c
maAqiTN The freedman of a freedman: (K:) or the slave of a slave of a freedman: whence the Arabs say, in reviling, fulaAnN saAqiTu bonu maAqiTi boni laAqiTK. (S.) See art. sqT. ― -b2- muqRaATN [which is its pl.] like suqRaATN and luqRaATN, signifies, accord. to IAar, The refuse, or lowest or basest or meanest sort, or mankind, or of people. (TA in art. xXr.)

makoCN c
makoCN The hole of a fox, or of a hare, or rabbit: or, accord. to Th, the hole of the kind of lizard called DabR. (L.)

makata c
makata, [aor.
makuta
,] He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, in a place: (K:) like makada: accord. to some, a word mispronounced: accord. to others for makava; the v being changed into t. (TA.)

10 Uisotamokatati Albavorapu c
10. Uisotamokatati Albavorapu The pustule became filled with pus, or matter. (IAar, T, K.)

1 makava c
1. makava, aor.
makuva
; and makuva, aor.
makuva
; inf. n. makovN [with which mukovN and mikvN (see below) are syn.] and mikRiyvaI (S, K) [like xiSRiySaI, q. v.,] and mikRiyvaMCu [like xiSRiySaMCu] and makavN and mukuwvN and mukovaAnN (K) and makaAvN and makaAvapN [which last is the inf. n. of makuva]; (TA;) He tarried; tarried and waited, or expected; (S, K;) was patient, and tarried, and waited, or expected: or he tarried, stayed, or stopped, expecting: loitered; tarried; stayed; waited; paused in expectation; fiI makaAnK in a place. (TA.) [In like manner,] tmkRv↓ He loitered; tarried; stayed; waited; paused in expectation. (S, K.)

5 tamakRava
5: see 1.

mukovN c
mukovN and mikovN↓, substs., from makava or makuva, A tarrying; tarrying and waiting, or expecting; &c. (S, A.)

mikovN c
mikovN: see mukovN.

makiyvN c
makiyvN Grave: (S, K:) who does not hasten in his affair: pl. mukavaMCu and makiyvuwna. (TA.) ― -b2- makiyvu AlkalaAmi (tropical:) Slow of speech. (Ibn-Abi-l- Hadeed.) ― -b3- Also makiyvN A man remaining; staying; abiding; remaining fixed, or stationary. (TA.)

saAra AlrRajulu mutamakRivFA c
saAra AlrRajulu mutamakRivFA The man journeyed, or proceeded, loitering; syn. mutalawRimFA. (S.)

1 makada c
1. makada, (S, L, K,) aor.
makuda
, (L,) inf. n. mukuwdN (S, L, K) and makodN, (K,) He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, (S, L, K,) bimakaAnK in a place; (S, L;) as also makata. (TA.)

maAkidN c
maAkidN Water (L) lasting, or continuing, (L, K,) unceasingly. (K.) ― -b2- naAqapN maAkidapN A she-camel abounding with milk; as also makodaMCu↓: (K:) or constantly, or always, abounding with milk; (L;) as also makodaMCu↓ (S, L;) and makuwdN↓: (S, L, K:) like nakodaMCu: (S, L:) pl. of makuwdN, mukodN, (K,) or mukudN, and makaAYidu. (L.) ― -b3- biYorN maAkidapN, and makuwdN↓ A well having a constant, or unceasing, supply of water: (L:) and rakiyRapN maAkidapN a well whereof the water remains without diminution [to which is added EalaI qaroni wAHidK laA yatagayRaru waAlqaronu qaronu AlqaAmapi, app. meaning, of the measure of one qaron, not changing; by qrn being meant the structure of stone which supports the wood whereto the pulley is suspended, and which is described as being of the proportion of a man]. (S, L.) ― -b4- wudRN maAkidN (tropical:) Unceasing love or affection. (L.)

makuwdN c
makuwdN: see maAkidN.

makodaMCu c
makodaMCu: see maAkidN.

1 makara c
1. makara, aor.
makura
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. makorN; (S, A, Msb, K;) and Amkr↓; (Msb;) He practised deceit, guile, or circumvention; or he practised deceit, guile, or circumvention, desiring to do to another a foul, an abominable, or an evil, action, clandestinely, or without his knowing whence it proceeded; syn. xadaEa; (Msb;) and of the inf. n. xadiyEapN: (S, A, K:) he practised an evasion or elusion, a shift, an artifice, or artful contrivance or device, a machination, a trick, a plot, a stratagem, or an expedient; he plotted; or he exercised art, craft, cunning, or skill, in the management or ordering of affairs, with excel-lent consideration or deliberation, and ability to manage according to his own free will; syn. of the inf. n. UiHotiyaAlN: (S, TA:) or to this explanation, conveyed by AHtyAl as the syn. of the inf. n., should be added secretly, or privately: (Lth, TA:) makorN is praised or dispraised according to the nature of its object. (El-Basáir.) [For further explanation, see what follows.] ― -b2- It is trans. by means of bi: and also, accord. to Z, by itself: (MF:) [but I know not any instance of its being trans. by itself: except as meaning he plotted a thing: see makora AlsRayRiY in the Kur, xxxv. 41, cited voce sayRiYN:] you say makara bihi, (S, A, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S, TA,) meaning, He deceived, beguiled, or circumvented, him; or he deceived, beguiled, or circumvented, him, and desired to do him a foul, an abominable, or an evil, action, clandestinely, or without his knowing whence it proceeded: &c.: (S, A, TA:) syn. kaAdahu: or it differs [somewhat] from kAdh, accord. to Aboo-Hilál El-'Askeree: (TA:) some say, that mkr bh signifies as above with the addition of feigning the contrary of his real intentions; which kAdh does not imply: or this latter signifies “ he did him harm, ” or “ mischief; ” and the former, he did him harm, or mischief, clandestinely. (MF, voce kAd.) See art. xdE. ― -b3- makara also signifies He managed with thought, or consideration, or acted with policy, and practised stratagem, in war. (TA.) ― -b4- makara QllRehu and Oamokara↓ are syn., (IKtt, Msb,) signifying, (tropical:) God recompensed, or requited, for makor [or the practising deceit, &c.]: (Lth, * Msb, TA: *) or makoru QllRehi signifies God's granting a man respite or delay, and enabling him to accomplish his worldly aims [so as to bring upon himself the punishment due to his evil actions]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or, accord. to IAth, God's causing his trials to befall his enemies, exclusively of his friends: or his taking men by little and little, so that they do not reckon upon it, bestowing upon them renewed favours for acts of obedience which are imagined to be accepted whereas they are rejected. (TA.)

3 mAkrhu c
3. mAkrhu He practised with him mutual deceit, guile, or circumvention; &c.; (A, * TA;) syn. xaAdaEahu. (TA.)

4 Oamokara
4: see 1, in two places.

6 tmAkrwA c
6. tmAkrwA They practised mutual deceit, guile, or circumvention; &c. (A, * TA.)

makuwrN c
makuwrN: see maAkirN.

makRaArN c
makRaArN: see maAkirN.

maAkirN c
maAkirN (S, A, Msb, K) and makRaArN↓ (S, A, K) and makuwrN↓ (K) epithets from makara: (S, A, Msb, K:) [the first signifying Practising deceit, guile, or circumvention; &c.: and the second and third, practising the same much, or frequently; deceitful, guileful, artful, crafty, or cunning; a trickster, or crafty knave.]

1 makasa c
1. makasa, aor.
makisa
, (TK,) inf. n. makosN, (Sh, A, K,) He diminished, or deducted from, a thing; (Sh, * A, * K, * TK;) syn. of the inf. n. taqoSN. (Sh, A, K.) Thus Sh explains makos in the saying of Jábir Ibn-Jinnee Et-Taghlibee:
OafiI kulRi OasowaAqi AlEiraAqi UitaAwapN
wafiI kulRi maA baAEa QmoruWN makosu dirohami
[Is there bribing in every one of the markets of El-'Irák, and in the case of everything that a man has sold the deducting of a dirhem?]. (TA.) [Hence,] you say, makasa fiI AlbayoEi, aor. and inf. n. as above; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and mAks↓, inf. n. mumaAkasapN and mikaAsN: (S, Mgh, Msb:) both signify He diminished, or deducted from, the price in the selling, or buying: (Msb:) or both signify he desired, or demanded, a diminution of, or deduction from, the price in selling or buying: (Mgh, TA, *) or the former signifies he collected property in selling or buying: (K: [but from what I find in the other lexicons, I think it probable that an early copyist has perverted the text of the K here by making a transposition; writing makasa fiI AlbayoEi yamokisu makosFA jabaI maAlFA wAalmakosu AlnRaqoSu waAlZRulomu for
