makasa yamokisu makosFA jabaI maAlFA waAlmakosu fI AlbayoEi AlnRaqoSu waAlZRulomu: in the TK we find jnI mAlA, which is certainly a mistake:]) or makosN signifies the diminishing (UinotiqaAS) of the price of a commodity: (M, TA:) and mikaAsN↓, the acting with mutual niggardliness in bargaining; or, accord. to EshShereeshee, the vying in acuteness between a seller and buyer, the former demanding a price and the latter offering less, time after time, until they agree to a reduced price. (Har, p. ???.) You say also, mukisa, meaning, He (a man) suffered a diminution, or deduction, in selling or buying and the like. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps, or the reverse may be the case,] He wronged a man; treated him, or used him, wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically. (A, * K, * TK. [In the first and second, only the inf. n. of the verb in this sense is mentioned.]) ― -b3- [Hence, also, app.,] He (the makRaAs, Mgh, Msb) collected a tax; syn. jabaI; [particularly, the tax termed makos:] (S, * M, Mgh, * Msb [in the first and third of which, only the inf. n. of the verb in this sense is mentioned:]) or he collected property. (A.) Hence the saying, (Mgh,) in a trad., (S,) laA yadojulu SaAHibu makosK AljanRapa (S, Mgh) [The taker of the tax termed mks will not enter paradise]; meaning, the EaXRaAr. (TA.)

3 mAks fiI AlbayoEi c
3. mAks fiI AlbayoEi: see 1. ― -b2- mAkshu, (K,) inf. n. mumaAkasapN [and mikaAsN], (TA,) He acted with him in a niggardly, a tenacious, or an avaricious, manner; syn. XaAHRahu: (K: but in some copies, XaAkasahu. TA,) or mAkshu fI AlbayoEi signifies he contended with him [by bidding against him or otherwise] in the sale. (MA.) [See, in art. kys, voce kaAsa, an ex. from a trad., accord. to one reading thereof.]

6 tmAksA c
6. tmAksA They acted in a niggardly, a tenacious, or an avaricious, manner, each with the other, in bargaining: (IDrd, K:) or tmAkswA fiI AlbayoEi they contended, one with another, [by outbidding or otherwise] in the sale. (MA.)

makosN c
makosN, an inf. n., (see 1,) used as a subst., (Mgh, Msb,) Money that used to be taken from the seller of commodities in the markets in the time of ignorance: (IDrd, M, K:) and a dirhem which the collector of the poor-rate used to take after he had finished the receipt of that tribute: (IAar, K:) or what is taken by the EaXRaAr, (S, Mgh,) or maAkis, (S,) or makRaAs: (Mgh, Msb:) so [accord. to some] in the verse above cited: (S:) the tax, or impost, which he used to take: (TA:) and generally, what the Sultán's guards take wrongfully on an occasion of buying and selling: so [accord. to some] in the verse cited above: (Msb:) pl. mukuwsN. (A, Mgh, Msb.)

makRaAsN c
makRaAsN (A, Mgh, Msb) and maAksN↓ (S) One who takes, or receives, what is termed makos: (Mgh, Msb;) i. e., (Mgh,) i. q. EaXRaArN. (S, Mgh.)

maAkisN c
maAkisN: see makRaAsN.

1 malaOa c
1. malaOa, aor.
malaAa
, inf. n. maloCN (S, K) and maloOapN and miloOapN; (K;) and maliYa; (TA;) and mlRO↓, inf. n. tamoliYapN; (K;) He filled (K;) a vessel &c. (S, TA.) You may also say malaOotuhu malFA, for maloYFA, (TA.) ― -b2- malaOa AlEayona (tropical:) He satisfied [or glutted] the eye by his comeliness of aspect. (TA.) See an ex. in a verse cited voce EaqibN. ― -b3- malaOotu minohu EayoniI (tropical:) [I satisfied, or glutted, my eye by the sight of his comeliness]. (TA.) ― -b4- maluWa, aor.
maluAa
, (K,) inf. n. malaMCapN and malaMCN; (S, K;) and malaOa, aor.
malaAa
; (K;) the former is that which commonly obtains; (TA;) He became rich, wealthy, &c., syn. SaAra maliyYFA. (K.) ― -b5- kalimapN tamolaOu Alfama (assumed tropical:) [A word, or saying, that fills the mouth;] i. e., gross, and abominable; not allowable to be spoken; that fills the mouth so that it cannot articulate. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b6- UimolaWuwA OafowaACakumo mina AlquroMni (assumed tropical:) [Fill your mouths with the Kur-án]. (TA.) ― -b7- muliYa ruEobFA, and maluWa rEbA, (tropical:) He was filled with fright. (A.) ― -b8- malaOa viyaAbiI (tropical:) He sprinkled my clothes with mud, &c. (A.) malaOa raAkibahu [He (a camel) bespattered his rider with his ejected cud]. (S, K, art. zrd.) ― -b9- malaOa EinaAnahu (assumed tropical:) He made, or urged, his beast to run vehemently. (TA in art. En.) ― -b10- muliYa, like EuniIa, [i. e., pass. in form, but neut. in signification,] and maluWa, (tropical:) He had the disease called mulaMCap. (A, K.) ― -b11- See 3.

2 mlRO furuwja farasihi c
2. mlRO furuwja farasihi He made his horse to run at the utmost rate of the pace termed HuDor. (TA.) ― -b2- And see 1, and 4.

3 mAlOhu EalaI AlOamori c
3. mAlOhu EalaI AlOamori, (S, K,) inf. n. mumaAlaOapN; (S;) and malaOahu↓; (K;) but this latter the lexicologists do not hold in good repute; (TA;) He aided, or assisted, him, and conformed with him, to do the thing. (IAar, * AZ, S, K.)

4 AmlO AlnRazoEa fiI qawosihi c
4. AmlO AlnRazoEa fiI qawosihi, (S,) and AmlO fI qwsh, and fI qwsh mlRO↓, (K,) (tropical:) He pulled his bow to the utmost. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- AmlOhu AllRehu, (S, K,) inf. n. UimolaACN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) God affected him with the disease called mulaMCap. (S, K.)

5 tmlRO mina AlTRaEaAmi waAlXRaraAbi c
5. tmlRO mina AlTRaEaAmi waAlXRaraAbi He became full of food and drink. (S.) ― -b2- See 8. ― -b3- tmlRO gayoZFA, and AmtlO↓, (tropical:) He became filled with rage. (S.) ― -b4- tmlRO XibaEFA, and AmtlO↓, He became filled to satiety. (TA.) ― -b5- tmlRO He put on himself a mulaMCap; i. e., a covering of the kind so called. (TA.)

6 tamaAlaWuwA EalaI AlOamori c
6. tamaAlaWuwA EalaI AlOamori They agreed, or conspired together, to do the thing: (ISk, S, K, TA:) they aided, or assisted, [and conformed with,] one another to do the thing. (TA.)

8 AmtlO c
8. AmtlO and tmlRO↓; (S, K;) and maliYa, aor.
malaAa
; (K;) It (a vessel, &c., TA) became full. (S, K.) ― -b2- See 5. ― -b3- AmtlO XabaAbFA (assumed tropical:) [He became full of sap, or vigour, or youth, or young manhood]. (The Lexicons, &c., passim.) And AmtlO AlXRabaAbu (assumed tropical:) [The sap, or vigour, of youth, or young manhood, became full, or mantled, in a person.] (S, K, in art. gTI.) [And AmtlO, alone, He was, or became, plump.] ― -b4- AmtlO EinaAnuhu (assumed tropical:) The utmost of his power, or ability, was accomplished. (TA in art. En.)

10 AstmlO fiI AldRayoni c
10. AstmlO fiI AldRayoni signifies jaEala dayonahu fiI mulaOLCa (CK, and a MS copy of the K) [app., He made wealthy persons, or honest wealthy persons, his debtors: but in one copy of the K, for mulaOLCa, we find mulaMCK, which affords no sense that seems admissible here: and in another, diyn seems to be put in the place of dayon, in both the above instances; and malaMCK in that of mulaOLCa; for Golius renders the phrase AstmlO fI Aldyn by opulentiæ studuit in religione sua: i. e., religionem suam in illa posuit: a meaning which IbrD rejects].

miloCN c
miloCN [A thing sufficient in quantity, or dimensions, for the filling of a vessel, &c., or] the quantity that a vessel, &c., holds when it is filled. (S, K.) ― -b2- OaEoTihi miloOahu wamiloOayohi wavalaAvapa OamolaMYihi Give it (i. e., the cup, TA) what will fill it; and what will twice fill it; and what will thrice fill it. (S, K.) ― -b3- HajarN miloCu AlkafRi A stone that fills the hand. (TA.) ― -b4- laka AlHamodu miloCu AlsRamawaAti waAlOaroDi To Thee be praise that shall fill the heavens and the earth. (TA.) ― -b5- miloCu kisaAYihaA A fat woman; that fills her ksAC when she covers herself with it. (TA, from a trad.)

malaON c
malaON An assembly, (IAar, S, K,) absolutely, (TA,) [whether of nobles or others]: pl. OamolaMCN. (IAar.) ― -b2- Nobles; chiefs; princes; syn. OaXoraAfN and EiloyapN; (K;) principal persons; persons whose opinion is respected. (TA.) (AlmalaOu AlOaEloIa [The most exalted princes; i. e.] the angels that are admitted near [to the presence of God]; or the archangels. TA.) See samEahu, for other explanations. ― -b3- A people of comely appearance, figure, attire, or adornment, united for some purpose or design; expl. by qawomN cw AlXRaArapi wAltRajamRuEi liloUiraAdapi: (Abu-l-Hasan, K:) [but this is wrong, see Beyd,
ii. 247.] Thus it is of a different class from rahaTN, though, like this word, a quasi-pl. n. It is an epithet in which the quality of a substantive predominates. (Abu-l-Hasan.) ― -b4- (tropical:) Consultation. (K.) [You say,] maA kaAna hecaA AlOamoru Eano malaUK minRaA (tropical:) This thing was not the result of a consultation and consent on our part: [and] OakaAna hecaA Eano malaUK minokumo (tropical:) Was this the result of a consultation of your nobles, and of your assembly? said by 'Omar when he was stabbed: asserted to be tropical in this sense by Z and others. (TA.) taHadRavuwA malaOF They conversed, consulting together. (S.) ― -b5- Opinion. (K.) [See a supposed example below.] ― -b6- Disposition; nature; manners; (S, K;) a nature rich in needful qualities: (T:) pl. OamolaMCN. (S.) [You say,] maA OaHosana malaOa baniI fulaAnK How good are the dispositions, or manners, and conversation, of the sons of such a one! (S.) ElJuhanee says,
tanaAdawoA yaAla buhovapa Uico raOawonaA
faqulonaA OaHosiniI malaOF juhayonaA
(S) [They called out, one to another, O Buhtheh! come to our aid! when they saw us: and we said,] Be of good disposition, or manners, O Juheyneh! or, accord. to some, Be of good opinion, O Juheyneh! (see above:) or, as some say, Aid well, O Juheyneh! taking mlO in the sense of mumaAlaOapF: [see 3]. (TA.) ― -b7- OaHosinuwA OamolaMCa kumo Amend your manners; or have good manners. From a trad. (S, K.) ― -b8- Also malaON A coveting. (K.)

muloOapN c
muloOapN A tremulousness and flabbiness and swelling of the flesh, in a camel, in consequence of long confinement after a journey. (K.) ― -b2- See mulaMCapN.

miloOapN c
miloOapN The manner in which a thing is filled. (K.) [You say,] UinRahu laHasanu AlmiloOapi (not AltRamalRuWi) Verily it is well filled. (K.) ― -b2- miloOapN An oppression occasioned by repletion with food. (K, TA.) [See also mulaMCapN.]

malaMCN c
malaMCN and malaMCapN↓ Richness, wealthiness, &c.: (K:) or trustiness, or honest. (S.) [See maliIoCN.]

mulaMCN c
mulaMCN: see mulaMCapN.

maliIoCN c
maliIoCN, (S, K,) also written and pronounced maliIRN, (Nh,) A rich, wealthy, opulent, man: (K:) or trusty, or honest: (S:) or trusty, or honest, and rich: (TA:) or a rich man, or one not literally rich, who is honest, and pays his debts well, without giving trouble to his creditor: (K, * TA:) or an able, rich, man: (Msb:) [a solvent man:] pl. milaMCN and OamoliYaMCu and mulaOLCu. (K.) ― -b2- Also mulaOLCu Chiefs: so called because rich in needful things. (TA.)

mulaMCapN c
mulaMCapN (K) and muloOapN↓ (S, K) and mulaMCN↓ (K) (tropical:) A defluxion, or rheum, syn. zukaAmN, (S, K,) occasioned by repletion, or a heaviness in the head, like a defluxion, or rheum, (zkAm,) from repletion of the stomach. (A.) [See also miloOapN.] ＝ -A2- mulaMCapN A piece of drapery which is wrapped about the body; i. q., UizaArN (TA) and rayoTapN: (S, K:) or the mlACp is a covering for the body formed of two pieces; (TA;) composed of two oblong pieces of cloth sewed together; (Msb, in art. lgq;) and the ryTp is of a single piece. (TA.) [It appears to have been generally yellow, (see warosN, and Oaworasa,) and was probably otherwise similar to the modern milaAyap, which is described and represented in my work on the Modern Egyptians, part i., ch. 1.] Pl. mulaMCN; (S, K;) [or rather this is a quasi-pl. n.; or a coll. gen. n., of which mlACp is the n. un.;] or, accord. to some, mulaON; but the former is better established. (TA.) Dim. mulayoYapN; for which mulayRapN was also used, accord. to a tradition. (TA.) ― -b2- mulaMCapu AlHusoni (tropical:) Fairness of complexion. (TA.) ― -b3- AlmaHoDu AlmulaMCu↓ (tropical:) Simple dust. (TA.) ― -b4- Also mulaMCapN The skim that forms on the surface of milk. (El-Moajam.)

maloMnN c
maloMnN (S, K) [and maloMnu, as it forms in the] fem. maloMnapN (K) and maloOaI; (S;) pl. milaMCN; (K;) Full: (S, K) said of a vessel, &c. (S, TA.) The masc. is also written and pronounced malaAn; and the fem., malaA: (TA:) and the vulgar say UinaACN malaA A full vessel. (S, TA.) ― -b2- maloMnN mn Alkarami (tropical:) [Full of generosity]. (TA.) ― -b3- See mamoluwoCN.

maAliYN c
maAliYN (tropical:) A majestic person: one whose aspect satisfies the eye. (TA.) ― -b2- maAliYN AlEayoni, and maAliYN liloEayoni, (tropical:) A person whose aspect satisfies the eye by his comeliness &c. (TA.)

fulaAnN OamolaOu liEayoniI mino fulaAnK c
fulaAnN OamolaOu liEayoniI mino fulaAnK (tropical:) Such a one is more satisfactory to my eye by his comeliness than such a one. (TA.) ― -b2- hecaA AlOamoru OamolaOu bika This thing is better for thee, and more satisfactory: expl. by Oamolaku [which is said to have this signification]. (TA.)

mamoluwoCN c
mamoluwoCN, pass. part. n. of malaOa, Filled. (S.) ― -b2- Also, (assumed tropical:) Having the disease called mulaMCap: as part. n. of maliYa. (A.) ― -b3- Also, (and accord. to some copies of the K, maloMn↓,) Affected by God with that disease: extr. [with respect to rule], (S, K,) as it is used in the sense of the pass. part. n. of OamolaOa: by rule it should be mumolaON. (TA.)

mumoliYN c
mumoliYN An ewe in whose belly are water and matter [such seems to be the meaning of OagoraAsN in the explanation] so that one thinks her to be pregnant. (K.)

XaAbRN mumotaliYN c
XaAbRN mumotaliYN [A youth in the full bloom of his age. See art. EaboEabN.]

malaAbN c
malaAbN: see art. lwb, in which, as well as here, it is mentioned in the K.

1 malata c
1. malata, aor.
malita
, (inf. n. malotN, TA.) He put [a thing] in motion, or into a state of commotion: (ISd, K:) like matala: also mentioned by IDrd, who expresses uncertainty as to its correctness. (TA.)

milRiytN c
milRiytN i. q. snofu Almaroxi; (K;) i. e., The leaves of the tree called marox. (TA.)

OamoluwtN c
OamoluwtN an epithet applied to a mafaAzap [or water-less desert]. (Marg. note in a copy of the S.)

OamaAliytu c
OamaAliytu Swift camels. (K.) It is said to be a quasi-pl. n.: or a pl. that has no sing.: or its sing. is OumoluwtN or UimaliytN: some of the lexicologists reject it. (MF.)

1 malavahu c
1. malavahu, aor.
maluva
, inf. n. malovN, He soothed, or tranquilized his mind, with words; spoke to him sweetly, or pleasantly; soothed him with agreeable words; (S, K;) not meaning to fulfil his words: as also malacahu, aor.
maluva
, inf. n. malocN: (TA:) ex. saOalotuhu HaAjapF famalavaniI I asked him to do a thing that I wanted, and he soothed my mind by a promise, not meaning to fulfil it. (A.) ― -b2- In like manner, He made him a promise, (as though he would repel him from him, S,) not meaning to fulfil it. (S, K.) Accord. to Ibn-Abi-l-Hadeed, He made him a concealed promise: but this is a strange explanation. (MF.) ― -b3- malava, inf. n. malovN, He lied; as also malaca. (TA, art. mlc.) ― -b4- malava AlZRalaAmu The darkness became mixed with the light: this happens at nightfall and at daybreak. (AZ.) ― -b5- malavahu biAlXRarRi He aspersed him, or bespattered him with evil. (A.) ― -b6- malavahu, [aor.
maluva
,] inf. n. malovN, He beat him lightly; (K;) like magavahu, q. v. (TA.) ― -b7- malava He (a hare, TK,) was unable to run; too weak to run. (K.)

3 mAlvhu c
3. mAlvhu, (inf. n. milaAvN, TA,) He treated him with dissimulation, and jested, or joked, with him. (K.)

malovN c
malovN and malavN↓ and mulovapN↓ The first, or commencement, of the blackness of night: (K:) or it is after the sadaf: (TA:) or the first, or commencement, of the blackness of the place of sunset: when it has become intense, and the last EiXaMC has come, it is called malas. (IAar.) ― -b2-
AlZRalaAmi Oatayotuhu malava↓, (S, K,) and malova AlZlAm, (K,) and Einoda mlvihi, (TA,) I came to him at the period when the darkness became confused, (S, K,) and had not yet become very intense, [as it has] when thou sayest Oaxuwka Oami AlcRiYobu [(Is this) thy brother, or the wolf?]; (S;) i. e. at the time of the prayer of sunset, and after it. (As, S.) ― -b3- SlAp Almlvi The prayer of sunset: in the dial. of Rabee'ah. (A.) ― -b4- maA kaAna Eahoduhu UilRaA walovFA wawaEoduhu UilRaA malovFA [His compact was not otherwise than weak, and his promise not otherwise than one not meant to be fulfilled]. (A.)

milovN c
milovN One who does not become satiated with coitus. (K.) You say rajulN milovN and UimoraOapN milovN. (TK.)

malavN c
malavN See malotN.

mulovapN c
mulovapN See malotN.

1 malaja OumRahu c
1. malaja OumRahu, (S, K,) aor.
maluja
; and malijahaA, aor.
; (K;) inf. n. malojN; (S, K;) He (a child) sucked [the breast of] his mother: (S:) or he took his mother's teat with the extremity of his mouth. (S, K.) And malaja AlnRaAqapa, said of a young camel, He sucked the she-camel; like salajahaA. (L, TA, in art. slj.)

4 Oamolajatohu OumRuhu c
4. Oamolajatohu OumRuhu, (Msb,) inf. n. UimolaAjN, (S,) His mother suckled him. (Msb.) [The masc. form of the verb is mentioned in the K.]

8 Amtlj c
8. Amtlj He sucked milk: (K:) or he (a young weaned camel,) sucked what was in the udder. (S.)

mulujN c
mulujN Sucking kids. (K.)

malojapN c
malojapN A single suck. (Msb.) [See also maloHapN.]

malojaAnu c
malojaAnu A man who sucks the teats of his camels, (or of his sheep or goats, TA,) by reason of his avarice; (S, K;) not milking them lest he should be heard: (TA:) as also maSRaAnu. (S.)

maliyjN c
maliyjN A foster-brother; syn. raDiyEN. (K.) ― -b2- An illustrious man. (K.)

maAlajN c
maAlajN (S, K) and maAlajapN, (S, in art. syE,) [A plasterer's trowel;] a thing with which one plasters: (S, K:) an arabicized word, from the Persian, (S,) [originally maAlaho].

OumoluwjN c
OumoluwjN [Sugar-candy]: see OuboluwjN.

UimolaAjapN c
UimolaAjapN A single act of suckling. (TA.) ― -b2- It is said in a trad., lA tuHarRimu AlUimolaAjapu walaA AlUimolaAjataAni, (S,) i. e. One act of suckling, or the giving one such, does not bar [the two parties from marrying each other], nor do two acts of suckling, or the giving two sucks, like as complete suckling does. (TA.)

1 malaHato fulaAnapN lifulaAnK c
1. malaHato fulaAnapN lifulaAnK, (aor.
malaHa
and
maluHa
, L,) (tropical:) Such a woman suckled, or gave suck, for such a one. (A, L.) ― -b2- malaHonaA lifulaAnK, inf. n. maloHN, (S,) We [meaning the wife of one of us] suckled, or gave suck, for such a one: (As, L:) or we suckled such a one. (S.) ― -b3- malaHa Alwalada [app. He caused the child to be suckled;] syn. with OaroDaEahu. (K.) [See OaroDaEa.] ― -b4- maluHa; (L;) and mlRH↓, inf. n. tamoliyHN; and tmlRH↓; (L, K;) the last said to be formed by transposition from tHlRm; but ISd, sees no reason for this assertion; (L;) (tropical:) He (a camel. L,) became fat. (L, K.) mlRHt↓ she (a camel destined for slaughter) became fat: (El-Umawee, S:) or, became a little fat: (K:) She (a camel) became fat in a small degree. (L.) Also tmlRHt↓ (tropical:) They (lizards such as are called DibaAb) became fat; as also tHlRmt. (L.) ＝ -A2- maluHa, aor.
maluHa
, inf. n. muluwHapN (S, Msb, K) and malaAHapN; (K;) this form of the verb is of the dial. of the people of El-'Áliyeh; (Msb;) and malaHa, aor.
maluHa
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. muluwHN; (S, Msb;) and malaHa, aor,
malaHa
; (IAar, K;) and AmlH↓, inf. n. UimolaAHN, of the dial. of El-Hijáz; (Msb;) It (water) was salt: (S, Msb, K:) or AmlH↓ signifies it became salt, having been sweet. (K.) ― -b2- maluHa, aor.
maluHa
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. malaAHapN (S, Msb) and muluwHapN (S) and miloHN, the first of which is the most common, and the last the least common, (TA,) (tropical:) It (a thing, S, Msb) was, or became, goodly, beautiful, or pretty; (S, Msb, K;) and beautiful of colour; or beautiful and bright; (Msb;) pleasing to the eye or ear; facetious. (The lexicons passim.) ― -b3- malaHa Alqidora, aor.
malaHa
and
maliHa
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. maloHN, (S, Msb,) He put salt into the cooking-pot: (K:) or put a proper quantity of salt into it: (S, A, Msb:) and accord. to Sb, mlRH↓ and AmlH↓ signify the same as malaHa: (ISd:) or malRaHahaA, inf. n. tamoliyHN, and OamolaHahaA, signify he put much salt into it, (S, Msb, K,) so that it [meaning its contents] became spoiled. (S, A.) ― -b4- malaHa, (S, K,) inf. n. maloHN; (S;) and mlRH↓, inf. n. tamolyHN; (TA;) He fed camels or sheep or goats with salt earth, (S, K,) or with earth and salt, the salt being more in quantity. (TA.) This is done when the animals cannot procure plants of the kind called HamoD. (S.) ― -b5- malaHa, aor.
malaHa
and
maliHa
, (K,) inf. n. maloHN; and mlRH↓; He salted fish. (K.) ― -b6- malaHa; aor.
malaHa
, inf. n. maloHN, He salted flesh-meat, and a skin, or hide. (L.) ― -b7- Also mlRHhu↓, inf. n. tamoliyHN, He rubbed his (a camel's, or sheep's, or goat's,) palate with salt. (TA.) ― -b8- maliHa, aor.
malaHa
, inf. n. malaHN, (tropical:) He, or it, (a man, &c.,) was blue, or gray, [see muloHapN,] in such a degree as to incline to whiteness; (Msb;) as also UimolaHRa↓, inf. n. UimoliHaAHN; and OamolaHa↓. (TA.) ― -b9- Also, (tropical:) He was black, with whiteness overspreading his hair: or, of a dusty white colour: or, of a clear white colour: (Msb:) [and in like manner,] UimolaHRa↓, inf. n. UimoliHaAHN, he (a ram) was of a white colour intermixed with black. (S, K.) ＝ -A3- maliHa, aor.
malaHa
, inf. n. malaHN, He (a horse) had the kind of swelling called malaHN. (TA.)

2 malRaHa
2: See 1, in six places. ― -b2- mlRH (tropical:) He (a poet) produced, or said, something goodly, beautiful, pretty, [or facetious]: (S, K:) and AmlH↓ he produced, or said, a goodly, beautiful, or pretty, [or a facetious,] word, or saying, or speech. (Lth.)

3 maAlaHotu fulaAnFA c
3. maAlaHotu fulaAnFA, (A,) inf. n. mumaAlaHapN, (S, A, K,) (tropical:) I ate with such a one. (S, A, K.) Abu-l-Kásim Er-Zejjájee disapproves of this, saying that a verb of this form is only derived from an inf. n., as in the cases of DaAraba and qaAtala; whereas this is derived from miloHN, a subst. [But his objection seems to me invalid: this may be an anomalous instance, and yet of classical authority, like many others.] ― -b2- maAlaHahu, inf. n. mumaAlaHapN and milaAHN, (tropical:) He was, or became, his foster-brother. (L, TA.) [AlmilaAHu is explained in the K by AlmuraADaEapu: Lth explaines it by AlrRaDaAEu, as is mentioned in the TA: AlmumaAlaHapu is explained in the A, Mgh, L, and other lexicons by AlmuraADaEapu: in the copies of the K in my hands, by AlrRaDaAEu; and so in one copy of the S: in another copy of the S written AlrRiDaAEu; and in another AlrRDaAE, without any vowel to the r: AlrDaAEu, syn. with AlmuraADaEapu, is evidently the right reading.] Abu-l-Kásim Er-Zejjájee disapproves of the verb used as signifying the act of two men's sucking each other; [but this is not what is meant by AlmrADEp;] and pronounces it a post-classical word. (TA.) You say bayonahumaA Huromapu AlmumaAlaHapi Between them two is the sacred or inviolable bond, or obligation, which is the consequence of their being fosterbrothers. (A.)

4 OamolaHa
4: See 1, in four places, and 2. ― -b2- AmlH Alqawomu (assumed tropical:) The people possessed milk; (tropical:) the people had fat camels or other beasts. (L.) ― -b3- AmlH (tropical:) He (a camel) carried fat; (L;) [meaning was fat]. AmlH Alqidora (tropical:) He put some
fat [which is termed miloH] into the cookingpot. (AA.) ＝ -A2- AmlH AlUibila He gave the camels salt water to drink. (K.) ― -b2- AmlHt AlUibilu The camels came to salt water to drink. (S.) ― -b3- maA OamayoliHa zayodFA (tropical:) [How very goodly, or beautiful, or pretty, is Zeyd! a diminutive form, meant to denote the contrary of the sense of a dim., being what is termed taSogiyru taEoZiymK, from maA OamolaHahu:] (T, S, K:) the verb is here put into the dim. form, being meant to be used as an epithet, as though they said mulayoHN: (T:) it is the only instance of a verb put into this form, except maA OuHayosinahu, (S, K,) and, as some say, maA OuHayolaAhu. (TA.) This is said accord. to the doctrine of the Basrees, who assert the AfEl of wonder to be a verb: but as to the Koofees, who say that it is a noun, [meaning an epithet,] they allow the formation of the dim. from it without restriction; and from its admitting the dim. form, they argue that it is a noun. (MF.) ― -b4- maA OamolaHa wajohahu, and fiEolahu, (tropical:) How goodly, beautiful, or pretty, is his face! and how good is his action! (A.) ― -b5- OamoliHoniI binafasika (tropical:) Grace me, or recommend me, (zayRinRiI,) [by thy speech]. (T, L.)

5 tamalRaHa
5: See 1, in two places. ― -b2- fulaAnN yataZarRafu wayatamalRaHu (tropical:) [Such a one affects to be clever, or graceful, and to be goodly, beautiful, pretty, or facetious]. (A.)

9 UimolaHRa
9: See 1, in two places.

10 AstmlHhu c
10. AstmlHhu (assumed tropical:) He esteemed him, or it, goodly, beautiful, or pretty; (S, K;) [pleasing to the eye or ear: (the lexicons passim:)] or found him, or it, to be so (TA.)

maloHN c
maloHN: see miloHN.

miloHN c
miloHN (S, M, K) and maloHN↓ (M) (tropical:) The act of sucking the mother or any nurse; syn. raDaAEN; (S, M, K;) a child's sucking its mother. (Abu-l- Kásim Ez-Zejjájee.) ― -b2- miloHN (tropical:) Milk. (IAar.) The following verse of Abu-t-Tamahán, who had some camels, of the milk whereof he gave to drink to a people that afterwards made an attack upon them, and took them, is cited by As, [app., accord. to the S, as an ex. of mlH in the sense of raDaAE; but as MF observes, it may be taken as an ex. of that word in the sense of milk;]
wiUinRiI laOarojuw miloHahaA fiI buTuwnikumo
wamaA basaTato mino jildi OaXoEava OagobaraA
(S, L.) The poet says, Verily I hope that ye may regard (Oano taroEawoA [which is understood]) the milk which ye have drank, of these camels, [lit., their milk in your bellies,] and the skins which they have expanded, of a people with matted and dusty hair, and of a dusty hue; as though their skins had dried up, and they had fattened upon them. [Another explanation will be noticed below.] IB says, that the last word should be read Oagobari, for the sake of the rhyme; for each verse of the poem to which it belongs ends with kesreh. (L.) ＝ -A2- miloHN a thing well known, (S, K,) [Salt;] that with which food is made pleasant: (L:) of the fem. gender (Z) generally; (O;) sometimes masc.: (K:) pl. milaAHN. (Msb.) Dim. mulayoHapN. (Msb.) ― -b2- maMCN miloHN, (S, K, &c.,) originally maliHo↓, from the verb maluHa, like xaXinN from xaXuna, contracted because of the frequency of its usage; (Msb;) and mAC maliyHN↓, (K,) and maAliHN↓; (IAar, ADk, Az;) [respecting which last, see what will be found after the explanation;] Salt water. (S, K, &c.) J says, that maAC mAlH is not allowable, except in a bad dial.: but Az says, that, though rarely found in the language of the Arabs, it is not to be rejected; and IB says, that it occurs in verses of chaste poets; and may be considered as used after the manner of a rel. n., [meaning cuw miloHK,] like rajulN taArisN, i. e. cuw turosK, and daAriEN, i. e. cuw diroEK: (TA:) it is a chaste word, of the dial. of El-Hijáz, but extr., being from OamolaHa AlmaMCu, like as you say baAqilN from Oaboqala AlmawoDiEu; and when it is said that it is rare, it is meant that it is not agreeable with its verb, not that it is rare with respect to usage, seeing that it is of the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz, who selected the most chaste words of the various dialects: or it is regularly formed from malaHa AlmaOCu, a form of the verb sometimes used. (Msb.) The pl. of miloHN is miloHapN and milaAHN and milaHN: (L, K:) and sometimes is said OamowaAhN miloHN salt waters; and rakiyRapN miloHapN a salt well. (L.) ― -b3- milaAHN Salt waters. (T, K.) qaliybN malyiHN↓ A well of salt water: (S, K:) pl. OaqolibapN milaAHN, occurring in a verse of 'Antarah. (S.) ― -b4- miloHN (assumed tropical:) Knowledge; science; learning; syn. EilomN. (IKh, Kz, K.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) Men of science; learned men; syn. EulamaMCu. (IKh, Kz, K.) ― -b6- (tropical:) Goodliness, or beauty. (K.) [Accord. to the TA, it is an inf. n.: see maluHa.] ― -b7- (tropical:) Fat, as a subst. (Sh, K.) ― -b8- (tropical:) Fatness: (K:) or a small degree of fatness. (TA.) ― -b9- miloHN and miloHapN↓ (tropical:) A sacred or inviolable bond, or the like, or any compact, bond, or obligation, which one is under an obligation to respect, or honour, or the cancelling or breaking of which renders one obnoxious to blame; syn. HuromapN and cimaAmN; and a compact, or confederacy; syn. HilofN. (K.) In some copies of the K, for HilofN is put HalfN. (TA.) ― -b10- Accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, this is the signification of the former word in the verse of Abu-t-Tamahán cited above, and the poet means, I hope that God may punish you for your perfidious violation of the sacred obligation to their owner, which they imposed upon you. You say bayona fulaAnK wafulaAnK miloHN, and miloHapN↓, There is a sacred or inviolable bond, &c., between such a one and such a one. [This meaning is derived from miloHN as signifying “ salt; ” the eating of which with another imposes upon the two parties a sacred mutual obligation.] The Arabs, says Abu-l-'Abbás, pay a high respect to salt and fire and ashes. (L.) [You say,] miloHuhu EalaI rukobatihi, so in the copies of the K, but correctly ElI rukobatayohi, as in all the other lexicons, (TA,) (tropical:) [lit., His salt is upon his knees;] meaning he has no good faith, so as to fulfil his promises, or engagements: (K:) or he has little good faith, so as to fulfil his promises, &c., for the Arabs swear by salt, and by water, because of their respect for them: (IAar:) or he violates the obligation imposed by such, the smallest thing making him forget it, like as the least thing scatters salt if a person puts it upon his knees: (T:) or he is fat: (K:) As says, that in the following verse,
laA talumohaA UinRahaA mino nisowapK
miloHuhaA mawoDuwEapN fawoqa AlrRukabo
[Blame her not; for she is of women whose fat is placed above the knees;] the woman meant was of the people called Ez-Zenj, whose fat is in their thighs, and mlHhA signifies their fat: (TA:) or he is sharp in his anger: (K:) or he is of evil disposition, rendered angry by the least thing; like as salt upon the knee is scattered by the least thing: (T:) or he is frequently engaged in altercation; as though his knees were much wounded by his long kneeling in altercation, and by his long striking his knees against those of another, and he therefore put salt upon them to cure them. (A.) [See also rukobapN.] ＝ -A3- nabotN miloHN, and maAliHN↓, A plant of the kind called HamoDN. (ISk, S.)

malaHN c
malaHN: see muloHapN. ― -b2- A certain disease and fault in the kind leg of a beast of carriage; (TA;) a swelling in the hock, or hock-tendon, (Euroquwb,) of a horse; (S, K;) less than what is called jaracN; which is a name given to it when it has become violent. (S.)

maliHN c
maliHN: see miloHN.

maloHapN c
maloHapN (tropical:) A single feed taken by a child from the breast. malojapN, with j, signifies a single suck. (TA.) ＝ -A2- maloHapN The main body of the sea; or the fathomless deep of the sea; or a great expanse
of sea of which the extremities cannot be seen. (K.)

muloHapN c
muloHapN (S, K) and malaHN↓ (K) (tropical:) A white colour intermixed with black: (S, K:) whiteness overspreading blackness in the human hair, and in anything: or a dusty white colour: or a clear white colour: or whiteness inclining to any kind of redness; like the colour of the antelope. (L.) [See also OamolaHu.] ― -b2- Also, muloHapN (tropical:) The utmost degree of blueness or grayness, [app. meaning the latter, from miloHN as signifying “ salt, ” as salt in the state in which it is commonly used in Arabia is of a pale gray colour,] OaXadRu AlzRarqi: (K:) or blueness, or grayness, (zuroqap,) of such a degree as to incline to whiteness. (S.) [See OamolaHu.] ― -b3- muloHapN (tropical:) A goodly, beautiful, pretty, or facetious, story, or narrative, and word, or saying, or speech; a bon-mot; (L;) waAHidapu AlmulaHi mina AlOaHaAdiyvi; (S, K;) [what is deemed beautiful, elegant, facetious, or the like, of stories, &c.: (Ibr D:) and so OumoluwHapN↓, coupled with OufokuwhapN in art. fkh in the TA:] also said to signify a bad, an abominable, or a foul, word, saying, or speech; a meaning taken from a trad. of 'Áïsheh, who applied this term [perhaps ironically] to a bad answer which she had given in consequence of her having misunderstood a question put to her: (L:) pl. mulaHN. (S, K.) As said nilotu biAlmulaHi [I have attained to the station, or rank, to which I have attained by means of goodly, or facetious, sayings, &c.] (S.) HadRavotuhu biAlmulaHi (tropical:) [I related to him goodly, beautiful, pretty, or facetious, stories.] (A.) ― -b4- [A curiosity, an extraordinary thing.]

miloHapN c
miloHapN: see miloHN.

maloHaAnu c
maloHaAnu: see miloHaAnu. ― -b2- [A sucker: see maSRaAnN in art. mS.]

miloHaAnu c
miloHaAnu, (S, K,) sometimes written maloHaAnu↓, (TA, art. Xyb, voce XiybaAnu,) [written in both these ways in a copy of the S in my hands,] (tropical:) A name given to one of the winter-months, because of the whiteness of its snow: (S:) the month called Jumáda-l-Ákhireh, jumaAdaI AlMxirapN, (K,) [in the old Arabian calendar;] because of its whiteness; Jumáda-l-Oolà, jumaAdaI AlOuwlaI, being called XiybaAnu: or this was a name of Kánoon el-Owwal, kaAnuwnu AlOawRalu; (TA;) and miloHaAnu was Kánoon eth-Thánee, kaAnuwnu AlvRaAniI: (K, TA:) [but see XiybaAnu:] or XiybaAnu and miloHaAnu were names applied to the days when the earth was white with hoar-frost, or rime. ('Amr Ibn-Abee-'Amr, Az.)

mulaAHN c
mulaAHN: see maliyHN.

maliyHN c
maliyHN and mulaAHN↓ and mulRaAHN↓, (S, K,) but the last signifies more than the first, (T, S,) (tropical:) Goodly; beautiful; pretty; (S, Msb, K;) and beautiful of colour; or beautiful and bright; (Msb;) pleasing to the eye or ear; facetious: (the lexicons passim:) fem. of the first with p: (Msb:) pl. of the same, milaAHN and OamolaAHN; (AA, S, K;) and of mulaAHN, mulaAHuwna; and of mulRaAHN, mulRaAHuwna. (K.) ― -b2- See miloHN. ― -b3- [Facetious speech.] ― -b4- One in whose counsel, or advice, one seeks a remedy; acc. to AA: hence the phrase qryX mlH AlnAs: acc. to some, one with whom one finds, or esteems, it pleasant to sit and converse. (IB, in TA, voce niqaAbN.) ― -b5- Oabuw AlmaliyHi [the bird Sifrid]: see SiforidN.

milaAHapN c
milaAHapN and malRaAHiyRapN↓: see malRaAHN.

mulaAHiIRN c
mulaAHiIRN, sometimes written mulRaAHiIRN, (S, K,) occurring in poetry written in the latter manner, (S,) A kind of white, long-shaped, grape: (S, K:) so called from [the colour termed] AlmuloHap; (S;) or from the [plant called] mulRaAH, because of its taste. (AHn.) ― -b2- Also, A kind of fig, (K,) small, of the colour termed OamolaH, very sweet, and which is dried. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, A species of the tree called OaraAk in which is whiteness and redness and the colour termed Xuhobap. (AHn, K.)

malRaAHN c
malRaAHN A seller of salt: or a possessor of salt: (IAar, K:) as also mutamalRiHN↓: (K:) which also signifies one who provides himself with salt for travelling-provision: or a trader in salt. (TA.) ― -b2- malRaAHN A sailor; a shipman; a seaman, or mariner: (T, S, K:) so called because constantly upon the salt water. (T.) ― -b3- Also, One who constantly attends to a river (nahor; in some copies of the K, baHor; TA) to put its mouth into a right or proper state. (K.) ― -b4- His occupation is called milaAHapN↓ and malRaAHiyRapN↓. (K.)

mulRaAHN c
mulRaAHN: see maliyHN. ― -b2- [A coll. gen. n.] A certain plant, (S, K,) of the kind called HamoDN; (Lth, T, S;) a leguminous garden-plant; n. un. with p; it is a tender plant, with a salt flavour, growing in smooth, or soft, and depressed, tracts of land: (T:) a herb of the kind called HamoD, having twigs and leaves, growing in tracts such as are called qifaAf, of a salt flavour, wholesome to camels and sheep: (M:) a plant like the qulRaAm, in which is a red hue, eaten with milk, bearing grain which is collected like as is that of the favR, and made into bread, and eaten: so says AHn, and he adds, I think that it is thus called because of its colour; not because of its taste: and in another place he says, that the mulRaAH is the raceme of the kabaAv of the OaraAk; thus called because of its taste, which is hot, as though containing salt. (M.) [Suœda baccata. Forsk., Flor., 69. (Freytag.)]

malRaAHapN c
malRaAHapN (S, K) and mamolaHapN↓ (K) A place where salt is generated. (S, K.)

malRaAHiyRapN c
malRaAHiyRapN: see malRaAHN.

maAliHN c
maAliHN: see miloHN and mamoluwHN.

OamolaHu c
OamolaHu (tropical:) A ram, (S, K,) and a he-goat, (S,) of a white colour intermixed with black: (S, K:) any hair, and wool, and the like, in which are whiteness and blackness: (TA:) that in which are whiteness and blackness, the former colour predominating: (AZ, Ks and others:) or of a dusty white colour: or of a clear white colour: (Msb:) fem. maloHaMCu; applied to a ewe of a white colour intermixed with black: (K:) or black, with its hair pervaded by whiteness. (TA.) Aboo-Dhubyán Ibn-Er-Raabal employs AmlH as one of four epithets which he applies to those old men most hateful to him. (S.) ― -b2- Also, (tropical:) Blue, or gray, [see muloHapN,] in such a degree as to incline to whiteness; an epithet applied to a man, &c. (Msb) OamolaHN AlEayoni Having the eye of that colour. (S.) ― -b3- Hence, katiybapN maloHaMCu [meaning (tropical:) An army, or a troop of horse, appearing of a white and black, or gray, hue, by reason of their glittering weapons; see also ktybp XahobaMCu]: (S:) or one that is white and great: (TA:) or, great. (K.) ― -b4- OamolaHu (assumed tropical:) Dew that falls in the night upon leguminous plants: so called because of its whiteness. (L.) Er-Rá'ee says, describing some camels,
OaqaAmato bihi HadRa AlrRabiyEi wajaAruhaA
Oaxuw salowapK masRaI bihi AllRayolu OamolaHu
meaning [by AmlH] dew: [They remained in it during the period of the season called AlrbyE, and their preserver from thirst was attended by comfort, being dew brought by the night]: he says, they remained in that place during the days of the season called AlrbyE, and while the dew lasted, so that he was (fahuwa [but this appears to be a mistake for fahiIa, “ so that they were, ”]) in a comfortable state of life: and he says msRI bh because the dew falls in the night: (S, L:) by jArhA he means the night-dew which preserved them from thirst. (L.) ― -b5- AlmaloHaMCu was also the name of a particular troop belonging to the family of ElMundhir, (S, K,) of the Kings of Syria, who had another called AlXRahobaMCu. (TA.) ― -b6- namirapN maloHaMCu A burodap with black and white stripes. (L.) XajarapN maloHaMCu (assumed tropical:) A tree of which the leaves have fallen, (L, K,) the branches, or twigs, remaining green. (L.) ― -b7- AlmaloHaMCu (in a camel, L) (assumed tropical:) Certain flesh in the back, (situate within, L,) extending from the withers (AlkaAhil) to the rump: (L, K:) or the middle of the back, between the withers (AlkAhl) and the rump: (T, S [in neither of which is reference made here to a camel]:) or the part between the hump of a camel and its rump: or
the vertebræ of a camel over which is the hump: (L:) or, in a camel, the part beneath the hump; containing six vertebræ (maHaAlaAt): pl. maloHaAwaAtN. (T.) faArsu AlmaloHaMCi The fat of the hump. (L.) ― -b8- OamolaHu A horse having the kind of swelling called malaHN. (TA.)

OumoluwHapN c
OumoluwHapN: see muloHapN.

mamolaHapN c
mamolaHapN: see malRaAHapN.

mimolaHapN c
mimolaHapN A thing [or vessel or the like] in which salt is put. (S, A.)

mamoluwHN c
mamoluwHN and mumalRiHN↓ (tropical:) A fat camel. (L.) ― -b2- mumalRiHN↓ (tropical:) A camel destined for slaughter that is fat: (S:) or having some remains of fatness. (L.) ＝ -A2- samakN mamoluwHN, and maliyHN↓, (S, K,) and miloHN↓, (Msb,) Salted fish; (S, K;) i. q. mumalRaHN↓. (K.) You should not say maAliHN. As to the saying of 'Odháfir,
baSoriyRapN tazawRajato baSoriyRaA
wAlTRariyRaA yuToEimuhaA AlmaAliHa↓
[A woman of El-Basrah who married a man of El-Basrah: he fed her with salted and fresh], it is not an evidence. (S.) ISd says, that some have disapproved of this word, as also of mlyH, not regarding the above verse as an evidence. You says, that mlyH and mmlwH are better than mAlH. (TA.)

mumalRaHN c
mumalRaHN and mumalRiHN: see mamoluwHN.

mutamalRiHN c
mutamalRiHN: see malRaAHN.

1 malaxa c
1. malaxa, aor.
malaxa
, inf. n. maloxN; (K;) and Amtlx↓; (L;) He pulled, or drew, a thing, grasping with the hand, or biting, (L, K,) and so pulling or drawing it out. (L.) ― -b2- Amtlx↓ He pulled out a thing; (L, K;) drew it forth: or drew it forth quickly. (L.) He drew his sword. (S, K.) He pulled out his tooth: (S:) and his eye. (Lh.) It (an eagle) pulled out an eye; (S;) as also tmlRx↓. (K, TA.) He pulled away his hand from the hand of a person grasping him. (L.) He pulled out a ripe date from its skin. (L.) He pulled off flesh from a bone. (L.) He pulled off the bridle and bit from the head of a beast of carriage. (L, K.) ― -b3- malaxa, aor.
malaxa
, (L, K,) inf. n. maloxN, (S, L, K,) He went, or journeyed, at a vehement rats: (S, L, K:) or, at an easy rate: and, sometimes, vehemently: (ISd:) or, quickly: (TA:) or he (a beast) stretched forth his arms in the pace called HuDor, in any way, well or ill. (Ibn-Hánee.) ― -b4- malaxa fiI AlOaroDi He went away journeying through the land, or earth. (TA.) ― -b5- fulaAnN yamolaxu fiI AlbaATili, (S,) inf. n. maloxN, (S, K,) Such a one goes to and fro, and occupies himself much, in vain affairs: (S, K:) or goes quickly and easily therein: (Sh:) or plays, or sports, and perseveres, therein. (L.) ― -b6- maloxN AlbaATili i. q. AltRabaxoturu [Walking in an affected manner] (L, in art. Dndd.) ― -b7- malaxa Alqawomu maloxapF SaAliHapF The people, or party, went, or journeyed, far in the land. (S.) ― -b8- malaxa He (a man) fled (IAar; and Az, from several Arabs of the desert.) ＝ -A2- maluxa, aor.
maluxa
, inf. n. malaAxapN, It (flesh-meat) was, or became, tasteless, or insipid; (S;) [i. q. masuxa]. See salaAxapN.

5 tamalRaxa
5: see 1.

8 Uimotalaxa
8: see 1.

maliyxN c
maliyxN, applied to flesh-meat, (S,) or, accord. to some, specially to a new-born camel that is slaughtered when it falls from its mother's belly, (L,) That has no taste; tasteless; insipid; (S, L, K;) i. q. masiyxN. (S.) See saliyxN. ― -b2- Corrupt: (L, K:) or any corrupt food. (IAar, L.) ― -b3- maliyxN Milk that slips from the hand. (L.)

maluwxiyRapN c
[maluwxiyRapN Corchorus olitorius, or Jews' mallow: so used in the present day. See xubRaAzN.]

malRaAxN c
malRaAxN Vehement in journeying, or in his pace. (S, * TA.) ― -b2- A slave who runs away often. (L, K.)

maAlixN c
maAlixN Fleeing; as also maAxilN and xaAmilN. (Az.)

mumotalaxu AlEaqoli c
mumotalaxu AlEaqoli (tropical:) A man deprived, or despoiled of his reason. (S, TA.) ― -b2- AlSRulobi mutamalRixi↓ A man weakened, or enervated, in the back-bone, or back; (K;) as though it were pulled asunder. (TA.)

mutamalRixN c
mutamalRixN: see mumotalaHN.

1 malida c
1. malida, [aor.
malada
,] (TA,) inf. n. maladN (K, TA) and maladaAnN, (M,) It (a branch, M, TA) was, or became, soft, tender, or delicate; (M, K;) and quivered, shook, or played loosely. (M, K, TA.) ― -b2- Also, inf. n. maladN, (tropical:) He (a youth) was, or became, soft, tender, or delicate. (T, S, L.) ― -b3- See also maladN, below. ― -b4- maladahu He drew or pulled it; strained it; or extended or stretched it; syn. madRahu. (K.)

2 mlRdhu c
2. mlRdhu, inf. n. tamoliydN, It (the imbibing of moisture) rendered it (a branch) soft, tender, or delicate. (T, L.) ― -b2- He softened it, namely a tanned skin or hide. (S, L, K.)

malodN c
malodN: see OumoluwdN. ― -b2- Also, The [creature called] guwl; (K;) i. e., i. q. siEolaApN; or an enchantress of the jinn. (TA.)

maladN c
maladN: see malida. ― -b2- maladN, (M, L, K,) and maladaAnN↓ (K) (tropical:) Youth, or youthfulness; and its softness, tenderness, or delicateness. (M, L, K. * [In the CK, for naEomap, is erroneously put niEomapN.])

maladaAnu c
maladaAnu: see maladN.

Oamoladu c
Oamoladu, OumoludN, &c.: see OumoluwdN.

OumoluwdN c
OumoluwdN (S, M, A, L, K) and UimoliydN↓ (M, L, K) and OamoladN↓ (S, M, L, K) and OumoludN↓ and OumoludaAnN↓ and OumoludaAniIRN↓ and malodN↓ (M, L, K) Soft, tender, or delicate; (S, M, L, K;) and lithe or limber: (M, K:) the first (S, M, L, K) and second, (M, L, K,) or all, (K,) applied to a branch: (S, M, L, K:) and the first and third, (S, M, L, K,) or all, (M, L, K,) applied in the same sense to (tropical:) a man, or young man: (S, M, L, K:) or OumolwdN, applied to a young man, (tropical:) beardless: (A:) or perfect in make, or full-grown, pubescent, and well-formed: (T, L:) and OumoluwdN (S, M, L, K) and OumoluwdapN (M, L, K) and OumoludaAniyRapN (M, L) or OumoluwdaAniyRapN (K) and malodaMCu (S, M, L, K) and malodaAniyRapN (M, L, K) [in the CK muloda AniyRapN] applied to a woman, or a damsel, (tropical:) soft, tender, or delicate; (S, M, L, K;) and of just stature: (L:) pl. of OumoluwdN (A, TA) and of UimoliydN (TA) OamaAliydu; (A, TA;) and of malodN, OamolaAdN. (M, L.) The O in Amlwd and Amlyd is to render them quasi-coordinate to words of the classes of EusoluwjN and qiTomiyrN; as is shown by their having the augmentative letters w and I. (IJ, M, L.)

UimoliydN c
UimoliydN: see OumoluwdN. ― -b2- Also, applied to a desert (SaHoraMC) i. q. UimoliysN (S, L, K) i. e., Bare, in which is nothing. (L.)

1 malaca c
1. malaca, aor.
maluca
, inf. n. malocN, He was quick in coming and going. (M, L.) This is the original signification. (L.) ― -b2- He (a horse) was quick in his running. (K, in which only the inf. n. is mentioned.) ― -b3- He (a-horse) stretched forth his arms, (macRa DaboEayohi, S, M, L, K,) in running, (S,) to a degree that he could not exceed, to overtake, (HatRaI laA yajida maziydFA lilRiHaAqK, M, L, K,) and contracted, or drew in, (Habasa, [perhaps a mistake for xanasa, which may mean either contracted, or threw back,]) his hind legs to a degree that he could not exceed, to overtake, without any confusion [in his motions]. (M, L.) ― -b4- malacahu, aor.
maluca
, inf. n. malocN and malaAcapN, He contented him with courteous and soothing speech, and made him to hear that which rejoiced him, without doing, or performing, anything. (T, L.) Accord. to Aboo-Is-hák, the c in this word is a substitute for v. (M, L.) See malavahu. ― -b5- malaca, inf. n. malocN, He lied; (K;) as also malava. (TA.) ― -b6- malacahu, (S, L,) inf. n. malocN,
(S, L, K,) He smote him and pierced him with a spear. (S, L, K. *)

malacaAnN c
malacaAnN and malacaAniIRN and malaAcaAniIRN: see malRaAcN.

maluwcN c
maluwcN: see malRaAcN.

malRaAcN c
malRaAcN A man who says but does not act, or perform; (S, L, K;) a liar; (S, L;) who behaves in an artificial manner, and is not true in his affection; (M, L, K;) as also maluwcN↓ (M, L [in the K milowacN, and said to be of the same measure as minobarN; but this seems to be a mistake]) and malacaAnN↓ and malacaAniIRN↓ (M, L, K) and malaAcaniIRN↓: (M, K:) [in some copies of the K, by a mistake in the last vowel-sign, each of the last three of these epithets is as though it were syn. with malocN, the inf. n of malaca, “ he lied ” &c.:] or a liar, who, if asked, will not tell truly whence he comes; as also all the above epithets: (M, L:) and malacaAnN↓ one who makes a show of sincerity, faithfulness, or honesty, concealing, or meditating, what is different therefrom. (S, L.) ― -b2- Also malRaAcN Stealthy, (M, L,) and light, or active; applied to a wolf. (M, L, K.)

1 malusa c
1. malusa, aor.
malusa
; (M, A, Msb, K;) and malisa, aor.
malasa
; (Msb;) or the second form is malasa, aor.
malusa
; (K;) [but the last of the inf. ns. here following seems to indicate that malisa is correct;] inf. n. malaAsapN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and muluwsapN, (M, K,) [accord. to rule, both of the first,] and malasN, (M, TA,) [accord. to rule, of the second;] It was, or became, smooth, sleek, or free from asperities; the inf. n. being the contr. of xuXuwnapN; (S, M, K;) it had in it nothing upon which to lay hold; it was, or became, smooth to the feel; (Msb;) and AmlAsR↓ signifies the same, (S, M,) inf. n. UimoliysaAsN; (S;) and AmlsR↓: (so in a copy of the A) and [in like manner] tmlRs↓ (S, A) and UimRalasa↓, of the measure UinofaEala, the n being incorporated into the m, both signify it was, or became, made, or rendered, smooth, &c. (S.) See also 4. ＝ -A2- malasa, aor.
malusa
, inf. n. malosN, (tropical:) He (a man) went away quickly, or swiftly: (TA:) and malasati AlnRaAqapu, (M,) and AlUibilu, (A,) aor. and inf. n. as before, (M,) (tropical:) the she-camel, (M,) and the camels, (A,) went quickly, or swiftly: (M, A:) or malosN signifies the going easily, or gently: and also, contr., the going vehemently: (M:) or a gentle mode of going or journeying: (IAar:) and the being light, or active, and quick. (TA.) It is said in a trad., siro valaAvFA malosFA, i. e., valaAva layaAlK cawaAti malosK; or valaAvFA sayorFA malosFA; (tropical:) [Journey thou three nights of quick, or of easy, journeying; or with a quick, or an easy, journeying;] or mlsA signifies a certain mode of going or journeying; and is in the accus. case as an inf. n. (TA.) malasa, aor. and inf. n. as above, also signifies (assumed tropical:) It (a thing) went back, or retired, (Uinoxanasa,) quickly; (M;) and so UimRalasa↓. (M, TA.) ＝ -A3- malasa AlZRalaAmu, [aor.
malusa
,] (TK,) inf. n. malosN, (A, K,) or malasN, (S, M,) The darkness became confused; (S, M, A, K;) as also Oamolasa↓, (TK,) inf. n. UimolaAsN: (K:) or became in the state after that which is termed malavN, (M,) or malovN. (TA.) See malosN below.

2 mlRshu c
2. mlRshu, inf. n. tamoliysN, He rendered it smooth, sleek, or free from asperities. (S.) You say, mlRs AlOaroDa, (TA,) biAlomalRaAsapi, (A,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) [He smoothed the land with the mlRAsp;] he drew the mimolaqap [or mlRAsp] over the land, [and so made it smooth, or even,] after the ploughing and sowing thereof. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, (S, A,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He made him to escape; or to be, or become, or get, clear, quit, free, or at liberty; mina AlOamori from the thing, or affair; (S, K;) and mno yadi gayorihi from the hand of another. (A.)

4 Oamolasa
4: see 1. ― -b2- Oamolasato XaAtuka The wool of thy sheep, or ewe, fell off: (K:) from Ibn-'Abbád. (TA.)

5 tmlRs c
5. tmlRs: see malusa. ＝ -A2- It (a smooth thing) slipped forth from the hand [&c.]. (Har, p. 119.) ― -b2- And hence, (Har, ubi supra,) (tropical:) He escaped; got away; or was, or became, or got, clear, quit, free, or at liberty; (S, * M, A, Msb, * K,) as also Anmls↓, (S, A, K,) and UimRalasa↓, of the measure UifotaEala, [or rather UinofaEala,] and AmlAsR↓; (K;) mina AlOamori from the thing or affair; (S, A, TA;) and mino yadiI from my hand. (A.) ― -b3- [Hence,] tmlRs mina AlXRaraAbi (assumed tropical:) He recovered from the wine. (AHn, M.)

7 Anmls c and UimRalasa
7. Anmls UimRalasa: see malusa: ＝ -A2- and malasa: ＝ -A3- and 5.

8 Uimotalasa
8: see 5. ＝ -A2- Oumotulisa baSaruhu (tropical:) His sight was suddenly taken away. (M, A, K.)

9 UimolasRa
9: see malusa.

11 UimolaAosRa
11: see malusa: ＝ -A2- and 5.

malosN c
malosN: see Oamolasu. ＝ -A2- Also, malosN, (A, K,) or malasN↓, (S, M,) The confusedness of the darkness: (S, M, A, K:) or it is after the malav, (M,) or malov: (TA:) the mlv is the first, or commencement, of the blackness of the west; and the mls is when the blackness has become intense, so that the time of the last EiXaMC comes; then the mls becomes confounded with the mlv, and the one is not distinguished from the other. (IAar.) You say, AlZRalaAmi Oatayotuhu malasa↓, (S, M,) or malosa AlZlAm, (TA,) I came to him when the darkness had become confused; (S, TA;) when the night had become confused with the earth. (TA.) The word is used adverbially and otherwise. (M.) See malasa AlZRalaAmu.

malasN c
malasN: see UimoliysN, in two places: ＝ -A2- and malosN, throughout.

malasaI c
malasaI: see UimoliysN. ＝ -A2- (tropical:) A she-camel that escapes and goes away so quickly that nothing attaches, or clings, to her: (S:) or quick, or swift, in the utmost degree: (Z, K:) or quick, or swift; as also maluwsN↓: (M:) or the latter signifies a she-camel excellent, or good, in the pace termed Eanaq, [so I render miEonaAqN,] that outstrips, and is seen to be first among the camels in the place of pasturage and the watering-place and every journeying. (AZ, K. *) ― -b2- Also, (assumed tropical:) A man who will not remain firm to a compact, covenant, engagement, or promise; like as the smooth thing will not remain firm. (M.) It is said in a proverb, (El-Ahmar, M,) alluding to dislike, or hatred, of faults or the like, (El-Ahmar, TA,) AlmalasaI laA Eahoda lahu (assumed tropical:) [He who will not remain firm to a compact, &c., for him there is no compact, &c.]; (El-Ahmar, M;) meaning, that he has got out of the affair in safety, there being nothing due to him, nor anything to be demanded of him. (El-Ahmar, TA.) [But see what here follows.] ― -b3- It is said in a proverb, applied to him in whose fidelity one does not trust, (TA,) AlmalasaI laA Euhodapa lahu, meaning cuw AlmalasaI; (Az, L, Msb, TA;) i. e., (assumed tropical:) He who steals a commodity, and sells it for less than its price, and escapes immediately and hides himself, so that if he who has a just claim to it come, he finds his property in the hand of him who purchased it, he takes it, and the price which the thief gained goes for nought, and the purchaser cannot return to him to recover the price: (Az, TA:) or it means, (assumed tropical:) he who goes away privily, gets out of the affair in safety, there being nothing due to him, nor anything to be demanded of him: or AmlsI means, a (assumed tropical:) man's selling a commodity which he has stolen, and abating the price, and then absenting himself; so that when it is plucked from the hand of the purchaser, he cannot sue the seller as responsible for the loss thereof: (Msb:) or (tropical:) the sale to which attaches no claim upon the seller for having acted unjustly: (A, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) the selling a thing without making one's self responsible for any loss or the like that may be occasioned by it. (TA.) One says, also, in selling, malasaI laA Euhodapa, meaning, that he has escaped from the affair, or become quit of it; that there is nothing due to him, nor
anything to be demanded of him: [i. e., (assumed tropical:) I am quit of the affair: no claim shall be made for indemnification.] (S.) You say, also, OabiyEuka AlmalasaI laA Euhodapa, meaning, (tropical:) [I sell to thee on the condition that] thou shalt get thee away, and not return to me, (S, Msb, K,) nor have any claim upon me for indemnification. (Msb.) [In some copies of the S, here and in art. Ehd, the verbs by which the meaning is explained are of the third person, as though referring to the things sold; but the right reading I hold to be that which I have followed. See also art. Ehd.]

maluwsN c
maluwsN: see malasaI.

maliysN c
maliysN: see Oamolasu, in two places: ＝ -A2- and UimoliysN.

mulayosaMCu c
mulayosaMCu: dim. of malosaMCu, fem. of Oamolasu, which see, in two places.

malRaAsapN c
malRaAsapN An implement (S, A, K) of wood (A, TA) with which land is made smooth, or even; (S, A, K;) as also mimolasapN↓. (A, TA.)

Oamolasu c
Oamolasu Smooth; sleek; free from asperities; [contr. of xaXinN;] (S, M, K;) having in it nothing upon which to lay hold; smooth to the feel; (Msb;) and maliysN↓ signifies the same; (TA;) and malosN↓ [in like manner], anything smooth or soft: (TA:) fem. of the first, malosaMCu: (M, A, &c.:) and pl. mulosN. (A.) You say, vawobN Oamolasu [A smooth garment, or piece of cloth]. And SaxorapN malosaMCu [A smooth rock]. (A, TA.) And qawosN malosaMCu and maliysN↓ A bow in which is no crack. (M.) And Darabahu EalaI malosaMCi matonihi and mulayosaAYihi↓ He struck him upon the even and smooth part of his back. (M.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A camel (A) having a sound back, (S, K,) free from mange or scab. (A, TA.) So in the proverb, (S,) haAna EalaI AlOamolasi maA laAqaI AldRabiru (tropical:) [What he that had galls on his back experienced was a light matter to him that had a sound back]: (S, K:) applied to him who has an ill concern for his companion. (K.) ― -b3- OaroDN malosaMCu: see UimoliysN. ― -b4- sanapN malosaMCu (tropical:) A year without herbage: (A:) or a year of sterility: pl. OamaAliysu, contr. to rule. (M.) ― -b5- AlmalosaMCu (tropical:) The lowest heaven. (TA, art. jrb.) ― -b6- qahowapN malosaMCu (A) or xamorN malosaMCu (K) (tropical:) Wine easy to swallow; (A;) wine that descends easily in the throat. (K.) ― -b7- malosaMCu [as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates] (assumed tropical:) Sour milk with which pure [fresh] milk is mixed; as also mulayosaMCu↓. (IDrd, K.) ― -b8- jiloduhu Oamolasu (tropical:) He has no blame attaching to him. (A, TA.) ― -b9- ximosN Oamolasu (tropical:) A fatiguing, severe [journey such as is called] xms. (K.)

UimoliysN c
UimoliysN (S, K,) and with p, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) (tropical:) A desert in which is no herbage: pl. OamaAliysu (S, K) and OamaAlisu, [the latter] contr. to general rule, (K,) the I being suppressed by poetic licence: (TA:) or OamaAlisu signifies land in which are no trees, nor fresh nor dry herbage, nor wild animals; sing, UimoliysN; app. from malaAsapN, [inf. n. of malusa,] i. e., smooth land, in which is nothing: (Sh, L, TA: *) or OamaAliysu is pl. of OamolaAsN, which is pl. [of pauc.] of malasN↓, meaning, an even place, (M, TA,) in which is no herbage; (TA;) and the pl. of mult. is muluwsN: and you say also, OaroDN malasN↓ and malasaI↓ and malosaMCu↓ and UimoliysN, meaning, land that produces no herbage; (M, TA;) and the pl. is OamaAlisu and OamaAliysu, contr. to analogy [unless pls. of UimoliysN, in which case the former only is so]. (TA.) ― -b2- You say also, rumRaAnN UimoliysN (T, M, TA,) and UimoliysiIRN↓, (T, S, M, K, TA,) as though the latter were a rel. n. from UimoliysN, (T, S, K, TA,) not, as is implied in the [S, and] K, as meaning a desert, but as syn. with UimoliysiIRN↓; (TA;) (assumed tropical:) A sweet pomegranate, having no stones: (T, M, TA:) and accord. to Lth, rumRaAnN maliysN signifies (assumed tropical:) the sweetest kind of pomegranate, which is that without stones. (TA.) [See XanobaMCu, voce OaXonabu.]

UimoliysapN c
UimoliysapN: see UimoliysN.

UmoliysiIRN c
UmoliysiIRN: see UimoliysN.

mmolasapN c
mmolasapN: see malRaAsapN.

1 maliSa c
1. maliSa, (S, M, A, K,) aor.
malaSa
, (S, K,) inf. n. malaSN, (S, M,) It (a thing, S, M, or a rope, Lh, M, A, and a bridle, Lh, M,) slipped; (S;) or fell, slipping; (K;) or got loose or free, or escaped, and slipped [away]; (A;) or slipped out by reason of its smoothness; (M;) from one's hand; (S, M, A;) as also UimRalaSa↓, and tmlRS↓: (M:) or AnmlS↓, (S, K,) also written UimRalaSa, (S,) signifies it (a thing, Lth, S,) escaped, or got loose or free, (Lth, S,) from one's hand, after having been seized or grasped: (Lth:) and [in like manner] tmlRS↓, it, and he, (a thing, S, or a rope, TA, and a man, S, A,) became safe or secure or free, or escaped, (S, A, K,) from one's hand. (TA.) You say, maliSati AlsRamakapu mino yadiI and AnmlSt↓ The fish escaped and slipped from my hand. (A, TA.) And maA kidotu mino fulaAnK OatamalRaSu↓ I hardly escaped, or became secure, from such a one. (S, A. *) ― -b2- He went back, or retreated, fleeing; as also maliza, inf. n. malazN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- malaSahu He set it loose, or free. (TA.) ― -b2- malaSa bisaloHihi Alvum dejecit: (K:) so says Ibn-'Abbád: but in the Tekmileh, malaSa bisahomihi he shot his arrow. (TA.)

4 AmlS c
4. AmlS, (K,) inf. n. UimolaASN, (TA,) It (a thing) made, or caused, to slip. (K.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) AmlSt janiynahaA, (Mgh, TA,) or bijanyinihaA, (Abu-l-'Abbás, TA,) or biwaladihaA, (S,) or AmlSt [alone], (M, A, K,) She (a woman, S, M, A, Mgh, and a camel, M, TA) brought forth her fœtus, or offspring, prematurely, (S, M, A, Mgh,) or dead: (K:) i. q. Oazolaqato bihi and Oasohalato bihi and HaTaOato bihi. (Abu-l-'Abbás, TA.) ― -b3- AmlS also signifies He (a man) became poor, needy, or indigent. (TA.)

5 tamalRaSa
5: see 1, in three places.

7 AnmlS c and AmRlS
7. AnmlS AmRlS: see 1, in three places; and see 7 in art. dlS.

maloSN c
maloSN (tropical:) Naked: [in the present day commonly preceded by EuroyaAn (vulgarly pronounced EaroyaAn), and with it signifying stark naked:] as though become divested of his clothes like a rope that is become divested of its villous coating. (TA.)

maliSN c
maliSN A thing that slips out from one's hand by reason of its smoothness; as also maliySN↓ and OamolaSu↓: (M:) a rope from which the hand slips, (S, K,) not being able to keep hold of it; (S, TA;) as also maliySN↓. (TA.) You say, samakapN maliSapN (M, A) A fish that slips from the hand by reason of its smoothness: (M:) or that gets loose or free, or escapes, and slips [away]: (A:) or, accord. to AA, (TA,) AlmaliSapu signifies AlOaTuwmu mina AlsRamaki [app. meaning a kind of thick-skinned fish]. (K, TA.)

maliySN c
maliySN: see maliSN, in two places: ― -b2- and see mumolaSN, in two places.

OamolaSu c
OamolaSu: see maliSN. You say also, rajulN OamolaSu AlrRaOosi, i. e. OabolaTuhu [app. meaning A smooth-headed man.] (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b2- Also, Tender; or soft. (TA.)

mumolaSN c
mumolaSN Brought forth prematurely; as also maliySN↓: (M, TA:) an abortion. (TA.) You say, Oaloqato waladahaA mumolaSFA She cast her young one prematurely; (TA;) as also maliySFA↓ and maliyTFA. (K, TA.)

mumoliSN c
mumoliSN A woman, and a she-camel, (M,) that brings forth her offspring prematurely, (M,) or dead: (K:) pl. mamaAliySu, with I. (M, TA.)

mimolaASN c
mimolaASN A woman, and a she-camel, (M,) that usually brings forth her offspring prematurely, (M,) or dead.. (K.) [Several points of resemblance, and some of exact agreement, will be observed between this art. and art. mls.]

1 maliTa c
1. maliTa, aor.
malaTa
, (K,) inf. n. malaTN (S, K) and
muloTapN, (K,) He (a man) had little, scanty, or thin, hair upon the sides of his face, or of his cheeks: (S [which indicates that it is like mariTa:]) or had no hair upon his body, (K, TA,) but only upon his head and beard. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 4.

4 OamolaTato c
4. OamolaTato, (S,) or AmlTt janiynahaA, (K.) She (a camel) cast her fœtus (S, K) before it had hair growing upon it; (S;) without any hair upon it: (K:) [like OamoraTatohu] and OumRuhu malaTatohu↓, (K,) aor.
maluTa
, (TA,) she brought it forth in an imperfect state. (K.) ― -b2- OamolaTa [perhaps a mistake for OabolaTa] He became poor, needy, or indigent; like OamolaSa. [TA, art. mlS.]

5 tmlRT c
5. tmlRT It (an arrow) was, or became, without feathers upon it. (K.) ― -b2- It [a thing] was, or became, made, or rendered, smooth; syn. tmlRS. (Sgh, K.)

8 AmtlThu c
8. AmtlThu He seized it, took it hastily, or snatched it unawares,; (Sgh, K;) like AmtrThu. (TA.)

milaATN c
milaATN [gypsum]: see XiydN. ― -b2- The shoulderblade; syn. katifN: (TA, art. srH:) or the humerus, or upper bone, of the arm; syn. EaDudN. (T, ibid.) of a camel. (ISh, ibid.)

maliyTN c
maliyTN The fœtus of a camel having as yet no hair grown upon it: (S, K:) or that is cast prematurely; as also maliySN. (K, TA, in art. mlS.) ― -b2- Also, A lamb or kid: or one just born. (TA.) ― -b3- See also what next follows.

OamolaTu c
OamolaTu A man having little, or scanty, or thin, hair upon the sides of his face, or of his cheeks; like OamoraTu: (S:) or having no hair upon his body, (Lth, K,) except the head and beard. (Lth.) ― -b2- An arrow of which the feathers have fallen off; like OamoraTu: (S:) or an arrow having no feathers upon it; as also maliyTN↓. (K.)

mumoliTN c
mumoliTN [like mumoriTN] A she-camel casting her fœtus without any hair upon it: pl. mamaAliyTu, (K, TA,) with I. (TA.)

mimolaATN c
mimolaATN [like mimoraATN] A she-camel that usually casts her fœtus without any hair upon it. (K.)

1 manaOa c
1. manaOa, aor.
manaAa
, (S, K,) inf. n. manoCN, (S,) He soaked a hide in tanning-liquid, or ooze. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- manaOahu He conformed with him in what he did. (TA.)

maniyoYapN c
maniyoYapN A hide in the first stage of tanning: (AZ, S, K:) it is next called OafiyqN; and then OadiymN: (AZ, S:) or a hide as long as it remains in the tanning-liquid. (TA.) ― -b2- A place where hides are tanned. (As, Ks, S, K.) ― -b3- Also, accord. to some, Tan, or that with which one tans. (TA.) ― -b4- This word is not to be pronounced without C, because maniyRapN signifies “ death. ” (MF.)

mamonaOapN c
mamonaOapN A black land: (K:) also without C. (TA.)

manojaniyqN mnjnyq
[manojaniyqN, as described in art. jnq (q. v.), seems to be the engine called by the Romans Onager: see Kitto's Pict. Bible, ii. 499: but was probably applied also to the balista.]

1 manaHahu c
1. manaHahu, aor.
manaHa
and
maniHa
, inf. n. manoHN, He lent him a she-camel, and a sheep or goat; (L;) that he might have the milk thereof, and return the animal after a certain period: this is the original signification: (L:) or he lent to him a she-camel, assigning to him her soft hair (wabar) and milk and offspring: (Lh, L, K:) and in like manner, he lent him a piece of land, that he might cultivate it and have the produce thereof: (L:) he lent him money or the like, to be repaid. (A, TA.) ― -b2- manaHahu, aor.
manaHa
and
maniHa
, (S, K,) inf. n. manoHN, (S,) He gave him a thing: (S, K:) he gave him a thing as a free gift. (A, TA.) ― -b3- tamonaHu AlmaroOapu wajohahaA AlmiroMpa The woman imparts somewhat of her beauty to the mirror: or directs her face towards the mirror. And in like manner, accord. to some, you say, when you direct anything (taqoSidu bihi) towards another thing, manaHotuhu UiyRaAhu. (L.)

3 mAnHhu c
3. mAnHhu, inf. n. mumaAnaHapN, He aided him, or assisted him, reciprocally, with a gift. (A.) ― -b2- mAnHt, inf. n. minaAHN and mumaAnaHapN, (tropical:) She (a camel) yielded plenty of milk in the winter, after the milk of the other camels had passed away. (L.) ― -b3- (tropical:) It (the eye) shed tears continuously. (K.)

4 AmnHt c
4. AmnHt She (a camel) was near to bringing forth. (S, K.) Sh says, I know not AmnHt in this sense: but Az says that it is correct, and that the objection of Sh does not invalidate it. (TA.)

5 tamanRaHotu AlmaAla c
5. tamanRaHotu AlmaAla (tropical:) I fed others with the property. So in the trad. of Umm-Zara, waMkulu faOatamanRaHu (tropical:) And I eat, and then feed others. (K, TA.)

8 UimotanaHa c
8. UimotanaHa He took or received, a gift. (K.) ― -b2- OumotuniHa maAlFA He was supplied with property, or wealth, by God. (K.)

10 AstmnHhu c
10. AstmnHhu He asked, desired, or sought, a loan, or gift, (minoHap,) of him; i. e., asked, desired, or sought aid, or assistance, from him; syn. Uisotarofadahu; (S;) or asked, &c., a gift from him. (K.)

minoHapN c
minoHapN A loan, or lending, of a she-camel or sheep or goat, that the person to whom the loan is granted may milk her for a certain period and then restore her to the lender: (A'Obeyd:) [and in like manner,] maniyHapN↓ a gift (minoHap) of milk; as a she-camel or sheep or goat that is given to another that he may milk her and afterwards restore her to the lender: (S:) or minoHapN signifies a ewe or a she-goat or a she-camel, which her owner lends to a man that he may drink her milk and restore her when her milk ceases to flow: (Msb:) or both words signify a she-camel or sheep or goat whose milk is given to another: (A:) or a she-camel of which the soft hair (wabar) and milk and offspring are conceded by the owner to another: (K:) or maniyHapN↓ signifies a she-camel or sheep or goat that is lent for the sake of her milk [&c.]; and minoHapN, the profit which the lender thereof bestows upon the borrower. (Lh, L.) The Arabs have four words which they use in the place of EaAriyRapN, viz. maniyHapN↓, EariyRapN, UifoqaArN, and UixobaAlN. (A'Obeyd, S.) ― -b2- minoHapN mino layanK Milch sheep or goats; (L;) [app. meaning, that are lent to a person]. ― -b3- Also minoHapN A loan of land, and of money. (L.) ― -b4- Also, A gift, or thing given; (S, L, K;) as also maniyHapN↓: (TA:) a free gift: (A'Obeyd, L:) pl. minaHN; (A;) and pl. of maniyHapN, manaAYiHu. (TA.)

manuwHN c
manuwHN: see mumaAniHN.

AlmaniyHu c
AlmaniyHu An arrow (of those used in the game called Almayosir, S) which has no lot, or portion, (S, K,) unless the person to whom it pertains be given something: (S:) it is the third of the arrows to which the term gufolN is applied, which have no notches, and to which is assigned no portion and no fine; these being only added to give additional weight to the collection of arrows from fear of occasioning suspicion [of foul play]: it is one of four arrows to each of which is assigned no portion and no fine; the first is called AlmuSadRaru; the next, AlmuDaERafa; the next, AlmnyH; and the last, AlsRafiyHu: (Lh:) accord. to some, (TA,) an arrow that is borrowed because it is regarded as fortunate: (K, TA:) or an arrow which has a portion assigned to it. (K.) ― -b2- kunotu maniyHa OaSoHaAbiI yawoma badorK (assumed tropical:) I was, among my companions, like the arrow called AlmnyH, on the day of the battle of Bedr; i. e., by reason of my youth, I was like the arrow that neither gains nor loses. (L, from a trad.)

maniyHapN c
maniyHapN: see minoHapN.

manRaAHN c
manRaAHN One who gives many gifts. (TA.)

mumoniHN c
mumoniHN A she-camel near to bringing forth. (S, K.)

mimonaHN c
mimonaHN and mamaAniHu: see mumaAniHN.

mumaAniHN c
mumaAniHN (S, K) and manuwHN↓ (S) (tropical:) A she-camel whose milk remains, (K,) or that yields plenty of milk in the winter, (S,) after the milk of the other camels has passed away; (S, K;) like mujaAliHN. (S.) You say also nuwqN mamaAniHu↓ [app. pl. of mimonaHN, which is perhaps not used. (TA.) ― -b2- Also the former, (tropical:) Rain that does not cease: (K:) and (tropical:) wind of which the rain does not cease. (TA.)

munodu c
munodu is a simple word; (K;) or, accord. to some, a compound word, as will be explained hereáfter: (TA:) Sb says, that it is with respect to time like mino with respect to place: (S, L:) it is indecl., [generally] with damm for its termination; and muco is indecl. also, [generally] with its final letter quiescent, (S, L, K,) [unless followed by a quiescent letter, when it is movent in different manners which will be shown below,] and it is formed from munocu by elision: (M, L, K:) mnc is also written and pronounced minocu, (M, L, K,) in the dial. of the Benoo-Suleym; (M, L;) and mc, mico, (M, L, K,) in the dial. of the tribe of 'Okl. (M, L.) Each may be a prep., governing what follows it in the gen. case, and used in the same manner as fiI [signifying In, or during, or from the beginning of]: and in this case, each is prefixed only to that which denotes present time: thus you say, maA raOayotuhu mucu AllRayolapi [I have not seen him in this night; or simply I have not seen him this night]: (S, L:) or each is followed by a noun in the gen. case, and in this instance is a prep., in the sense of mino [meaning Since, or lit., from,] when relating to a past time [such as a particular past day or the like]; and in the sense of fiI [meaning In, or from the beginning of,] when relating to the present time; and in the sense of mino and UilaI together [meaning From the beginning to the end of; or during the whole course of; or simply during, or for;] when relating to a computed period of time, or number of days or the like: ex. [relating to a past time,] maA raOayotuhu munocu yawomi Alxamiysi [I have not seen him since Thursday, UilaI QloMna to the present time]; (Mughnee, K;) and [relating to the present time,] munocu yawominaA or EaAminaA [in, or from the beginning of, (this) our day, or (this) our year;]; and, [relating to a computed period of time, or number of days or the like,] munocu valaAvapi OayRaAmK [from the beginning to the end of, i. e., during, or for, three days]. (Mughnee.) Each may also be a noun, governing the noun which follows it in the nom. case, as signifying a particular day or the like, or as signifying a definite length of time: in the case of a noun signifying a particular day or the like, you say, maA raOayotuhu muco yawomu AljumoEapi [I have not seen him (since the commencement of a space of time); the commencement of the space of time thereof (i. e., OawRalu mudRapi Eadami ruWoyatiI UiyRaAhu the commencement of the space of time of my not seeing him) was Friday; meaning, since Friday]: and, in the case of a noun signifying a definite length of time, you say, maA raOayotuhu muco sanapN, meaning, Oamadu celika sanapN, [I have not seen him (during, or for, a time); the time thereof (i. e., Oamadu Eadami ruWoyatiI UiyRaAhu the time of my not seeing him) is a year; meaning, during, or for, a year;] and the noun in this latter case can only be indeterminate; for you cannot say, muco sanapu kacaA: (S:) when followed by a noun in the nom. case, as in the instance of munocu yawomaAni [or, accord. to more approved usage, muco yawomaAni, as will be shown below, The time is two days, meaning during, or for, two days], each is an inchoative, and what follows it is an enunciative; and its meaning is the time with respect to what is present, and to a computed period, or a number of days or the like; and the commencement of the space of time with respect to a past time [such as a particular past day or the like]: or each is an adv. n. [of time], an enunciative, of which what follows is the inchoative, and meaning bayona wabayona, as in the instance of laqiytuhu munocu yawomaAni, [or, rather, muco yawomaAni,] i. e., bayoniI wabayona liqaAYihi yawomaAni [Two days have been between the time in which I now am and (the time of) my meeting him]: (K:) but this opinion is rejected by Ibn-Hájib. (TA.) Accord. to some of the Arabs, for they differ on this point, mc governs in the gen. case a noun signifying a past time and one signifying a time not past: and accord. to some of them, mnc governs in the nom. case a noun signifying a past time and one signifying a time not past: (M, L:) but the general and most approved way is to make mc govern in the gen. case a noun signifying a time not past, and in the nom. case one signifying a time past; and to make mnc govern in the gen. case a noun signifying a time not past and one signifying a time past: (T, M, L:) most of the Arabs hold, that each must govern in the gen. case a noun signifying the present time; and that it is preferable to make mnc govern in the same case, and to make mc govern in the nom. case, a noun signifying a past time: (Mughnee:) [they therefore say, munocu AllRayolapi and mucu AllRayolapi, and munocu yawomi Alxamiysi and munocu yawomayni; but they say, muco yawomu Alxamiysi and muco yawomaAni.] Some [or, rather, most] say, lamo Oarahu muco yawomaAni, and lamo Oarahu munocu yawomayni, [I have not seen him for, or during, two days;] making mc [in these instances] to govern the nom. case; and mnc, the gen. case. (L.) Such is said when the period of separation is a day and part of a day. (Msb, art. Xhr.) The Benoo-Dabbeh and Er-Rabáb make mc to govern the gen. case in every instance. (M, L.) The phrases, maA raOayotuhu muco EaAmN OawRalu, and muco EaAmN OawRala, (S, K, art. wOl; and L,) and muco EaAmu AlOawRali, and muco EaAmFA OawRala, [I have not seen him since last year,] are also mentioned by different authors. (L.) The Arabs generally agree in pronouncing mnc with damm to the c when it is followed by a movent or a quiescent letter; (T, M, L;) as in lamo Oarahu munocu yawomK, and munocu Alyawomi: (T, L:) and to pronounce mc with the c quiescent when it is followed by a movent letter, (T, M, L,) and with damm and [sometimes] with kesr when it is followed by a conjunctive A; (M, L;) as in lamo Oarahu muco yawomaAni, and lamo Oarahu mucu Alyawomi, [and muci Alyawomi]: (T, L:) and so say most of the grammarians. (T.) Lh says, The Benoo-'Obeyd, of the tribe of Ghanee, make the c of mc movent when it is followed by a movent or a quiescent letter, and make the noun following it to be in the nom. case, saying mucu Alyawomu; and some of them pronounce it with kesr when followed by a quiescent letter, saying muci Alyawomu; but this is not the proper way. (M, L.) In the phrase maA raOayotuhu mucu Alyawomi, the Arabs make the c movent because of the occurrence [otherwise] of two quiescent letters together; and they [generally] give it not kesr, but damm, because the latter is the final vowel of its original mnc. (M, L.) One says also, maA laqiytupu munoca Alyawomi, and muca Alyawomi, which fet-h to the c in each. (K.) The Benoo-Suleym are related to have used the expression maA raOayotuhu minocu sitRN [by stR meaning six nights], with kesr to the m of mnc, and with the noun following it in the nom. case: and the tribe of 'Okl are related to have used the expression micu yawomaAni, with the n elided, and with kesr to the m, and damm to the c. (M, L.) ― -b2- Each of the two words mnc and mc is also followed by a verbal proposition, as in the instance
maA zaAla muco Eaqadato yadaAhu UizaAzahu
[He has not ceased, since his two hands tied his wrapper of the lower part of the body]: or a nominal proposition, as in the instance
walaA zilotu OabogiI AlmaAla muco OanaA yaAfiEN
[And I ceased not to seek wealth from the time of my being a youth, or young man]: in such cases, each is an adv. n. prefixed to the proposition [and governing it virtually in the gen. case], or to a noun significant of time [understood as] prefixed thereto [in the same manner]: or, as some say, each is an inchoative. (K.) ― -b3- The original of mc is mnc, because they restore the dammeh
to the c in the case of the occurrence of two quiescent letters together; as in the instance of mucu Alyawomi, for were not its original with damm, they would give it kesr: [but this some do, as has been shown above:] and because its dim. is munayocN: (K:) for when mc is used as a proper name of a man, its dim. is thus formed, by restoring the n, that it may be of the measure fuEayolN: (IJ, M, L:) or when mc is a noun, it is originally mnc; and when it is a particle, it is itself original. (K.) ― -b4- Accord. to some, mnc (T, S, L, K) and mc (K) are originally mino and Uico, which are made one word, (T, S, L, K,) by eliding the hemzeh, and then giving damm to the c because of the occurrence of two quiescent letters together; (K;) munocu kaAna [and muco kaAna] meaning mino Uico kaAna: (T, L:) but there is nothing to indicate the truth of this opinion: (S, L:) or, as some say, mnc and mc are originally the prep. mn and cw in the sense of AlRaciI (L, K) in the dial. of Teiyi: so says Fr.; adding, that when either governs a gen. case, it is used in the manner of mano; and when it governs a nom. case, it is as though one said, [in using the expression munocu Oawo muco yawomaAni,] mina QlRaciI huwa yawomaAni; and that the former government prevails in the case of mnc because the n is not suppressed: (L:) or, as some say, they are originally mino and the noun of indication caA; so that in the phrase maA raOayotuhu munocu yawomaAni, [accord. to more approved usage, muco yawomaAni,] we virtually say, mino caA Qlowaqoti yawomaAni: but each of these assertions is a deviation from the plain way. (K.)

1 mahaja c
1. mahaja, aor.
mahaja
, (inf. n. mahojN, TA,) He sucked [the breast of his mother]. ― -b2- mahaja Inivit ancillam suam. (K.) ＝ -A2- mahaja He became goodly in countenance after disease. (AA, K.)

8 Oamotuhija c
8. Oamotuhija (tropical:) His soul was torn from him. (A, K.)

muhojapN c
muhojapN Blood: or the blood of the heart: (S, K:) pl. muhajN. (A.)
