An Arab of the desert is related to have said, dafanotu muhojatahu, meaning damahu: so in the S: but in a marginal note in a copy of that work, it is said that this is a mistake; and that the correct expression, as mentioned by IKt and others, is dafaqotu muhojatahu I poured forth, or shed, his blood: and so it is in the copies of the A. (TA.) In like manner, dafaqa AllRehu muhojatahu (tropical:) May God destroy him! (A. [See also dafqa.]) ― -b2- Also, (tropical:) The soul, or spirit. (S, K.) Ex. xarajato muhojatuhu (tropical:) His soul went forth, or departed. (S.) OunotuziEato muhojatuhu (tropical:) His soul was torn from him. (K.) ― -b3- Also, (tropical:) One's self: the best of one's self, and one's powers, efforts, endeavours, or energy. (L.) Ex. bacalotu lahu muhojatiI (tropical:) I gave, or gave up, myself, and the best of my powers, efforts, endeavours, or energy, to him, or it. (T.) ― -b4- Also, (tropical:) The purest, choicest, or best, of anything. (L.) ― -b5- Also, (assumed tropical:) The heart. (MF.)

maAhijN c
maAhijN: see OumohujN.

OumohujN c
OumohujN (K) and OamohujaAnN↓ and maAhijN↓ (S, K) Thin milk: (S, K:) or, the first and second, milk free from water: and, the second, milk of which the froth has become still, and which is clear, and not thick: and, the last, thin milk, of which the taste has not changed; as also OumohuwjN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, the first, Thin fat; (S, K;) as also the second and third: (K:) or raw fat. (M.) ― -b3- The first is an epithet of a form not mentioned by Sb. (TA.) It may be a contraction of OumohuwjN. (IJ.) [And the like may be said of OumoludN.]

OumohujaAnN c
OumohujaAnN: see OumohujN.

OamohuwjN c
OamohuwjN: see OumohujN.

mamohuwju AlbaToni c
mamohuwju AlbaToni Lax in the belly. (K.)

1 mahada c
1. mahada, (S, L, K,) aor.
mahada
, (L, K,) inf. n. mahodN [q. v. infra]; (S, L;) and mhRd↓, (L, K,) inf. n. tamohiydN; (TA;) He made plain, even, or smooth, this is the original signification: he made a place plain, even, or smooth, [makaAnFA being understood,] linafosihi for himself: (L:) he spread a bed, (S, L, K,) and made it plain, even, or smooth. (S, L.) ― -b2- mahada lahu (assumed tropical:) He did well, or kindly, in his affair in his absence; like fahada and faOada. (L, art. fhd.) ― -b3- mahada, aor.
mahada
, (inf. n. mahodN, L,) He gained, or earned, or sought to gain sustenance, and worked, (L, K,) linafosihi for himself. (L.) ― -b4- mahada linafosihi xayorFA, and Amthdhu↓, (tropical:) He prepared for himself good, good things, or the like. (L.) ― -b5- lahu manozilapF saniyRapF mhRd↓ (tropical:) [He prepared, or established, for him a high station]. (A.) ― -b6- fulaAnN EinodiI yadFA maA Qmotahada↓ (tropical:) [Such a one has not prepared for himself, with me, a benefit, for me to owe it him]: you say this when one has not conferred upon you a favour or kindness. (AZ, L.) And fulaAnN EinodiI maA Qmotahada↓ mahoda caAka (tropical:) [Such a one has not prepared for himself, with me, that thing, that I should owe it him]; is said on one's asking a kindness without having previously conferred a benefit; (AZ, JK, L;) and with reference to one who acts in an evil manner, when asking a kindness, or when a kindness is asked for him. (AZ, L.)

2 mhRd c
2. mhRd, inf. n. tamohiydN, (tropical:) He adjusted, or arranged, an affair, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) and made it plain, (A, Msb,) and easy. (Msb.) See 1. ― -b2- mhRd nafosahu lifiEoli AlOamori (assumed tropical:) He disposed and subjected his mind, or himself, to do the thing. (S, * K, * Msb, art. wTn.) ― -b3- mhRd, inf. n. tamohiydN, (tropical:) He accepted, or admitted, an excuse. (S, L, Msb, K.) You say, mahRadotu lahu AlEucora (tropical:) I accepted, or admitted, his excuse. (Msb.)

5 tmhRd c
5. tmhRd and Amthd↓ It (a bed) became spread, and made plain, even, or smooth. (A.) ― -b2- tmhRd lahu AlOamoru (tropical:) The affair became adjusted, or arranged, and made plain, and easy, for, or to, him. (Msb.) ― -b3- tmhRd firaAXFA [He spread for himself a bed, and made it plain, even, or smooth]. (A.) ― -b4- tamahRadato lahu EinodiI HaAlN laTiyfapN (tropical:) [A genteel situation was prepared for him with me, or at my abode]. (A.) ― -b5- tmhRd (assumed tropical:) He (a man, TA) became possessed of authority and power; syn. tamakRana. (S, L, K.) ― -b6- tmhRdt nafosuhu (assumed tropical:) His mind, or he, became disposed and subjected [lifiEoli AlOamori to do the thing; see 2]; syn. tawaTRanato. (K, art. wTn.)

8 Amthd c
8. Amthd It (a camel's hump) became spreading and high. (S, L, K.) See 1 in three places.

10 Astmhd firaAXFA c
10. Astmhd firaAXFA [He asked, or desired, that a bed should be spread for him, and made plain, even, or smooth]. (A.)

mahodN c
mahodN [A child's cradle, or bed;] a place prepared for a child, and made plain, even, or smooth, (S, * L, K,) that he may sleep in it: (L:) a bed; a thing spread to lie, recline, or sit, upon; (A, Msb;) as also mihaAdN↓; (S, A, L, Msb, K;) so called because of its plainness, evenness, or smoothness: (L:) Az says, that the latter word is more comprehensive than the former: (L:) it is applied to the ground, or earth; [meaning a plain, an even, or a smooth expanse; see a verse of Lebeed cited voce xawaAliqu:] (Az, L, K:) and so is mahodN: (K:) some say, that mahodN and mihaAdN↓ are [originally] two inf. ns., of the same meaning: or that the former is an inf. n., and the latter a simple subst.: or that the former is sing., and the latter pl.: (MF:) the pl. of the former [in common use] is muhuwdN, (L, Msb, K,) and mihaAdN; and of the latter, [pl. of pauc.,] OamohidapN (L, K) and [of mult.,] muhudN. (L, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Oalamo najoEali QloOaroDa mihaAdFA↓ [Kur, lxxviii. 6,] Have we not made the earth an expanse (bisaAT) adapted to be travelled over. (K, TA.) ― -b3- labiYosa AlmihaAdu↓ [Kur. ii. 202,] (tropical:) Evil is that which he hath prepared for himself in his final place.
(K.) Such is said to be the meaning. (TA.) ― -b4- sahodN mahodN Good; goodly: the latter word is an imitative sequent. (L.)

muhodN c
muhodN Elevated ground or land: (IAar, L, K:) or depressed and smooth and even ground or land; (K;) as also muhodapN↓: (En-Nadr, K:) pl. mihadapN and OamohaAdN: (K:) but the former of these pls. is doubtful. (TA.)

muhodapN c
muhodapN: see muhodN.

mihaAdN c
mihaAdN: see mahodN.

mahiydN c
mahiydN Pure butter: (L, K:) or the purest of butter when melted, and that which has the least milk. (L.)

mumahRadN c
mumahRadN (tropical:) Lukewarm water; neither hot nor cold. (A, K.)

1 mahara AlmaroOapa c
1. mahara AlmaroOapa, (AZ, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
mahara
(S, Msb, K) and
mahura
, (K,) inf. n. mahorN, (S, Msb, TA,) He gave the woman a mahor [or dowry]: (A, Mgh, Msb, K:) or he assigned to her (jaEala lahaA) a mahor: (K:) and OamoharahaA↓ signifies the same as maharahaA, (AZ, S, Msb, K,) which is of the dial. of Temeem, and the more usual: (Msb:) or maharahaA has the first of the above significations, (A, Mgh, Msb, K,) or signifies he set apart for her a mahor: (Msb:) and OamoharahaA↓ signifies he named for her a mahor and married her to himself for it; (A, Mgh;) or he married her to another man for a certain mahor; (Msb, K;) or he sent for her a mahor. (TA.) ＝ -A2- mahara AlXRaIoCa, (S, K,) and fiyhi, and bihi (K,) and fiyhi tmhRr↓, (K, * TA,) and mahara SinaAEatahu, (A,) and fiyhaA, (Mgh, Msb,) and bihaA, and fiyhaA tmhRr↓, (A,) and mahara fiI AlEilomi wagayorihi, (Msb,) aor.
mahara
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. mahaArapN (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K) and mihaArapN (L) and muhuwrN (Msb, K) and mahaArN and mahorN, (K,) He was, or became, skilled, or expert, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) in the thing, (S, K,) and in his art, or craft, (A, Mgh, Msb,) and in science, &c., (Msb,) knowing its abstrusities and niceties, or having learned the whole of it; syn. Hacaqa. (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K.)

2 mhRr c
2. mhRr, inf. n. tamohiyrN, He desired a colt: (K, TA:) he procured for himself a colt. (JK, K, TA.) [In the CK, and in a MS. copy of the K, we find Almahor put by mistake for Almuhor.] Aboo-Zubeyd says, describing a lion,
Oaqobala yarodiI kamaA yarodiI AlHiSaAnu UilaI
musotaEosibK OaribK minohu bitamohiyri
He came [beating the ground with his feet] like as a horse comes [so beating the ground] to a man borrowing him for covering, wanting by his means to procure for himself a colt. (TA.) [In the L, and TA, yarowiI is put for yrdI in both instances: but it is corrected by SM in the margin of the L.]

4 Amhr AlmaroOapa c
4. Amhr AlmaroOapa: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- Amhr AlnRaAqapa He called, or rendered, (jaEala) the she-camel a mahoriyRap: (K:) [it has sometimes, if not always, the latter meaning; for] it is said of the breaker, or trainer; and is like OaroHalahaA. (TA, in art. rHl.) ＝ -A3- Amhrt Alfarasu The mare had a colt following her. (TA.)

5 tamahRara
5: see 1, in two places.

mahorN c
mahorN A dowry; a nuptial gift; a gift that is given to, or for, a bride; syn. SadaAqN: (S, A, Msb, K:) pl. muhuwrN, (K,) or muhuwrapN, like as buEuwlapN is pl. of baEolN, and fuHuwlapN of faHolN. (Msb.) zawojN mahorK A husband from whom a dowry is got: (S, art. bhr:) or a husband who has not nobility of race, and who therefore doubles the dowry to make himself desired. (TA, same art.) See bahorN. ― -b2- The hire of a prostitute. Ex. nahaI Eano mahori AlbagiIR He forbade [receiving] the hire of the prostitute. (Mgh, Msb.)

muhorN c
muhorN A colt; the male foal of a mare; (S, K;) and of a mare kept for breeding: (TA:) or the first male offspring of a mare or other animal; (K;) i. e., of a tame ass; &c.: (ISd, TA:) fem. with p; a filly: (S, Msb, K:) and dim. muhayorN: (JK:) pl. masc., (of pauc., TA,) OamohaArN, and (of mult., TA) mihaArN and mihaArapN; (S, Msb, K;) and pl. fem. muharN and muharaAtN. (S, Msb.)

UibilN mahoriyRapN c
UibilN mahoriyRapN Camels of Mahreh; i. e. certain camels, so called in relation to Mahreh Ibn- Heydán, (T, S, Msb, K,) a tribe, (K,) or a great tribe, (TA,) or the father of a tribe of El-Yemen: (S:) or in relation to Mahreh, a district of 'Omán: (Msb:) they are excellent camels, that outstrip horses; and some add, that they are unequalled in quickness of running, understanding what is desired of them with the least training, and having names, by which being called, they answer quickly: (Msb:) [and hence, any such like camels; i. e. any excellent, fleet, camels: (see 4:) n. un. mahoriIRN:] pl. mahaAriIRu [which is irreg. like ZahaAriIRN] (S, Msb, K) and mahaArK (S, K) and mahaAraI, (K, TA,) written in the L mahaAriI, (TA,) [and so in the CK,] or mahaAraA, the I being changed into A, (Msb,) [but it generally retains the form of I, though pronounced A.] See also HuwXiIRN.

mahiyrapN c
mahiyrapN [A woman to whom a dowry has been given: and hence,] a free [married] woman: (S, K:) opposed to surRiyRapN: (A:) pl. mahaAYiru. (A, TA.) And, (TA,) One whose dowry is dear. (K, TA.)

maAhirN c
maAhirN Skilled, or skilful, (A, Msb, K,) fI SinaAEatihi, in his art, (A, Msb,) and bkulRi EamalK, in every work, (A, K,) fiI Eilomi wagayorihi in science &c., (Msb,) knowing its abstrusities and niceties, or having learned the whole of it; syn. HaAciqN: (A, Msb, K:) and, (K,) in most instances, (TA,) [but only when used absolutely,] a good swimmer; (JK, K;) as also mutamahRirN↓: (Z, TA;) pl. maharapN: (A, K:) also mutamahRirN↓ a lion skilled in slaying his prey. (K.)

mumohirN c
mumohirN A mare having a colt or foal. (S, K.)

mamohuwrapN c
mamohuwrapN A woman dowered; to whom a dowry has been given; or for whom a dowry has been set apart. (Msb.) It is said in a proverb, kaQlomamohuwrapi UiHodaI xadamatayohaA [Like her who has been dowered with one of her two anklets]: (S, K:) or OaHomaqu mina Qlomamohuwrapi UiHodaI xadamatayohaA [More stupid than she who has been dowered with one of her two anklets]: (Mgh:) applied to him who has reached the utmost degree of stupidity: from the following case: (TA:) a stupid woman demanded of her husband her dowry, (K, TA,) when he paid her his first visit, and she said, I will not obey thee unless thou give me my dowry: (TA:) so he pulled off one of her two anklets (K, TA) from her foot, (TA,) and gave it to her, and she was content with it. (K, TA.) In like manner, a certain man gave to another property, and he married with it the daughter of the giver, and then reproached her for the dowry he had given her: so they said, kaQlomamohuwrapi mino maAli OabiyhaA [Like her who has been dowered from the property of her father]: (K, TA:) [a proverb] applied in relation to him who reproaches for that which is not his own. (TA.)

mutamahRirN c
mutamahRirN: see maAhirN, in two places.

1 maMCa c
1. maMCa, aor. yamuwoCu, inf. n. mawoCN (K, TA: in the CK muwoCN) and muWaMCN (but see below) or (as in some copies of the K) muwaMCN; (K;) and OamowaOa↓; (AA;) It (a cat) mewed: (K:) like maOaI, (TA,) and OamaA. (S in art. Amw.)

4 AmwO c
4. AmwO: see 1. ― -b2- Also, He (a man) mewed like a cat. (K.)

muWaMCN c
muWaMCN, accord. to the K, an inf. n. of maMCa; but accord. to the L and other lexicons, The mew of a car; a word expressing the sound of mewing. (TA.)

maWuwoCN c
maWuwoCN (in some copies of the K, mawuwoCN,) A mewing cat. (K.)

maAYiYapN c
maAYiYapN and maAYiyRapN and maAYiyapN [and epithet of] A cat. (K.)

1 maAta c
1. maAta, aor. yamuwtu, (inf. n. mawotN; Msb,) and maAta, (originally mawita, like xaAfa, originally xawifa, MF) [sec. per. mitRa,] aor. yamaAtu, (S, K,) which latter is of the dial. of Teiyi; (TA;) and maAta, (in which the medial radical letter is originally I, like baAEa, MF) aor. yamiytu, (K,) a form which some have disapproved; (MF;) and maAta, (originally mawita, Kr,) sec. pers. mitRa, aor. yamuwtu, like daAma, (originally dawima, Kr,) aor. yaduwmu, (Kr, Msb, &c.,) and like the sound verbs naEima, aor. yanoEumu, and faDila, aor. yafoDulu, (TA,) of the class of words in which two dial. forms are intermixed; (Msb;) He died; contr. of HayiI. (K,) ― -b2- [maAta Eano baniyna wabanaAtK He died having passed away from, i. e. leaving behind him, sons and daughters. And maAta Eano vamaAniyna sanFp He died having passed beyond eighty years; i. e. being eighty years old.] ― -b3- AllRabanu laA yamuwtu [The milk will not die], in a saying of 'Omar, in a trad., means, that if a child sucks the milk of a dead woman, it becomes unlawful for him afterwards to marry any of her relations who would be unlawful to him if he sucked her milk while she was living: or it means, that, if milk taken from the breast of a woman is given to a child to drink, and he drinks it, the consequence is the same; that the effect of the milk in producing this consequence is not annulled by its separation from the breast; for whatever is separated from a living being is termed myt, or dead, except the milk and hair and wool on account of the necessity of making use of these. (TA.) ― -b4- maAtati AlOaroDu, inf. n. mawataAnN and mawaAtN, (tropical:) The land became destitute of cultivation and of inhabitants. (Msb.) ― -b5- maAta (tropical:) It (soil) became deprived of vegetable life. Hence an expression in the Kur, xxx. 18. (Az, Er-Rághib.) ― -b6- maAta (tropical:) He became deprived of sensation; [dead as to the senses]. So in the Kur, xix. 23: [but this appears to me doubtful]. (Az, Er-Rághib.) ― -b7- maAta (tropical:) He became deprived of the intellectual faculty; [intellectually dead;] or ignorant. Hence an expression in the Kur, vi. 122; and another in the Kur, xxvii. 82; and xxx. 51. (Az, Er-Rághib.) ― -b8- maAta (tropical:) [He became as though dead with grief, or sorrow, and fear;] he experienced grief, or sorrow, and fear, that disturbed his life. Hence what is said in the Kur, xiv. 20. (Az, Er-Rághib.) ― -b9- maAta (tropical:) He or it, was or became, still, quiet, or motionless. (K.) ― -b10- mAtati AlrRiyH (tropical:) The wind became still, or calm. (TA.) ― -b11- maAta (tropical:) He slept. (AA, K.) ― -b12- maAtati AlnRaAru, inf. n. mawotN, (tropical:) [The fire died away;] the ashes of the fire became cold, or cool, and none of its live coals remained. (TA.) ― -b13- maAta (tropical:) It (heat or cold) became assuaged. (TA.) ― -b14- maAta (tropical:) It (water) became dried up by the earth. (TA.) ― -b15- maAta (and AstmAt↓, TA.) (tropical:) It (a garment, TA,) wore out; became worn out. (A, K.) ― -b16- mAt (tropical:) It (a road) ceased to be passed along. (TA.) ― -b17- baladN tamuwtu fiyhi AlrRiyHu [A town, or country, &c., in which the wind becomes broken, or loses its force]. (TA.) ― -b18- maAta fuwqu AlrRajuli (tropical:) The man slept heavily; became heavy in his sleep. (TA.) ― -b19- yamuwtu mina AlHasadi (tropical:) [He dies, or will die, of envy]. (TA.) ― -b20- maAta (tropical:) He became poor; was reduced to poverty: he became a beggar. (TA.) ― -b21- (tropical:) He became base, abject, vile, despicable, or ignominious. (TA.) ― -b22- (tropical:) He became extremely aged, old and weak, or decrepit. (TA.) ― -b23- (tropical:) He became disobedient, or rebellious. Iblees is said, in a trad., to be OawRalu mano maAta because he was the first who became disobedient, or rebellious. (TA.) ― -b24- maAta (assumed tropical:) He (a man) became lowly, humble, or submissive, to the truth. (TA.)

2 mawRatati AldRawaAbRu c
2. mawRatati AldRawaAbRu The beasts of carriage died in great numbers; or deaths amongst them were frequent. (TA.) ― -b2- See 4.

3 maAowata
3: [mAwthu,] inf. n. mumaAwatapN, He vied with him in patience, (K,) and in firmness, or steadiness, or the like. (TA.) [In the K, the inf. n. is expl. by muSaAbarap; and in the TA, by muvaAbatap also.]

4 AmAthu c
4. AmAthu and mwRthu↓ (but the latter has an intensive signification, S,) He (God) caused him to die; put him to death; killed him. (S, K.) ― -b2- AmAt (tropical:) He (a man) lost a son, or sons, by death. (ISk, S.) ― -b3- AmAt fulaAnN baniyna Such a man lost sons by death. (A.) ― -b4- AmAtt She (a woman, AO, S, K, and a camel, S, K.) lost her offspring by death. (S, K.) ― -b5- AmAtwA Death [or a mortal disease] happened among their camels. (K.) ― -b6- maA Oamowatahu signifies maA Oamowata qalobahu [(tropical:) How dead is his heart!] for one does not wonder at any action that does not increase: (S, K:) therefore what is here meant is not literally death. (TA.) ― -b7- AmAthu (tropical:) He (God) rendered him poor; reduced him to poverty. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b8- AmAthu (tropical:) He [or it] caused him to sleep. Ex., in a prayer said on awaking, AlHamodu lilRehi AlRaciI OaHoyaAnaA baEoda maA OamaAtanaA Praise be to God who hath awaked us after having caused us to sleep! (L.) ― -b9- yumiytu AllRayola (assumed tropical:) He sleeps during the night. (W, p. 9.) ― -b10- AmAt AllRaHoma, (and mwRthu↓, TA,) He took extraordinary pains in thoroughly cooking, and in boiling, the meat. (K.) And in like manner, onions, and garlic, so as to deprive them of their strong taste and odour. (TA.) ― -b11- Oumiytati Alxamoru The wine was cooked, and ceased to boil. (TA.) ― -b12- [AmAthu is also employed in various other senses, agreeably with the senses of the primitive verb.]

6 Darabotuhu fatamaAwata c
6. Darabotuhu fatamaAwata (tropical:) I beat him and he feigned himself dead, being alive. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He pretended to be weak and motionless by reason of acts of devotion and fasting: [see the act. part. n. below]. (TA.)

10 AstmAt c
10. AstmAt [He sought death: &c.: see musotamiytN]. ― -b2- UisotamiytuwA Sayodakumo, and daAbRatakumo, Wait until ye ascertain that your game, and your beast of carriage, has died. (A.) ― -b3- AstmAt [properly, He sought, or courted, death;] i. q. Astqtl; (S, K; in art. qtl;) meaning he cared not for death, by reason of his courage. (JM, in art. qtl.) ― -b4- AstmAt (assumed tropical:) He (a man) was pleased with death; content to die. (TA.) ― -b5- AstmAt (assumed tropical:) He (a man, TA.) tried every way, or did his utmost, in seeking a thing. (IAar, K.) ― -b6- AstmAt, inf. n. UistimaAtN, (occurring thus with the final p elided, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He (a man, and a camel, IAar,) became fat after having been emaciated, (IAar, K.) ― -b7- AstmAt (tropical:) It (a thing) became relaxed, loose, or flabby. (A.) ― -b8- AstmAt liynFA (assumed tropical:) It attained the utmost degree of softness: said of a fine skin, that is likened to the thin pellicle that adheres to the white of an egg: and of other things, as also AstmAt fiI AllRiyni: and in like manner, fiI AlSRalaAbapi, in hardness. (TA.) See musotamiytN ― -b9- And see 1.

mawotN c
mawotN (and mawataAnN↓, TA,) Death; lifelessness; contr. of HayaApN: (S, TA:) as also muwaAtN↓, (S, K,) and mamaAtN↓. [Occurring in the Kur, vi. 163, xvii. 77, and xlv. 20,] (S, * TA, in art. HI, and Jel, in vi. 163.) [See also muwtaAnN, below: and see 1.] Or mawataAnN↓, signifies much death, like as HayawaAnN signifies much life. (Msb, in art. HI.) ― -b2- Almawotu AlOaboyaDu, and AljaArifu, and AllRaAfitu, and AlfaAtilu, Sudden death. (IAar, in T and TA, art. flt.) ― -b3- Almawotu AlOaHomaru Death by slaughter with the sword. (IAar, in T, TA, art. flt.) ― -b4- Almawotu AlOasowadu Death by drowning, and by suffocation. (IAar, in T and TA, art. flt.) ― -b5- banaAtu Almawoti (assumed tropical:) [The daughters of death;] meaning deadly arrows. (A, TA, voce jaEobapN, q. v.)

mayotN c
mayotN: see mayRitN. ― -b2- OaroDN mayotapN: see mawaAtN: Unfruitful land; like as ArD HayRapN means fruitful land, or land abounding with herbage. (TA, in art. HI.) ― -b3- mayotapN Carrion: whatsoever hath not been killed in the manner prescribed by the law. (K, Jel, ii. 168.) See mayRitN.

muwtapN c
muwtapN (tropical:) A fainting, or swoon; (K;) and languor in the intellect: (TA:) or [an affection] like a fainting, or swoon: (Lh:) madness, or insanity, or diabolical possession; syn. junuwnN; (AO, K;) because it occasions a stillness like
death: (TA:) or a kind of madness or diabolical possession (junuwnN), and epilepsy, that befalls a man; on the recovery from which, his perfect reason returns to him, as to one who has been sleeping, and to one who has been drunk. (S.) [See humozN.]

miytapN c
miytapN A kind, mode, or manner, of death: (S, K:) pl. miyatN. (TA.) ― -b2- maAta fulaAnN miytapF HasanapF Such a one died a good kind of death. (S.) ― -b3- maAta miytapF jaAhiliyRapF He died a pagan kind of death, in error and disunion. (TA, from a trad.)

mawotaAnu AlfuWaAdi c
mawotaAnu AlfuWaAdi (tropical:) A man who is [dead, or] not lively, in heart: (A:) a man who is stupid, dull, unexcitable, or not to be rendered brisk, sprightly, or lively; (S,. K;) as though the heat of his intelligence had cooled and died: (TA:) fem. with p. (S, K.) ― -b2- See muwtaAnN and mawaAtN.

muwtaAnN c
muwtaAnN (Fr, S, K) and mawotaAnN↓ (K) and muwaAtN↓ (Fr) Death, [or a mortal disease, or a murrain,] that befalls camels or sheep or the like. (Fr, S, K.) The first is of the dial. of Temeem: the second, of the dial. of others. (Et-Tilimsánee.) ― -b2- waqaEa fiI AlmaAli muwtaAnN, and muwaAtN↓, Death [or a mortal disease] happened among the camels &c. (Fr.) ― -b3- Also, The like among men. Ex., from a trad., yakuwnu fiI AlnRaAsi muwtaAnN kaquEaASi Alganami There will be, among men, a mortality, or much death, [or mortal disease], like the quEaAS that befalls sheep or goats. (TA.)

mawataAnN c
mawataAnN (assumed tropical:) Inanimate things, or goods; dead stock; such as lands and houses [&c.]; (S;) contr. of HayawaAnN [q. v.] (S, K.) It is made of this measure to agree in measure with its contr. HywAn: both these words deviate from the constant course of speech; being of a measure properly belonging to inf. ns. (TA.) [See also mawaAtN.] ― -b2- UiXotari AlmawataAna walA taXotari AlHayawaAna Buy lands and houses [or the like], and buy not slaves and beasts of carriage [&c.]. (S.) ― -b3- rajulN yabiyEu AlmawataAna A man who sells utensils or furniture or the like, and anything but what has life. (L.) ― -b4- See also mawotN.

mawaAtN c
mawaAtN That wherein is no spirit or life; an inanimate thing. (S, K.) [See also mawataAnN.] ― -b2- mawaAtN (you say OaroDN mawaAtN, TA,) (tropical:) Land that has no owner (S, K) of mankind, and of which no use is made, or from which no advantage is derived, (S,) and in which is no water: such as is also called OaroDN mayotapN↓: (En-Nawawee:) land that has not been sown, nor cultivated, nor occupied by any man's camels &c.: mawataAnN↓ signifies the same as muwaAtN (mawaAtN?), namely, land that is no man's property; and is also written mawotaAnN: (L:) or mawataAnN signifies land that has not yet been brought into a state of cultivation: (Fr, S, L, K:) in a trad. it is said, that such land is the property of God and his Apostle; and whosoever brings into a state of cultivation such land, to him it belongs. (S.)

muwaAtN c
muwaAtN: see mawotN and muwtaAnN.

mayRitN c
mayRitN and mayotN↓ signify the same, [Dead, or dying]: (Zj, S, K:) the former is originally mayowitN, of the measure fayoEilN: (S:) the latter is contracted from the former; and is both masc. and fem.; (Zj, S;) as is also the former. (Zj.) 'Adee Ibn-Er-Raalà says,
layosa mano maAta faQsotaraAHa bimayotK↓
UinRamaA Almayotu mayRitu AlOaHoyaMCi
[He who has died and become at rest is not dead: the dead is only the dead of the living]. (S, TA.) Or mayotN↓ signifies One who has died (actually, TA,); and mayRitN, as also maAYitN↓, one who has not yet died, (K,) but who is near to dying: or, accord. to a verse cited by AA, to Kh, mayotN is applied to him who is borne to the grave; [i. e., who is dead, or lifeless]; and mayRitN, to him who [is dying, but] has life in him. (TA.) Fr says, you say of him who has not died, UinRahu maAYitN, Eano qaliylK ↓and mayRitN; but you do not say of him who has died hcA maAYitN↓: (S:) but some say, that this is an error, and that mayRitN is applicable to that which will soon die. Those who assert that myRt is applicable only to the living adduce the following words of the Kur, [xxxix. 31,] UinRaka mayRitN waUinRahumo mayRituwna: (TA:) i. e. Verily thou wilt die, and verily they will die. (Msb.) MF observes, that mayotN is asserted to be contracted from mayRitN; and if so, that there can be no difference in their meanings: that the making a difference between them is contrary to analogy; agreeably with which, they should be like hayonN and hayRinN, and layonN and layRinN: and also contrary to what has been heard from the Arabs; for they made no difference in their use of these two words. (TA.) [See also what is said of mayotapN, below.] The pls. are OamowaAtN and mawotaI and mayRituwna and mayotuwna. (S, K.) The first of these is pl. of mayRitN, and consequently of mayotN, because this latter is contracted from the former: as mayRitN is of the measure fayoEilN, and this measure resembles faAEilN, it has received a form of pl. which is sometimes applicable to the measure fAEl: (Sb:) or AmwAt is [only] pl. of mayotN. (Msb.) [The second form (which is applied to rational beings, Msb,) is also pl. of myRt and myt.] The third and fourth are [only] applied to rational beings. (Msb.) The fem. epithet is mayRitapN and mayotapN and mayRitN (K, TA) and mayotN. (TA; and so in some copies of the K, in the place of mayRitN.) mayRitapN is an epithet applied to a female rational being; [and its pl. is mayRitaAtN:] mayotapN, to a female brute, for the sake of distinction; and its pl. is mayotaAtN: the latter is contracted because it is more in use than the former epithet applied to a female rational being: (Msb:) the pl. of myRt and myt as fem. epithets is as above [OamowaAtN and mawotaI]. (TA.) ― -b2- mayotapN↓ signifies That which has not been slaughtered (AA, S, K) [in the manner prescribed by the law, i. e., carrion]: or that of which the life has departed without slaughter: so in the classical language and in the language of practical law: all such is unlawful to be eaten, except fish and locusts, which are lawful by universal consent of the Muslims: (En-Nawawee:) or, in the common acceptation of the language of law, what has died a natural death, or been killed in a state or manner different from that prescribed by the law, either the agent or the animal killed not being such as is so prescribed; as that which is sacrificed to an idol, or slaughtered [by a person] in the state of UiHoraAm, or not by having the throat cut, and that which it is unlawful to eat, such as a dog: (Msb:) [and any separated part of an animal of which the flesh is not lawful food: see EaAjN.] ― -b3- baladN mayRitN A tract of land without herbage, or pasture, (Msb, in art. bld.) ― -b4- mayRitN (assumed tropical:) An unbeliever; like as HaIRN means a Muslim. (TA, in art. HI.)

mayRitN c
[mayRitN and mayotN are employed in various other senses, agreeably with the senses of the verb.]

maAYitN c
maAYitN: see mayRitN. ― -b2- fulaAnN maAYitN fI AlgamRi (tropical:) [Such a one is dying, or absorbed, in grief]. (TA.) ― -b3- mawotN maAYitN A severe, painful, or violent, death: (TA:) like layolN laAYilN: the latter word being added to corroborate the former. (S.)

mamaAtN c
mamaAtN: see mawotN.

mumiytN c
mumiytN and mumiytapN (tropical:) A woman, and a she-camel, that has lost her offspring by death: (S:) and a woman who has lost her husband by death: (TA:) pl. mamaAwiytu. (S.)

mutamaAwitN c
mutamaAwitN (tropical:) [Feigning himself dead]. ― -b2- (tropical:) An epithet applied to A hypocritical devotee, (S, K,) who pretends to be like one dead in his devotion, who lowers his voice, and moves little: as though he were one who put on the outward appearance of devotees, and constrained himself to characterize himself by the characteristics of the dead, that he might be imagined to be weak by reason of much devotion. (TA.)

musotamiytN c
musotamiytN A courageous man, who seeks, or courts death: (K:) a man who seeks to be slain; who cares not, in war, for death: (S:) abandon-
ing, or devoting, himself to death, (msotarosilN lilomawoti,) as also musotaqotilN. (A.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Abandoning, or devoting himself to a thing, or affair; syn. musotarosilN liOamorK. (S, K.) ― -b3- hawa musotamiytN UilaI kacaA, as also musotaholikN, (tropical:) He [is devoted to such a thing, so that he] imagines that he shall die if he do not attain it. (A.) ― -b4- Ru-beh says,
wazabadu AlbaHori lahu katiytu
waAllRayolu fawoqa AlmaACi musotamiytu
[And to the froth of the sea there was a sound like that of boiling, and night impended over the water]. (S.) [It is implied in the S that mstmyt here signifies musotarosil.] ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) One who feigns himself to be insane, or possessed by a devil; not being really so. (TA.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) One who feigns lowliness, or submissiveness, in voice, &c., to this man until he feeds him, and to this until he feeds him, and, when he is satiated, is ungrateful to his benefactors. (TA.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) One who makes a show of being good and quiet or tranquil, and is not so in reality. (Ibn-El-Mubárak.) ＝ -A2- musotamiytN The thin pellicle that adheres to the white of an egg. (K.) [See 10: and see also musotamiyvN, in art. myv.]

1 maAva c
1. maAva, aor. yamuwvu, inf. n. mawovN (and in the CK mawavN) and mawavaAnN; (S, K;) as also maAva, aor. yamiyvu; (TA;) and AmAv↓; (Hr;) but this is disapproved by IAth; He steeped a thing in water, and mashed it with his hand: (TA:) he mixed and moistened a thing in water. (S, K.) [See also art. myv.] ― -b2- See also 7. ― -b3- mAvati AlOaroDu The land became soft and even. (Msb.)

4 Oamowava
4: see 1.

7 AnmAv c
7. AnmAv, inf. n. AinomiyaAvN, It (a thing) was steeped in water, and mashed with the hand: (TA:) it was mixed and moistened in water. (S, K.) [See also art. myv.] maAva↓, aor. yamuwvu, is also [thus] used intransitively. (Msb.)

miyvaACu c
miyvaACu, with kesreh, of the measure mifoEaAlN Soft and even land. (Msb.) [See also mayovaACu, in art. myv.]

1 maAja c
1. maAja, aor. yamuwju, inf. n. mawojN (S, K, &c.) and mawajaAnN and muWuwjN; (TA;) It (the sea) was in a state of commotion; was tumultuous; (Msb;) was agitated with waves, conflicting, or dashing together; (S, K;) as also tmwRj↓: (TA;) or this latter signifies it (the sea) was, or became, very tumultuous. (Msb.) [You say,] maAja Almawoju The waves were in a state of commotion; were tumultuous; conflicted, or dashed together. (TA.) [And hence,] maAja Oamoruhumo (assumed tropical:) Their affair became in a confused and disturbed state. (TA.) ― -b2- maAja, inf. n. mawojN and mawajaAnN, (assumed tropical:) It (anything) was in a state of commotion, or agitation. (TA.) ― -b3- maAja (tropical:) He was in a state of commotion, or agitation, and confounded, perplexed, or amazed. (IAar.) ― -b4- AlnRaAsu yamuwjuwnN (tropical:) The people, or men, are in a state of commotion, or tumultuous. (S.) ― -b5- maAjati AlnRaAsu (tropical:) The people were in a discordant and disturbed state of affairs. (Msb.) ― -b6- maAja Eani AlHaqRi, inf. n. mawojN, (tropical:) He declined from the truth, or from the true, right, or just, course. (A, K.) ― -b7- maAjati AldRaAgiSapu, inf. n. muWuwjN, (tropical:) The patella, or knee-pan, moved backwards and forwards, or from side to side, between the skin and the bone, or, as in one copy of the K, flesh: (K, TA:) and in like manner AlsRiloEapu [the ganglion]. (TA.)

5 tamawRaja
5: see 1.

mawojN c
mawojN, [a coll. gen. n., Waves; billows; surges; or a collection of waves;] water rising above other water: (TA:) pl. OamowaAjN: (S, K, Msb:) mawojapN has a more special signification; [namely, a wave, a single wave;] and the pl. of this, which is the n. un., is mawojaAtN. (Msb.) ― -b2- farasN gawojN mawojN: see art. gwj. mwj is here an imitative sequent. (TA.) ― -b3- mawojapu AlXRabaAbi (tropical:) The prime of youth. (K.)

nAqp mawojaI c
nAqp mawojaI (assumed tropical:) A swift (naAjiyap: in the CK naAjibap) she-camel, whose OanosaAE [or woven thongs of the fore girth] have moved round (jaAlat) by reason of the backward and forward motion (AixotilaAf) of her fore and hind legs. (K.)

mawRaAjN c
mawRaAjN [A sea tumultuous with waves]. (K, art. rd.)

maAYijN c
maAYijN A sea in a state of commotion; tumultuous; agitated with waves, conflicting, or dashing together. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, and mutamawRijN↓, A man in a state of commotion, or agitation. (TA.)

mutamawRijN c
mutamawRijN: see maAYijN.

1 maAca c
1. maAca, [aor. yamuwcu,] He lied. (L.)

maAcN c
maAcN Good in natural disposition, happy in spirits, cheerful in mind, merry, jocose, (L, K,) and pleasant in speech. (L.) See TaAbN.

maAciIRN c
maAciIRN (K) and maAciyRapN (S, L, Msb, K) A soft coat of mail, easy to the wearer; (S, L, Msb, K;) and [so] the former, any weapon: (K:) or the latter, a white coat of mail. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, (Msb,) the latter, White honey: (S, L, Msb, K:) or [in the CK and] new honey: or pure honey: or excellent honey. (K.) ― -b3- Also, the latter, Wine. (S, L, K.)

1 maAra c
1. maAra, aor. yamuwru, inf. n. maworN, It moved from side to side, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) like the knee-pan on the knee; (A;) or to and fro, like as the tall palm-tree moves; (S;) as also tmwRr↓: (S:) it came and went; (T;) as also tmwRr↓. (K.) You say of a camel, tamuwru EaDudaAhu The upper bones of his two arms move from side to side. (S, TA.) And maAra AlsRinaAnu fiI AlmaToEuwni [The spear-head moved from side to side in the person pierced]. (A.) And AlTRaEonapu tamuwru The thrust inclines to the right and left. (TA.) And AlnRujuwmu tamuwru The stars come and go. (TA.) And maAra AlgubaAru, inf. n. maworN, The dust moved to and fro: or became raised by the wind. (M, K.) ― -b2- It moved round about, (T, TA,) and to and fro: (TA:) it was in a state of commotion; in a state of tumult: (S, * M, Msb, K:) said of the sea, (Msb,) &c.: (M:) it was in a state of quick motion or commotion. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., that when the soul, or spirit, was blown into Adam, maAra fiI raOosihi faEaTasa It circulated, and moved to and fro, in his head, and he sneezed. (TA.) And in the Kur, [lii. 9,] yawoma tamuwru AlsRamaMCu maworFA On the day when the heaven shall actually be in a state of commotion, or tumult: so accord. to Ed-Dahhák: or shall move from side to side: so accord. to AO and Akh: (S:) or shall come and go; or move to and fro; or reel. (T.) And in a trad. of Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr, bikataAYiba tamuwru karijoli AljaraAdi With troops moving to and fro, in a state of commotion, like the leg of the locust, by reason of their multitude. (TA.) You say also, maArati AlnRaAqapu fiI sayorihaA The she-camel was in a state of commotion, and reeled, in her pace, or going: and in like manner you say of a mare. (TA.) ― -b3- maA OadoriI OagaAra Oamo maAra, a saying of the Arabs, related by IAar, (TA,) I know not whether he have come to low country, or turned and returned to high country (najod): (S, TA:) or have come to the low country, or come to the high country. (IAar, K, * TA.) ― -b4- maAra AldRamu (S, &c.) The blood ran, or flowed, upon the surface of the ground; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) and in like manner you say of tears, meaning they flowed: (M:) or the blood poured upon the surface of the ground, and went hither and thither, (TA,) sideways. (A.) ― -b5- See also 4.

4 AmAr AlsRinaAna fiI AlmaToEawni c
4. AmAr AlsRinaAna fiI AlmaToEawni [He made the spearhead to move from side to side in the person pierced]. (A.) AmArt AlrRiyHu AlgubaAra The wind
made the dust to go to and fro: or raised the dust. (M, K.) ― -b2- AmAr AldRama He made the blood to run or flow; (T, S, * IKtt, Msb;) as also maArahu↓, (IKtt, Msb,) inf. n. mayorN. (IKtt. [as in the TA; but this seems to be a mistake for maworN.])

5 tamawRara
5: see 1, in two places.

maworN c
maworN A road: (T, S:) or a trodden and even road: (M, K:) an inf. n. used as a subst.: because people come and go upon it. (TA.)

muwrN c
muwrN Dust moving to and fro (M, K) in the air: (TA:) or raised by the wind: (M, K:) or carried to and fro by the wind. (T, S.) ― -b2- See also mawRaArN.

mawRaArN c
mawRaArN, (TA,) or mawRaAru AlmilaATi, (S, TA,) A camel that moves the upper bones of his two arms from side to side; (S, TA;) and mawRaAru AlDRaboEayoni [signifies the same]. (A.) ― -b2- mawRaArapN, (M, K,) or mawRaArapu Alyadi, (S, Msb,) A she-camel quick in her pace: (S, Msb:) or easy in her pace, and quick. (M, K.) ― -b3- riyHN mawRaArapN Wind that blows the dust to and fro: or that raises the dust: pl. riyaAHN muwrN, which is extr. [with respect to rule]. (M.)

maAYiraAtN c
maAYiraAtN Bloods [flowing, and running hither and thither]. So in the following verse (of Rusheyd Ibn-Rumeyd El-'Anazee, TA; not of El-Aashà [as it is said to be in the S in art. EwD;] Sgh, in TA, art. EwD:)
Halafotu bimaAYiraAtK Hawola EawoDK
waOanoSaAbK turikona ladaI AlsRaEiyri
[or AlsRuEayori, i. e., I swore, or I swear, by bloods flowing and running hither and thither, around 'Owd, and stones set up to be worshipped, left by Es-Sa'eer or Es-So'eyr]. 'Owd and Es-Sa'eer [or Es-So'eyr] were two idols. (S, TA.) [See also another verse, cited in art. Ez.]

mawozN c
mawozN A certain kind of tree, (Mgh,) or fruit, (Msb, K,) well known; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) [the fruit of the banana-tree, or musa paradisiaca;] i. q. TaloHN [in one of the acceptations of this latter word]: (Msb:) it is lenitive, diuretic, provocative of venery, and augments the spermatic fluid and the phlegm and the yellow bile, and the eating much of it is very oppressive, (K,) for it is slow of digestion: (TA:) the tree grows in the manner of the barodiIR, [i. e., papyrus, or perhaps other rushes,] and has a long and broad leaf, which may be three cubits by two cubits, (AHn, Mgh, TA,) the mawoz [i. e., the fruit] is found, where it grows, throughout the whole year, (AHn, as cited by 'Abd-El-Lateef,) and there may be on one of its racemes from thirty to five hundred fruits; (AHn, Mgh, K, TA;) this is seen in the districts of Makdishoo [between Abyssinia and the country of the Zenj]; (TA;) and when this is the case, the raceme is propped up; (AHn, Mgh;) it rises to the height of the stature of a man, [and higher,] and its offsets continually grow around it, every one of them smaller than another; and when it has produced its fruit, the mother-tree is cut down at the foot, and its offset that has attained to its height fructifies, and becomes a mother, the rest remaining its offsets, and thus it continues: whence the saying of Ash'ab, to his son, as related by As, Wherefore dost thou not become like me? to which he answered, Such as I is like the mawozap, which does not attain to a good state until its mother dies. (AHn, TA.) mawozapN is the n. un. (S, Msb.)

mawRaAzN c
mawRaAzN A seller of mawoz [or fruit of the bananatree]. (K.)

1 maAsa c
1. maAsa, aor. yamuwsu, (Msb,) inf. n. mawosN, (Sgh, Msb, K,) He shaved (Sgh, Msb, K) the head, (Sgh, Msb,) or the hair: (K:) but Sgh says, that its correctness requires consideration, and it was doubted by IF. (TA.) See muwsaI, below.

AlmaAsu c
AlmaAsu, not OalomaAsN, (K,) i. e., with the disjunctive hemzeh, (TA,) for this is an incorrect pronunciation, (K,) of the vulgar, as Sgh and others have plainly asserted; but IAth says, I think that the hemzeh and lám in it are radical letters, as they are in AlyAs, [i. e., UiloyaAs or OaloyaAs,] and it is not Arabic; and if so, its place is under the letter hemzeh, because they say OalomaAsN; but if they be [prefixed] for the purpose of rendering the word determinate, the present is its [proper] place; (TA;) [The diamond;] a certain precious stone, (K, * TA,) reckoned among jewels, like the yaAquwt and the zumurRurc, (TA,) the largest of which is like the walnut, (K, TA,) or the egg of the pigeon, (TA,) and this is rare, or very rare, (K, TA,) the only instance being said to be the one called Alkawokabu AldRurRiIRu, which is suspended at the tomb of the Prophet: (TA:) it breaks all stony bodies, and the holding it in the mouth breaks the teeth, and fire has no effect upon it, nor iron, but only lead breaks it and powders it, [a strange mistake, for it is well known that it is powdered by being pounded in a steel mortar,] after which it is taken [in the state of powder] upon drills, and pearls &c. are drilled with it. (K.)

muwsaI c
muwsaI [A razor;] a certain instrument of iron, (M, Msb, TA,) with which one shaves: (Lth, L, K, TA:) of the measure fuEolaI, (Ks, M, Msb, K,) from Almawosu, [inf. n. of maAsa,] so that the m is a radical letter, (K,) accord. to Lth, (TA,) [for] Lth says, (L, TA,) Almawosu is the root (taOosiys [lit. foundation]) of AlmuwsaI, (L, K, TA,) the thing with which one shaves; (L, TA;) therefore, (Az, Msb, K,) it is imperfectly decl., because of the short fem. A [written I], (Msb,) without tenween; (Az, K;) and Fr cites a verse [of obscene meaning] in which it is made fem.: (TA:) or it is from Oawosayotu raOosahu, meaning “ I shaved his head, ” (ISk, M, * Msb, K,) of the measure mufoEalN, (ISk, Msb, TA,) so that the I is a radical letter, as El-Umawee and Yz say, and Aboo-'Amr Ibn-el-Alà inclined to think it so, (TA,) and therefore it is perfectly decl., (Msb,) with tenween, (Msb, K,) when indeterminate; (Msb;) or it is of the measure mufoEalN because this measure is more common than fuEolaI, and because it is perfectly decl. when indeterminate, whereas fuEolaI is not so when indeterminate and when determinate: (Ibn-EsSarráj, TA:) but IAmb says, that it is masc. and fem., and perfectly decl. and imperfectly decl.: ISk says, that the approved way is to make it perfectly decl.: (Msb:) [but] he says that it is fem. [also, and if so it is imperfectly decl.]: (TA:) and it is related of A'Obeyd, in the Bári', that he said he had not heard it made masc. except by El-Umawee; (Msb;) who asserted it to be masc. only: (TA:) the pl., accord. to him who makes it imperfectly decl., is muwsayaAtN; and accord. to him who makes it perfectly decl., mawaAsK. (Msb.) The dim. of mwsI, in the sense above explained, [not as a proper name, in which case it is muwsaI only, without tenween, and has no relation to the same word signifying a razor,] is muwayosiyapN, [but by rule it should be muwayosaI, like HubayolaI,] accord. to him who says hecihi muwsaI; and muwayosK accord. to him who says hecaA muwsFI. (ISk, TA.)

maAXN c
maAXN [Indian peas;] a certain grain, well known, (S in art. myX, and K,) round, smaller than the HimRaS [or chick-pea], of a tawny colour inclining to greenness; it is in Syria and India; and is sown; (TA;) also called majRN and xulRarN and zinRN: (TA, art. mj:) it is of moderate temperature; and the mixture made thereof is commended, being beneficial to him who is fevered, and him who is affected with rheum; it is lenitive; and when cooked with vinegar, it is beneficial for purulent pustulous mange or scab; and an external application thereof strengthens feeble limbs: (K:) the word is arabicized [from the Persian maAXo], or postclassical. (S.) ＝ -A2- Utensils and furniture, of the meaner sort, of a house or tent. (IAar, K.) Hence the saying, AlmaAXu xayorN mino laAXa, [in one copy of the K I find laAXK, but the former seems to be the right reading,] meaning, Mean house-
hold utensils and furniture are better than nothing; or] what is in the house, or tent, of worthless utensils and furniture, is better than its being empty: (K, TA:) lAX is here contracted [from laAXaIoCa] for the sake of its resembling mAX. (TA.) And xaAXa maAXa and xaAXi maAXi signify the same as maAXN thus used: (K, TA in art. xwX:) or the refuse, or meanest sort, of people, or of mankind; as in the M. (TA.)

mayobapN c
mayobapN A certain remedy, or medicine: (K:) [an arabicized word] from the Persian maIo “ a beverage, ” and biho “ a quince: ” quince-beverage; diacydonium; a medicine prepared of the juice of quinces: some of it is raw; and some, not raw: some is perfumed; and some, not perfumed. (TA, from the book entitled Má lá yesa'u, &c.)

1 maAta c
1. maAta, aor. yamiytu: see art. mwt.

dArI bimiytaACi daArihi c
dArI bimiytaACi daArihi, [as also bimiydaACi,] My house is opposite to his house. (L, not in the TA.) [See also art. AtI.] ― -b2- miytaACu TariyqK The measure of the two sides, and the distance, of a road; as also miydaAC. (L, not in the TA.) [See also art OtI.]

1 maAva c
1. maAva, aor. yamiyvu, (inf. n. mayovN, K,) i. q. maAva, aor. yamuwvu, inf. n. mawovN; (S, K;) [in the CK, for Almawovu is put Almawotu;] as also myRv↓, inf. n. tamoyiyvN; (K;) and AmAv↓, inf. n. UimaAvapN; but this is disapproved by IAth; (TA;) and AmtAv↓, inf. n. UimotiyaAvN; (K;) and UimRaAva↓, [for UinomaAva,] inf. n. UimRiyaAvN; (TA;) [but the last form I have only found used intransitively;] He steeped a thing in water, and mashed it with his hand: (TA:) he mixed and moistened a thing in water: (S, K:) or mAv and myRv↓, he steeped anything, such as saffron, and dates, and raisins, and the preparation of churned milk called OaqiT, in water, so that it dissolved, and mashed it with his hand. (Lth.) ― -b2- maAva He dissolved salt in water; (ISk, Lth;) and in like manner clay, or loam. (ISk.) ― -b3- AllRehumRa mivo quluwbahumo kamaA yumaAvu AlmiloHu fiI AlmaACi [O God, dissolve their hearts, like as salt is dissolved in water!] (TA, from a trad.)

2 myRv c
2. myRv: see 1. ― -b2- (tropical:) He rendered a man gentle. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) He rendered a man submissive. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) It (fortune, or misfortune,) rendered a man expert and submissive. (TA.) ― -b5- [And so] tmyRv↓ (tropical:) He (a man) became submissive, and languid, or flaccid. (TA.)

4 Oamoyava
4: see 1.

5 tamayRava
5: tmyRvt AlOaroDu The ground became softened (and cooled, S,) by rain. (S, K.) [See also maAvati AlOaroDu, in art. mwv.] See 2.

7 AnmAv c
7. AnmAv, [inf. n. UinomiyaAvN;] (ISk;) and UimRaAva, inf. n. UimRiyaAvN; (Lth;) It (salt) became dissolved in water; (ISk, Lth;) and in like manner, clay, or loam. (ISk.) ― -b2- See 1.

8 AmtAv c
8. AmtAv, (inf. n. UimotiyaAvN, TA,) He attained to an easy state of life; (K;) or a pleasant life. (TA.) ― -b2- AmtAv He steeped in water, and mashed with his hand, and drank, the preparation of churned milk called OaqiT. (K.) ― -b3- See 1.

mayRivN c
mayRivN Soft. (K.) ― -b2- rajulN mayRivu Alqalobi (tropical:) A man of soft, or gentle, heart. (TA.)

mayovaACu c
mayovaACu Even, or plain, or soft, land: pl. miyvN: (S, K:) you say, OaroDN mayovaMCu, and OaraADK miyvu: (A:) [see also miyvaMCu, in art. mwv:] an even, or a plain, or soft, tract of sand: and a hill of good soil: (L:) and a [water-course such as is called] taloEap, that becomes as large as half, or twothirds, of the valley. (L, Sh, in TA, voce tlEp.)

musotamiyvN c
musotamiyvN The thin pellicle that adheres to the white of an egg. (AA, K.) [See also musotamiytN, in art. mwt.]

1 maAHa c
1. maAHa, aor. yamiyHu, (S, K,) inf. n. mayoHN; (A, K;) and AmtAH↓; (A, [and the same seems to be indicated in the S, where it is said that UimotiyaAHN signifies the same as mayoHN;]) He descended into, (S, A,) or entered, (K,) the well, and filled the bucket: (S, A, K:) this is done when its water is little. (S.) ― -b2- maAHa AlmaMCa, aor. yamiyHu; and AmtAHhu↓; He drew water by descending into the well and filling the bucket. (A.) ― -b3- maAHa fiI miXoyatihi, (S, A, K, *) inf. n. mayoHN and mayoHuwHapN; (K;) and myRH↓, and tmAyH↓; (A;) (tropical:) He walked in a certain elegant manner, (K,) with a self-conceited gait, and with an affected inclining of his body from side to side, (S, A,) like as a duck walks. (S, K.) ― -b4- marRa yatamayRaHu↓ (tropical:) He passed along so walking, and looking at his shadow. (A.) ― -b5- Also tmyRH↓ (tropical:) He inclined his body from side to side in walking: (K:) and tmAyH↓ he, or it, (a drunken man, and a branch, S,) inclined from side to side; (S, K;) as also myRH↓ and tmyRH↓: (TA:) which last is also said of a branch, or twig. (M, L, art. rOd.) ― -b6- AlsRakoraAnu yatamayRaHu↓, and yatamaAyaHu↓, (tropical:) [The drunken man reels, or inclines from side to side in walking]. (A.) ― -b7- maAHati AlrRiyHu AlXRajarapa (assumed tropical:) The wind made the tree to incline. (TA.) ＝ -A2- mAHhu Einod AlsRuloTaAni, aor. yamiyHu, (S, K, *) inf. n. mayoHN, (K,) (tropical:) He interceded for him with the Sultán. (S, K.) ＝ -A3- maAHahu, aor. yamiyHu, (S, K,) inf. n. mayoHN and miyaAHapN; and AmtAHhu↓; (K;) (tropical:) He gave him [a thing]. (S, K.) ― -b2- maAHa (tropical:) He conferred a benefit, favour, or kindness. (L.) ＝ -A4- maAHa faAhu, biQlomisowaAki aor. yamiyHu, (S, K,) inf. n. mayoHN, (K,) (tropical:) He rubbed and cleaned his teeth with a toothstick: (AA, S, K:) or [so accord. to the L; but in the K, and] he cleansed out the saliva from his mouth with the tooth-stick. (L, K.)

2 mayRaHa
2: see 1.

3 mAyHhu c
3. mAyHhu, (A, K,) inf. n. mumaAyaHapN, (A,) (tropical:) He commingled, or conversed, or held intercourse, with him; (K;) namely, with a Sultán; and in like manner with women. (A.) ― -b2- bayoniI wabayonahu mamaAyaHapN wamumaAlaHapN (tropical:) [Between me and him are a commingling, or converse, or intercourse, and fellowship in eating.] (A.)

5 tamayRaHa
5: and 6: see 1.

8 AmtAHhu c
8. AmtAHhu: see 1. ― -b2- (tropical:) It (heat, and work or labour,) made him to sweat. (A.) ― -b3- AmtAHt AlXRamosu ciforaI AlbaEiyri (tropical:) The sun drew forth the sweat from the protuberance of the camel's head, behind his ears. (K.) ＝ -A2- See 10.

10 AstmAHhu c
10. AstmAHhu, (S, A, K,) and AmtAHhu↓, (A,) (tropical:) He asked him for a gift. (S, A, K.) AmtAHhu↓ (tropical:) He came to him seeking his bounty. (L.) ― -b2- AstmAHhu (tropical:) He asked him to intercede for him, (S, A, K,) Einoda AlsRuloTaAni with the Sultan. (S, A.)

maAHN c
maAHN The yolk of an egg: or its white. (AA, K.) [See also muHRN.]

mayoHN c
mayoHN (tropical:) Profit; advantage. (K.) See maAYiHN.

miyHN c
miyHN A bad kind of dates; i. q. XiySN (K.)

maAHapN c
maAHapN The court of a house: (K:) a dial. form of baAHapN. (TA.)

mayRaAHN c
mayRaAHN (tropical:) A man who walks with a self-conceited gait, and with an affected inclining of his body from side to side: (L:) fem. with p. (S, L.)

maAYiHN c
maAYiHN A man who descends into a well and fills the bucket, when its water is little: pl. maAHapN. (S.) The maAtiH is he who draws the water from the mouth of the well. (L.) ― -b2- maAYiHN (tropical:) A tooth-stick; syn. siwaAkN: so called because it draws away the saliva, like as he who descends into a well ladles out the water: (L:) and so (accord. to some, TA) mayoHN↓. (K.)

1 maAda c
1. maAda, aor. yamiydu, inf. n. mayodN (S, L, Msb, K) and mayadaAnN, (L, Msb, K,) It (a thing) was, or
became in a state of motion, or commotion; was, or became agitated: (S, L, Msb, K:) or, in a state of violent motion or commotion; or violently agitated. (El-Basáïr, TA.) So in the expression in the Kur, [xvi. 15; and xxxi. 9;] Oano tamiyda bikumo Lest it (the earth) should be convulsed with you, and go round with you, and move you about violently. (El-Basáïr, TA.) ― -b2- maAda It turned or twisted about, or became contorted and convulsed. (IKtt.) ― -b3- maAda fiI AlrRumoHi (tropical:) He (a man pierced) writhed upon the spear. (A.) ― -b4- maAda It (the mirage, saraAb,) was in a state of commotion; it quivered, or trembled. (L, K.) ― -b5- maAda (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, confounded, perplexed, or amazed. (TA.) ― -b6- maAda, (aor. yamiydu, TA, inf. n. mayodN or mayadN, L,) (tropical:) He (a man, L,) became affected with a heaving of the stomach, or a tendency to vomit, and a giddiness in the head, by reason of intoxication, or of voyaging upon the sea. (L, K.) ― -b7- You say also maAda bihi AlbaHoru, aor. yamiydu, inf. n. mayodN, (tropical:) The sea affected him with a heaving of the stomach, &c. (L.) And maAdato bihi AlOaroDu (tropical:) The ground went round with him. (A.) ― -b8- maAdati AlHanoZalapu, (aor. yamiydu, L,) The colocynth became affected by day-dew, (L, K,) or by moisture, (L,) and in consequence, changed [in odour, or stinking]: (L, K:) and in like manner a date. (L.) ― -b9- maAda, (S, A, L,) inf. n. mayodN (L) and mayadaAnN; (A;) and tmAyd↓; (A;) It (a branch) inclined from side to side. (S, A, L.) ― -b10- (tropical:) He inclined from side to side in walking. (L.) ― -b11- maAda, inf. n. mayodN and mayadaAnN, It inclined to one side: as the earth is, in a trad., described to have done before the mountains were formed. (L.) ― -b12- maAda (tropical:) He (a man, S,) affected a bending of his person, body, or limbs; (L;) he walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side; (S, L, K;) and maAdato and tmyRdt↓ signify the same, said of a woman. (A.) ＝ -A2- maAda He conferred, or bestowed, a benefit or benefits, or a favour or favours. You say, maAdaniI fulaAnN Such a one conferred a benefit or benefits upon me. (L.) ― -b2- maAdah, (L, Msb,) and AmAdhu↓, (L,) He gave him. (L, Msb.) ― -b3- maAda He furnished persons with, or gave them, provisions for travelling; syn. zaAda. (L.) [In the K, zaAra He visited.] ― -b4- He brought a people wheat, or food; i. q. maAra, (S, L, K,) of which it is a dial. form. (S.) ― -b5- He trafficked as a merchant. (L.) ― -b6- maAda, inf. n. mayodN and mayadaAnN, It increased, or grew; syn. raAEa and zakaA. (M, L, K.) [In the copies of the K in my hands, for rAE is put zAg.]

4 Oamoyada
4: 5, and 6: see 1.

8 AmtAdhu c
8. AmtAdhu He asked him, or desired him, to give him. (L.) ― -b2- AmtAdhu He asked or desired him to bring him wheat, or food. (A.)

mayoda c
mayoda a dial. form of bayoda, (S,) in the sense of gayor: (S, L;) and in that of EalaI: (L:) or that of mino Oajoli. (S, L.) It is said in a trad., OanaA OafoSaHu AlEarabi mayoda OanRiI mino qurayoXK wanaXaOotu fiI baniI saEodi boni bakorK [rendered in art. byd]. (S, L.) See what next follows.

faEalotuhu mayodaA celika c
faEalotuhu mayodaA celika, (M, K,) or mayoda clk, (L,) I did it on account, or for the sake, of that. (M, L, K.) mino mayodaA celika has not been heard. (M, L.)

mayodapN c
mayodapN: see maAYidapN.

miydaMCN c
miydaMCN The amount, and measure, of a thing: (L, K:) and the two sides, and distance, or extent, of a thing, (L,) or of a road; (K;) and the surface of a road. (L.) One says, lamo Oadori maA miydaMCu celika I knew not what was the amount of that, and its measure: or, what was the measure of its two sides, and its extent: as also miytaAWuhu. (L.) ― -b2- The extreme limit of the distance to which horses run; and so myiYotMCN. (S, TA, art. OtI.) ＝ -A2- miydaMCN A mode, manner, fashion, or from. Ex. banuwoA buyuwtahumo EalaI miydaMCK waAHidK They built their houses, or constructed their tents, after one mode, &c. (L.) [See also miYotaMCN, in art. AtI.]

hecaA miydaAWuhu c
hecaA miydaAWuhu, [thus in the copies of the K and in the TA, app. a mistake for miydaMCahu, like tiloqaMCahu,] and bimiydaAYihi, and bimiydaAhu, This is opposite to, or facing, it. (K.) And daAriI bimayodaA daArihi, with fet-h to the m; (as also bimiytaMCi dArh, L in art. myt; and bimiYotaMCi dArh, S in art. AtI;) My house is opposite to his house. (Yaakoob, L.) ― -b2- miydaMCu AlTariyqi: see miYotaMC in art. OataI, and miytaMC in art. myt.

mayodaAnN c
mayodaAnN (S, L, Msb, K, &c.) and miydaAnN↓ (K) A horse-course; race-ground; hippodrome: (Msb, TA:) pl. mayaAdiynu: (S, K, &c.:) of the measure faEolaAnN, (IKtt,) from mAd “ it was in a state of motion; ” because the sides of the horsecourse shake on the occasion of a race: (Msb:) or from mAd “ it turned or twisted about, or became contorted and convulsed; ” because the horses wheel about, and bend or convulse themselves, in the place so called: or of the measure faloEaAnN, from madFI “ a limit, or goal; ” because horses run to their goals in the place so called; originally madoyaAnN, the second and third radicals being transposed; as in biyzaAnN, originally buzoyaAnN: or of the measure fayoEaAlN, from madana “ he abode, or dwelt; ” because horses confine themselves especially to the place so called for wheeling about and the like. (IKtt.) ＝ -A2- EayoXN mayodaAnN A delicate, a pleasant, or an ample and easy, life. (S, L.) ― -b2- mayodaAnu AlxulafaMCi (tropical:) a term applied by historians to The period of the reign of Khaleefehs; from twenty to twenty-four years. (MF, TA.)

miydaAnN c
miydaAnN: see mayodaAnN.

mayuwdN c
mayuwdN That moves about, or is agitated, much; that vacillates much: (L:) an intensive epithet; applied in a trad. to worldly prosperity. (L., art. Hyd.)

mayRaAdN c
mayRaAdN: see maAYidN.

maAYidN c
maAYidN (tropical:) A man affected with a heaving of the stomach, or a tendency to vomit, and a giddiness in the head, by reason of intoxication, or of voyaging upon the sea: pl. mayodaI. (L.) ― -b2- maAYidN A branch inclining [from side to side: see 1]: (A, L:) as also mayRaAdN↓: (L:) [or rather the latter signifies inclining much, or frequently, from side to side:] pl. [of the former] muyRadN. (TA.) ― -b3- fulaAnN yamoXiI EalaI AlOaroDi fayRaAdFA mayRaAdFA (tropical:) Such a one walks upon the ground with an elegant and a proud and a self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side. (A, Art. fyd.)

maAYidapN c
maAYidapN (and mayodapN↓, El-Jarmee, L, K) A table with food upon it: (S, L, K:) without food upon it, a table is not thus called, but is called xiwaAnN: (AAF, S, L:) or also applied to a table itself: (L:) MF says, that this latter application is allowable, considering that food has been, or is to be, placed upon the table: but El-Hareeree asserts it to be incorrect, and the former application only to be allowable: (TA:) mAYdp is thus used in its proper sense of an act. part. n., and is from mAd “ it was in a state of motion; ” as though the table [which was generally a round piece of leather or the like spread upon the ground] moved about with what was upon it: (Zj, L, Msb: *) or from mAd “ he brought wheat or food; ” because food is brought upon it [or as though it brought food]: (L:) or from mAd “ he gave; ” as though it gave of what was upon it to those around it: (El-'Ináyeh:) or it is of the form of an act. part. n. and used in the sense of a pass. part. n., from mAd “ he gave, ” (AO, S, L, Msb,) like raADiyapN in the phrase EiyXapN raADiyapN; (AO, S, L;) because what is thus called is given by its owner to the people [who are to eat]: (Msb:) also, food itself; (Akh, AHát, ISd, L, K;) even if without a table: (L:) [pl. mawaAYidu]. See also faAvuwrN. ― -b2- maAYidapN: (tropical:) A round piece of land or ground: (L, K:) likened to a table. (TA.)

mawaAYidu c
mawaAYidu: see maAYidapN. ― -b2- Also, Calamities: formed by transposition from maMwidu. (T, L.)

mumotaAdN c
mumotaAdN Asking, or desiring, to give; asking or
desiring, a gift. (K.) And Asked, or desired, to give; one of whom a gift is asked, or desired. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- mumotaAdN A man [asking, or desiring, and ― -b3- ] asked, or desired, to bring wheat or food. (S, L.)

1 maAra Oaholahu c
1. maAra Oaholahu (T, * S, A, Msb, *) and EiyaAlahu, (M, K,) aor. yamiyru, (T, S, A, &c.,) inf. n. mayorN, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) He brought, or conveyed, or purveyed, TaEaAm, [here meaning wheat, or other corn, and food, victuals, or provision, of any kind, (see miyrapN,)] (T, S, M, A, K) to, or for, his family, (T, * S, A,) or his household: (M, K:) or he brought to them miyrap, i. e. TaEaAm: (As [accord. to whom, as I find in the TA, the aor. is yamuwru, but this I suppose to be a mistranscription,] T, Mgh, Msb:) or he gave them miyrap: (TA:) and OamaArahumo↓ signifies the same as maArahumo; (K;) and so lahumo AmtAr↓: (S, * M, K:) or you say, humo yamotaAruwna liOanofusihimo they bring, or convey, or purvey, TEAm for themselves; (T;) and linafosihi AmtAr↓, (A,) or Almiyrapa linafosihi AmtAr↓, (Mgh, Msb,) he brought, (A, Mgh, Msb,) or conveyed, or purveyed, (A,) TEAm for himself. (A, Mgh, Msb.) See miyrapN.

4 Oamoyara
4: see 1.

8 Uimotayara
8: see 1.

mayorN c
mayorN: see miyrapN.

miyrapN c
miyrapN: i. q. TaEaAmN [here meaning Wheat, or other corn, and food, victuals, or provision, of any kind,] (T, S, A, * Mgh, Msb, K, *) which a man brings, or conveys or purveys (yamotaAruhu) [to be laid up in store for himself or his family or household, or for sale]; (S, TA;) and mayorN↓ signifies the same as miyrapN [in these senses, as will be seen from what follows], and is applied to victuals, or food, or aliment, syn. quwtN. (TA.) Ex. jaAlibu Almiyrapi, (K,) or Almayori↓, (M,) [The bringer, or conveyer, or purveyor, of wheat, &c.] And OataAhu bimiyrapK He brought him TaEaAm. (T.) And jaAWuwA biQlomiyrapi [They brought, or conveyed, or purveyed, the wheat, &c.] (A.) And maA Einodahu xayorN walaA mayorN↓ [He has not wealth, nor wheat, &c.] (T, S, A.) ― -b2- Also, (T,) The bringing, or conveying, or purveyance, of TaEaAm [here meaning as explained above] from another place (T, M, A, K,) [for one's self or family or household, (see 1,) or] for sale: (T:) pl. miyarN. (M, arts. dfO and Syf; &c.) The first miyrap is the riboEiyRap (M, arts. dfO and Syf,) which is the myrp in the beginning of [the season called] the XitaMC [or winter, i. e., in the latter part of December or in January, during the season of rains called AlrRabiyE, about which time, the species of millet called curap, which, as Niebuhr mentions, (Descr. de l'Arabie, p. 135, note,) is called in El-Yemen TaEaAm, is gathered in]: (S, K, art. rbE:) the second, the SayofiyRap, (M, arts, dfO and Syf,) also called the SaAYifap, (S, M, K, art. Syf,) which is the myrp in [the season called] the Sayof [or spring], (S, M, art. Syf,) in the first part of the Sayof [i. e., in the latter part of March, about which time, wheat, and a second crop of millet (curap), and barley, are gathered in]: (M, art. Syf:) the third, the dafaYiyRap, (M, arts. dfO and Syf,) which is [also] in the first part of [the season called] the Sayof [or spring, and consequently immediately after the SayofiyRap, commencing in the season of the dafaYiIR rains, and app. continuing during part of April, when the same grains are gathered in; or by the Sayof in this instance may be meant summer, but the more proper meaning is spring, and the term dafaYiyRapN seems already to point to the season of the dafaYiIR rains]: (M, art. dfO:) and the fourth, the ramaDiyRap, (M, arts. dfO and Syf,) which is the myrp coming when the earth becomes burnt [by the sun, about July, when the month of ramaDaAn began at the period when the calendar by the months was fixed by Kiláb Ibn-Murrah, about two centuries before the Hijreh, and at which season of the year a third crop of curap is gathered in; for in some parts of Arabia they have three crops of this grain in the year; the second and third being sown immediately after, or produced by the grain which is let fall in cutting, the first and second]. (M, art. dfO.)

mayRaArN c
mayRaArN: see maAYirN.

maAYirN c
maAYirN (S, M, K) and mayRaArN↓ (M, K) One who brings, or conveys, or purveys, miyrap, (S, * K,) or mayor: (M, L:) pl. of the former, muyRaArN (S, M, K) and mayRaArapN, like rajRaAlapN. (S, K.) You say naHonu nanotaZiru muyRaAranaA, and mayRaAratanaA, [We are expecting our bringers, or conveyers, or purveyors, of wheat, &c.] (S.) The pl. mayRaArapN is applied to A company of men who go together from the desert to the towns or villages to bring miyrap. (TA.) It is said in a trad. AlHamuwlapu AlmaAYirapu lahumo lAagiyapN, meaning, The camels that carry miyrap for them for sale and the like are exempt from the eleëmosynary taxation, because they are working beasts. (TA.)

1 maAzahu c
1. maAzahu, aor. yamiyzuhu, inf. n. mayozN; (S, A, Msb, K;) and myRzhu↓ (S, K,) inf. n. tamoyiyzN; (S;) or the latter has an intensive signification; (Msb;) He put it, or set it, apart, away, or aside; removed it; or separated it; (S, A, Msb, K;) from another thing, or other things; (Msb;) as also AmAzhu↓: (K:) [or the second, rather, he did so much, or greatly, or widely; like zayRalahu.] You say, maAzahu minohu, and myRzhu↓. (A.) Ex. maAza AlOacaI mina AlTRarRiyq He put aside, or removed, what was hurtful from the road. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur, [viii. 38,] liyamiyza QllRehu Alxabiyva mina AlTRayRibi [That God may separate, or sever, the evil from the good]. (Msb.) [It seems also, from what is said in the A, that maAyazotu bayonahumaA signifies I separated them two: besides having another signification, which see below.] You say also maAza AlXRaIoCa, (aor. and inf. n. as above, TA,) meaning, He separated one part of the thing from another; faSala baEoDahu mino baEoDK, (M, TA,) or Eano baEoDK: (as in a copy of the A:) expl. in the K as signifying faDRala baEoDahu EalaI baEoDK [he judged, or made, part of the thing to excel, or to have excelled, another]; but the explanation in the M is the right. (TA.) And AlOaXoyaMCa myRz↓ He separated the things after knowledge of them. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence, He distinguished it, or discriminated it, or discerned it. And maAza bayona AlOaXoyaMCi, and bayonahaA mayRaza↓, He distinguished, or discriminated, or discerned, between the things. This is what is meant by its being said,] Almayozu also signifies AltRamoyiyzu bayona AlOaXoyaMCi. (TA.) You say also, bayonahumaA maAyazotu↓ [I distinguished, or discriminated, or discerned, between them two]. (A.) From myRz AlAXyMC, meaning as explained above, is [also], app., derived the phrase sinRu AltRamoyiyzi, used by the doctors of practical law, as signifying, [The age of discrimination;] the age at which one knows what things are beneficial to him and what are hurtful to him: or, accord. to some, AltRamoyiyz is a faculty in the brain whereby meanings are elicited. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- maAza [is also intrans., and signifies] He (a man) removed from one place to another. (IAar, K.) See also 8.

2 mayRaza
2: see maAzahu, throughout.

3 maAoyaza
3: see maAzahu, in two places.

4 Oamoyaza
4: see maAzahu, first signification.

5 tamayRaza
5: see 8, throughout. ― -b2- You say also, fulaAnN yakaAdu yatamayRazu mina AlgayoZi Such a one almost bursts asunder with wrath, or rage. (S, K. *) The like is said in the Kur, lxvii. 8, tropically, of hell. (A, TA.)

6 tamaAoyaza
6: see 8, throughout.

7 Uinomayaza
7: see 8, throughout.

8 AmtAz c
8. AmtAz, and tmyRz↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) and AnmAz↓. (S, A, K,) and UimRaAza↓, (Lh, TA,) [the
last being a variation of that immediately preceding,] and AstmAz↓, (S, A, K,) It was, or became, put, or set, apart, away, or aside; or removed; or separated; (S, A, * Msb, * K;) from another thing, or other things: (Msb:) and the last, AstmAz↓, he went, or withdrew, aside, or to a distance, (K, TA,) Eani AlXRaIoCi from the thing. (TA.) All these forms are syn.; but in the phrase mizotuhu falamo yamRazo [as though signifying I put it, or set it, apart, &c., but it did not remain so] Lh allows the verbs to be only in these two forms: (TA:) [though AnmAz↓ is used in other cases; for] you say Eano AnmAz↓ muSalRaAhu He shifted from his place of prayer; or quitted it for another. (TA.) [See also 1, last signification.] You say also, AmtAr Alqawomu, meaning, baEoDuhumo mino baEoDK tmyRz↓ [The people were, or became, put, or set, apart, &c., one from another]: (S, TA:) and, as also tmyRzwA↓, they became on one side: or they became alone, or separate: and the former, they withdrew, in a company or troop, aside; as also AstmAzwA↓: (TA:) and [in like manner] tmAyzwA↓ they became separated: (A:) and they formed themselves into separate companies, or troops, and went away, one from another. (TA. [AltRamaAyuzu being there said to signify AltRaHazRubu waAltRanaAfuru.]) ― -b2- [AmtAz, and the other forms mentioned above, in the first sentence of the paragraph, as syn. with it, also signify It was, or became, distinguished, or discriminated, or discerned: in which sense, tmyRz↓ is the most common. You say also, fulaAnN tmyRz↓ biQlokarami Such a one was, or became, distinguished by generosity. And AlOaXoyaMCu tamaAyazati↓ and tumayRazat↓ The things were, or became, distinguished, or discriminated, one from another; or distinct.]

10 Uisotamoyaza
10: see 8, throughout.

mayozN c
mayozN inf. n. of 1, q. v. ― -b2- Also, High or elevated rank or condition or state [by which one is distinguished from others]. (TA.)

miyzapN c
miyzapN [The act of putting, or setting, apart, away, or aside; of removing, or separating]: a subst. from maAzahu. (TA.) ― -b2- [Discrimination, or discernment: and hence,] understanding. (TA.)

rajulN mayRaAzN c
rajulN mayRaAzN, and mumayRizN↓, [A man of much discrimination or discernment.] (A.)

mumayRizN c
mumayRizN [Distinguishing, or discriminating: and hence, a rational animal]. rajulN mumayRizN: see mayRaAzN.

1 maAsa c
1. maAsa, aor. yamiysu, inf. n. mayosN and mayasaAnN, He walked with an elegant and a proud and selfconceited gait; or so walked with an affected inclining of the body from side to side; (S, M, A, K;) excepting that in the A the fem. forms of the pret. and aor. are given;) as also tmyRs↓: (S, A, * K:) accord. to the Lth, mayosN signifies a kind of mayasaAn, [app. a mistranscription for mayalaAn, or inclining,] with, or in, the gait and motion above described, like that of the bride, and of the camel; for he sometimes does this in going along with his hawodaj [or litter which serves as a vehicle for women]. (TA.)

4 OamaAsato jisomahaA c
4. OamaAsato jisomahaA [She (a woman) made her body to incline from side to side in walking in the manner above described.] (M.)

5 tamayRasa
5: see 1.

mayosN c
mayosN A kind of tree, (AHn, S, M, K,) of great size, (A, Hn, M, K,) resembling in its growth and its leaves the [kind of willow called] garab: when young, it is white within; but when it grows old, it becomes black, like Mbunuws [or ebony], and so thick that wide tables are made of it; (AHn, M;) and camels' saddles (riHaAl) are made of it. (AHn, S, M.) ― -b2- Hence, A camel's saddle (raHolN), as being made of the kind of tree above described. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, A species of grape-vine, that rises somewhat upon a trunk, (AHn, M, K, *) not all of it spreading out into branches: (AHn, M:) AHn adds, its native place is the district of El-Jezeereh called Sarooa (saruwE), and it is related, of a person of knowledge, that he saw it at Et-Táïf: and hence the name of the raisins called mayosiIR↓: (TA:) [but ISd says, in continuation of AHn's account of the former of the trees above mentioned, not of the latter,] an Arab of the desert informed me, that he had seen it at Et-Táïf, and hence, he said, the raisins called mayos [not mayosiI] are thus named: (M:) [and F says,] mayosN signifies a kind of raisins; as well as a species of grapevine &c. (K.) ― -b4- Also, [The pole of a plough;] the long piece of wood that is between the two bulls. (AHn. M.)

mayosiIRN c
mayosiIRN: see mayosN.

mayosaAnN c
mayosaAnN: see mayRaAsN.

mayosuwnN c
mayosuwnN: see mayRaAsN. ― -b2- Also, A boy beautiful in stature and face. (K.)

mayuwsN c
mayuwsN: see mayRaAsN.

mayRaAsN c
mayRaAsN (S, A, K) and mayosaAnN↓ (Ibn-'Abbád, A, K) and mayuwsN↓ and maAYisN↓ (K) One who walks with an elegant and a proud and selfconceited gait; or who so walks with an affected inclining of the body from side to side: (S, A, K:) [or the first and second and third, one who does so much, or often, or habitually: and the last, being a simple act. part. n., one so walking:] fem. of the first and second, with p: (A, TA:) and mayosuwn↓ signifies the same as mayRaAsapN, in the sense explained above, applied to a woman, and is of one of the measures not mentioned by Sb, like zayotuwnN; or it is from masana, and therefore of the measure fayoEuwlN; but more probably from Almayosu. (M.) ― -b2- Also, AlmayRaAsu The lion that so walks; (K, TA;) an epithet applied to him because of his little regard for him whom he meets: (TA:) or the lion: (Sgh, TA:) and, (accord. to IDrd, TA,) the wolf; (K;) because he so walks. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, guSonN mayRaAsN An inclining, or a bending, branch. (M.)

maAYisN c
maAYisN: see mayRaAsN.

1 maATa c
1. maATa, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) aor. yamiyTu, inf. n. mayoTN (Msb, K) and mayaTaAnN, (K,) He removed; retired, or went, to a distance; or became remote; (As, IAar, * A 'Obeyd, S, Msb, K;) Eanohu from him; (IAar, A'Obeyd, S, K;) as also AstmAT↓; (TA;) and AmAT↓; (IAar, A 'Obeyd, S, K;) but As disallows the last in this sense; (S, * Msb;) it occurs, however, in a trad.: (TA:) also, he went away; (S, TA;) and so AmAT↓: (TA:) and it (a thing) went away. (TA.) ― -b2- He, or it, inclined to one side; or declined; i. q., maAda, and HaAda. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, aor. as above, inf. n. mayoTN, He declined, or deviated, from the right course; or acted unjustly; (AZ, Ks, S, K;) fiI Hukomihi in his judgment. (AZ, Ks, S.) ― -b4- [See also mayoTN, below: and see 3.] ＝ -A2- Also, (A 'Obeyd, S, Msb, K,) inf. n. mayoTN; (TA;) and AmAT↓, (A 'Obeyd, S, Msb, K,) inf. n. UimaATapN; (S, Msb;) or the latter only, accord. to As; (S, * Msb, TA;) He removed, put away, or put at a distance, (A 'Obeyd, S, Msb, K,) him, or it; (A 'Obeyd, S, Msb;) and maATa bihi signifies the same as AmAThu; (Msb;) and some say bihi mayRaTotu↓ [if this be not a mistranscription for miTotu bh] in the sense of OamaTotuhu. (TA.) You say, AlOacaI Eani AlTRariyqi OamaATa↓, (Mgh, TA,) inf. n. UimaATapN, (S, Msb,) He removed, or put away, or put at a distance, what was hurtful from the road, or way; (S, Mgh, Msb, TA;) and [some say] maATahu, inf. n. mayoTN. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., EanRaA yadaka OamiTo↓ Remove thou from us thy hand. (TA.) And maATa bihi and AmAThu↓ signify He took away him, or it; syn. cahaba bihi and Oacohabahu. (TA.) ― -b2- mayoTN also signifies The act of repelling, impelling, pushing, or thrusting; (S;) and so miyaATN↓: (S, K:) and both signify the act of chiding: (S, K:) the former
being an inf. n. of which the verb is maATa, aor. yamiyTu: (K:) [the latter, app., an inf. n. of which the verb, namely mAyT, is unused; the like being said of hiyaATN, which we find coupled with miyaATN.] You say, Alqawomu fiI hiyaATK wamiyaATK↓ The people, or company of men, are engaged in making a clamour, and repelling, &c.: (S, in the present art. and in art. hyT:) or hyAT and myAT, respectively, signify the most vehement driving in coming to water, and the most vehement driving in returning from water; (Fr, K;) and maA zalonaA biAlhiyaATi waAlomiyaATi means we ceased not to be engaged in coming and going: (Fr, TA:) or advancing (Lh, TA) and retreating: (Lh, K:) or labouring, or striving, or conflicting, one with another, to overcome, (Lth, TA,) and inclining [one towards another]: (Lth, K:) or collecting together, in a neuter sense, and mutual retiring to a distance: or collecting themselves together for peace or reconciliation, and dissolving themselves from a state of peace or reconciliation: or raising a clamour, or confused noise; and retiring to a distance: or saying No, by God, and Yes, by God. (TA.) [See art. hyT.] You say also, maA zaAla fiI hayoTK wamayoTK, meaning He ceased not to be engaged in crying out, or vociferating, or calling for aid or succour, and in evil, or mischief, and raising a clamour, or confused noise. (K in art. hyT.)

2 mayRaTotu bihi c
2. mayRaTotu bihi: see 1. ― -b2- myRT bayonahumaA, inf. n. tamoyiyTN, He wavered between them two. (TA.)

3 miyaATN c
3. miyaATN: see 1, throughout the greater part of the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b2- bayonahumaA mumaAyaTapN and muhaAyaTapN and muEaAyaTapN and musaAyaTapN are said to signify Between them two is low, faint, or gentle, speaking. (TA in art. hyT.)

4 OamoyaTa
4: see 1, in five places.

6 tmAyTwA c
6. tmAyTwA They removed, retired, went to a distance, or became remote, one from another; and their mutual state became bad, disordered, or disturbed; (S, K;) contr. of thAyTwA. (Fr, S, in art. hyT.)

10 UisotamoyaTa
10: see 1, first sentence.

mayoTN c
mayoTN: see 1. ― -b2- It also signifies Inclination: so in the trad., lawo kaAna Eumaru miyzaAnFA maA kaAna fiyhi mayoTu XaEorapK [If 'Omar were a balance, there would not be in it the inclination of a hair]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, A state of mixture, or confusion: mentioned only by IF. (TA.)

maAYiTN c
maAYiTN and haAYiTN are explained by IAar as signifying Coming and going. (TA.)
